description:
The chicken is to die for ! 
So juicy and flavorful I highly recommend it. 

My partner had steak, sad it was perfect and tender, I tried the fries with the steak and they are so good! Soaked in the steak juices, perfectly salted, just yummy!
author: Latifa A.

description:
Cafe Claude, you are a French Cloude floating amid the SF financial district.  A little piece of Paris for the hefty price of San Francisco - a little food staycation for those that want more than food... like jam (no, not the fruity jar-ed kind - the melodic kind). I like that this restaurant integrates a musical live jazz experience with the romantic French prose of food - the escargot; the wine; the French onion soup; the chocolate soft cake.  It is an experience for the taste buds - and for the ear buds over a most memorable experience with your best buds (the human ones).  

It is nice that the people running the restaurant are  from France, and are very helpful and kind in making recommendations and providing decent service (though it could have been a bit more efficient). 

What dishes did I enjoy?

(1) The escargots en croute.  I liked the buttery, garlic and parsley infused reduction with shallots and anchovy - and how the escargot were baked in like delicate swirled angels sleeping in a puff pastry blanket.  

(2) My favorite dish was the french onion soup (soup a l'oignon). And is the oignON spot ON. My only constructive criticism about this dish is that I wish it were less salty. However, the onion soup gratinee had a most beautiful red wine aftertaste that married well with the melting emMENTAL cheese that is a mental wonderland. The baguette crouton was sliced in the perfect thickness to create a golden ratio of onion soup. 

(3) Actually - I take that back. My actual favorite dish was the dessert. The Moelleux au Chocolat was in fact my favorite dish here.  The soft chocolate cake was not too sweet - which I appreciated as the bitterness of the chocolate was able to come through to surface in its natural roughness. The Creme Anglaise vanilla sauce was poured in, melding in with the chocolate to form a chocolate-creme anglaise combination that was black and white harmony at its most intimate peak. 

What dishes could have used perhaps a little more thoughtfulness?

(A) The Casserole de Champignon. The ingredients were great - the farro verde, the king trumpet mushrooms, the carrots, the broccolini and kale.  I just wish there were more flavor other than butter. And I wish that there was more to it. I am a person who appreciates simplicity when it comes to good food - but there is simplicity done thoughtfully and tastefully and simplicity done in the other direction. I am afraid this fell in the latter category. 

(B) Confit de Canard. The duck was crisp, but it came at the expense of moisture, for I have never eaten such a dry piece of duck in my life. I was also a bit disappointed at the portion size. I did appreciate the warm puy lentils and the frisée; and I enjoyed the flavor of course mustard against the duck.  

Cafe Claude, I applaude that you share a little piece of France - and beautiful live music with it - in the oft busy SF life. Merci beaucoup.
author: Vivienne K.

description:
Just a great experience on a Saturday night. Service,ambiance , and food were great.

Every dish we ordered was delicious and well prepared.

Service was friendly and helpful and great to interact with 

My friends , who had just spent two months in Burgundy, were smitten with the place. 

Great live jazz on weekends.

Check them out
author: David G.

description:
I would say this place has great ambiance and cocktails... but the food isn't spectacular. I wouldn't eat here again. There was a live singer which was lovely though, as was the service.

Come to enjoy the jazz and drinks!
author: Mina P.

description: Excellent service and food. Felt like i had been there 100 times but it was my 1st time.  Was with a large group and everything was awesome.
author: Chris L.

description:
Worst service ever. Hmm... Did our server think we were in France? I mean, if that's the case, then maybe we shouldn't have left her a 20% tip. She only came by TWICE within three hours - to take our order and give us water, and to give us our bill and take it back with her. 

We had to cancel our wine order because she failed to bring it to us. We flagged down different servers to get her attention. This is such odd behavior for a server in a pretty nice French restaurant. I will not be recommending this restaurant to friends. Slow service (if any) and tough/dry chicken.

What we ordered:
-Large mussels $21.00
-4 glasses of 2017 Cibonne, Provence $12.00/per glass 
-Soupe a l'oignon $12.00
-Coq au vin (tough chicken)
-Trout Amandine
-Croque Madame
-Espadon (delicious swordfish - this was the best plate)
author: Angellica Y.

description:
We are greeted immediately by a hostess upon entering. We had reservations at 8:30pm on a Monday and we came in at 8:15pm and was able to get seated right away.

The decor is pretty, and a perfect place for a date. There was candles on the tables and dimmed lights.

Now the best part, the food...

Assiettes de 3 Fromage ($18) - 3 different cheeses out of a variety that you can choose from. Unfortunately I do not remember the names of the cheese, but I like 2 out of 3 of the cheese that we chose. My friend likes salty cheese but it was way too salty for my liking. The honeycomb and walnuts were tasty though.

Moules a la Provençale ($19) - these mussels were in a very tasty saffron tomato stew. We got the larger one and after having the cheese appetizer and the mussels.. I was already pretty full. The mussels were cooked nicely and the stew was a great compliment with the mussels. It also came with a baguette with olive tapenade but since I do not like olives, I took a bite and put it down.

Espadon ($27) - the pan seared swordfish was delicious. It also came with cherry tomatoes and potatoes. At this point, my stomach was bulging out of my jeans but it was so good that I finished the fish.

Creme brulee ($10) - I was done eating at this point but we decided to share a dessert to try anyways. The creme brulee is pretty big and great for sharing even with maybe 3 people. I took a few bites but I was so full that I didn't have room for more. It was the best creme brulee I ever had. It was so soft and creamy and the glazed part on top wasn't too sweet. Amazing, and I didn't even need coffee to go with it.

Service was great. Our server was attentive and filled our water whenever we were low. He made sure regularly that we enjoyed our food and that we were doing okay. He even sweeped off the bread crumbs from our table when we were transitioning from appetizers to our entree. He even said bye to us as we were leaving.

Overall, amazing experience and will be having more future dates here.
author: Julian Y.

description:
This is one of my loves in the City. I have so much experience popping in in Saturday's, meeting with friends, having long extended lunches.

The place is still a gem. They doubled in size over the past year. Never minded the cramp, right space so it'll be a challenge for management to keep it as it always was.

Love the Kir royals, the onion soup and the Croque Madame.

Forever a treat and highly recommended.

Oh, Martha- I hope you see this... you are wonderful...
author: Dennis I.

description:
We went there for dinner. And here's what we got:

Casserole de champignon: It was some sautéed veggies thrown on wild rice smothered with a sauce. That is not mushroom casserole. Especially, when there is only 3 pieces of mushroom hidden amongst carrots and yellow squash. It was as if they grabbed some vegetable medley from an Olive Garden. 
Spinach side dish: it was more like lemon served with wilted spinach and no garlic. 
Steak frites: a strange cut of steak that tasted like it was marinated with cinnamon. We had to work our muscles really hard to cut edible sizes of meat. 
Slightly dirty vodka martini: it was dirty and very salty for sure. 

With so many negatives, why 2 stars? Music was good and servers were nice.
author: Sinan G.

description:
I was so hoping to walk away from this dinner with a five star experience based on some of the reviews I had read, but sadly that wasn't the case. 

Probably one of the worst experiences of the recent years at an upscale restaurant. Made reservation on OpenTable a week ahead of time and requested special occasion treatment due to my husband's birthday celebration. 

We were greeted and seated outside in the COLD weather and despite my complaint about having made a reservation and special occasion we were directed outside to dine at metal chairs and tables instead of the upscale sitting inside with white linen and proper atmosphere. The heaters didn't work well, we sat there in our jackets the entire time and made for an all together a lousy experience!! 

The appetizers escargot and foie gras were mediocre, the escargot was a bit on the tough side and lacked the flavor we are used to. The niciose salad was a disappointment as it was prepared with canned tuna, nothing fresh about it. We ordered 3 onion soups and found pieces of charcoal burnt onions inside the soup!! Not very appetizing.

The trout was probably one of the better entrees that we ordered. Others were steak tartare, steak and fries, and crispy duck. They were all OK nothing great. 

The dessert was probably the best part of the dinner which was chocolate mousse, apple tart and creme brûlée (please note the extra star is for the desserts). Service was super slow and we were told it was due to the restaurant being full!!

As I mentioned at the beginning, the way we were treated specially with a reservation, on a special occasion and on a cold night was really insulting and made it so miserable that we didn't get to enjoy much about the dinner. Disappointed and will not be back and cannot recommend it to friends.
author: Mehrnaz H.

description:
What an amazing night. I've lived in SF for nearly 10 years and had always heard about this place but never made my way towards it until a friend had suggested it after having a great experience herself.

The hostesses were so charming and seated us immediately. It was a busy Saturday night and there was a live band playing, people laughing and the energy felt very....French. But France in the 20's where everything was romantic in a gypsy sort of way.

The real reason I am writing this review is because our server Jillian was incredible. She greeted us with a warm smile and told us a few favorite things on the menu she enjoyed. We talked about bottles of wine and she upsold me a bottle that was way worth the price. All of her suggestions were delicious (the duck!) and she checked in on us in a timely manner. I saw her walking around to her other tables and she seemed very familiar with them too.

I highly recommend getting away from the tech-soaked city and escaping to this cute cafe but only if you get Jillian as your server! I will be back again. Tomorrow. I will see you tomorrow.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
Service was OK. We went for a special occasion, and made multiple mentions that this was a birthday dinner. No customary birthday-stuff was provided. Granted, that's not totally standard, so I can give them a pass on that. 

As to the meal itself:
- We shared three boards of charcuterie, pate, and cheeses as appetizers. These were generally all fine, though nothing to write home about. There was not quite enough bread, so we had to ask for more.
- We also got escargot. They looked good, though I did not partake.
- I ordered the steak frites. The fries were fine -- standard, crispy shoestring ones. The steak was mediocre. It was quite sinewy and a little tough. It came with a slab of garlic butter on top, which I had to manually rub in. The ultimate test of quality there was that I made it about halfway through, then lost interest and just snacked on my fries.
author: John L.

description:
I love the vibe of this restaurant. Tucked away down an alley - so unless you're looking for it you won't find it. They've recently renovated and created a bar area - my favorite place to eat. I came early - so I was the only one at the bar.... Hearn... the bartender all to myself. 
He recommended the following and I listened:
1. Steak tartar very good but a different preparation than I've had before. They use a mustard and its chopped. They serve with little toasts. Very large portion for the smaller size so make sure split. It was very good - toasts were  a little too hard

2. Coq au vin- I was disappointed. I had to ask for salt? This takes a long time make so no one was tasting this along the way? I didn't finish it.

The bartender kept asking if I wanted bread - I finally caved and so glad I did the bread is Awwwesome! I'm picky it has to have the right crust and the right crumb on the interior with the right butter. Mmm

They have a good wine list by the glass. The had a st emilion Bordeaux that was sooo good. Would definitely go back for a glass of vin and pain.
author: jami V.

description: Came here for dessert & wine so can't speak for the rest of the menu, but loved this place. Tucked in the alley way the sound of jazz drew is in on 9pm on a Saturday. The inside is old French with a cozzy bar & live jazz with a dance floor. Loved it
author: Michelle H.

description:
Wow. Absolutely delicious food. We were a party of five and ordered the cheese plate with fruit and honeycomb (delicious but a bit small), tomato soup (B+) and swordfish, fried duck and the vegetable casserole. All the main dishes were phenomenal. 
For desert we ordered the creme brulee, chocolate mousse and chocolate souffle. All were delicious as well. The waiters were highly knowledgable and responsive.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
After studying abroad and visiting France I was dying to find a french gem in Fidi. After looking on opentable I thought this place would be a great spot to check out. We had a reservation for lunch at 2:30PM but after running late from another event they were more than willing to change it to 2:45PM. Thank you for that! 

This location is in an alley so don't expect to be finding on the street casually walking by. I actually like that since it's hidden from all the crowds and to me makes it a little more special. Once you come up to the place you realize that there is an outside area and a small indoor area. The place has a black mirror wall that really expands the place and you realize how small it is. Bathrooms are also through the back door & shared I believe. 

WHAT WE GOT: 

- Escargot - Not my fave. The puff pastry was a nice touch but I thought it tasted better with the bread vs the escargot itself. 

- Steak & Fries - I asked for it rare and it came pretty done. The steak wasn't cooked evenly and while I was excited about the bone marrow butter, I thought the taste steak/meat was covered by the gravy they added on top. The french fries were super crispy though which I enjoyed.

- Crispy Duck - The crispy duck was perfectly crisp on the outside while staying juicy on the inside. I wish there were other sides vs. what it came with since it felt like something was lacking.

- Solace - Get this! If you're a fan of gin and want something refreshing this is a great option. 

Overall, the service was OK. The waitress was sure to make sure she was available when we ordered and asked for the check, but aside from that it felt hands off. TBH it was nice spot to check out but I don't think the food/portions warranted the high prices.
author: Keizzel C.

description:
Came here last night for a drink and a small bite. Very cute outdoor terrace but it was too hot so inside it was. The staff was very friendly and checked in the right amount. My salade lyonnaise was delicious, though they used bacon pieces instead of pancetta and for some reason I prefer the latter. Our cocktails were as more than the salad, but very refreshing. The baguette paired with delicious butter was super standard, would've liked to see a personal touch with some variety. I don't think they made it in-house.

Overall a good experience!
author: Tash B.

description:
***Updated June 18 2018***

Finally got around to give Cafe Claude another try after they reached out to apologize for the previous experience.

The staff were very friendly and attentive; I couldn't remember the name of my server but she had light colored hair pulled back in a pony tail. The place was much bigger inside than what I imagined but divided into different areas so it had a more of a quaint bistro feel to it.

Foie Gras Torchon - dressed with huckleberries and paired perfectly with a glass of sauterne. What a great start to my evening! Typically, I prefer terrine over torchon as it is more "pure" but I was very pleased with my starter.

 Coq au Vin - As a default rule, I almost never order chicken in a restaurant. My partner does not follow this restriction. In the end, I liked his entree even more than mine -- so much that I convinced him to swap.
 
Short Ribs-the special of the night and i did not disappoint! I loved the robust flavors and the mushrooms it came with were perfectly done.

Apple Tartin - This is an absolute must! Flakey, buttery, caramel doused, and topped with ice cream. 

I was really happy with my meal here and look forward to returning soon!

~~~~~~~~~~~
Came here for Valentine's Day. I made reservations a month in advance. On my reservation they mention they have a covered outdoor seating that I might be placed in depending on availability. That's fine.

Fast forward a month and I arrive for my 6:30pm seating. The outdoor covered seating is not fully enclosed and exposed on an entire long edge. I'm seated at the very end of the awning, not even fully under the covering. Even with the heat lamps it is very drafty and extremely cold despite having  my long jacket on -- met neighbor had to put on their gloves! Not to mention we were packed in side to side like sardine without even a courtesy inch gap to separate the dining tables. I have flown on budget airlines or movie theatres that have given me mor elbow space. They really should have informed their guests. I saw so many shivering couples and the couple sitting next to me were also complaining.

After deciding to brave the weather and look at the menu, we soon realized this meal was going to be awful in this miserable condition. We then informed the staff we would be leaving and then went off and had an amazing meal comfortably seated inside the Mystic Tavern (formerly Burritt Room) indoors. 

Overall I'm incredibly disappointed and embarrassed that a business would subject their customers or patrons to such terrible dining experience conditions.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
They remodeled. Place looks great. The wall paper is amazing. The steak tar tar is still best in the city. We always request double quail egg!
Live music nightly I think.  We had martini's and felt like we were in France! Will be back asap!
author: sally s.

description: Great food, live music, very nice place. I got the swordfish and my husband had the duck confit.  Both exceeded our expectations! Portions are good, not to small not to big.  Our waiter was a dry, bit the food and music made up for it.
author: Perciella B.

description:
Very much still going strong after so many years!!

The service was a little less grouchy than I recall, the salads better than I remember, and the menu broader. 

I had the Salade Nicoise and it was great. I loved the big hunks of dill in amongst the lettuces, the anchovies draped over the tuna, the capers along with hard eggs. 

My lunch partner had a trout special that was part almandine but then went all roasted, chopped cauliflower on top of that. It looked really tasty and reports were that it was excellent. 

They have 4-5 different sandwiches at lunch, plus a couple soups, and half a dozen salad options. Not to mention 4-5 main dish options.

Solid calm quiet semi-formal but very casual bistro. Compares to Balthazar in NYC, though way less dramatic.
author: Lanny B.

description:
This place has reminded me so much of France! It's a really intimate dining experience and I loved all the photography and decor inside! The menu has a variety of food selections, ranging from small bites/ appetizers to big meat plates, to delicious desserts!

We got the beef tartare, escargots, French onion soup, coq au vin and creme brûlée. 

Beef tartare was actually a pretty portion. We got the small size but still too big to be finished. This was okay I'll give it 3.5/5.
Escargots were soooo tasty, with the mini puffs on top and the rich garlic sauce and olive oil. Very mouthwatering!! 5/5
French onion soup was also good but not too impressive. 3/5
Coq au vin is a chicken plate made with red wine sauce, paired with carrots and mushroom. The chicken is so tender and the sauce tasted amazing with the wine aroma! 4.5/5
The creme brûlée was cold inside with warm caramel outside. Very creamy and delicious4.5/5
author: Crystal S.

description:
Cafe Claude was recommended to me by a friend who said it was his favorite restaurant in the city.  It's quite a small restaurant and down a little alley way with a nice mural outside.  You can choose to sit inside or outside (inside doesn't seem to have air conditioning) depending on how crowded it is.

The service here is impeccable - they're constantly refilling your waters, checking on you, and the food comes out relatively fast.

I tried the goat cheese salad and absolutely loved it.  The portion was just perfect for me, and it came with two large croutons with goat cheese toasted on top.  It was fabulous!! I am inspired to try and recreate at home (although I'm sure mine won't be nearly as good).

My boyfriend had the steak and frites and could not stop talking about how good it was the rest of the evening.  He definitely enjoyed it but the price was reflective of the quality ($28).

Ordering a glass or two of wine to go with dinner is just mandatory - you can't go to this cute little French restaurant without having some wine!

To top it off - the creme brûlée was probably the best I've ever had.  It was so smooth and creamy, I was in heaven.  It's a perfect size to split between two people - I didn't need any more than that (and I have a big sweet tooth!).

Overall we spent ~$100 for two people (including a salad as an entree) with no appetizers.  It's somewhere I would recommend for a special occasion, or even happy hour!
author: Kenna H.

description:
Despite how hard I looked, I couldn't find any of my beloved Claude Monet's lily pads hanging around the sidewalk of Cafe Claude, but I did come across some pretty amazing cuisine, not to mention a more-than-inviting atmosphere.  I will forever and always dote on French cuisine just as much as I dote on French art such as that of my Claude Monet.  So, it was quite fitting when my fiancé I found ourselves seated at a fantastic cafe named after my favorite artist (not saying that Claude Monet actually inspired the naming of this restaurant).

The presence of live jazz music made up for the lack of lily pads, but the music-induced ambience sure made me feel as if I was enjoying myself in little old Giverny.  The music filled the entire interior and exterior space, and as my fiancé and I were sat outside we enjoyed the lovely weather in addition to the fantastic music.  I believe that the live jazz music only occurs on Thursday nights (though I could be wrong)...if I'm not wrong, you should plan a date night here on Thursday's!  Even were you to come on any other night, Cafe Claude is brilliant choice for date night, especially if you do opt to sit outside (given it is warm enough - but don't worry, there's heated lamps).  Sitting outside gives the sense that you're in a Parisian alley, enjoying all the luxuries of life.

All this and I haven't even gotten to the food.  Though everything else makes the trip to Cafe Claude worth it, the cuisine is the star.  We ordered the escargot to begin with, and that's a must as this escargot is topped with some beyond good pastry substance.  Then we got the croquet madame, charcuterie board, and the French onion soup for splitting.  This was the second best croquet madame I have had (the very best being in Paris) because of how perfectly balanced and rich every ingredient was.  The French onion soup was also in the top 5 best that I've had - and this soup was huge!  So that was all savory and delicious, but we ended on a high note by getting the chocolate cake soufflé which was just as good as those you would get in France.  Clearly these chefs were trained well!  

There's also some superb cocktails here; I've been having a constant craving for any drink that infuses some lavender or rose...and I found myself in luck here when finding the Sparkles in the Sky cocktail.  It was so good that it was almost impossible to keep myself from throwing it back just like that.  I had to be a classy lady.  Speaking of class, all the waiters conducted themselves so well - there wasn't an unfriendly face there.  In the end, I absolutely loved Cafe Claude and it's a hidden secret in San Francisco!
author: Lauren K.

description:
Cute french-inspired spot.

We had the beef tartare (made tableside) which was excellent. We also shared the steak frites. The steak wasn't the best cut, but it was decent.

Service was okay. It was super hot inside, though.
author: Michelle B.

description:
Cafe Claude delivers all the French Bistro hits!

Friendly welcome, nice ambiance, excellent food and affordable wine list. We had escargot en crute, steak frites, duck confit, a nice cheese plate and a very nice Crozes Hermitage. We will be back.
author: John C.

description: I love the French dries here and their molten lava chili ate cake dessert.  It's seriously out of this world.  The ambiance is also quaint but seating can feel rather limited.
author: James L.

description:
Hmm. I've eaten here a bunch of times - including three times this month. After a number of wobbly visits, this last time was pretty disappointing.
1)place was nearly empty at 6:30 yet I had to wait several minutes for a hostess to seat us at the entry.
2) upon being seated, waaaay too long a wait for water and our orders taken. Especially given that the place was empty.
3) really inexperienced server. I think I knew more about the menu than she did .
4)while the entrees were fine, our chocolate mousse dessert was heavy - like cake frosting from a can - not the light airy treat I'd enjoyed in an earlier visit.
Sorry guys - you were my go to restaurant for clients downtown, but now I must go elsewhere until you turn this mess around.
Perhaps the expansion has taxed your resources, perhaps you're more of a bar-emphasis place now,  or perhaps I caught you in between managers or chefs...
author: Al M.

description: Very pretentious. Drinks ok, Steak Fritters, well steak was chewy. Desert like warm. At best. Supposed to be served hot. Very disappointing to say least. Band was great!!! Good Jazzmusic.
author: Lorna B.

description: Over the last few years, when we visit to San Francisco, we go to Cafe Claude for lunch and we have been happy with the food and service.  Today though, we were disappointed with the food.  I ordered the crispy duck confit and although the skin was very crispy, the meat was very chewy.  I think it was overcooked.  We had a very good, polite waiter who was a young man but we did not get his name because we thought it was going to be on the receipt but instead, Natasha's name was on it who we really never interacted.
author: Retired M.

description:
This place is on point! The staff are super sweet and accommodating and the food is real tasty. Since we don't usually have French food, we really went for it during lunch.

We started with their escargots en croute ($12 for 6) and beef tartare (large $18). The escargot was sooo good! It had this puff pastry on top that went perfect with it, and then we dipped the bread from the bread basket into the leftover pesto sauce. The beef tar tar was alright, it has a more sour taste than we would have liked, and the presentation probably could have been better. My sisters were not into eating something that looked like a plopped down brain but they're also younger. I thought it was good.  

For entrees, two of us ordered the espadon/ swordfish that came with potatoes and asparagus ($27) and was in my opinion the best dish of the meal! Softest and tastiest swordfish I've ever had in my so far short lifetime. I, myself ordered the duck/ confit de canard ($26) and came with lentils over some type of salad. I was surprised with the lentils since I expected to not enjoy it as much as I did. It definitely helped that was some nice pork pieces mixed in with the lentils. I would have preferred less of it though. The duck itself was tasty but had some really dry and stringy parts that I had to leave because they were unchewable but it was a small amount. 

My sisters ordered (the 2 of them) the steak frites ($28) and the casserole de champignon ($20). The casserole was probably my second favorite dish. It's not very colorful but it's really delicious and I just love baby carrots. The dish was very comforting too. The steak was definitely the most disappointing dish since my sister had asked for medium rare and her steak was completely done and she didn't tell us that the steak was so chewy it was hard for her to eat it until we were out of the restaurant. 

Overall I had a good experience with only a couple setbacks but I would definitely suggest going with the seafood and chicken dishes! The staff will be awesome and super sweet!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
We've eaten here many times and always enjoyed it. Tonight we had three dishes that all had too much lemon!
Coq au vin
Goat cheese salad
Trout almandine 
Guess lemons were on sale
author: leslie d.

description:
Probably the best French food I've had in SF. I was pleasantly surprised because of the handful of French restaurants I've been to in SF, I've not been impressed.
Cafe Claude gets many things right. 

We started with some of their house cocktails yuum. Also had mussels, onion soup (best ever!), tomato bisque. Main course for me was steak frites, which was divine. My husband had the vegetable casserole which was good also. Got desserts with birthday candle since it was my birthday .

Service was top notch. The Friday night live music was nice. The location is cute alley, reminded me of Europe. We really enjoyed our time at Cafe Claude. It's a winner!
author: Vol T.

description:
After a rather upsetting encounter with the manager, Amber, I decided it would have been a huge inconvenience to everyone to cancel last minute since I had planned my birthday dinner several weeks in advance. 

The restaurant is located in a super cute alleyway very reminiscent of a small neighborhood restaurant in Paris. Under normal circumstances I would have been completely enamored by the atmosphere and the location- very unexpected in the best way.

Upon sitting at our table, I was immediacy approached by Amber who apologized for her behavior on the phone. She seemed genuinely apologetic and mentioned how she implemented a corrective action for herself- she would ask the customer to be on hold if she were to ever to feel as stressed as she was earlier that afternoon. This way no other customer would have to experience the unpleasantness I experienced. I appreciated Amber's professionalism and service recovery.

Aside from that, the restaurant does have lovely live music and great ambiance almost transporting me back to Paris. Highlights include: fantastic cocktails, great classic French bistro food (steak tartare prepared right at table side!), amazing live jazz music. 

What started out as a terrible experience at Cafe Claude, ended up becoming a surprisingly enjoyable birthday dinner with friends.
author: Mindy H.

description:
I got lost finding this spot, thought it was in Belden Lane but it's actually a block up on Bush Street. 

Once we made it in, yum yum for hh and our server was entertaining. Before the place got busy, he insisted on taking fotos for us =)
Live jazz band made it lively. We had a large pot of tasty mussels, escargots(bit on the bland side); buttery foie gras and shared a medium-rare steak. All smiles!
author: Vee V.

description:
Service was great. Ambiance was great. I enjoyed all of our starters but disappointed with the main courses.

What we got: 
Escargot- good! Sizzling hot with a nice puff atop each escargot.
Foie- good! Very palatable. Not as strong as eating actual foie gras. 
Steak tartare- okay. Taste was interesting. A lot of new flavors. Not what I expected. Can go with or without. 
French onion soup- ok. Wish there was more cheese!

Steak and frites (medium rare)- overall, can be cooked better. Loved the fries! Smells and almost tasted like that of one of my fave fast food chains'. Loved the bone marrow butter on top of the steak. Can eat a whole stick by itself. Steak was nicely cooked outside but pretty rare inside. Overall, I would say I've had better steak. 
Duck Confit- can go without. Love duck, but if not cooked properly, will taste dry. That is the case with this. 

Tip: ask for a side of aioli with the fries! It was awesome.
author: Tina S.

description:
Delicious! This place hit the spot for a relaxed Saturday lunch: I recommend the SALADE DE CHÈVRE CHAUD and a glass of rose. My husband got the steak tartare and said it was just right. Cool atmosphere and attentive service.
The bathrooms are in a hall behind the restaurant which is pretty common for their European counterpart restaurants, but not what I'd expect in San Fran.
author: Susan H.

description:
My friend and I came for Restaurant Week (RW)- we made reservations and were late due to delays in BART, but the hostess was very understanding. We were seated at a nice table without any issues, and proceeded to order the RW menu and added on some escargots (a must-order for me!). We ordered:

-Escargots: delicious! They came with these little pastry puff hats, which added a slight crunch. There weren't as many herbs as I usually like, but still very good. TIP: Don't eat all of the complimentary bread- save some so you can dip them into the butter/herb remnants in the wells of the escargot plate. Yum!

-Salt Cod Brandade Croquettes (RW): there was a bit of a hiccup because our waiter told us after we ordered that they didn't have any croquettes anymore. I told him to come back again because my friend had gone to the restroom and obviously couldn't make a choice. When she got back, she said that she didn't want to do the RW menu anymore. The waiter came back and told us that they were already in the process of making our food and it was essentially too late. What's the point of telling us after we ordered then telling us that we can't change it! Luckily, the guy came back around said that he was told that they had enough croquettes for the two of us. The croquettes were very good and I'm glad we were able to have them after all of that.

-Hanger Steak a la Plancha (RW): sadly very disappointing. My friend got it medium and I asked for medium rare. The waiter didn't double-check which one had which, but it didn't matter because they were too well cooked on both sides. Way too much chewing to enjoy this. 

-Roasted Apple Crumble a la Mode (RW): very, very good. I had a terrible experience with a similar apple crumble at another french restaurant, and that crumble attempted to get the right balance of caramelized apple/sugar/crunch. This one got it right. 

Overall, still enjoyed it, although I would avoid the steak in the future. 4/5.
author: Elodie T.

description:
Please see Candice G's review as she nailed it.

Poor service, complete lack of respect for a reservation of 5, sitting us outside on a freezing day (at that point, just say you don't have an available table), mediocre food and high prices warrants this 2 star review. Yes, I'm sure if you get a table inside, this place is charming, yada yada, but sadly, a ship that runs this way for one guest definitely trickles down.

I went with the soup of the day which was ok. Not robust and hearty, more watery and sparse and at $10 it was a rip off. The chevre chaud was pretty pedestrian. Two pieces of room temp toast with room temp goat cheese spread on a delightful, but very basic salad.

The bad service just added to a pretty sad experience. Service had no clue what was going on. They messed up every dish on who it went to, they didn't know the menu, we finished our coffees when the one dessert arrived, and when you sit people outside on a freezing day, comp these people some dessert or a glass of bubbly, will ya?

They lost my biz.
author: Stephanie Y.

description: I enjoyed the French Onion Soup. The lighting of the restaurant is a lit dark but is part of the French Style.
author: Macarena F.

description:
I've been to Cafe Claude a couple times over the past ten years and it's never really stood out to me as a great experience so, I was surprised this place was picked for a business lunch last week. Maybe you've already seen my coworkers reviews but, I couldn't agree more with how mediocre the experience was overall. 

I was pretty confused that our reservation was for an outside table in the freezing rain. My guess, they totally forgot or overbooked the restaurant. Everyone inside looked warm and cozy but, we were left to fend for ourselves outside against the aggressive pigeons. I'm a pretty laid back dude and rarely write negative stuff here on Yelp but, the service was bad. I mean, real bad. It was clear to me that we were an afterthought to the waitstaff and managers inside.

As far as the food goes, meh. Overpriced French food with little soul and considering I just returned from Burgundian culinary escapade, Cafe Claude was real boring. Ok enough of this, I'm not interested in reliving the mediocrity.
author: Benjamin F.

description:
My disdain for restaurants in this immediate area continues... 

We had lunch reservations for a business lunch for 5 and the table they had "reserved" for us was outside in the alley and it was 48 degrees and raining. I sh*t you not. 

Why would you give a table that went through the effort of making advanced reservations the worst and most unwanted table in the joint? Sure there's a heat lamp on one side that kept one arm of the two people on the end of the table mildly warm, but we all had to leave our jackets on, I was freezing from head to toe, and at one point a skittish pigeon attacked our table. No thanks. 

Our servers were largely absent and we ended being waited on by 3 different people, including the host. Our lunch took far longer than expected and the only reasoning we could offer was because no one server wanted to come outside to serve because it was way too cold... and they wouldn't have been wrong. We would know since we sat out there in our jackets still shivering for almost 2 hours. 

I got the soup of the day (lentil) served in a bowl but not even topped off all the way so it was more like a cup with an extra large brim around it only drawing more attention to how sad the portion was. The creme fraiche couldn't have looked less appetizing if it tried (see photo if you think your stomach can handle it) and the soup was soooo watery yet full of all the fleck-y grainy stuff you'd expect to find at the bottom of the pot. My table-mate and I who also had soup had to wonder if they watered down what was left in an attempt to (barely) fill the bowl to complete the order. Soup du Jour? More like river water. 

On the bright side, my frites were good but I'm a person who loves a soggy fry and I seem to be in the minority on that.

Each time a different server would bring out a round, there was always confusion about where the drink, or dish, or coffee went at the table. Every time. Every single thing. Some basic serving and table seat numbering would have helped them avoid the mix-up every single time they brought anything to the table. 

If the price point were lower they'd absolutely be a 3-star restaurant but for a $10 a cup of watered down soup, a "reserved" table in the cold with the animals of alley, and absent service, 2 stars seems right on the money.

They should be embarrassed about the experience they so carelessly provided.
author: Candice G.

description:
I stopped by here for a quick meeting and drinks during the JP Morgan conference. It was a very wet and rainy day, and this being set up in an alley, definitely made this feel a lot like Paris.

 Unfortunately it was a little bit cold, and they weren't letting anyone sit inside who did not already have reservations. Still a nice atmosphere, and maybe I'll be back there to try the food as well.
author: Chris W.

description: Very nice cafe/restaurant with Parisian atmosphere. Good light cocktails (I tried one with sparkling wine and one with vodka). Presentation was nice as well. Food is delicious. We were group of four so we got some clams and tartar as appetizers and duck, roasted hen and cow ay vin to share. Everything is very fresh, delicious and super rich with flavors. Desserts: chocolate mousse, apple tart and of course creme brûlé. Mmmmm that one was the best. Made my night!!!!
author: Asiyat T.

description: This is the second time I have came here. The service is great and the staff was friendly. However, the food was alright. I got the chicken coq au vin and it was not so good. Tasted like the sauce had been burnt and the chicken was a tad over cooked. The vegetables were good but sad to say my overall meal was meh. They were super busy and fit my friend and I in last minute so I'm going to give them another try because I think they can do better and maybe I can update my review add at least one more star.
author: David P.

description: The food, ambiance & service were outstanding. When I return to the city I will certainly be dining here. And will come in the evening to experience the music. And Jose was so accommodating. Just a lovely experience.
author: Sharon A W.

description:
Classic but never cliche Parisian dining in the middle of a classic San Francisco alleyway. Doesn't get any better than that! I had the opportunity to come to Cafe Claude with a good friend just for the last night of the 2017 San Francisco Restaurant Week, which for all intensive purposes can serve as the perfect gauge to what kind of food they serve on a normal day. And Cafe Claude was offering up a real nice option four full courses for only forty dollars for SFRW. You cannot get a better deal than that! 

We came on a Sunday evening, where it was busy inside but with decently cool weather outside we chose to sit under the heat lamps and a big covered awning. Nothing like French Food in a San Francisco alleyway on a Sunday evening! At 40 dollars a person for their 4 course pre-fix dinner, it was an affordable way to sample new dishes that aren't normally featured on their daily dinner menu. We began with a rather large amuse bouche otherwise known as the Gravlax Tartine which was a pumpernickel toast topped with house creme fraiche, bread and butter picked radish, salmon roe and frisee. Then we moved on to a Charred Chicories Salade topped with macerated carrots, French feta, spiced walnuts, pear and drizzled with a toasted walnut vinaigrette. The main course featured an Alsatian Braised Pork mixed with a healthy does of potato dumplings, roasted apples and braised rainbow chard. We wrapped with a Creme Brulee dessert which was made with Tahitian vanilla. 

I really loved the pumpernickel toast with a heavy dose of sweetness and savoriness thanks to all of the creme fraiche. The Salade was filled with a ton of veggies but couldn't get over all of the extra "roughage". I really liked the pork dish as cooked well done but nicely tempered with the dumplings and all of the apples and chard. The highlight for me was the divine creme brulee because you can never go wrong with dessert especially with an after hours coffee or wine! The service and ambiance at Cafe Claude is always on point whether you are sitting inside or out on the street. As the night wore on, the place got even busier especially outside on their makeshift patio on the street. It didn't really feel like Parisian dining tonight as Cafe Claude had more of an East Coast vibe to its atmosphere. This meal gave me a real feeling for the kind of meal they serve every night at Cafe Claude and I can't wait to go back to sample their regular menu. A lovely way to spend a romantic San Francisco meal or with a group of friends.
author: Jason F.

description:
We went on the fourth Friday of the month because they have Tango music and dancing.
Everything went very well. To have a table next to the tango dancing part of the restaurant you need to reserve in advance, but the rest of the place had tables available.
The food was very good, but we only have small plates. My friend had the onion soup. 
I had the Croque Monsieur, a sandwich bathe on bechamel sauce with some delicious french fries and some French Malbec which was excellent.
With my friend we shared a crème bruelée that was done perfectly well.
The best though were the gracious and friendly staff, that never stop smiling even when the were very busy.
author: Diana Z.

description: We had a delightful lunch on Bastille Day 2018, after walking from the Embarcadero Park celebration. Both croque monsieur and steak frites were perfect. The decor is engaging and the staff pleasant and efficient. Thank you!
author: L G.

description:
Feeling fancy during lunch! I started with a Sparkles in the Sky cocktail which was a sparkling wine with lavender. I actually enjoyed it as the lavender was just a hint and it didn't taste like soap and the drink had a good amount of sweetness. We started the meal with the Foie Gras Au Torchon and it was delicious! It was rich and silky and went amazing with their walnut raisin bread. That probably could have been my meal. As my main course, I got the Steak Frites with bone barrow butter and port shallot sauce. I ordered it medium rare, but it seemed more like rare to me as there was a lot of pink and a lot of parts that weren't as cooked as I would like. The steak itself (or the parts I ate) was really good though and I like the butter and the sauce.

Overall, it was a good meal. I felt very rich after eating it.
author: Sophia Y.

description:
I've had Café Claude on my potential visit list in SF for a while now. All in all, my experience was certainly not negative but I had definitely been hoping for more.

I made a reservation one night about two minutes before making the 15-minute walk over for my reservation at the bar. When I arrived, I was already impressed by the heated seating outside (although I was not ABOUT to be out there because it was cold) and the nice ambience, even visible from the outside of the restaurant. When I entered, I saw that there was no bar seating, and the host informed me that one party had finished their meal but had been chatting leisurely for ages. Long story short: It was sort of funny because the host went to talk to the manager, and then they talked to someone else, and I knew they were trying to find me a table because they kept looking over at me in their hushed whispers...in a few minutes, the manager came over and explained that bar seating probably wouldn't open up for a while and that if I would be OK with a table (which I was--solo dinner before heading to the airport) I could be seated right away. 

After a while, the friendly waitress came over and gave me the wine menu, from which I proceeded to solicit a suggestion to accompany the confit de canard (duck confit). She smiled and said, "That's an easy one...the pinot noir from Bourgogne." I was definitely pleased with her recommendation and had a second glass later. 

I ordered the onion soup as an appetizer, and thought it was good although not particularly flavorful. The cheese was sort of a mass, so it was sort of like soup with the cheese added onto the top. Onion soup is one of those things that I find French restaurants either do very well or just very OK, and unfortunately, this was the latter for me. I followed this up with the duck confit, which was overcooked (which made me very sad!). The crispy skin on the duck was nice--actually, a very nice touch--but was overshadowed by the fact that it was overcooked. The duck was accompanied by lentils and frisée, which was oddly a bit overpowering. I kept coming up on these very noticeable chunks of onion that were very jarring. 

The venue had wonderful live music all evening and overall an excellent ambience. It's relatively small with a nice vibe, and I could tell that people really enjoy themselves here. I would totally come back here for happy hour to enjoy a glass of wine and music with friends, although I think I will move onto some other French restaurants on my list for my next trip to SF. On the whole, a 3.5, rounded down because the environment eclipsed my expectations.
author: Willie R.

description:
I don't know why this place isn't packed for lunch. I love their options makes choosing hard. I ended up selecting the Croque monsieur which comes with a large salad. Excellent bread and melted gruyere and ham. I couldn't finish it so had the rest the next day. 

Service was outstanding but not a pest. 

The in side was air conditioned.
author: Frank T.

description:
What a lovely place for a date! My boyfriend took me here one evening, and I was impressed by the classy atmosphere and quality of service. He had made a reservation, and we were seated shortly after we arrived. The waitress was super sweet and made us feel welcome. 

We immediately jumped into entrees. I had the Truite Amandine, which is trout with almonds, haricot verts, golden raisins, capers, and sauce meuniere. The mixture of flavors sounded appealing and it lived up to my expectations! Just the right intensity of savory with a hint of sweetness from the raisins. Very tasty and decent-sized portion. Would recommend.

This time we didn't dabble in wine or dessert, but I would venture to try either of those menus in the future. I've already recommended Cafe Claude to friends who are always looking for another upscale restaurant to take business and romantic dates. It's wonderful that this atmosphere serves any occasion!
author: Stefanie C.

description:
Highly recommend for when you want to treat yourself to rich french food. Bread and butter are delicious. I got the quiche lorraine and salad, which was excellent. Salad was a bit too heavily dressed for me, but really good. 

My colleague loved the french onion soup and salad he got. We went for a work lunch and would definitely come back!
author: Jo M.

description:
I enjoyed lunch at this location because of the Yelp reviews. I would not have been able to find this on my own had someone else not mentioned that there is an entry through the alleyway.

Although I wasn't particularly excited about the seating arrangement on the patio, I did enjoy sitting outside. Service was initially friendly, but I had to ask for my glass of wine, which finally came after my first course.

Food was good and service was friendly, but I had to ask for utensils and my wine, which is not what I would expect from this establishment.
author: MJ T.

description:
This place is a little hidden gem. We found this based on all the great Yelp reviews, always and I mean always check Yelp!

We started with drinks while we waited, they were very good. We then sat down in a cozy corner. The tables are spaced very closely, but it's not annoying at all. I ordered the steak tartare. My stomach had been bothering me and I didn't want anything difficult to digest. It really settled my stomach. I read before dinner that uncooked foods are often easier to digest. I don't know if that's true, but it felt like it worked for me!

The steak tartare was brought out and prepared tableside. A nice little show. They asked me what I wanted mixed in, of course I said everything. It got some looks from other tables, and someone else ordered it a bit later. It really is an impressive show. They gave me a nice piece of steak, a nice big portion. 

My wife ordered her food, it was fish and she loved it. I kept smelling her fish and had to move away. It smelled good, and not fishy. But it was still fish. I'm usually not picky with that, but the smell was so intoxicating that my tartare started tasting like a fish!

All in all, I definitely recommend checking this place out. It's cozy, fun, and has great food.
author: Alden K.

description: Terrific lunch with friends. The nicoise salad, the carrot/red bell pepper soup, the lentils--all were lovely. And the bubbly brut rose was lovely, too.
author: Jill H.

description:
Been passing by cafe Claude a lot now that I work in the city and have been meaning to try it out. Finally booked a reservation and was definitely not disappointed! Great food + great service!

They have happy hour between 4-6, where several dishes are $7, not sure about drinks. Too bad none of the things I wanted was on the happy hour menu tho :(

My friend and I shared a couple of dishes: foie gras, steak and frites, escargot, and steak tartare (5 oz). This was actually more than enough for 2 people.

Foie gras (3.5/5)
This dish was overall pretty sweet. It came with two slices of toast, similar to French toast to me, with mandarin slices and a generous slab of foie gras, which was super fatty and rich. Overall, it was enjoyable, but savory + sweet was just a little odd for me. 

Steak and frites (3.5/5) 
This dish gives you a very generous portion of meal and fries. The fries were perfecttttt. However the steak was a bit too cooked for my liking. I asked for medium rare, but this was closer to medium or medium well, so it was also a bit tough. Comes with a fat slice of bone marrow butter which gives it a great flavor though!

Escargot (5/5)
Super delicious garlicky buttery flavor to it! Would totally come back just for this dish. Ask for extra bread to dip it in he delicious garlic sauce! The escargot itself was very tender and the little flakey pastry on top paired perfectly with it.

Steak tartare (5/5)
I loveeee steak tartare! Cafe Claude gives you an option for 3oz or 5 oz dish, and obviously I ordered the 5 oz. It ended up being too big of a portion even for someone like me and a friend to share, so I recommend getting the 3 oz next time. The server prepares the tartare in front of you so that it can be customized to your liking. Comes with crostinis as well. Massive portion and great flavor! 

Would totally come back again. Absolutely love their small plates, and plan on trying some of their desserts next time!
author: Joanne Y.

description: My favorite place for lunch in downtown San Francisco, unlike many other "French" restaurants, this one has a real Parisian aura to it [thank God (!)].  The Croque Monsieur is nothing short of wonderful, and the pomme frites are as they should be.  Recommended.
author: Tavistock B.

description: They recently remodeled the bar area, and now it's so much better and specious. Quick drink at the bar or a nice romantic dinner at the main dining area are both great! I always love the decor and atmosphere here. Service is good and food is great especially Coq au vin and steak tartare. Wine menu is limited but I like their selections. Don't miss the music night as well!
author: Lana B.

description:
This is a decent choice in this part of town, where many restaurants are tourist traps serving subpar food.  I thought the food was solid, the service was pretty good, and the live jazz was very pleasant.  Be prepared for expensive wine.

I was there with two others and we shared two salads (Nicoise and frisee), the Croque Madame, and the beef tartare.  I thought the Croque Madame was excellent.  The bread was buttery and crispy, and the egg was cooked perfectly (runny yolk, solid white.)  The frisee salad would have been wonderful but the yolk of the egg wasn't runny, which was disappointing.  But it was well dressed and the slab bacon was crispy on the outside but still  had a nice chewy heft to it.  The tartare was respectable, but a little heavy on the capers.  I think the tartare at Wayfare Tavern is the best, but at least Cafe Claude's was far better than the last two I've had (at Cafe Prague and at Etcetera Wine Bar where they both put tomato products in, yuck!)  

We were seated outside and even with the heat lamps and protective plastic tenting, it was still quite chilly, I had to keep my coat on for the duration of our meal.  But I was still glad we sat outside because inside would have been loud with the live music.

Our server was adorably French (and either just moved here or was laying it on quite thick with the accent.)  He was pretty attentive and got everything right, including a special request.

My biggest complaint about this restaurant was that their wine by the glass is very expensive.  The most affordable option was $11 and most were in the $13 - $16 range.  And the pours are quite miserly.  I'm attaching a photo of two of our glasses before we'd even taken a sip.  If I'm paying $13 for a glass of wine, I think I should get at least 5 ounces.
author: C S.

description: Live jazz and outdoor seating. Ambience is great for a chill laid back dinner. I had the croque madame sandwich - egg, ham and bechamel sauce. Sandwich was okay, too oily for my taste. But I would return to try other dishes.
author: Katy H.

description: This is a very authentic French restaurant with the kinds of classics one would expect to see on a menu of any good restaurant in Paris. I started with the escargot which was bathed in a garlic butter sauce. For my entrée, I had the Coq au vin. The red wine sauce was delicious, especially with the little bits of pancetta floating in it. Finally, the crème brûlée melts in your mouth. The custard is perfectly creamy and sweet and the caramelized sugar is just the right color of caramel brown. If you like French cooking, you will not be disappointed with Café Claude!
author: Jeromy C.

description:
I like to focus on the up sides of restaurants and the only good thing happening for this place was the french onion soup and free bread & butter. We were a party of 3 for a weekday lunch and our food came out 2 hours later. My gf was hangry and trust me you do not want to see the hulk unleashed. Finally got my order which was supposed to be a medium rare steak (all three of us confirmed with the server to have it this way) but it came out well done. WTF. After waiting so long for our food?? Come on now.... did the chef take a smoke break and leave the meat on the grill? didn't even bother sending it back at that point with our flight or fight instincts on overdrive for nourishment. Tried to pay our bill but couldn't find our sever. Def tested my patience in front of my gf's sister who I was meeting for the first time. Hopefully not the last after this horrendous meal. 

My advice: skip this place and checkout the nearby other restaurant options instead. This place needs to step up its game. Not worth the time or money unless you want to leave disappointed.
author: Sung P.

description: Been here several times whenever I visit San Fran. Food was delicious and they do have live performances here on the weekend.
author: Cecilia H.

description:
The romantic appeal of San Francisco's back alleys has long been lost on me.  When cafes opened on Belden Alley and began serving dinner al fresco I was mystified.  This was the same alley that housed dumpsters full of restaurant waste all day and down which I'd seen rats routinely darting.  Cafe Claude opened on another alley, Claude Lane, and I felt similarly though I'll admit to enjoying a post-work drink there now and then.  

It'd been years since my last visit but on this evening I walked here from the new MOMA with friends in tow who knew not where we were headed.  What still looked like sort of an abysmally dark alley was seen through their fresh eyes as we ventured down the lane.  Then, stepping into Cafe Claude we were greeted in a way that helped overcome any reticence I might have been wrestling with.  

All eyes in my party lit with joy when we entered to a trio of jazz musicians (sultry femme singer included) in Cafe Claude's entry.  It seemed as though we'd stumbled into a very well-known (to others) secret and it felt both romantic and very special.  Remember this place if those are the feelings you're going for.  

No one was sitting outside and it still looked less than appealing to me.  Indoors, however, was packed.  Two tight rooms full of diners enjoying French bistro fare and wine with musical accompaniment.  Ooh la la, tres chic.    

Despite what was an overly long wait between first course and entree (and for which no explanation was given), the food and service here were good, enhanced by the ambiance.  I enjoyed traditional Soupe A L'Oignon ($11) and a Salade with Lardons.  The Steak Frites ($28) wasn't best in class but it was still good and worked well in this environment.  Others at my table had Trout Amandine ($25) and Coq Au Vin ($24) and registered satisfaction.    

Despite falling off my radar the fact that Cafe Claude is still packing them into the FiDi on a weekend night says something for the appeal of their offering.  Be certain to visit on a night with live jazz (Thursday - Saturday, 7 - 10 p.m.) as it'll smooth over any minor flaws and deliver what I'll now call a perfect ambiance.  

In a dark San Francisco alley.  Who knew?

*  Other stuff:  $1 oysters and $6 cocktails + bites (poutine anyone?) available during HH.  This might just be Cafe Claude's sweet spot.
author: Tracey A.

description:
What a great evening! Cocktails were delightful, cauliflower soup delicious, an almost middle eastern riff on the trout almondine (not the classic brown butter sauce, but raisins, and really complex flavor palate.  Easy walk from Union Square.  Wish we lived closer!
Dressy by Central Coast standards, casual by City standards.  (collared shirts for guys)
author: Marjorie L.

description: Cozy location, fantastic ambience and delicious food! We found this place through Yelp and were very pleased with our dinner. The Steak Frites was yummy. It would have been 5 stars if it was served with Bernaise sauce and if the restrooms were nicer/better located. Two minor things. I highly recommend a table inside if it is chilly out.
author: Kristina S.

description: Nice place, I was dieing for a steak tartar that didn't disappoint me very fresh and meat hand cut so it was perfect, magri de canard perfect as well, the chocolate mousse didn't impress me but was fair. Overall a place to enjoy mostly if you like quiet service and admostphare.
author: Mercedes C.

description:
My mom and I were out shopping in Union Square and although all of the shoes and dresses were fitting amazingly, hunger slowly took over. I started searching on Yelp for a yummy place that was walking distance to us and came upon Cafe Claude. What an awesome find!

We ordered the three cheese (cow only) cheese plate, French onion soup and escargot. Honestly, the cheese plate would have. been enough as both my mom and I were full after eating each and every bite of it. Loved the walnut bread (ask for extra if you order the cheese plate)! The French onion was delicious and my mom enjoyed her escargot (I didn't come near it).

The best part of dining here was our waitress, Lohane. She was wonderful! Super friendly and nice. 

I look forward to dining here again. It's a great date spot too!
author: Anastasia N.

description: Great service and great food. What more could you ask for? I was in town for work but decided to meet up with an old friend. She suggested this restaurant and it was such a great choice.  Upon entering the restaurant we were promptly greeted and seated. Luckily my friend made reservations...we came just before the lunch crowd.  But I would definitely suggest reservations if you can.   My friend had made reservations under her alias, which was cause for laughter on our part as well as the wait staff, who were phenomenal by the way.  We had a running joke throughout our meal and it was such a fantastic place to be able to relax and catch up with an old friend. We ordered steak tartare, escargot en croute (amazing garlicky flavors with a small delectable pastry puff on top), Soupe a l'oignon (definitely a must), salad maison (a light salad made with butter lettuce) and steak frite with bone marrow butter (out of all the dishes this wasn't my favorite, but it also could've been because we feasted on everything else and were pretty full).  Next time I come, I'll prob try the duck cause that looked delicious as well. Thanks to the staff for making our lunch so enjoyable.
author: Cristina N.

description:
Excellent service!
The steak tartare is probably the best We ever had! The foie gras torchon is great with the huckleberries! The charcuterie platter was disappointing, the selection of meat is ark. The escargot are ok, the parsley is too strong, and the escargots were not washed enough, therefore we could eat the sand at the same time.
Wine selection is on point.
author: Meliza L.

description:
The most terrible customer service! We actually got kicked out of the restaurant for being there "for too long".  Let me tell you. We got there at 3 pm. Our main course was served at 5:30 pm (took them 2.5 hrs to bring it!!!!). Sure enough, it was cold. And then, at 5:45 we were asked to leave. And never mind we ordered several bottles of expensive wine there while waiting for 2.5 hrs for our food to arrive. Ridiculous!!! 
My experience with them 5 years ago was not much better either.
author: Zhanna B.

description:
I really do like this place. I like it that there is music on the weekends and you can sit at the bar, though making a reservation is, by far, recommended since it gets packed.

I'm writing this review, though, really for one reason only. Just to have the opportunity to tell this restaurant that if you call something mushroom casserole (casserole de champignon), put some damned mushrooms in it! Or, at least, more than just the couple that were in mine, and I've had this twice. I thought the first time was a fluke. 

Please, oh please, make it REALLY MUSHROOMY!

(But thanks for the music!)
author: Rusty K.

description: Love this place. Down an alley, very Euro feel. Waiter was French, that helps of course. Had the duck for lunch. Cooked in duck fat of course. Why are the French so good at duck?? So moist, the skin so deliciously crispy. Waiter was great, this is a solid performer. All guests were happily plump!
author: Steven D.

description: Nice atmosphere. The food was decent. Not the best tasting French onion soup but it sure looked pretty.  I was unimpressed with the staffs knowledge of the cheese and the best pairs for the cheese platter.
author: JJ M.

description:
Our group o' five called ahead on a Thursday evening and found an opening at 8 pm, and were seated immediately upon arrival. 

Amazing French food at reasonable prices. We split the moules a la normande ($19 for the large size which was perfect for five hungry adults), and it came with a side of frites on the house. I hadn't heard of hard cider being used to cook mussels, but it turned out magical. Creamy sauce that we couldn't stop dipping bread into.

Two of us got the scallop on risotto special of the night, while I opted for the daube de boeuf provencale. Perfectly cooked juicy meat on a big pile of buttery papperdelle. Their coq au vin was also delicious, with an earthy wine sauce that tasted almost like mole.

Live music in the corner nook, with the line-ups listed outside on a glowing sign. Unsure if the musicians are that comfortable or if the acoustics work quite right, but a lovely use of a tiny space.

Great service, particularly the general manager. When our server accidentally spilled a giant dollop of ketchup on my friend's sleeve, she was immediately there to address the situation, even offering her card if my friend wanted to dry clean the garment later.
author: Kevin L.

description:
ALLEY WAY RESTAURANT

One of the advantages of working in the Financial District in SF is that you can eat at several interesting places nearby your work. Even though most of the eateries are chain restaurants. What I noticed is that there are quite a few French eateries around the Financial District. There is one that is about 2 blocks away from my work - Café Claude.

I ate at Café Claude two Thursdays ago for lunch. I previewed the menu. The item I intended to order was the bavette steak with bone marrow butter as that butter sounded very tasty. For dessert one item that looked appealing was the crème brulee made with tahitian vanilla. As an art history major one of the artists I studied was Post-Impressionist artist Paul Gauguin who visited Tahiti. That was the reason why I thought of ordering the crème brûlèe. When I got to the restaurant the poulet roti got my interest because it came with foie gras bread pudding. Then I pondered that if I ordered the bavette steak I can order a foie gras appetizer, which was foie gras poêle on toasted brioche. I did take my time to order. That resulted in cutting my lunch time and I decided not to order the crème brûlèe for dessert. Instead of buying two items - the bavette steak and foie gras - I decided to order the poulet roti that came with the foie gras bread pudding. I also decided to order the pomme frites.

The poulet roti was half chicken as you get the breast with the drumette portion of the chicken wing and the leg quarters. The sign of a good roasted chicken is if the breast is moist. The breast of the roast chicken was moist. I liked the bread pudding as you can taste the melted foie gras inside it. Overall I like when foie gras is the focus of the dish as you can really taste the foie gras. The fries, which cost $8, were ok. However something was missing about the meal. At first I couldn't figure why. Then I remember Thomas Keller stating how he loves to cook food to invoke memories. The last time I ordered a roast chicken with a side order of fries was when I ate at Bouchon in Yountville four years ago. The roast chicken at Bouchon was one of the best I ever had because of the crispy skin and moist meat of the breast. The fries, which cost $7, were plentiful and crispy. The meal at Bouchon was the best combination of roast chicken and fries I ever had. That might seem harsh to compare a Michelin star restaurant with a café but most of all it's about the value you pay for the meal. I felt that the fries at Café Claude weren't up to par as they cost $7. Due to my lunch at Café Claude I felt the rating I gave was valid given the price I paid for my meal.
author: Gerald R.

description: One of the things I always need to do when visiting San Francisco is to have lunch or early dinner at a French restaurant. We just had 5pm dinner at this very French restaurant which is located up an ally. We liked the menu so our concierge made 5pm reservations for us. Dining early is great cuz you can walk around Union Square after a 2 hr meal while it's still light out during the summer. To start we had a California and French Chardonnay. We prefer the oaky buttery texture of most California chards so my second glass was of the Napa varietal. Whenever I go French, I always have to have the silky texture of foie gras; this was terrine style thus it didn't look like a liver! The house salad was the best I've had. I chose the duck over chicken; it was ok as the inside was a little dry but crunchy it was on the outside. My wife had the trout which was smothered with green beans. I think I need more coaching on French cuisine as I need to appreciate the different preparations. For dessert, we shared a soft chocolate cake which most Hawaii residence know as Roy's chocolate soufflé. It was outstanding. Their latte paired beautifully with the chocolate cake. Next time I'll have a salad, two apps  and dessert. It'll be more fun that way.
author: Dan M.

description:
Came here for dinner with a couple of coworkers tonight. I had just finished stress eating half a bowl of pad thai so I wasn't super hungry.

We started off with the charcuterie-- my favorite by far was the duck prosciutto-- kind of like ducky sort of bacon. I like that the butter here is salted here, but bread is nothing special. Given I'd just eaten, I had the steak tartare appetizer as a main. Steak tartare was quite bland (not salty or peppery, nor tasting of meat, really), although the steak was decently fresh. Got the creme brulee as a dessert and the sugared crust on top was the perfect thickness, although the portion size is definitely sufficient for two.

Last time I had the coq au vin and it was just okay. 

I definitely think that if you are to come here, sitting inside would be a much more enjoyable experience than the tables they have in the alleyway, given that it is less cold, windy, and that they have live jazz inside!

2.5 stars for me, but I'm sure I'll be back again with coworkers.
author: Nicole H.

description: Enjoyed a dinner there very much last month while celebrating my birthday!  The cuisine was very good! We missed the live music because we had theater tickets so we had to leave as it was about to start! Had we known it was live jazz night, we might not have gotten theater tickets!  We will be back! Salut, et à bientôt!
author: Catherine M.

description:
Très charmant!

Café Claude brings the cafe concept back to France--not the cafes in SF that serve cold brew in mason jars catering to yuppies and/or hipsters showcasing Macbooks; rather, the original café featuring carefree people-watching and memorable noms by adventurous chefs.

We came for SF Restaurant Week, but they do have fixed price menus on a regular basis that are quite a good deal for trying different things without breaking the bank (which unfortunately happens all too often, especially in Downtown SF).

Complimentary bread: 
Better than your average bread and butter, with really creamy and indulgent butter. The baguette was tougher than I'd like and served cold, but this is normal in French cuisine (I guess French people must have strong teeth)

Regular menu entree:
$22 Confit de canard (crispy duck leg confit, lentils, frisée, chopped egg): The duck itself was delicious and distinctively roasty though a bit dry; at the end of the day I prefer the juicy duck breast from Absinthe. The spicy lentils did stand out and reminded me a bit of Moroccan food. Overall I was content because this dish turned out filling with the well portioned duck and the side of lentils.

$40 Prix fixe:

1. Alsatian tarte flambee (puff pastry, caramelized onions, creme fraiche, bacon lardons): Mmm buttery flakey puff pastry! The sweet caramelized onions, luscious creme fraiche, and hammy bacon were excellent toppings, all outstanding on their own and balanced in flavor and texture by the endives. Curiously, it's built like a taco and looks like a taco, but way fancy.

2. Carbonnade flamande (Flemish beer-braised beef, pearl onions, winter root vegetable puree): Frankly I was disappointed with the portion size, but if you eat it reeeeaaaaallllllllyy sloowwwwwwwwlllyyyyyy and mindfully appreciate the nuances, you will be more satisfied because you will notice the culinary finesse going into this dish (and also because it will last longer and feel less small). The beef is so tender, you could probably sneak it into someone's juice cleanse without them noticing

3. Choux aux chantilly (almond profiteroles, vanilla bean cream, orange gastrique): Tasty and a nice sweet dessert at the end of the meal, but nothing too special and it's somewhat difficult to taste the almonds and the orange. (FYI gastrique is a sweet and sour sauce, not gastric acid as I had been thinking)

(Word of caution: the lighting outdoors may not have the best layout. Boo was seated under the lamp so cast a shadow over the table and complained in exasperation that it was difficult to see what he was eating!)

As some reviewers pointed out, service can be a tad bit slower than what you're used to in the hustle and bustle in-and-out of SF--Cafe Claude is good for relaxing over a French cafe experience that is authentic even in the laid-back vibe. Presentation may not be the most photogenic either, but this is not a trendy place like State Bird. Don't worry too much about documenting your food on Instagram; instead, soak up the ambiance in its entirety, and don't be in a rush if you can help it! 

Cafe Claude is quite neat when it comes to the details. Everything is branded with the restaurant logo reminiscent of the Tour d'Eiffel (the menu, the check, even the little piece of paper covering the butter). And the overall setting somehow pulls of casual romantic: classy with the live jazz, unpretentious with the splendid but basic outdoor patio seating under an awning, and quintessentially Parisian in its quaint location tucked into an alleyway. Chouette!
author: Edna C.

description:
It really breaks my heart to write this review, because this used to be one of my favorite SF spots for drinks + dinner + weekend jazz. But man oh man, my lunch here yesterday was a complete disappointment from start to finish. 

So here's our experience went down...
- I booked our 12:30pm table via Yelp Reservations first thing in the morning. I received a few text message confirmations. Everything seemed all set for our party of 4. However, when we arrived at 12:30 on the dot, the frazzled hostess had difficulty locating our resy. I'm not sure if she ever did find our reservation in the system, but she decided to seat us outside on their patio. Now keep in mind, it was raining and cold this particular day. Sitting outside in a FiDi alleyway wasn't exactly ideal (especially when we saw vacant tables inside). Alas, we found a table under a heat lamp and decided to make the best of things. 
- It took about 10 minutes before a server greeted our table and took our drink order. And then it took another 15 minutes for those drinks to arrive and for us to then place our food order.
- I ordered the Croque Monsieur with mixed green salad (a French bistro staple). My co-workers ordered bowls of the Lentil Soup, and our business client ordered the mussels.  We also got an order of the pommes frittes for the table to share. Long story short, the food took quite a while to arrive. My Croque Monsieur tasted like it had been sitting out for a while. And the salad that came with it had a dressing that was so salty that I finally gave up after a few bites. My co-workers felt that the lentil soup was fine (albeit watery in texture) but not exactly memorable. The mussels seemed to be a hit with our one lunch buddy. But the fries were lukewarm and soggy. 
- Our over-worked server was friendly, but she would disappear for long patches of time. And we finally had to hail down the hostess to order espresso + dessert and someone to bus our table. 
- My co-worker ordered a non-fat latte. After waiting 10 minutes (and after everyone had already received their coffee and espressos), she was then notified by our server that they don't have non-fat milk. And the best part was when they told her "We don't serve non-fat lattes because we're a French restaurant." Um... ok? Then why did you accept her order in the first place?
