However, the stage is different for lunch -- you can find better value elsewhere.  Food quality is reasonable but entrees around $20 usually yields slightly larger potions around here. I ordered the trout almondine ($22) which came with a small butterflied trout topped with green beans, capers, and golden raisins.  The sweet and savory raisins and capers play made the dish interesting, went well with the buttered haricot and trout.  I also asked for a side salad ($10) which consisted of a small plate of bib lettuce and a few slivers of radish, dusted by chopped tarragon.  The lettuce was fresh but plain.  Honestly, for the same price, I would opt for the entree sized, also overpriced salad from across the street at Mixt.  My coworker ordered the Steak Frites ($23), medium rare.  A piece of meat about the size of an empanada arrived medium with fries.  It appeared stringy and she only worked her way through half of it before pushing it way.

I'm a fan of their HH but not lunch.
author: Amy J.

description:
I made reservations for a party of three on Monday at Cafe Claude. I have read many good reviews on Yelp about the restaurant and wanted to feel the French vibe. We were promptly seated inside (it was too cold out) and given menus. Our server, Benjamin took care of our table. 

For lunch we ordered the Charcuterie Platter consisting of salami, prosciutto, and coppa. This was served with fresh bread, pickles, dijon mustard and arugula. My friend and I both ordered the Croque Madamme and it came with a green salad. My other friend ordered the Moules Frites. The Croque Madamme was exactly what I imagined it would be. A ham and cheese sandwich with an egg on top. Quite delicious when the cheese is caramelized on the bread. The mussels were also equally appealing but I didn't get to try them because I'm allergic. For desert we had creme brulee, chocolate cake, and a fruit tart. My cappuccino came with a piece of dark chocolate.

Service was excellent. We were given a through explanation of the menu and our server was very attentive to our table. The atmosphere definitely felt authentic along with the food. Overall, I was very pleased.

I definitely recommend dining al fresco if weather permits. This restaurant would serve you well.
author: Tim G.

description:
Fabulous dinner.  I booked it on Open Table after reading the Yelps.

We were seated with Devon who was fantastic, attentive and great personality.  She was there when we needed her, and not when we didn't.  

My mom the water snob asked for sparkling water even though I was paying.  Ugh!  That was $7 fyi.  We also had a bottle of Cab Franc ($48), Foie Gras ($19), Haricots Verts (green beans with lemon and almond sautee, $8), Pommes Frites (fries, $8), Coq Au Vin ($24), one more glass of the Cab Franc ($12) and then a Moelleux (dessesrt, $8).

The prices were not as high as I thought they'd be, I didn't really have time to inspect the menu before we went, I just skimmed the yelp reviews.  So even though it is certainly not cheap, it was worth the money.  All in I spent $180 for 2 people...we shared the Coq Au Vin and other sides, so you can definitely plan on it being spendy, but it was a great dining experience.
author: Heidi I.

description:
Fantastic dinner. Everything was to perfection. Our server was very helpful and never rushed us. What a perfect place for date night if you are missing Paris. 
It's in a small alley, as would be in Paris.
author: Karrar A.

description: Service was great. Ambiance was great. Food was just ok. There are better French spots in SF but we did enjoy our evening.
author: Mark H.

description: We've been coming to Cafe Claude for several years and have always received exemplary customer service and amazing dining choices. Amber and her staff, including Noah and Horatio have been attentive to our preferences and always seek to provide a 10-star experience. We last went to Cafe Claude on Dec. 22 and everything was perfect--the wine, the cheese, the coq au vin, the port, the superb service, and warm ambiance. Thank you all so much for a wonderful start to the holiday season!
author: Susan B.

description: The food is outstanding. Very delicious and unique. I recommend that if anyone goes to SF visit this cafe
author: Mohammed E.

description: I love this place and having been going here off and on for over 20 years. I recently took my family of 4 here for a dinner out downtown. The live music was great, the atmosphere was great even the service was the usual to be expected. The food was really nice too - we started with escargot, steak tartare and a frisbee salad. All straight ahead bistro items and all good respectable representations. Dinner was steak frites (kid 1), swordfish (kid 2), chicken (wife) and duck confit w/lentils for myself. I thought the swordfish was really good and came with a nice assortment of green beans, the steak frites was enjoyed. The duck and chicken would be really good in any other city, but just ok here. A couple deserts and a bottle of wine and the bill before tip was $340 which failed the value test even in hypercrazy San Francisco. Next time, it will be just for lunch and we will keep it simpler.
author: Scott D.

description:
This is a really cute alleyway lol. We unfortunately came too late and only caught the last few minutes of the jazz music, but we did get a couple classic French desserts. The tarte aux pommes and moelleux au chocolat were bomb, but kinda pricey. Maybe I'm just used to more exciting dishes a la Bouche.

And when I asked what moelleux meant, the waitress said she'd ask her friend who was French. That's kinda weird...
author: Vivian H.

description:
The good: service was fast and pleasant. 
The bad: our two plates came out at a blazing pace, making me wonder. The chicken was overcooked and dry, and the sauce tasted burnt, as if it had been simmering all night waiting to be added to our late night dinner plate. The fish was ok, a bit bland, and the green beans were so hard and crunchy I believe they were raw. Maybe some ppl like that. We didn't have a starter because they were out of the escargot. The special mixed drinks weren't good either. Two plates and two drinks for $100. Not a good use for a C note. Wouldn't recommend.
author: El C.

description: Great atmosphere, tucked in to a little alley off of Bush street.  Nice people, Manager came and talked to us.  Good waiter.  Had escargot with puff pastry, some fantastic orange and carrot soup and some swordfish with asparagus with a nice bottle of rose.  Had some nice live jazz going in the background.  Definitely go back to this.
author: Rick R.

description:
Oh how the mighty have fallen.  I used to love coming to Cafe Claude and the ambiance and drinks are still great.  Unfortunately, the food has definitely fallen off and while the service strives to meet the price point, it falls short.  

Ordered their classic steak tartar (which have had numerous times), foie gras, and the bavette steak to share.  The tartar is definitely lacking and while the foie gras was delicious, it wasn't enough to make up for the disastrous steak my dining companion and I were served.  I could tell that the steak had a big piece of connective tissue running through it. If you've ever cooked a steak, you can spot this a mile away.  Needless to say, it was inedible (I almost choked to death on bite 2).  I mentioned to our server that the steak was really chewy.  He was nice, but didn't take it off the bill or offer to bring out a new one.  Bill came, steak still on there.  I told him I wouldn't be paying for the steak (which he had to know when he cleared the plate and it was still there).  He immediately took it off the bill, but then the manager came over to say "we took care of it for you."  If by "taking care of it" you mean that I had to tell you to take it off the bill and that I was refusing to pay for it, then yeah...you took care of it.  

I love old school SF restaurants, but Cafe Claude has seen better days.  Pop in for a drink if you are in that area, but don't spend your money on a full meal here...it just isn't what it used to be:(
author: Karen W.

description:
I made reservations for 9:00pm on Valentine's day. Arrived at 8:45pm on time early and excited to try out this place that has good reviews. Did not get seated until about 9:40pm, was told that there was a lot of traffic which pushed everyone else back...and so our reservation was pushed back as well...finally got stale tasting, hard, cold bread at 10:10pm. It is currently 10:55pm and I have yet to see even a single plate of food on this table...

Tell me again what was the point of making a reservation here again?

The waiters are nice tho...or I'm sure they must be nice knowing that we're hungry and waiting...

edit* the waiters ignore us...only 1 waiter actually assists us well...it's the one French guy

Will edit later on the rest of the night

Edit* 11:03pm we have the second course on our table...where's the first course?

Edit 2* 11:13pm the first course meal has arrived...we were given a new fork, all hope is not lost...the food actually tastes good
-the girlfriend says they get 2 stars since they can't help it 1 person is in the back cooking their set meal...

Edit 3* 11:25pm the main entree is out...the place has been closed for about 1 hour...I'm thinking about sleeping here...food is good...can't tell if it's becuz I'm hungry or it's actually good

Edit 4* 11:59pm dessert is served...It looks good...but I've already digested everything and I feel full. The guy that assisted us apologized off the bat, the apology was a nice change of pace...you sir have bumped up the review to a 3 star...only because there's no 2.5 but none the less a 3 star.

Last Edit 12:05am we finally got the appetizer! wait...shouldn't that have been first? currently 12:10am...there is no waiter, waitress, or hostess...if I really wanted to...I could walk out...how do I get the bill to pay for this?

Final comments...food is good, tasted pretty good...atmosphere...lots of hungry couples waiting with us...honestly I will not be coming back because of the level of professionalism...I hope they get their act together and get things going/out at a respectable time.

If I could...this place would get a 2.5 star review...everything took way too long to be served, took way too long to be seated...took way too long to be noticed...
author: Christopher W.

description:
My girlfriend and I were leaning towards going 3-stars on this, but that's because we're not big fancy-dinner-connoisseurs, so this place is a little out of our league. However, on a vacation to SF, we decided to try this place on a whim after our reservations fell through at Chez Panisse thanks to a 90-minute delay on BART (I'm really, terribly sorry that your city has to deal with such an egregious transit system...but I'll Yelp review them later....)

The portions were good for the price and I enjoyed my dish, the coq au vin, which was chicken, bacon, veggies in a red wine sauce. She got the tuna niçoise and wasn't as impressed - not that it was necessarily bad, but the tuna was quite salty. The service was excellent - our waitress was quick to take care of us 110%. For anyone who enjoys French food, I'd recommend this place. It's casual but not too casual and the food is decent and it won't entirely break the bank.
author: Josh E.

description:
4 hour dinner on Valentine's Day. With a reservation. Need I say more but good food so you decide lol

Update: laughed so hard we cried at how comically bad this was. Good thing I had great company. 

Post Dinner Thoughts: Arrived at 8:44pm for an 8:45pm reservation so I was feeling pretty good about it. Hostess told us it would be just a few minutes... as at least 5-10 other couples showed up to be told it would be"just another minute".

15 minutes later we were seated, so things were looking up. Right off the bat, we ordered two glasses of champagne and two cocktails, ready to celebrate our Valentine's Day night. I would say at least 15 more mins went by before our champagne glasses were served. We then ordered our two identical 4 course prix fixe menu items with the wine pairing. 10 mins later our first cocktail order and 4 small (very small) pieces of bread came.

A good 25 mins later our first wine pairing came out, and another 5 our first course. Great pairing with fairly delicious soup.

Our second wine pairings came out about 15 mins after the first dish was cleared, but this time I'd say we had to wait about another 15 mins before our second food course arrived... 

Then 10 mins after our second course was cleared, our third course arrived!! This seems like great news, except that what's the point of a wine pairing if it isn't delivered with/before your food?? Another 10 minutes were spent alerting someone and waiting for our wine to be delivered. Once it was though, the food was delicious.

Lastly, and most hilariously, we were offered coffee which we accepted. Our waiter then came over holding the bill and asked us if we would like anything else... Maybe our fourth course prix fix dessert??? It ended up being absolutely delicious but come ON my girlfriend literally laughed until she cried because as realistic as she is, this was just ridiculous!!!!!!

Tl;dr: good food, good wine pairing, not worth $300+. Nice staff but have some very, very huge issues serving popular nights.
author: Chris B.

description:
Decent food and decent service. Menu online is not accurate. They no longer have the pre fixe lunch for $25 (either that or they just didn't feel like offering it on a busy day). 

Beef tartare was good and made with quail egg and served with the traditional mixers.
Trout was tasty, but very very oily (what likely makes it taste so good).

Overall a decent lunch place, but without the pre fixe its nothing special.
author: Oliver L.

description:
SEGREGATED seating. VERY DISAPPOINTED.

With the new addition of a 2nd dining area at Cafe Claude, all the asian couples were seated in this newly added area. If you were asian, you were seated in this part of the restaurant. Even if only part of the couple was asian, they were still seated in this area. The girlfriend and I thought this was weird. I personally thought that this was very, VERY uncool. Being as this is the bay area and San Francisco especially. I'm still shaking my head at this establishment. To ensure that was possibly an accident, the girlfriend and I decided to leave through the back of the of this dining area so that we would walk through the other part of the restaurant; and to my disappointment, there was not one asian person seated in the main dining area at Cafe Claude. This is FUCKED UP!

Now on to the dining experience.

As I made reservations 2 days prior, and arriving 15mins late (thanks bay bridge traffic) we were seated right away in the new dining area. When we checked in at the main part of Cafe Claude, only 25% of the tables in the main dining area were filled, so as to why the hostess chose to seat us in the secondary dining area, I have no fucking idea why.

Our server was cordial, polite, and informative. She was professional and a terrific reflection upon the establishment. The wait for our food was the exact opposite. We and the tables around us waited about 45-55 minutes for our mains dishes. How do we know, we spoke with our surrounding tables. One couple joked and said "we thought the long wait was because they didn't like us". We noticed how the men were constantly looking at their watches as they waited for their dishes. We noticed how the women looked around for the server to bring their mains. Mind you the restaurant was NOT packed. This was the day before Valentine's day. I can only imagine that the wait would possibly be doubled. Maybe if you were NON-ASIAN, your food might be served to you faster.

We ordered two appetizers. The escargot and foie gras. Those took about 20 minutes until there were served. For our mains we ordered the bavette and coq au vin which took about 50mins. 50 minutes, seriously. For dessert we ordered some type of chocolate cake and coffee. That took 10mins.

We arrived at 6pm. We left at 8:50pm. Over 2 and a half hours for 2 appetizers, 2 mains and 1 dessert. If it wasn't for the glasses of wine we ordered and the wonderful company of my girlfriend, this dining experience definitely could have been a very, very disappointing night.

If you are asian, I advise you to dine else where as there are so many other wonderful places to eat in San Francisco. And when you go dine there, ensure that the restaurant does not segregate you to one section as Cafe Claude.

Once again, I am very disappointed with this establishment and will not dine here again.
author: Paul U.

description:
As the French would say: "Bof". Which means "so-so".

We dined here the day before Valentine's day. The restaurant looks like an authentic Parisian bistro, which is nice. The tables are a little too close together, like in France though.

Service was friendly & pretty good. The French servers kept on refilling our waters without us ever asking. We never had to wait too long between the appetizers, entree & dessert. 

My husband ordered the soup of the day: carrot & orange. Pretty good but average. Nothing too amazing. 

He then had the Steak Frites. I'm from France and I told him, as he ordered, that Steak Frites is really just Beef & Fries. It may sound fancier in French but it's a very simple dish (a good one if it's well made, sure) that you can eat in many other kinds of restaurants! 
In my opinion, you don't have to go to a French restaurant to have Beef & Fries so my advice to you is to get something French that you won't eat elsewhere: like the Confit de Canard, or Foie gras- unless you're vegan. If so, you unfortunately don't have many options in French restaurants except the sides maybe.

I had the salmon served medium rare. That's how I like my salmon. It was a little bit more than medium rare but still moist and good. The potatoes served on the side were again very average & some were undercooked. There was nothing that made this dish stand out from other salmon dishes you'll eat in other restaurants. I definitely won't remember this salmon.

For dessert, we split a moelleux au chocolat. While it was good, it could have had a more liquid center. Fruits on the side would have been nice as well. It was a bit boring and so was its presentation. Maybe we're just boring in France ;-)

We had a good time but we probably will not return even if we did appreciate the staff's professionalism & the decor of the restaurant.
author: Leslie S.

description: Went with co-workers for an early lunch and was seating promptly.  Server was nice; however, forgot the specials for the day and stated she had a "brain fart."  Not really appetizing to hear prior to eating...  Items ordered for lunch were Duck Confit, Steak & Fries, and Nicoise Salad.  All were great; especially the duck.  Deserts were fantastic as most of their pastries are as well.  Will be back for the "Yuge" madeleines!
author: Aaron H.

description: Some friends who live nearby introduced me to this place. Very unassuming location, but every dish was fantastic. You won't be disappointed. Hope to return some day.
author: Barry S.

description: First time coming here to the restaurant.Had a little trouble finding the place it is tucked away in alley, but glad that we found it. We were seated quickly and given the menus. The waiter happened to be French which was awesome since I was able to speak French with him. We ordered the mussels with french fries along with the charcuterie platter as appetizers which were both excellent. For entrees, I had the poulet roti and my wife had the trout which was also very good. They also had a live Jazz band which added to the fun ambience for the evening. Great evening and will come back.
author: Alain T.

description: Friendly staff and great service! There was live music and the place has a nice ambience. The food was okay, a bit salty for me but overall acceptable.
author: Annie H.

description: I used to love this little bistro tucked in an ally. Maybe it was a bad Friday night. Maybe it was the noisy construction. But between the bad service and the horrible, undercooked on the inside, overbooked on the outside, chewy steak and soggy, yes soggy, fries, this last visit was an overall awful experience. Won't be going back. Only gave it two stars because I used to like it so much.
author: Amy M.

description: A Gem!. I hadn't heard about Cafe Claude before a friend suggested it for lunch. The onion soup was better than I'd had at any restaurant in years, and especially better than any that I'd had in NYC recently. It reminded me that the whole comparison of NYC to San Francisco is a quantity vs. quality argument. I've had unsurpassable food on this trip, and Cafe Claude is a new favorite for its food, as well as ambience and service.
author: J E L.

description:
Took my bf to dinner last Friday (031315) just because he was craving. 

We were seated inside. It was pretty packed but that didn't bother me. It was when my bf and I started to feel a little sweaty. We asked if we could be seated outside cause the weather was pretty warm that Friday night. I got to hear and see the live jazz play which was pretty nice but I'm more into the food. I forgot to take a video but that's ok. I'm sure I'll experience it again next time I come back. 

Unfortunately he wasn't too happy about his steak. He asked for medium rare but it tasted more like medium. We both thought, maybe a different cook or maybe Friday the 13 was after him lol jk. I wish I took a picture of it to show what I mean but it's ok. It still tasted pretty good. 

I will still give Cafe Claude 5 stars because the escargot, steak tartare and an awesome waitress made up for it. I forgot her name but she recommended wine that went perfectly with our entrees. She was very friendly and energetic. I love love love their escargot! I will always go back for it. I ordered a different entree this time and it was their Friday dinner special, Monkfish. I can't even explain how scrumptious it was!!! They put this type of creamy lobster sauce around mash potatoes with spinach and a piece of monkfish on top. It filled me up perfectly!

Can't wait to come back and try a different entree next time =)
author: Sharmaine M.

description:
Love Cafe Claude for its intimate atmosphere and tucked away location- even though it is an SF staple by now it really does make you feel as if you're in a small restaurant in Paris. 

We ordered the cheese plate to start and I had the steak frites for my main course. 

The food was great though the waiter seemed lacking in confidence or enthusiasm when we asked him to recommend some cheeses / asked him questions about the main course options. 

I would definitely come back as the food is consistent in quality and the ambience is hard to beat.
author: Simone A.

description:
How on earth do people find out about Cafe Claude if it wasn't for Yelp? It is hidden and tucked away in an alley. I would be too scared to walk through those alley in SF.

The minute we got into the restaurant, I was surprised how nice it looked. Dimmed light and classy seating area. We ordered:

- Steak tartare = fresh, rare, and tasty. Good portion size!

- Clams = appetizer to start us off. It was very buttery.

- Ahi tuna salad = too much dressing made the whole dish soggy. 

Overall, I like the ambiance of this place but the food did was not sub par. Did not enjoyed my meal as much as I would like to. Maybe it was one of those off-night or I ordered the wrong things.
author: Owie N.

description: I am not sure how the food will be.  I got the single patron brush off with rude treatment and a clear message that an empty seat at the table was not desired.  Some places do this.  Sorry.  I walk out and find a hospitable alternative.  My rating is "incomplete".  They are too cool for me.
author: Gary S.

description:
You know how girls say that French accents make them weak in the knees? I feel that way about the thyme vinaigrette in the salade Nicoise here. It binds little grape tomatoes, capers, fingerling potatoes and tuna confit together, creating a compelling overlay to a near perfect compilation of light, yet substantial / unique, but cohesive, fare. Is it a teaser, a segue to your dessert? Or will it be my full meal? Is it "good" for me? Surely, there are healthier salads out there. 

Intriguing? Oui. Mesmerizing? Bien sûr.

And those apps: steak tartare, moules avec frites, escargot. Enough to make me brave the armpit that is Claude Ln (creviced between Chinatown and Union Sq).
author: Melissa W.

description:
I have to say that my overall experience at Cafe Claude was wonderful! I first came upon the restaurant when I was looking up places to eat in the San Francisco area for my fiancées birthday. 

Before I could enjoy this lovely venue I actually had to find the restaurant first!! That was probably one of the only things that was hard for me to figure out about this place. When I say I'm not the avid city goer - I am not fibbing- because I went looking up and down the streets and convincing myself that my gps was broken and I still couldn't find it. But luckily my fiancée is much better at finding his way around! 

Cafe Claude was down an old brick paved alley way with a very quaint red awning at the entrance.  We had to pass a few small outside tables before getting to the main door where we were greeted by a lovely young woman who quickly escorted us to our table. I really have to say that the ambiance was fantastic. The entire restaurant was on the smaller side and dimly lit which made it very intimate and romantic. My fiancée and I had taken our seats and immediately were introduced to our waiter. He was nicely shaven, tall and very polite.

I have to say that the food, which was very fairly priced, was amazing and full of flavor:) The portion was more than enough for me and I still have some food to spare! I had the chicken and it was cooked to perfection. Not only was my main course flavorful but the cheese plate I had ordered beforehand was to die for! 

Five stars and a definitely happy customer who is sure to come back:)
author: Andrea B.

description: escargots and fois gras were 10/10, trout was 9/10 because it was a little bit oily, chocolate soft cake was 10/10 without pouring vanilla sauce, chocolate mousse was a bit too sweet so 7/10
author: Johnson C.

description:
Came here to celebrate our 4 year anniversary a weekend earlier. 

SERVICE: 
I thought the service needed a bit of work since it was one server to 7 tables on the inside on a Saturday. I felt like they need another server to better accommodate the group. They may have only had 2 servers, one for indoor and one for outdoor. It took awhile to get the menus to us, to have things ordered and water to be re-filled.

SPACE:
It was very crowded, you are sitting right next to the other table. I understand it's the city and space is limited but it was so loud in the space. You couldn't even hear the live music, which was part of the reason we came to the restaurant.
 
FOOD: 
Mediocre - for the cost, I would have expected better.

Escargot En Croute 
Soup A L'oignon 
Truite Amandine 
Chou-Fleur

It may just have been an off day for them. Maybe go on a weekday with less people so the two servers can be more attentive.
author: Irene C.

description:
Quite honestly one of my best experiences ever having French food!

It was a spontaneous thing, deciding to have French for dinner last night. We'd been to Cafe Claude a few times about 4 years back, but it was never as memorable as I'd expected it to be. This time however, the establishment has made a loyal fan out of me, and next time I'm in Union Square, this will be my place for French fare. A big plus for the ambience. The stroll into Claude Lane itself was like stepping in an off-the-beaten-trail before walking up into this cute, warm, cozy restaurant. We felt immediately transported to Paris.

He ordered:
Pre-Fixe Dinner for $45: 
-Foie Gras Torchon Amuse Bouche
-Escargot en Croute
-Coq Au Vin
-Bread Pudding

I ordered:
-Seared Foie Gras
-Pomme Frites
-Truite de Amandine (Trout)

Each French classic we ordered was possibly it's best version. Especially big props on the Seared Foie Gras (properly rendered), Coq Au Vin (beautiful kick of red wine flavors coming through without being too thick, the meat just melted off the bones), Trout (this place executes it with perfection, and it was a great contrast with haricots vert and almonds, and the addition of raisins just added a right touch of sweetness). 

I think a lot of the lower-rating reviews are unfounded. You know you're coming to have French food, you should probably expect the price tag. It's a reasonable price for it's calibre. Overall the food was beautifully refined, I enjoyed every bite and savored its moment. The dishes are not heavy-handed or starchy with the sauces, and the flavors and texture come through perfectly. 

Can't wait for our next return!!

Bon Apetit!
author: Natalie W.

description:
Cafe Claude is sexy as f*ck!

Gold dim lighting. Intimate seating. Wait staff with sensuous French accents. Soothing live jazz music.

Everything about it screams five stars for a romantic date place EXCEPT

For... 

One...

Thing...

Cafe Claude's Coq Au Vin.

Forget about the solid appetizers of French Onion Soup, Pate, Steak Tartare, and Escargot that we started dinner with, the Coq Au Vin (highlighted on Yelp) completely ruined my image of Café Claude. 

Absolutely atrocious cannot begin to even describe this dish. It tasted exactly as it looked: horrendous. Here's a pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/gsf5yf5HS3h8Z8MHpJ4t3w?select=Y-j1suCftNf5kU5Z_qKmGA#Y-j1suCftNf5kU5Z_qKmGA

The chicken was as dark as coals with a tough and dry exterior crust (even the bacon was dry). The sauce was worse. Not reduced enough, it was watery and the alcohol didn't burn off from the red wine and cognac leaving an unappetizing lighter fluid aftertaste. YUCK.

Julia Child would have had a field day with this one if she was still alive.

After dinner, Café Claude became as sexy as Ron Jeremy...present day. 

OTHER NOTES:
*Tucked into the Claude Lane alleyway just past Subway.
*Great romantic date spot; saw a couple having their wedding dinner at Café Claude.
*Expect a wait even with reservations. 
*Heated outdoor seating and two separate indoor dining areas.
*Our waitress was awesome. She was very friendly and attentive.
*Live Jazz Thursdays - Saturdays from 7:30 PM - 10:30 PM
*Sutter-Stockton parking garage is 3 blocks away
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Okay! Redeemed. Fully.

Since my last visit, after which I wrote of my dismay regarding the quality and size of the mussels, these good folks have clearly taken some very positive steps toward remedying the problem. Our server/bartender told us of the newer better mussels and somewhat reluctantlywe chose to to give the the mollusks another shot.

Wow! The quality of the mussels themselves was right up there with the best I've had. The broth was very good as well. Overall a massive improvement.

Tartare is near perfect as always and service was solid and attentive. 

Thank you, Cafe Claude!
author: Martin S.

description:
Delicious food and great service! Very knowledgable, friendly staff -shout out to Didier! 
Favorites: escargot and fromage
author: Emily L.

description:
Delicious!!! My family and I visited Paris this year, and Cafe Claude did an excellent job replicating restaurants there (minus all of the smoke!!).

We made reservations, though the place wasn't too packed around 6:00 on a Friday. 

On to the food...

Get the steak tartar! Seriously if you don't get anything else on the menu you have to get this. The meat is so perfectly flavored, and is amazing with the crostinis provided. Other memorable dishes were the mussels, and pate platter! Mmmmm.

The duck confit came with these lentils which I loved too.

Great restaurant for a date or family, with great food, service, and of course... live music.

Will be back!
author: Michelle L.

description: Food was amazing and service was great. Mussels was delish. The pasta dish I had was the mussels and red pepper pappadelle ,it was just the right amount of sauce, it was fresh and very filling.  My friend got the trout with almonds, and she throughly enjoyed it. We also shared the cream spinach.... yum. I Love creamed spinach, so i may be biased but it was delicious.  The servers were all very attentive and made great recommendations. Will be back if I'm in the area. Ideal to make reservations for indoor seating. We didn't have one so we sat outside with a canopy over us and a heat lamp. It was sufficient to have us remove our jackets.  My pictures from our meal don't give the food it's justices it deserves.
author: Alicia A.

description:
A standard bistro in a sexy little alley with other restaurants. With seating outside in the alley, musicians crammed in the corner, and a tiny curved bar, it has the right look and feel of a romantic, yet bustling bistro.

We hit the bar for the live music that plays Thursday through Saturday from 7P to 10P. The performers were not loud and served as subdued background music. Primary purpose of most customers was to eat dinner while the music was very secondary.

Bistros should have good French fries. Their fries passed the test with long, thin strands of potato that were crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside. The cocktails were good, but not special.
author: Brian U.

description:
I took the wife here for a special occasion at a friend's recommendation. We weren't disappointed. After finding the place on its namesake street, we arrived a bit early expecting to get a drink before our table was ready. However, they were happy to seat us a little bit early so we had our drinks at the table. They were having live jazz that night, which added a little bit of a fun appeal.

Having drinks and listening to jazz while we decided on food was a perfect way to get in the mood for dinner. We had the escargot appetizer, which came with a nice little puff pastry on top. It was pretty delicious and the buttery sauce was perfect for dipping the bread (of which our server was kind enough to bring an extra serving just for that purpose!). The only surprise of the menu was being informed that the risotto had been replaced with duck confit spaghetti.

For dinner, we had a steak frites (classic French, of course) and the duck confit with lentils. Both were excellent, and the lentils were a nice addition to the duck. The soft chocolate cake really finished off the dinner debauchery (along with a sweet dessert wine!).

I'd definitely recommend this place. It's small, and pretty intimate, which makes for a nice romantic meal. With the jazz, it did get a little loud at times, but that was ok.
author: Brent W.

description:
2stars for the wine 
Food was cold 
Cute 10 table restaurant 
Tables in ally were  a turn off  
Bathrooms take you out to a back avenue somewhere ? 
One time only in San Francisco never again
author: Christi K.

description:
Claude Lane is an unappetizing dark alley that seasoned city dwellers would hesitate to enter after nightfall. But the two restaurants and the club down there make a successful effort to keep the street free of litter and as inviting as an unappetizing dark alley can be.

My 3 dinner companions ordered moules, foie gras, steak frites, duck and steak tartare. The latter prepared with a raw quail egg and flourish at the table (totally revolting to me but enthusiastically enjoyed by the lady friend who ordered it)

My sweetcorn lentil soup, made with vegetable stock was delicious. As was the vegetable casserole to follow. Really striking that the chef didn't default to cheese like almost every other restaurant does for vegetarian options. Ingredients from local farms or boutique suppliers were prepared with care and imagination.

Deserts were also good, though no avoiding dairy here.

The 'greeter' sported a sullen Bardotian pout, one server was unsubtley camp, another would start sentences in French before 'remembering' to switch to heavily accented English. The overall effect was a theatrical caricature of a Parisian restaurant.

But this is a cosy, intimate place with wonderful food and entertaining staff. The live jazz band was the only understated thing in the place but like everything else was excellent and kept the volume to a comfortable level. The median age of diners seemed 65, dressed smartly for dinner, with a sprinkling of hip youngsters. There was a genuine French family at one of the outside tables (I don't think they were paid extras!) which was reassuring.

The bill for 4 of us (drinks, deserts, coffee and a bottle of Sancerre) was $350 including the $60 tip. Very reasonable for San Francisco - and cheaper than flying to France for the night.

For a picky vegetarian this was the best meal I've eaten out in ages. Rush down that unappetizing dark alley - even if you get mugged you won't be disappointed!
author: DB Cooper ..

description:
The food at Cafe Claude is overpriced for the quality received by customers. For lunch, I purchased one of their pasta lunch time specials for $25 dollars (with tax + tip the total was $30). Paying about $30 for lunch is ridiculous--especially when the ingredients to make this dish are less expensive in the grocery store. However, I gave Cafe Claude the benefit of doubt and thought the food would justify the exorbitant price--it didn't. 

The box of fettuccine alfredo with pea sauce, lima beans, and shrimp was swamped with an oily and bland pea sauce. The shrimp were dime-sized, and of skimpy portions in the pasta. There were only eight pieces of dime-sized shrimp in a box of about two and a half cups of pasta. Cafe Claude made sure the pasta lunch box was packed with lima beans that were under cooked and tough to chew. As a result, I ended up throwing away the lunch. It was just too nasty and messy to eat. Now, I understand why people avoid lunch time specials. Cafe Claude is not worth the hassle or hype.
author: Sarita S.

description:
Let me preface my review by saying that Cafe Claude has been our favorite restaurant in San Francisco since 2009.  Seriously, we were their #1 fans.  We live in Portland and a trip to Cafe Claude is always highly anticipated.  The food was always fantastic, reasonably priced, great service and a fun atmosphere.  We tell everyone to go there...

That being said, I am sad that I have to reduce my rating from 5 stars (I would have given it 10 stars in 2009) to 4.  They always treat us very well---our service was great again last night.  However, if I was rating the food only, I would reduce the rating to a 3.  I'm not sure what has happened, but the food has really diminished.  When I was reading through the reviews last week I was startled to see that there were several negative ones.  I figured they must be wrong.  Nope.

The escargot was delicious.  I was reasonably happy with the coq au vin.  I thought it was flavored well and tender. I am very sensitive to salt and did not think it was overly salty as others have said.   I would order it again.  My husband and son both ordered the duck confit.  The duck was tender, moist and full of flavor.  It was the plate itself that failed.  The lentils were terrible---dry and totally tasteless.  The frisee wasn't much better.  The duck could have been improved with a light port sauce or any type of sauce to accompany.  The duck would pair much better with a mashed potato, hash or a light pasta.  My husband commented that he felt the food had just been dumped on his plate with no caring.  

As always, the service was very nice.  We visited for our combined birthday/anniversary dinner and the manager brought us complimentary champagne.  Our server brought us a delicious chocolate mousse for dessert. VERY NICE touches and much appreciated!!!  Our waiter, who is French, was also outstanding.  The great service is why I am giving a 4 instead of a 3 for the restaurant overall.

This review is hard for me to write because we have been such big fans.  On our first and subsequent trips we would moan in pleasure with every bite we took.  This time, we were making excuses to each other to justify the food..."They must have a new chef, must have someone new in the kitchen, it's still good, just not great, my coq au vin is pretty good...."  It's not good when one goes there.  We just wanted to love it as we normally do.  We also heard the lady at the next table complaining about a corn cake and some others stating that it's not as good as it used to be.  The restaurant was not as full as it once was.  It used to be packed.  We had late reservations, so that could be why.  Or, it could be that word is getting out that it's just not as good anymore.  I hope Cafe Claude is listening and takes the words of their devoted customers to heart.  I would hate to see this once-wonderful place go out of business.

Overall rating 4 due to the great service,  Food alone 3.  :(  Please work on fixing this so I can return Cafe Claude to my Favorite Restaurant in San Francisco!  We are returning in October and hope to see great improvements!  Also, my YELP profile asks where I want to eat my last meal on earth.  It has said Cafe Claude since 2009!  I don't want to change it, but at this point...
author: Deb P.

description:
This place is really small. When weather permits, groups will be seated in a small, not very upscale outside area. Don't expect to be able to see jazz bands perform because they play in the corner, in an isolated area from all seats.

On food (4 stars): 
We (a party of two) got steak frites and Coq au Vin. The steak was cooked to medium rare with really nice Bordelaise sauce. The fries were a little too salty, and honestly were not anything impressive. If someone told me the fries were from McDonald's, I would not have known. Coq au Vin was on the generous side in portion size, and the broth/sauce had bold, really savory flavors. The chicken was tender (fell off the bones!), and the garnishes (chestnuts and potatoes mostly) were nice. 

For dessert, we got Paris Brest. The waitress described the dish as a fluffy bagel with creme, and yeah, that's what it was. I would have liked more blackberry sauce to go with the chou. It was very light and refreshing, and I'd recommend it for people who don't want to get heavy desserts.                  


On service (2 stars): 
First of all, I arrived a little early (about 15 minutes) and I wasn't offered a drink for 10 minutes, just sitting there. I asked the waitress about their Grenache blend - because I wanted to know if it was Grenache-Syrah blend (I love those), and she had to ask the bartender before coming back. There aren't many wines on the "by the glass" list and I would have expected her to be more knowledgeable.  

*** Update: I used to have a rant here about how the restaurant gave me a little note about how "Our international guests often ask about tipping." and that continued to suggest a 15-20% tip. I was offended because I (now I realize wrongfully) interpreted that the restaurant assumed some things about me because my party was all Asian. The manager of the restaurant messaged me and (apologetically) explained that the Cafe actually gives the little note to every table, in which case, I understand. (I still don't quite get why the restaurant would choose such a potentially offensive practice, but maybe they'd figure it out.)
author: Wonhee P.

description: I love the steak tartar, frisée salad and the green beans!! Went 3 times in one week while staying in the neighborhood.
author: David N.

description: We had the most wonderful experience (and food here). The first time we tried to come was on Valentine's Day.  We had to leave our reserved table after one drink because of an illness (unrelated). The GM and staff were so gracious and understanding even with losing a table on vday. We came back a few days later and the GM recognized us and, again, she was so kind and welcoming. The food was absolutely delicious. The jazz music and candle light made for a cozy atmosphere. I highly recommend this place for a great night out.
author: Kate W.

description: Always a classy place. I've entertained clients here, celebrated a wedding anniversary here, and have caught a solo meal late in the evening. I make it a point to try and visit every time I'm in town.
author: Jason W.

description: The ambiance, music, service and food were wonderful! I would definitely recommend for an intimate evening with a few friends or on a date.
author: David H.

description:
This place is just OK especially for the price they charge. They gave us bread and butter, but the baguette came to us cold. We ordered the assortment of pate, I had the coq au vin and my husband ordered the steak frites. The pate was pretty good, but the bread that accompanied it was very hard. My chicken was tender. The potatoes, onions, mushrooms, and carrots that came with it were OK. My husband ordered his steak medium rare and it came out perfect. The truffle butter was really good, too.

The service was a little bit slow, we had to wave down our waiter a few times despite the fact that the restaurant was small. Overall, the food was good, but I think it's overpriced.
author: Anita C.

description: Wonderful live music, cozy ambiance and amazing food. The escargot comes very hot and can burst when you try to get it off the plate. The duck confit was a bit salty but very delicious nonetheless. Ample selection of wine. And the chocolate mousse was not too thick or heavy and melts in your mouth.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
Solid 4 stars, but I'm bumping it up to 5 stars because of the staff. My girlfriend surprised me by taking me here last night for my birthday. I can't recall any other place in San Francisco having such a nice and courteous staff.

- Fromage Assortment: We had no idea what to order, but our waiter helped us pick the top three cheeses. Be sure to order the Pierre Robert (cow/soft) and pair it with honey!  
- Truite Amandine (trout) - generous serving of fish cooked just right, topped with green beans. Capers were a nice touch.
- Coq Au Vin (chicken) - very soft and moist. Flavorful sauce with big bits of bacon, potato, and onions.
- Pommes Frites (fries) - a little on the salty side, but still good especially with the herb sauce which had a subtle kick to it.
- Paris Brest (dessert) - the dough reminded me of a cream puff. It had the right amount of sweetness with the marscapone and blackberry sauce.

Nice ambiance inside and the tables were spaced just right - we didn't feel crammed. We sat inside toward the back which had a more private feel. Everyone we came into contact with was very friendly and attentive to us. Very cool having the live jazz trio in the background!!
author: Josh L.

description: I had the pleasure of having dinner here to celebrate my good friend's birthday. I was quite impressed that they sat my friend down at the time of our reservation, even though I was running late--I appreciated that gesture, as I have worked in restaurants before and it can be a drag to give up a table like that. I ordered the house salad and the steak frites. My friend had the tomato soup and a main salad dish. The food was good, not mind blowing, but it was good. The wine and champagne were tasty and matched their price tags. We enjoyed the live piano music and our waitress was super French! I will be back on another occasion.
author: Jeanette Jane G.

description: Lovely stop on a small alley near Union Square. Had escargots en route and a salt cod appetizer with a great Sauvignon Blanc. Friendly service, unpretentious.
author: Anne K.

description:
* Nice for a downtown lunch *

Snuck away on a back alley, this bistro was hopping with downtown business types.  But they found me a table right away, without reservations.

I was seated next to a table with what I thought at first was a "power couple" that was meeting up for lunch squeezed in between their busy schedules wearing their best fancy business attire.  But couldn't help but laugh inside at their conversation as it evolved. He was single, she was recently divorced. She was totally into him.  He was clueless.  She was talking negatively about her ex-husband and dropping all sorts of hints for him to pick up and guide him.  He was focused on the food and had conversational vocabulary heavily reliant upon the words "yum" and "tasty."  She kept escalating her hints until she finally got through to him by the time of my main course by being rather direct.  They did end up working out the details to meet at his place after work once he got clued in to her desires.  Oy....Lunchtime drama.

In any case, on to the food.  They brought a nice baguette with excellent butter.  A good start for a bistro!  Photo:  http://www.yelp.ca/biz_photos/cafe-claude-san-francisco?select=kZ7BluPF6sxeP0g-WIoauA#kZ7BluPF6sxeP0g-WIoauA

The winelist had a decent selection, and I settled on a glass of Medlock Ames Cabernet Sauvignon, which was surprisingly pleasant and well balanced considering it was a 2010.  

The wine paired well with the steak frites.  The steak was served with a classic Bordelaise sauce that was velvety and intense in flavour.  The steak was cooked perfectly medium rare towards the rarer side, as I prefer.  It was very tender and well seasoned.  They had clearly rested it well before slicing as it was extremely juicy. The fries were standard fare with a little herb dusting.  Overall a very respectable lunch plate:  http://www.yelp.ca/biz_photos/cafe-claude-san-francisco?select=JM9ctehOLXPWeig5kAB1OA#JM9ctehOLXPWeig5kAB1OA

Service was very efficient. I would definitely return when in the area for lunch, but I imagine the side table conversation wouldn't be as entertaining on a second visit!
author: Marc D.

description: The food is amazing, and the waiters make you feel like if you where in France. He use french expression to serve you.
author: Colleen P.

description: When they name the lane after the cafe it better be good and Cafe Claude delivers.  Overall a really good experience, food was probably 3.75 stars; taking off a quarter pt there for the chicken liver mouse which had the consistency of mayonnaise  not mousse.  For dessert someone in the kitchen switched out the caramel sauce for some sort of tart apple sauce which assaulted the taste buds when biting into the bread pudding.  Bread pudding wasn't anything to rave about either.  All the other food items were excellent as was the ambiance, wine, and the service.
author: Leonard S.

description:
I cringe at the thought of eating snails, but I pushed myself because I love to try new things and tried their ESCARGOTS EN CROUTE. It was actually delicious! The snail is cooked with some butter and herbs and covered with a small, light puff pastry that went well together. Nice appetizer. For dinner I ordered their COQ AU VIN. The chicken was a dark meat that was soo tender just slid right off the bone! I don't necessarily like dark meat, but it was good, easy to eat, and had a hearty flavor. I wish there were more fingerling potatoes though, because there was plenty of meat. 

Our group had about 15 people so we had made reservations. For some reason, they sat us outside, even though they totally could have accommodated us inside. They had heaters, but for those sitting furthest away, it was still chilly. Service was not bad, but I think the waitress could have been more upbeat and friendly and could have gone out of her way to do more; she couldn't even separate the check for us or even looked to care.
author: Sarah R.

description: 1st time here but 3rd or so for my gf. Was happy to see steak tartare on menu . Enjoyed this restaurant that was close to our hotel. Service friendly and not obtrusive. Menu had several choices. Genuine cafe ambience nestled on one of the side alley streets. Good wine selection but I thought the domestic choices could have been less mainstream.  We enjoyed a bottle of Chinon with our meal...having French with French. 2 starters, 2 entrees, 1 bottle of wine $140.
author: Steve J.

description:
Reminiscent of a French sidewalk cafe/bistro, Café Claude is a typical French restaurant but stays true to its roots. A small intimate environment coupled with French "comfort" foods (a la steak frites, coq au vin, and foie gras) on a short menu, with a reasonably-priced yet very good wine selection, Café Claude is the perfect place to go for a first date, business lunch, or taking your parents out to dinner after they spent half the day helping you assemble furniture. 

I've had the opportunity to enjoy both their brunch and dinner menus, and while I enjoyed the selection of sparkling wines and champagnes at brunch, their dinner menus bring me back to the days I spent in Europe -- a high standard to meet. 

Looking forward to coming again!
author: Richard Y.

description:
Came here before they officially started their business on a weekday. No customer enter yet, but we decided to just head on in to see if we can get seat. They told us we can just have a seat while we wait for them to officially start so we just looked at the menu while we wait. We read good reviews on this restaurant so we decided to check it out since opentable had a promotional code to get a discount on our meal so why not. We weren't hungry yet so we just order two appetizer dish.

Mussels Provencal--Portion size was decent, but the dish was nothing special to me. I wish they had pepper on the table so I can season it a little more. I can't help to say even their bread and butter tasted better. 

Steak Tartare--They helped us mix the dish. It was also nothing special to me. Eating it made my mouth really dry for some reason. Also, adding the mustard in the dish tasted really weird. Most definitely will not eat it again.

The food was not the biggest disappointment. It was the service. You can now pay with opentable which I thought was pretty cool and we were using it to pay our bill. It wasn't working as it should be so we asked our server if she knew how we should operate it. She told us some people had issues with it as well, but she decided to speak with the manager to see if she can help. The manager didn't even bother to help us, she only told the server it's not their problems and we had to figure it out ourself because they're not opentable. If you as a restaurant wants to work with opentable as one of the payment options then you should know how to trouble shoot if it's not working or report it and give customer advance notice instead of telling us it's not your problem and that we have to figure it out ourself. When we contacted opentable about our issues they were extremely kind and try to figure out a solution for us. I just didn't like how the managers at Cafe Claude didn't care to help us. I like our server though, even though she couldn't help, but at least she tried.
author: Sury C.

description: Amazingly cozy restaurant. We sat at the bar. Loved the wine and cheese. We loved the bartender.  Let him pick the cheese for you   - he had really great choices for us! Wish we could have stayed for dinner but we were meeting friends at a different place. Next time we are in the city we will!
author: Chelsey L.

description: Natasha was an amazing server! I highly recommend this place to anybody looking for great French food and service. Definitely coming back whenever I visit the Bay.
author: Esteban L.

description:
Cafe Claude has been on our list for over a year and we just managed to find our way there last week.  Frankly I never know what to expect.  I have been to many places in SF which have great reviews and I just don't see it.  That said, Cafe Claude had good reviews but I now go into these things with lower expectations.

Cafe Claude did not disappoint.  It is located in an ally along with several other eating establishments.  We  made a reservations (which I recommend) via Open Table and that went without a hitch.  The restaurant is lovely and they have a very nice bar area with live music.  Tables are far enough apart so that you have some privacy to enjoy your dinner.

The staff was excellent.  Helpful, friendly, attentive and all around just great.  I want to point out something here.  I had ordered a second drink mid meal and the staff got busy with another table.  I'm not sure if it was the owner, hostess or someone else but they were watching and a few seconds later out comes a drink.  This is just great service and to me, shows that they really care about the experience and their customers.

The food:  Excellent!  Onion soup was very good and prepared so that there was just enough baked cheese to enjoy but not so much that it was  problematic to eat.  We went with the Coq Au Vin and it was delicious.

For dessert I went for the Moelleux Au Chocolat. Awesome!

Was it expensive?  I don't  think so for what I received and the experience I walked away with.  I have been to so called brew pubs in SF and paid more and it was not 1/2 the food or experience.

This was a great experience and I would go back - and will.
author: Drew M.

description:
Cafe Claude is great for a romantic date or a special occasion, such as Valentines Day!

The restaurant is small and cozy but that's why it's perfect for an intimate party. A birthday event would probably not be as appropriate if you have more than 10 people. 

The best part, and exactly the reason why we came here, was for the live Jazz music. The band is fantastic but the down side is, you don't really get to see them throughout dinner since they are crammed in a tiny corner next to the bar at the entrance of the restaurant. Also, the band (consisted of 3 individual) takes frequent breaks throughout the night (or at least when I was there) so don't expect live music for the entire course of dinner. 

As for the food, it was fabulous. We started off with the famous Escargot, which was our first time trying it by the way, and although it was rich, it was indeed fantastic. It was definitely a decadent start for the night, but fortunately, our main courses of two different types of fishes wasn't too heavy. We opted for the special of the night, Monk Fish with kale and potatoes and a lobster sauce, and for me, the Arctic Char with veggies on the side. The veggies honestly, was amazing, and to me, even better than the char, but that's probably because I am a natural veggie lover. Both fish dishes were cooked extremely well and very well flavored. The monk fish was a very interesting texture, more chewy and tough than normal fishes like trout or cod, but the different twist made it enjoyable. 

Now, for the grand finale, was the JAW DROPPING CREME BRÛLÉE. OH-EM-GEE this creme brûlée was hands down the best we have ever had. It was perfectly torched on the top but cold on the bottom with just the perfect amount of creaminess but not heavy at all, just flawless. I just about devoured it all by myself in less than 5 minutes and really wish I could have licked the plate without anyone judging (but of course, I didn't!). 

Overall, a great place for a lovey dovey dinner or great for a girls date and I definitely recommend the creme brûlée!!! Please try it because I am still dreaming about it..
author: Luby H.

description: Yikes. I don't know how this place has so many visits and reviews. Food is just simply horrible. I had the duck that was burnt not crispy and everything on the plate so ultra salty. Decided to review for any visitors from out of town who may make the same misktake.
author: Starla L.

description:
3.5 stars, went here with friends for a late weekend lunch recently.  They have an awning and patio area in the alley that is also covered around the sides, which shields you from dining al fresco in the alley, and gives you enough air circulation and space to make you feel comfortable on a summer afternoon.    

We ordered family-style, so each of us could have a wide taste of dishes: foie gras, goat cheese salad, french onion soup, almondine trout, steak & fries, mussels & fries, and their special du jour: the duck confit risotto. And finished it off with chocolate mousse dessert(recommended) and a shot of espresso.  

Foie gras - good sear on both sides so you get a subtle crunch before the softness of the fatty liver seeps into your taste buds. Mussels were delicious - cooked in garlic, creamy saffron stock and fries were crispy outside and moist inside. Onion soup came hot and fresh from the oven with melted/crusted gruyere cheese on the sides of the bowl. Trout almondine was seasoned well and skin was so crispy and easily devoured by our group.

Steak - medium rare, but it came out medium done, and sauce was over-salted.  Risotto texture was cold and overcooked - and duck confit was presented in shreds (looked like jerk chicken) with a couple of fava beans and figs to garnish atop a very mushy and bland risotto dish.

Big nod to our waiter though, who was attentive and after realizing we did not like the risotto, informed the chef, so he discounted half off from the risotto dish on our final bill.
author: Vinh T.

description:
Nondescript, underwhelming, and all around unremarkable are words that I would use to describe our recent lunch and first visit to Cafe Claude. We made reservations via OpenTable, arrived first and ten minutes early, were told they weren't ready, walked further down Claude Lane to kill time, and were seated after an old man that came a few minutes after opening. We were seated, were given menus, and twiddled our thumbs as we waited to place our orders and as the restaurant itself still seemed to be waking up. I mentioned some $5 off deal that popped up when I checked into the restaurant via FourSquare and was given a brush-off by the hostess as the discount was never addressed afterwards. Who cares about $5, but why the heck is it even on the app?? 

So, we placed our orders and were somewhat disappointed by the lack of nonalcoholic beverages. The bread came out and we were left to eat it with our hands and no appetizer plates (the server placed it down and speed-walked away from the table). Snail forks were provided before the escargot came out (and the server again disappeared) so we had to signal for someone to come so that we could even ask for appetizer plates. The escargot was incredibly delicious and piping hot -- if a snail fan, I would highly recommend it. Whatever it was baked in tasted excellent over the bread. 

Our sandwiches subsequently came out and the ingredients were really fresh. The sandwiches were good but nothing amazing (I had the house-cured beef and my companion had the chicken). The fries however were quite delicious. We also opted for a dessert afterwards and the apple tart was good but again nothing to write home about. at. all.

The overall experience was disappointing as I had higher expectations for Cafe Claude. The prices were moderate for the quality and quantity of food. Plus the ambiance left much to be desired as the restaurant is tucked into a space on Claude Lane with minimal lighting and a not-very-clean shared bathroom. I won't be back given the slew of excellent food options available in SF.

Wow, just got an email from OpenTable saying that we did not honor our reservation. Dude, we were there from 11:30A - 1:30P. Employees, please learn how to use the reservation modules!!!!! This is a first for me. Going from three to two stars.
author: Jan P.

description: I've been dining here for many years and have always loved the food, service and atmosphere. I've had everything from celebratory to business and solo lunches and always love to come back for what I remember as cordial service, and some of the best French bistro food in SF. Today, however, was a sad let down. I made reservations in the bar area and learned that you can now book a bar stool! Luckily, the host called me back to let me know this and since I was meeting a friend/colleague I requested a table in the bar area and that was taken care of since I arrived early. The server and host were very nice and professional but I had not been there in awhile and found the food to be inedible. The house salad was a tower of rotten, over dressed Boston lettuce, which I ended up sending back (which I never have had to do), the steak tartare was a bland lump of grey raw meat served with stale "crostini" and the pomme frites limp and soggy. The wine (and the server was nice enough to offer a taste on the 2 choices) was fine and my colleague seemed to enjoy her croque monsieur, but perhaps she was just being polite. I'm sorry to say, I don't think I will be returning to once a beloved café  any time soon. I hope the management can make some improvements, because I don't think it's the front of the house staff's problem. They deserve better.
author: Marcia S.

description:
We wandered in without reservations on a Thursday night. Recommendations 150% recommended as it would have been a 2 hour wait indoors. But, with heatlamps running on the patio it was actually not bad at all and we decided to sit outside.

The wine list is good and the glass of cote du rhone I ordered was delicious. We started with a cheese plate to share. The plate had 4 distinct cheeses, all of which were good and I loved the inclusion of honey and apples which paired well.

For my entree I enjoyed the steak frites. The steak, done just a tad over my requested medium was juicy and flavorful. And let's just say I was hoarding my frites in a corner to keep others at the table from stealing them all. I enjoyed the aoli that came with them as well. 

Service was very good and although we were smushed against another party the atmosphere was enjoyable, particularly with the live music.

I would definitely return, particularly when it's not passover so I can sample some of their other goodies. Prices are comparable to other restaurants in the area - a bit pricier than  the average night out.
author: Rachel E.

description: I always enjoy the steak tartare here.  They do it perfectly.  As for other food, the coq au vin was very good, but the trout almondine was a bit boring.  Overall though, solid French food, and excellent steak tartare.
author: Yasi N.

description:
What a scrumptious summations Café Claude was this weekend! Not only was the French aura of the restaurant left abounds for us to discover on a spur of the moment, but I was pleasantly surprised after two locations to find a successful brunch spot hidden in an alleyway!

Their Niçoise salad with anchovies and eggs was absolutely designed with flavor on board. Delectable to the extreme! Nearly as delicious was a dish my date and I shared: the escargot plate, which was buttered and served with garlic and puff pastries.

Though we were only there for brunch, we kept hearing about The Mondo Trio. Apparently during many evenings, Café Claude hosts live jazz performances from groups such as them (who were scheduled for later that day) regularly!

We had been walking for awhile that morning to find a decent restaurant for brunch. Had either of the first two other intended spots actually been open, I would never have gotten the opportunity to eat here. I am very grateful this was the result.
author: Garett T.

description: I had the half roasted chicken...it was very good....their rum and cokes were very delicious too
author: John T.

description:
We must have hit this place on an off night. The service was great, but the food tasted like we had asked a diner in Kansas to cook us Coq au Vin. I ordered the confit de carnard and my fiancée ordered the Coq au vin. The confit was quite dry and not tender. The lentils were a little sour too. My fiancée ordered the Coq au Vin and found it to be underwhelming as well. The frisée was overdressed, but the lardons were quite tasty. The patê was either so rich as to be almost bitter or hard and not easily spread with weird after tastes. Nothing about the meal was that enjoyable, especially considering the price. 

However the service was very nice. They took away empty glasses and didn't rush is at all. They also left the all the plates on the table until everyone finished, which makes things much more pleasant. 

The live jazz is real good. I definitely enjoyed the ambiance. 

Overall, I won't be coming back. There are much better French restaurants for the same price range. Ones that will not over cook deep fried duck.
author: Ben R.

description: Had lunch here recently with my son after returning from vacationing in France.  Such a pleasant experience.  Was almost like being in Paris again...  Loved the French Onion soup. Next time we will try the steak frites.
author: Lorraine L.

description: Aggressively mediocre. True French bread and the crem brûlée is fantastic! Best I've ever had but everything else was a disappointment :(
author: Charlotte B.

description:
My ever growing list of Unfinished Reviews
has gotten so bad that feelings of shame
are now guilting me to finally finalize them.

And unlike some past and current New Year resolutions
(where I start off really, really believing I'm gonna finish, but then start feeling okay when I don't),
I am totally knocking out some of these bad boys.

So be prepared for a barrage of some super funny, ultra useful, and amazingly cool reviews;
alternatively, they may turn out to be outright rude, painfully vague, and wholly uncool.

Regardless, the read should be enjoyable and maybe worth it at the end.

On to the review of Café Claude:

Have you ever heard Michael Buble sing a jazz standard?

I like how the familiarity of the song
allows me to hear and appreciate his take on a classic.

Café Claude is kinda like that.

The fare is enjoyable, yet nothing to yelp about.
But the outdoor seating on a warm night
coupled with a live jazz trio
gives the place an alluring quality and really makes it worth the experience.

The whole thing borders on touristy.  I know.  I know.  How I know.
But it works.

What I guess I'm trying to say is:
it's definitely worth a try.
author: Dan B.

description:
This truly feels like a cafe experience in Paris. The location off a cobblestone alley is perfect. I prefer the outdoor seating if weather permits, though it can get a bit cramped out there.

The first time I came here I made the mistake of not ordering mussels, and suffered as they were served to nearby tables and I could smell their decadence. I always order the mussels now. I also love the quiche lorraine, soupe a l'oignon, coq au vin, and the salade nicoise. The mousse au chocolat is a great way to end the meal. They've also got a pretty extensive wine list from which to choose.
author: Julia V.

description: Very standard French, but what I ordered was sub-quality. Ordered the mussels and fries - the sauce and french fries were outstanding, but the mussels themselves were very small and shriveled. I love seeing a bowl full of big mussels, but these were small, overcooked, and really stuck to the shells in string pieces when you try to remove them. The sauce was great with bread and fries had good dip, but the main ingredient seafood should be high quality and cooked well at a restaurant like this.
author: Sarah B.

description: I love Cafe Claude! It's such an intimate setting - dark and sexy. The food is good and the service is friendly. Every time I go, I'm reminded that I must return.
author: Monica S.

description:
The manager reached out and sent me a $50 gift card to give them another chance. 

That was a kind gesture and good customer relations so We came back to give it another go. The dishes were consistently better this time however service was still a bit off. 

Not sure if the girl serving us was new or if they were understaffed and so she was stressed but it took a very long time to take our order (30+ min), for our food to come out (40+ minutes), and finally to give us our check (40+ minutes). At that point we were so tired of waiting that we got up to pay at the server station so we wouldn't have to wait to get our card back. We ended up being there for nearly 3 hours which is pretty nuts since we didn't order multiple courses, just 2 entrees. 

I reaaaaally want to love this place but after 2 experiences like that, I have to be honest and stick with my original opinion.
author: Ashley U.

description:
So sad to write this. I've been a loyal fan of Cafe Claude for years! Food is great, ambiance fabulous and usually the service is spot on (even for a French restaurant ;)
Today I went to meet a friend for lunch. While Cafe Claude usually calls for a leisurely lunch, this went WAY beyond. We were there for almost 2 hours waiting for our food. I inquired several times as NO ONE had checked in on us for at least an hour. Wine and water were empty. Finally at around 2 after being there for almost 1.5 hours our food arrived. No apology. Nothing taken off the bill. And at this point the restaurant has been only about a 1/4 full for the last hour. I know this is all first world problems but I was ridiculously late getting back to work and no one even acknowledged the delay as we left. It was soo disappointed. You've lost a customer. I would rather got to Cafe de la Presse where I expect them to be rude but at least the food comes out on time.
author: Ellie H.

description:
After a late night search, we walked into a charming space with a lovely hostess. I thought we were safe.
I ordered the duck confit- MISTAKE! It was soft on the outside and hard on the inside- ugh
My partners swordfish was overcooked but he kept it.
I sent my meal back and got a steak- rare. But the sauce was cloying and way too thick. It was served by the  vampire like manager who hexed me with her too close service. Scary. Pommes frites were good, tho 
     On to dessert, the hostess had raved about the créeme brûlée, so we wanted to try it. I had memories of amazing brûlées with a glass like crust of burnt sugar and custard underneath. WRONG!!!!
   I have NO idea what they were thinking or if they knew brûlée means burnt? Long story short, another instance of soft on top and hard inside- 
    I sent it back but guess what? Same-same
They could give a hoot about the lady who sends things back! It was closing and too bad for us!
80 dollars later, I was embarrassed I had taken my lover to a really bad meal in a place that looked so charming. I actually thought of calling and asking if any of their staff knew it was supposed to be a "French"
Restaurant? If you want REAL French food, go to 
"Le Central" up the street on Bush. Order the cassoulet, and smile,knowing you are getting French food as it should be prepared and not a FRAUD.
author: Tig T.

description:
A cute shop front tucked in an alley on Claude, Cafe Claude has a beautiful interior with a nice nighttime ambiance perfect for a well-dressed night on the town.

The menu options are on the pricey side, but the quality of the food is pretty good. I ordered the pan-seared Arctic char, which was served over a bed of corn. The char itself was pleasant but had no strong tastes. This is a pattern I tend to find with French cuisine - the tastes are too weak or too strong for my liking. But what the hell do I know?

We ordered pomme frites to start, but they served us (cold) bread after, and the pomme frites actually came out after our dishes, which basically twofold defeated the purpose of ordering them in the first place.

For all the other similarly pricey options in San Francisco, I'd personally take my chances venturing out and probably wouldn't come back, but I would highly recommend the place for others to try for its atmosphere.
author: Riki N.

description:
This was my second visit.  There are several French restaurants in this part of San Francisco.  Based on my previous dinner 2 years before I would have rated Cafe Claude in the middle in terms of quality.  Much to my pleasant surprise I had a very nice beer, tasty salad, nice steak tartar, and a delicious chocolate cake.

It was very nice and I would say, based on this meal, that Cafe Claude is towards the top in terms of their food.  Atmosphere is clean and somewhat modern while also being traditional.
author: Harrison P.

description: Disappointing. Waiter--possibly busboy recently promoted--couldn't pair wines with dishes, didn't know anything about the cheese selection, and charged me for a glass of wine I didn't buy.  And a previous reviewer called the escargots right: lacking in flavor and garlic and with only a stingy amount of butter. There's so much great French food in this beautiful city. Why, oh why did I waste my $$ here?!
author: S. T.

description:
Great food, great champagne.

The pate selection was delicious. Especially whatever the creamier of the three was.

I had the chicken with vegetables (had a different name I can't remember). I would have drunk the sauce from the bowl if not for the shame of covering myself in delicious sauce, publicly.

Great service too. Hard to find. It's tucked in an alleyway. Definitely worth the search.
author: Daniel B.

description: Pretry disappointed. The pate plate just wasn't good. The venison and duck wasn't tasty. The French onion soup was so so. We got full from the bread and butter. Not coming back. Sad, this place used to taste really good.
author: Irina M.

description: Great French place! Food and atmosphere are top notch..bon appétit! You will have s great time
author: Jerome M.

description:
I would be the first to admit that I've always underrated Cafe Claude and I've been quite harsh when my meal fell short in my previous trips.  Still, I find myself coming back again and again.  

Yesterday I tried the pork belly lunch special.  The pork was super-tender, soft, and juicy.  My only qualm was that it had too much of the black pepper sauce, and the black pepper flavor was a tad strong.  Still, it was a very enjoyable meal.  Service was, as always, prompt, friendly, and efficient.  

Here's to a well deserved fourth star.  I have a feeling I'll be back again soon.
author: Angel S.

description:
Such a romantic place! Very elegant, feels very European. 

The food is delicious and the presentation is stunning.

Staff is very attentive and knowledgeable. 

You must try the steak, creme brûlée and the fruit tarte. 

A bit pricey for a casual dinner but perfect for a special night out.
author: Anat A.

description:
Muscles in the white wine sauce to open along with the fromage plate were a solid choice.  They were a bit understaffed as we were not aware dinner service didn't start till 530 but the spirits and wine selection got us through.  I started off with their onion soup which was very savory with a strong hint of burgundy.  Coq Au Vin for the entree was a sound choice.  Very rich and baked with pearl onions and fingerling carrots.  For dessert I opted for creme brûlée but was very disappointed.  The taste and texture was fine but was expecting something more spectacular based on the rest of the meal.

Great atmosphere and staff.  Our waiter was french and gave very strong wine recommendations through out the meal.
author: Mike B.

description: We had a good experience at Cafe Claude in spite of the hit or miss cuisine.  The service was very good though became less attentive as the dining room filled.  The noise level also increased pretty dramatically from our early seating to prime dinner time when we were paying.
