Reading other reviews and judging from our experience, the kitchen seems to have trouble cooking steak to the right doneness.  We received medium rare steaks that were closer to black and blue -- one got sent back and the replacement was not good and remained uneaten.  The fries were very good.  The cut of steak was not great though for the price it was to be expected.  We also tried the house salad where the most prominent flavor was salt.  The swordfish was very good with excellent flavor and balance.  For dessert we all ordered the moelleux au chocolat.  The concept here is exactly the same as one of our all time favorite desserts, molten chocolate cake with creme anglaise.  Unfortunately, both the cake and the creme were over-sweet, the creme additionally being light on vanilla.  We had a great time, but because of the food, it's unlikely we will return.
author: Brett T.

description:
Cafe Claude is my personal hidden gem, and I almost hate to review it. I come in here sometimes to get some work done at off-hours, and enjoy what seems to be the most authentic French bistro cuisine in the city.

The menu is exactly what you would want, and then some. Escargot, onion soup, duck confit, steak frites, daily specials, etc., and it's all delicious. The prices are expensive but reasonable, especially in light of similar upscale bistro experiences like Bouchon or Balthazar in NY. The food here is simpler, but just as rewarding.

My personal favorite is the Wednesday lunch-only Bistro Burger, made from an aged NY/flat-iron blend that ranks among the best I've ever had. Apparently Claude has a burger on the permanent menu in the Marina now, but I can't imagine it lives up to the one here.

Some people seem to have issues with the service here, but I've only had fantastic experiences with the staff. Maybe coming at off-hours is the key. Enjoy!
author: Aaron J.

description: Not very flexible when come to seatings. Despite there are seats available , we are told we need to have main course dinner to be able to get seated.
author: Chloe S.

description: We come up to San Francisco once a year from LA and seek out venues where we can listen to jazz and have a nice cocktail.  Cafe Claude, tucked away in one of the alleys not far from Union Square,  is now our must-visit spot.  The atmosphere is so romantic!  The jazz was really good.  And our server Robert was key to our wonderful dining experience.  He was attentive yet unobtrusive striking that perfect balance guests are always seeking yet rarely find.  Cocktails were delicious and the food was good enough.  Escargots, Coq au Vin, French Onion Soup.  They ran out of the daily special far too early in the evening (NOTE: we tried to order it at 8:00 and it was unavailable.  Review would have been 5 stars had they not run out) but Robert suggested a salad that ended up being the highlight of the meal.  We cannot wait to come back!
author: Nikki C.

description: Wanted to squeeze this little gem in while we were in town and was delighted to have arguably the best sandwich in the city for lunch!! Couldn't have asked for a more relaxed setting from walking around all day! Absolutely charming!
author: Dillon B.

description: Ariana was an incredibly knowledgeable and friendly ambassador of this lovely French restaurant off the busy path.  Truly enjoyed the steak tartare prepared tableside and a recipe going back 30 yrs at this restaurant.  The foie gras with huckleberries also most notable. Highly recommend!!!
author: Sharon W.

description:
There are so many wonderful places to dine in San Francisco and this is one of them!  A great choice when you are wanting to stay near Union Square area.  The steak tartare was very good and the table side preparation was an unexpected element of fun!

The live Jazz is wonderful and makes the whole experience!
author: Bink P.

description:
It was a cold day and mama was in town. I wanted to impress her, but not break the bank. And yeah, Cafe Claude is a sexy joint, but it totally works for mama dinners.

The place was PACKED. The hostess seemed to take a liking to me and sat us almost immediately. Sorry folks who'd seemed to be waiting a while; you win some, you lose some.

I opted for something utterly French: Steak frites (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/cafe-claude-san-francisco?select=UvP_9iMHyT5yy9PAkuuxHQ#UvP_9iMHyT5yy9PAkuuxHQ), tasty, tasty steak with fries. How can you go wrong?

Mama (with the tiny appetite) went with the pumpkin soup (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/cafe-claude-san-francisco?select=EZVq1k6W4SDq2PAFD4h2vg#EZVq1k6W4SDq2PAFD4h2vg), which, actually, was kinda gross. It was grainy from the added sugar and far too sweet as anything but dessert. Seriously, folks, put that on the dessert menu.

The glass of Cabernet I ordered with the steak was delicious. Mama's French cosmo, super frou-frou (with its raspberry garnish) wasn't too bad.

All in all, tasty food with great service. I just wish mama had received something tastier so she wouldn't have to fill-up on the bread basket. (The bread, not the basket.)
author: Adena B.

description:
We came here Saturday for SF Restaurant Week at about 11:30. We were a little skeptical with almost no one in the restaurant on a weekend, but it slowly filled up. Their Dine About Town menu consists of a cheesy soup OR salad for appetizer, a tuna salad OR quiche for the entree, and a cookie to go for dessert. The wait for food wasn't too long, but the bread they served while we waited was very dry, cold and hard (at least heat it up a bit, no?), and the appetizer salad I chose had large leafy greens that were DRENCHED in dressing. I choked on the dressing about 4 times while trying to eat it before giving up (the vinegar was kind of burning my throat). My friend got the soup and it tasted decent, a lot of cheese if you like that. At this point we're very disappointed in the restaurant. The quiche I chose was decent, it smells like Asian egg tarts and had bacon and eggs in it, tasty. And the salad that came with the quiche was much better, not overdressed or too large to try to eat in one bite. The cookie dessert to go was also really hard, but edible. 

All in all, I think the entrees here may be worth trying, but their "restaurant week" menu is not impressive. I personally wouldn't come here again. Also I noticed the tuna salad my friend ordered was already on the normal menu, which defeats the purpose of restaurant week. 4 stars? Yelp, you disappoint me.
author: Connie W.

description:
Enjoyed dinner here with my family. We couldn't get a reservation til 8:45, but the wait was worth it!  Our fault for making them last minute. 
Started with steak tartare app made table side and also shared the chèvre salad. Both delish!  The tartare had cornichons, capers, and quail egg- wonderful combination. 
We all shared our entrees- cod and shellfish stew, duck confit, coq au vin, and pork chop. All yummy!  Topped it off with creme brûlée. 
Service was exceptional. Personable, efficient, couldn't ask for a nicer server.
author: Dale H.

description:
Dinner chilling with live jazz music in a small alleyway in Lower Nob Hill. 5 stars for the ambience and very attentive service. 4 stars for the food which was very good (but not excellent.) best part of the meal thou, definitely desserts. Our Lemon Tart and Creme Brulee was absolutely delicious! Don't leave Cafe Claude without an order of Creme Brulee~ you won't reget it (:
Oh and Bee's Knees cocktail is my personal favourite!!
author: May N.

description:
Had a 5:30 reservation for three people on Friday night. We walked in to a virtually empty restaurant, aside from two diners, a bartender at an unoccupied bar, a waitress sitting at a table, and "joe", who is supposedly the manager, and quite frankly, full of too much attitude and self-absorbance to be bothered with customers. But on with the story... 

We walk up to the host stand and "joe" seems too busy doing nothing to acknowledge our existance for a few long minutes. When he finally does give us the time of day, my husband tells him we have a reservation, we are about 20 minutes early and we have a fourth person in our party. 

Well, apparently, the 5:10pm dinner crowd was just about to roll through the door because he told us "oh, i only have a table for three of you, and don't think i can accommodate you."

Really???? I looked around the empty dining room, then pondered the vacant alley on which this restaurant resides. Huh...

Well, he did tell us "they had a lot going on tonight and..." but I don't know what he was going to say and really didn't care because i was already half way out the door at this point. i don't have patience for people or establishments that act like their customers are an inconvenience, and I definitely don't put up with the attitude.

Luckily, another restaurant gladly accommodated our party of four. We had a lovely meal served without pretension, and dropped $300+. So, I guess there always is a silver lining.

In retrospect, I guess I should thank "joe" over at Cafe Claude for being such a prick because we all agreed that we ended up at a much better place and had a much better meal elsewhere.

Never again, Cafe Claude. Never again.
author: Heidi M.

description:
What does one do when the food, ambiance, and drinks are 5 stars but the service is actually cringe worthy? 

You've got me Yelp. 

Literally everyone who works here has a "I don't give a flying fuck" attitude. Which is really strange seeing as the prices on the menu would allude to stellar service. 

If you can brush off elitist entitlement for long enough to enjoy some delicious food do it to it. If you're the kind of diner that likes to be taken care of (or checked on in general) take a hard pass. Such a god damn shame seeing as this place has the potential to be a wait list worthy gem.
author: Ryley P.

description:
I don't know why this place has such high reviews? I made a reservation for 6pm and there was like maybe one or 2 tables there when I arrived.. and they still made us wait about 5 minutes to "prepare our table"? 

Food was alright.. had steak tartare, duck confit, and fries. Tartare was cool because the host/waitress does a little show of mixing all the ingredients for you. Don't think I would ever come back here. 

Btw, the hostess/waitress looks like Brie Larson.
author: Angela L.

description:
This restaurant is in an alley and hard to find. Look for the loehmans and turn into the alley.

We started off with the cheese plate which was amazing. You choose 3 cheeses from their menu and it comes with strawberry compote,  honey,  candied walnuts,  and acme bread. 

I had the coq au vin. I felt the sauce was a little too salty for me. The chicken was very tender but the dish only came with a drumstick and brest meat. So kind of small if that is the only thing you ate eating.
author: Tiffany S.

description: One of my favorite places in the city. Great food and even better atmosphere. My wife and I order the escargot and tartar to start, both where delicious. Then we followed that up with steak frites and the daily special, monkfish. Everything came out great! Can't wait to come back!
author: Richard N.

description:
I made Valentine's Day reservations here a month in advance after reading the reviews on Yelp, but just a week before Valentine's Day , I got a call informing me that they would only be serving a prix fixe menu for $75 a person!!! (Furthermore, the menu did not look exciting at all: pork shank for the main course, really?) AND THEY ASKED FOR A CREDIT CARD NUMBER OVER THE PHONE TO HOLD THE RESERVATION!!!

Now, only a week before one of the busiest dining days of the year, I have to scramble to find another reservation or just overpay for a meal I don't want and trust someone I've never met over the phone with my credit card info.

This place needs to either be upfront about their prix fixe menu A LOT further in advance, or at least put something better than pork shank on the menu if they plan on charging $75 a plate!!!

I'm talking to the concierge at the JW Marriott where I am staying for the weekend about other places we can still get in, but I am also informing them to watch out for the inconsiderate menu changes at Cafe Claude.
author: Matt M.

description:
This cafe is in an alleyway, so it was a bit confusing to find. Customer service was definitely up to par; my server (forgot his name) was really friendly and patient.

Escargot - 4/5 - SUPER hot! It comes on a hot plate, so remember to let it cool down before you eat it. The seasoning on it was so good, I used it in place of butter for the bread basket.

Steak Tartare - 2/5 - I have definitely had better.. it lacked taste, I feel like it just tasted like.. cold solid hot mustard.

Mussels w/ Frites - 4/5 - The butter seasoning was goooooooood, I soaked the fries right into that.

Including tip, bill came out to be around $60.
author: Elvi T.

description: Average food, especially given the prices. The steaks were made from poor cuts of meat. There are better Italian restaurants in the neighborhood.
author: V S.

description:
Salt soup.  Not that nice tasting French bistro style food. It's not Paris. It's San Fran.  Yet they try hard to bring you cuisine similar to what you'd find in Paris run if the mill bistro.  Pate and cheese are all edible but it's not that original umami taste originating from aging fine ingredients. You just taste the salt.  Nothing more.  We ordered others including steak tar tar, firies and steak. And a couple others. All bad tasting and all salt soup. Stay away from the food. 

The seats are arranged too closely together and the place is super loud.  Nothing cozy about this place. And they are not that comfortable. 

The waitress who served us got the "fleece the fine residents of SF con scheme down to science."   We ordered regular plain water.  She said no problem. We have Evian and that is our plain water.  I said fine but I don't want to pay for water.  She again says that is the plain water we offer and charges us $7 anyway.  

I wish I can say something nice for the wine selection but French wine sucks compared to CA cabs. Actually, French cuisine ,unless a modern chef infused it with additional taste pallet, pretty much is cheese, grease, baguette and SALT.  No wonder Parisians are always ticked off at something.  You eat bad food and you'll be pissed enough to cause a revolution or conspire with the Italians and Spaniards to steal spice from the orient. Yuk.  Stay away.
author: Allen K.

description: Excellent meal!  My husband and I came here for our anniversary dinner and couldn't be happier. We started with the corn chowder and escargot, they were both so delicious!  For the entrée I had the coq au vin which was so flavorful, I highly recommend it!  My husband had the duck which was very nice, not super oily.  We ended with the chocolate cake and port.  The chocolate cake was amazing!  Overall a wonderful meal with great ambience and lively live music.
author: Libby S.

description: Service was quite slow but the food was delicious. Had the escargot, beef tartare and coq au vin and it was all amazing. I would definitely recommend this place!
author: Evelyn B.

description:
It was nice to have the bartender greet us hello as we walked in. We were also acknowledged by a server and then pretty quickly seated by the hostess. My partner and I were casually dressed and came in here for a late lunch. I thought they were going to be pretentious. Nope. Young, slim female was our server with clear ear plug hole earrings was very nice, efficient, attentive but not hovering at all. Refilled our bread basket and water. We ordered:

Manhattan and their IPA both better than average
Soupe A Loignon (onion soup) was delicious! A nice hint of spicy in the broth (too bad it's made with veal broth)
Pommes Frites (french fries) were yummy! omg and that picante herb dipping aioli sauce! drool
Quiche Lorraine (spinach and bacon quiche) the dough was fresh, buttery and crumbly; the smoked bacon superb. Nice that it comes with a side of mixed greens
Creme Brulee - Perfect ratio of creme to the top caramelized sugar! YUM!
Coffee - dark roast. Oh yeah. :)

I'd definitely come here again! Yum.

Bathroom is behind a dark door at the end of the restaurant (kind of hidden). Don't worry, it seems ominous but when you open the door, the hallway and latrines are very well lit. :)
author: Mayana P.

description:
There is one and only one way to mess up an onion soup, and that's to go stingy on the gruyere and not form the unctuous crust at the top. Cafe Claude succeeded in messing up this utterly simple, basic appetizer dish.

Service is clunky at best.

Way too expensive for what it is.

Finally, staff actually forced me to leave my umbrella outside. Forced. When we left, my umbrella - a $50 umbrella - was gone. I asked to be reimbursed and was told they couldn't be held responsible for lost or stolen goods. Fine, then don't force me to leave it outside. My very unsatisfying $18 meal (for a soup and soda!) ended up costing $70.

Don't waste your time. Bad food, bad service. San Francisco is bursting at the seams with excellent French bistros. This is definitely not one of them.
author: Katia S.

description:
Considering this place had over a 1000 reviews and was 4 stars, I really was expecting 4 stars! Unfortunately this place was just an average, 3 star for me! The location is sort of hidden, but apprantly really noticeable with all the reviews. 

The menu had appealing options that I had difficulty choosing from, but I settled on their open faced sandwich "Croque Madame". It was basically a sandwich with ham, cheese, some kind of creamy sauce, and an egg on top. It was really good, don't get me wrong, but I just wasn't amazed by it. I felt like the quality of food was equivalent to a regular restaurant, not how a fancy restaurant should be. There was so much freaking cheese and creamy sauce it made the dish feel really heavy. There was a salad to balance it out, but it wasn't enough. 

As an appetizer, we got the patte. The bread was good, but not addicting like some place I have been to. The patte was okay. The liver looked so gross. 

On my way out I did see the Mussels and French Fries! Should I have gotten that?
author: Katrina T.

description:
Updates yet again---- YELP only lets me do 1 official update.. Fail on you Yelp. 
After my last experience here on Valentine's Day which wasn't great (read below) cafe Claude asked us to come back for a complimentary dinner. So we did, and it was GREAT. We'll be back yet again, and I'll once again update my review from a 2 to a 4 star rating.. I guess I'm very easily persuaded.. (Used to be 5 stars but .. Baby steps) 
______


I hate leaving this review because I have been to Cafe Claude maybe 30 times in the last 6 years. It's been one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco but in the last year it has gone down hill terribly.

The last straw on the camels back was last nights dinner, Valentine's Day 2016- $75 3 course + amuse bouche -prefix menu- all reservations, should be pretty easy to prep for one would think. 

We got there at 8:45 for our 9pm reservation and was told our table would be ready at 9. We grabbed a drink at the bar ... Then another one..and at 10pm we were finally seated. We were given menus but no one came to take our order from the very limited prefix menu for another 40 minutes. We ordered but was told they were out our choice of first course (truffle soup) but instead they had a delicious carrot soup we should try, so I said that was fine.. 20 minutes more go by before someone brought us a breadbasket with the hardest, most stale bread I've ever had, anywhere.. We had to give up as you couldn't actually chew through it.. So we continued to wait until finally they brought out our "carrot soup" or .. Last minute carrot water.. It really was- clearly a Hail Mary they threw together after realizing they didn't have enough of the "good appetizer" - it was terrible and we sent it back and told them so. Then at this point we also told them they still hasn't brought us our amuse bouche .. Which, as far as I'm aware goes before the first course? They then came running out with that, and due to our frustration over the carrot juice they even brought us a beet+goat cheese salad which was delicious. We got the remaining courses in a "steady pace" there after which were all .. So so.. Nothing too exciting.. Except the pork main which came with a sauce full of Wazabi that would randomly just punch you in the face every other bite.. After all was said and done, it was 12:30. 3.5 hours spent waiting for nothing. The manager came over and apologized and said they had comped all our wine for the evening but still left us with a $175 bill for the food, which honestly- they shouldn't have charged anyone for that evening - it was a joke.

While we were sitting waiting we were looking around at other couples at the other tables.. And it seems everyone was just looking around at each other in frustration.. Did they forget about us? What's going on here? Is this a joke.. ? If this had been a 2nd or 3rd date, 3.5 hours could have been the ultimate challenge.. I can only imagine.. 

I feel bad for cafe Claude.. It used to be magical.
author: Adam O.

description:
After seeing all the positive reviews on Yelp, I decided to take my love here for a birthday celebration. Although the atmosphere and live music was nice, overall I was disappointed with the food and service here. 

Upon stepping in to the restaurant, we waited about 3 minutes before we were greeted by the hostess. She was on the phone during the whole time and we weren't sure if we should wait for her to help us or get someone else's attention, since she clearly saw us but didn't give any signal that she would be with us shortly. So, it was awkward for those few minutes when we didn't know what to do.

Our server was nice and friendly.

The pate trio, for $18, was pretty underwhelming. Of the three varieties, only the duck liver was good while the other two were just off. What disappointed me most was the week-old bread that came with this dish; it was dry, tough, and a downgraded for this dish as a whole.

The steak tartare was also a disappointment. The staff would make it on front of you as part of the presentation. She asked how spicy we would like it to be, so I said "medium" which to her means literally one drop of tobacco sauce on a large order. There was no spice, no kick, and no flavor. We probably ate less than half the dish.

The Frisee salad was fine.

The pork chop was probably one of the redeeming dishes on their menu. The meat was cooked nicely and it was tender and juicy. But all the stuff that came with the dish were just okay and did not really complement the dish.

We enjoyed the live music.
author: Al B.

description:
Nice and good should never be used to describe your dining experience in SF. 

I love french and I often choose my meal destination solely for ambiance but even with the alley way outdoor dining and jazz, this was still just nice and good. Cute, sweet, friendly, casual but just nice and good.
author: Miss H.

description:
This place is nice. They do French food well. My gf and I were just sad that they had no mussels on the menu. We ordered a spinach plate and my gf took a bite and found a metal wire. 

They were able to take that plate off our bill and also complimented us for a free dessert! The reason why I'm marking this as 3 starts is because we made a reservation and arrived 10 minutes early. We were not able to be seated until 5 minutes after our reservation time because their waiters were late. Sorry, but we are just early birds!!! 5:30pm is the best!

I would come back if they had mussels!
author: Jeffrey L.

description: This charming little restaurant in an alley (along with a couple of sister restaurants) just two blocks from our hotel near Union Square was a great find. Lovely decor. Our waitress could not have been more delightful--friendly and helpful and efficient. Even the manager was generous with his time. We had had a large lunch, so only had wine and salads--Nicoise and arugula--but they were ample and delicious. It is now one of my all-time favorites!
author: Bonnie W.

description:
I've eaten here before, and the food was quite good albeit overpriced. Thats what the extra star is for. 

My review  is not for the food, but for the shitty shitty attitude in this place. After having lunch at the Ferry building, me and a group of my friends were walking around the area and we stumbled upon Cafe Claude and thought this might be a nice place for some coffee and dessert. The outside area where we wanted to sit was COMPLETELY empty (see picture), so we went in and asked if we could be seated outside. The hostess or waitress told us they were busy and could not accommodate 4 for dessert only, we would have to get lunch. While this would be totally acceptable if they were actually swamped, her attitude and the fact that there was NO ONE outside pissed me off enough to write this review. What made this whole thing even more obnoxious is that block further, in another cafe with a similar vibe, which actually had people inside and out, we were greeted politely and quickly seated... Sorry Cafe Claude, you suck.
author: Nika G.

description:
Oh, romance. Candles and sultry music to be expected!

My boyfriend took me here when we first started dating. He didn't place reservations, so since it was a Saturday night, we waited at the bar for a good 45 mins until we got a table. We didn't mind the wait because it gave us more time to chat, get a drink or two, and listen to the live Jazz. 

We both would've preferred sitting inside, but all the inside tables were essentially reserved for the night. Our table was not very impressive--thin metal chairs and a wobbly table set outside on a concrete, stoop-like space. If it hadn't been for the food, it might not have been worth it. 

The waiter was very helpful, and had great recommendations! (Tip: Don't be afraid to ask the waiter to explain dishes.) 

This place is a little difficult to find (it's located in an alley), so park your car when you're nearby and opt for the short walk, rather than trying to park close to the restaurant, itself. 

Attire tip: Business casual to dressy. 

I wore a lacy black dress with a flowy skirt. My boyfriend wore a white collared shirt, blazer, and dark jeans.
author: Joanna S.

description:
Went here for a special date night. Great experiences. 

Started with a charcuterie/pate' plate. WOW! Amazing. Big potions and high quality poriducts. Very tasty. 

Dinner was wonderful:
Quinoa salad. Un like any other quinoa salad I have ever had. Very surprised completely delicious well seasoned. 
Mussels: good portion. Garlic, lemon, could have been salted a little better but very good.
Trout: AMAZING!!! I cannot say it enough best fish I've had in a long time. Super flavorful.

Our wait staff person was amazing!! We loved her!! She kinda messed up on the timing of our dinner plates, but we could have cared less as she was very charming and loveable. Plus, they gave a us a little glass of champagne for free each for the mistake. 
We felt very taken care of, important, and the food was very good. Totally recommend.
author: .Strapped ..

description:
Im not going to go into detail about what bothered me about this place. Im just going to say this. I had the coq au vin and what ever that was not coq au vin. You should be ashamed to call yourself a french restaurant serving that. 


BOOO!

Nothing like i had last time i was there last year.
author: Stuart S.

description: 6 for Dinner last night, was excellent not a bad app or entree that hit the table.  I had the Trout and my wife had the Steak Frites which was great , as good as any steak frites in Paris we have ever had.  Gelato was fabulous, try the pistachio it is excellent it has a full pistachio flavor.  best I have had in the states.  Also service was top notch, all servers had a great attitude!
author: phil b.

description: Lovely place with great ambience for birthday celebrations or any other occasions. Live jazz music and great indoor and outdoor seating. Food and wine was delicious with starters to entree !! But what made the bday celebration absolutely wonderful was our amazing waiter Noah who was incredibly attentive, professional and friendly. The service was fantastic and couldn't ask for anything better. Merci bien cafe Claude :)
author: Gena R.

description:
Super mediocre French food. The service was fine, nothing great. The paté appetizer was lovely but I was surprised how flavorless the bread was that they brought to the table. 

My husband and I both got steak frites but the steak was incredibly chewy and the fries were overly salted. Honestly I wouldn't have come here but I had a gift certificate. There are MUCH better french places in the city.
author: Jessica R.

description:
Words cannot describe how much I love Cafe Claude. I'll try to do it justice to the best of my abilities!

I came for a lovely evening dinner with my girlfriend. We had agreed to shake things up and make things fancy. Following Google Maps, we were directed into a shady little alleyway tucked away within the vast SF urban landscape. But shady it was not! Quite the opposite...it was packed with a decent handful of restaurants, with loads of outdoor seating.

Upon entering Cafe Claude, we were whisked away into a very charming French restaurant with an amazing ambiance. The dim lighting, the incredibly talented jazz band, the intimate seating (esp. for two)...it was all very romantic.

We were seating right away, early even, at a table in the corner of the restaurant. Our server came by immediately, and was very helpful and polite. She provided some excellent cocktail recommendations, and attended to our every need. She even brought out what looked like a giant nail filer to whisk away the crumbs off the table after our meal and having finished the bread. (Sad to say, I just might be uncultured, seeing as I've never encountered a restaurant that does this. Completely mind-blown when I saw this.)

My girlfriend ordered the Confit de Canard, while I opted for the Porc. For cocktails, my girlfriend ordered the Hummingbird, while I got the Vieux Carre. For desert, we ordered the Creme Brulee.

The Confit de Canard was well cooked and still moist. A solid dish, with a solid duck flavor. The meat complimented really well with the lentils and greens.

The Porc was amazing! Cooked medium, and placed on top of a delicious stew of sweet potato, cabbage, and other goodies, I was completely satisfied with my dish. The meet was really tender, cooked to perfection, and still quite moist.

**Amusing fact** - as the waiter brought us our food, he exclaimed: "watch out, the plates are hot." Oh indeed they were, sir!! Quite a surprise to see Cafe Claude doesn't warm up their plates, but heats them to a very high temp - excellent to keep the food warm throughout the meal!

Back to the review~

Our cocktails were really good. The Hummingbird - a mixture of St. Germain Elderflower liquer, sparkling wine, soda water, and fresh lemon juice - was well made, and the perfect light cocktail for my girlfriend. A solid recommendation by our amazing waitress.

My Vieux Carre - a combination of cognac, rye whiskey, sweet vermouth, and bitters - was also a solid drink, touched with a slice of orange rind. In comparison to another vieux carre I've had at a fancy SF speakeasy, I'd say this probably takes the cake. Rather than the dry taste you get from some vodka or gin drinks, this had a really heavy, flavored taste from start to finish. It also went well with the Porc dish.

To round things up, the dessert tasted great! Their creme brulee was really smooth, compounded with an intense vanilla flavor, and a nicely caramelized crust on top. My girlfriend and I were left wanting more afterwards, but after all the food, we were both quite full towards the end.

Overall, an amazing dining experience. A very romantic/intimate place to bring that special someone for any special occasion, or if you're just in the mood for something different. Enjoy the food, enjoy the music, and just immerse yourself in this delightful French restaurant! Cafe Claude is a must if you ever find yourself in San Francisco!
author: Kevin J.

description:
mixed feeling about Cafe Claude.  
First I never rarely write reviews about restaurant - I am not a foodie and I am not the right person to judge food.  I will leave that to others.  

This review is about service.   
My friend and I were there on a Saturday night.  We had a nice meal - 2 glasses of whisky, salad and entrees each with 2 glasses of wine - around $95 per person... 
When we were done with our meal, we asked for a dessert wine to sip while we were sitting and catching up on life...  
We were barely done with our drinks (and had already taken care of the bill) that the hostess came to us asking us to leave since she had other customers already waiting for our table.  

This is totally unacceptable.  Overbooked? - not my problem.   
I would have understood if she needed the table to sit the next couple and asked us nicely with an offer to take care of our last glass or offer us another one at the bar to continue our conversation... but not blankly ask us to leave...    

This restaurant is not getting my business back any time soon.
author: Severine C.

description:
As a starter, I had the Escargots en Croute, which were quite good but would've been even better if they were less oily.

As a main course, I got the big Steak Tartare. It was excellent, very fresh & high quality meat. You mix the onion, egg yolk, mustard etc yourself, so you can control how much you want (though it's a bit of a hassle).

For dessert, I had the Crème brûlée, which was fantastic, one of the best I've had. 

Service was also great. Very polite and cheerful waiters/waitresses. Location not so great, it took me 10 minutes to find it in that tiny dirty side street.

Overall, very highly recommended.
author: Lea V.

description:
We had a birthday party for 10 people here last month, and the experience was fantastic. From making reservation to dining, from the restaurant's manager to servers and bus boys, they are always professional and friendly. And the food is exquisite and excellent. Even though we had to seat outside, it turned out to be great, we had a great time and good memory. 

Please noted that party for 8 and above would need more time in advance to schedule with their event organizer or their manager. Also, they will charge $5/ person if you bring your own dessert even if it was your Birthday Cake, which sounds kinda ridiculous!
author: Tai V.

description:
I look young. I can't help it, it's my Asian genes. 
Yes, I treat myself out to nice dinners every now and then. I love dining with girlfriends in all kinds of places. I do NOT appreciate dirty looks from uppity snooty older people. Don't be jealous! pshhh... Cafe Claude seemed to have a few of these sort of people in there but I digress.. They cannot stop me from enjoying a meal. Our server was a total sweetheart so that made up for the crummy folks at the bar.

If someone took me here on a date, I'd enjoy it. Cafe Claude is cozy, intimate, dimly lit, and has live jazz on some nights. I miss Paris.


escargots en croute - garlic, butter, parsley, almond, pernod, shallots, anchovy, puff pastry. While this dish was pretty solid, I believe it still needed work. A little more garlic and this would have been divine. I love escargot. Also was nice to just eat it with puff pastry rather than having to fork it out of its shell. Don't get me wrong, I'm a pro but the puff pastry is a nice touch.

assiete de 3 pates -
    pate de campagne - country style pork pate , black pepper, red wine. LOVED the black pepper with the red wine. The flavors married very well into the pork pate. 
    truffle mousse - chicken liver, truffles, cepes, marinated in sherry. This was a little bland for me. 
    sauternes mousse - goose liver marinated in sauternes wine. When I had my first bite of this, I immediately thought of my dear friend Manda Bear B. Sauternes always make me think of her. Actually, wine makes me think of her. She's so fabulous! 
My only gripe with the pate is that I wish they gave us more crostinis. 3 girls, 3 pates, and only like pieces? COME ON!

steak tartare (larger order, $17) - hand chopped raw flank steak, quail egg, mustard, cornichons, capers, shallots, parsley, croutons. I am a huge fan of steak tartare. It is probably one of my favorite dishes. Cafe Claude mixes the tartare tableside. Extremely fresh! The flank steak is of outstanding quality. Great bite to it, yet still fatty. Just needed a little more mustard and it would have been perfect. Still, Cafe Claude has got a pretty good hold on steak tartare.

truit amandine - farm raised trout, sliced almonds, pole beans, sauce meuniere. Trout amandine can get screwed up royally. If not done properly, the fish ends up sitting in a pool of greasy butter. Thankfully, this has only happened to me once or twice in my life and it did not happen at Cafe Claude. Trout was slightly crisp, flaky, juicy, and citrusy.
author: Susy C.

description: Tricked by the good Yelp review again :(.  Made a reservation for this place because of the good reviews and the fact that they had live jazz.  The service and cocktails were great but the food was pretty bad.  The chicken had no flavor and the steak was a pretty terrible cut of meat which was really hard to chew.  The fries and tuna tartare were good so I'll give this place 3 stars for drinks, ambiance, and the live jazz.
author: Diana D.

description: I appreciate that the waitstaff, and all team members, seem vested in making the experience at Café Claude feel memorable and special.  The food is GOOD .. not over-the-top great-- but what it lacks, it makes up for in atmosphere and people.
author: Kelly C.

description:
Everything is just ok in here. 
If you are expecting peace and quite while you are dining or just want a quite corner it is not going to happen. They have live music, so it is very loud. And it is very busy with customers, so it gets really noisy!
Food is ok, desert is the best and service not bad.
Not on my list of favorite places to eat in SF.
author: Bianca G.

description: Love the location, which feels intimate and beautiful relative to the busyness of downtown, the service, the espresso drinks, and the prices. Overall the food is pretty good, but not incredible. Recently ordered the trout and it was the boniest piece of fish I've had in a restaurant, but that was a bit unusual given past positive experiences there.
author: Rose G.

description:
Solid 3.5 stars
Service was good, but not great. 
The restaurant was in the alley way! hahahah 
Very quaint place!

Dining with great company for dinner--can't complain!

We ordered:
Three pâtés; 2.5/5 I am very particular about my pâtés, but I only enjoyed 1 out of the 3 pâtés. (I would pass on this dish) 
Coq au vin: 2.5/5 Eh, it was okay. Too much wine IMO 
Confit De Canard: 3/5 The duck was better than the chicken dish! 
Macaroni Gratiné: 3/5 Pretty good, even though I am not a big fan of mac n cheese 
Bread Pudding: 4/5: Yum!!!

Not sure if I would come back..I am not a huge fan of French cuisine.
author: Jen H.

description: Very nice French Restaurant. Friendly staff and great food. Suitable for lunch and A glass of Rosé. I had my Nicoise plat. Really light and refreshing.
author: Unyo N.

description:
I'm going to explain my one star and let you decide which is more important..

First of all, it was pretty cool to walk down this small alley to find this place.  The ambiance was pretty modern and cool; it was reasonably busy for a Sunday night, and my colleague and I were greeted right away.  We are in town for a Tech Crunch convention for my FanWire company (shameless plug), so we were wearing our geeky tech tshirts.

We sat down, ordered some drinks, the mixed cured meat appetizer, 2 duck confits, pommel frites, two desserts, coffee.. Basically a pretty solid meal.

The food:  Outstanding.  Everything was fresh, and delivered at the perfect temperature.  

So why did I give this a 1 star?

You can have the best meal in the world, but if you don't feel welcome by the establishment, is it really worth dealing with snobbery?  I mean, it started with our waitress basically just 'getting by' with her serving of us.  And I observed her attention and constant conversation to the people on both sides of us.  Mind you, I used to wait tables for 7 years, and I watch Restaurant Stakeout, so I'm very keen on this.

But to make matters worse, the manager, Haley, completely ignored our table, and would give the best customer service to the couple on each side of us.. She literally prepared food, chatted with them, gave one guy a glass of wine on the house, and we didn't receive a single complement.  Funny thing is that she's judging a book by its cover when the reality is, I'm having the most impact on Haley's career.

So to all of you reading the reviews, you can use your best judgement when dealing with this.. The food is great, but there is a ton of other restaurants in San Francisco that are amazing and you won't feel unwelcome and ignored by the staff if you are wearing Tshirts with your company name on it.

p.s .The only reason I knew her name is because I asked another waiter.  And I'm never coming back.
author: Kory A.

description:
I came here with my parents and GF for my birthday. Our reservation was at 6 so I assumed that everything on the menu would be available but it was not. 

The food was very good. 4.6 stars. 
The service was very good. 4.7
The overall organization was OK 4.2

This a good restaurant with good food and good prices for what you get but very far away from getting five stars.
author: Justin S.

description: We were here for our anniversary weekend.. The food was alright. The best dish was the escargots.. The cheese platter was ok. Service staff was very sweet. We were excited about the French onion soup but it was very ordinary.. Overall the experience was alright we may go again to try other times on the menu.
author: Akki N.

description: I came to Cafe Claude to meet a friend for a nice dinner. I brought along a nice bottle of red wine for the occasion. I agreed to the $20 corkage fee, but when the waitress assistant brought some small wine glasses used for an unremarkable wine I asked for glasses more appropriate for a nice red wine. We were told we would have to wait until the dishwasher wash able to wash some. So we waited. After quite a long wait the assistant arrived with some glasses used for white wine. When I questioned her on this she said they only had 10 glasses even though the table next to use had a party of 6 all drinking from the larger red wine glasses. My point is that we were treated like 2nd class citizens from the moment we arrived with our own bottle of wine. I will never go back, especially for a special occasion. I advise not to do the same.
author: David J.

description:
I went here after work with a couple of buddies based on a friend's recommendation. We were wearing t-shirts and jeans and felt a little underdressed once we went in but hey, this is Cali.

It was a little amusing when the waitress asked us if we had reservations and paused dramatically when we said "no" before she said she could accommodate us when the restaurant was virtually empty. 

The ambience is nice and more formal. Feels like a place you would go to for a work thing or a date not with family. The waitress was French I think and super sweet. 

We ordered family style and I got to try several items. My favorites were the beef tartare and the desserts. The apple tart, chocolate cake and bread pudding were all very good. The coq au vin and steak were just OK I thought. 

I will go back to try Claudine which is next door and owned by the same folks but is supposed to be more casual.
author: Sunil R.

description:
New Year's Eve Fix Menu was utterly disappointing.

When the food is too greasy that one can't taste anything beyond grease it's a big problem. Item after item all we could taste was the grease. 
Our stake was also burned (in addition to being disgustingly greasy). We asked for Medium-Well. The two star only comes from the desert, which was nothing special but at least edible.

We sat in the patio, the heater wasn't strong enough, and to make things far worst on a cold night, they turned on a fan somewhere inside the building that generated a coldddddddddd air circulation right beside our table. The fan started few minutes after a strong smell of weed, so not sure if that is related.

They gave us some new year celebration items at the end of our dinner, which was nice, defiantly the nicest part of our experience there!!
author: Bright L.

description:
First time here for dinner.  Small cute place.   We were seated right in the dining area close to the door of the entrance & it was cold!  

We had the Beet salad - 3/5
Duck Pasta - 3.5/5
Chicken - 0/5  (was burnt & on the house after complaining)
steak Tartar - 4/5
Escargot - 3.5/5

Service was great!  I think there are other places that are better for the money.  Glad we tried it.
author: Marie E.

description: Quaint Parisian-style bistro great for morning coffee, service with a smile, and an excellent brunch! The art on the walls ain't bad either! Manny gives them 5 Stars...
author: Manuel T.

description:
The place was a bit difficult to find considering that its located in a street that's a bit alley like. My friend and I were a bit hesitant to walk down Claude Lane at first since we saw some homeless people walking out of there, but we eventually manned up and found the place just fine without any trouble. We arrived a little past noon and there were plenty of seating available and we were seated promptly. 

We both ordered the Croque Madame ($12) which was really good. It was pretty much a ham sandwich with a sunny side up egg on top and it came with a side of skinny fries. We are both not big on ham, but we ended up really liking the sandwich. Towards the end, it got a bit too heavy for me because of the egg and the runny yoke. The fries were also delish; very crispy. The portions were generous; I mean I barely ate dinner that night. 

Service was very fast and friendly. My friend and I were out of there within 45 minutes. I would definitely come back here with my boyfriend Claude.
author: Samantha C.

description: The food was good, but the place is very small and noisy and we could not hear the band. We came for the live music in a first place. If you want to hear it you will have to sit at the bar, since that band is crammed in a small corner behind the bar.
author: Mike R.

description: Feels a little like Paris, the location and all. Used to be better. Food is hit or miss, Great steak tartare, good steak & frites, but the Coq au Vin was cooked to long and then had almost cold uncooked mushrooms thrown on top. On one occasion I thought the manager should have told the cackling LOUD drunk lady to tone it down, or move on to a dive bar. Ear splitting.
author: Peter C.

description:
Despite rave reviews we were unimpressed. Maybe we got the B Team in the kitchen today but for $85, thats not acceptable. 
My grilled fois gras had to be sent back as it was cold in the middle. Eating cold raw liver might be enjoyable to some, but frankly it turned my stomach. After a re-sear it was scortched on the outside and gelatinous on the inside. Ugh! The side crisps tasted like they were cooked in the fish fryer...faintly fishy. The only thing good on that plate was the mango chutney. 
Hubs cod croquette was ok but the flank steak was tough and overcooked on the outside and undercooked on the inside. Tarragon potatoes were good. He had an apple cobbler that was ok, while I had the creme brulee that was awful. The sugar was about 2mm thick and scortched while the custard was just ok, nothing special. 
All and all we were quite disgusted. Im not a dine and dasher, but I seriously considered just getting up and walking out. The waiter was nice though, so we didn't, but frankly, we should have.
author: A D.

description: Fantastic!!!!! Coq au vin was rich and delicious. My friends who got the steak frites and the duck loved their dishes as well as the mussels they enjoyed as an appetizer. Their play on a Moscow mule was great and refreshing. The devils kiss was so tasty, like an alcoholic raspberry lemonade. Started with delicious fresh bread and butter. We told our waitress it was our friends' birthday and they brought out a 'surprise' molten cake that was amazing. Our friend loved her birthday night. The waitress was perfect, devon. Very helpful, attentive and interactive. Its down an alley, which was cool and off the beaten path.
author: Sarah L.

description:
"Where the heck are you going," I thought as my friend darted down an alley as we were walking from the Ferry Building to Union Square via the Financial District.  "They're open!  Let's have lunch."  I agreed, not because I was hungry, but because my feet needed a rest.  Down the odd little alley was Cafe Claude, just opening for lunch.  We didn't have a reservation, but it wasn't a problem.

Cafe Claude is very French, yet very unpretentious.  Perhaps our waiter could have kept our water glasses filled better, but he was very nice (not to mention cute, in a hipster geeky sort of way) so I cut him some lack.  The menu was a bit spare, but included some intriguing dishes.  I decided to try the moulles frites, which was a generous serving of mussels piled high with herbed french fries.  I loved the broth so much that I was tempted to sop all of it up with their delicious bread.  I didn't quite clean my plate, but it wasn't for lack of trying.  I'd love to come back when the weather is nicer and yes, sit on the patio in that odd little alley.
author: Susan Y.

description:
***In case you don't want to read the review: Food 3 Service 1.5. Recommend reading if you have food allergies. 

Came here yesterday for lunch with a best friend and her newly acquired husband celebrating their exchange vows only about an hour before. We were a large party who ordered either the flat iron steak or trout for our main course (apps we had were fine).  All was going fine until not even 3 minutes into eating our main course that my friend's son began complaining about a stinging/tingling tongue and itching around his mouth. He was having an allergic reaction! Shit! Wait...he's allergic to fish SO he ordered steak.  Well after back and forth questions with the wait staff and the manager to investigate how he could be having this allergic reaction it was finally discovered that they cooked the steak and fish on the SAME flat top. Next to each other! Juices from both cross contaminating the other!! It's NOT a grill, but a flat top! 

In all, the staff/manager mishandled the situation to the point of no longer having anyone in our party as return visitors and some have been many times before. The manager was more concerned about whether we had informed the waitress about the food allergy and she did not report to the kitchen properly. How about "Are you ok?", "How do you feel?", "Do you need medication, a doctor?" Then what we were told was that we should have informed her.  Again...he ordered steak so why the hell would he need to report any food allergy to pesce! Also, another excuse the manager gave us was that it is also a small kitchen "SO!!, you're filthy!," is what I would have liked to respond but we are cordial people. Kitchens can be pretty gross to begin with, but I can only imagine what else goes on back there. Ughhh. 

Oh by the way, he is a sous chef at an upscale restaurant in the area (was never mentioned); he just kept kindly asking to speak with the chef to better understanding what was going on. For how politely he dealt with the situation he should have been treated with far more hospitality. Far more. Just disgraceful in my opinion. 

In the end, he was never offered another dish and we had to ask them to remove it from the final check. Not sure if they apologized? They were just kind of insincere and unaccommodating. This type of shit would not fly back east. Just keeping it real. 

Side Note: As a New Yorker, I cherish the NYC Department of Health's Restaurant Inspection Results grading system because of shit like what happened at this place. What happened here was elementary food handling/prep course stuff that I'm sure every member of Claude's had to take. It sucks he had a reaction and luckily I had benadryl to share with him, but I just keep thinking "Shit, thank god no one ordered chicken!"  I suffer from crazy food allergies and chicken is one of them; I go into anaphylaxic shock immediately. Hence, the arsenal of benadryl and my epi-pen which is always on me.
author: Dee S.

description:
A perfect find for a nice lunch. Small and quaint. Enjoyed my French Onion Soup very much.
Would go back again.
author: David H.

description:
Popped into Cafe Claude for lunch this weekend. Restaurant was half-full, yet it took an hour for our food to arrive after we ordered (all five of us ordered soup or salad...it should not have taken that long!). And two of our soups were luke-warm, but it took so long to get them that I just ate my tiny $9 bowl of luke-warm soup and ate when I got home.

Based on the service and the quality of food, I would not return, nor would I recommend it to others.
author: Molly S.

description: We were so fortunate to secure a last minute Valentine's dinner reservation here.  Every aspect our meal from start to finish including the service was delightful.  My husband and I went with the wine pairing for the prefixed menu and was paired down to dessert.  The atmosphere was relaxed and the music provided by the jazz band made our evening perfect.
author: Jeanette E.

description:
Very fun location on Claude lane. Would be great for a date. It felt very European eating outside while a live band played at the restaurant. 

I took my cousin here for Bastille Day. The restaurant was understandably busy (I'm glad we made a reservation) and people were waiting at the door and in the alley to be seated. Once we were seated under a heat lamp, we were presented with the menus. The dinner menu is reasonably sized and had a lot of great options. I ended up going with a nicoise salad that was very delicious. They had a special wine flight in honor of Bastille Day and each of the wines on that were very very good.
author: Aneilia M.

description: I really love this place! The service is great and the staff know a lot about the wine options. The food is really good. I've gone a couple times on dates and it's always a perfect atmosphere for a romantic and intimate setting. The portions are fairly large.
author: Eugene P.

description:
I really enjoyed the food here.  At first I wasn't too sure about the place - not too big and tables are close together.  The menu isn't huge but we picked out a salad and the mussels to share.  The french onion soup was yummy.  The chicken dish was big while other entrees were smaller in size. The bread and all dishes were yummy.  I was pleasantly surprised.  Not cheap but I think it's worth it if you are in the area and are looking for a nice place to eat.  

I would come back.
author: Frida C.

description:
Great atmosphere. It is the perfect amount of romantic, classy, but comfortable. This place is like a more intimate version of Balthazar in New York, but the food here is more traditional french cuisine.

STEAK TARTARE appetizer is delicious. The waitress brings a little cart near your table and mixes the ingredients in front of you. 

TRUITE AMANDINE was such a great choice and prepared to perfection. The fish was moist on the inside and  had a crispy outside. But, I do think that this dish is only good for someone that likes lemony capery flavors. Don't get this is you don't like those flavors because you will probably HATE the dish.

COQ AU VIN is amazing. The chicken was fall off the bone tender, and the wine sauce was strong and thick, and the flavors were nicely absorbed into the chicken and vegetables. 

FRENCH MARTINI was really good, very sweet drink. Next time I'm trying the SOLACE per the waitress' recommendation.

Service is great too, and I would definitely come back to try the other options on their menu!
author: Jessica L.

description: While visiting for work a co-worker and I were in a French mood.  This place looked good, so we gave it a shot.  We were not disappointed.  The place is very cozy and it felt very authentic; like you would find in Paris.  The food was equally well executed.  I will have to keep this place in mind the next time I'm in the city so I can try other things on the menu.  Bravo!
author: Melissa A.

description: Very solid food. Steak frites is an awesome dish. If you order it medium rare it will come medium rare. Great cheeses. Great service. Good drinks.
author: Maxwell B.

description:
Excellent food, cool location, good music; marginal service. We were in town celebrating my husbands birthday and went based on yelp reviews. I indicated it was my husbands birthday in the reservation but apparently the host didn't pay attention. They wedged us in between two other couples even though there was a vacant, private table by the window. We asked to move and they said they had to leave the table open. About 15 mins later they gave the table to a couple at the bar who decided to have dinner. Nice! We had to shout to have a conversation the entire night. 

Our server was not that friendly and very slow. 

Food and music were superb. Definitely a good spot to check out. I recommend sitting outside if the weather is nice. Seems a lot more private.
author: R S.

description: Oh wow! Amazing food, venue very nice, lighting romantic. I got the roasted Marys chicken....never tasted so wonderful. Wine selection outstanding. Prices reasonable...hey, you only live once. Not great if you wanted a real jazz experience. Three guys playing when we went and they were not that good. But, everything else...sweet! Definitely going back!
author: Lucia S.

description: Wonderful service. Good food, and good atmosphere. Derrick really made the night. He paid attention to everything and really cared to ask the right questions to make the night memorable for my wife and I. First time here and will come back again hopefully to be served by Derrick. Overall good was good and vibe was relaxing. Neighborhood gem. Thank you.
author: Arman B.

description:
This was my second trip to Cafe Claude and just like last time its was great, the food is delicious, i tasted the Confit de Canard, Escargots en Croute, Coq au Vin, Truite Amandine, Frisee au Lardons, the cheese plate and wine. everything was delicious except for the Escargots which was a bit bitter. i highly recommend getting the Confit de Canard and the Frisee au Lardons, you will not regret it.

Ambiance was good with Jazz playing and service was great, i let the waitress select my wine and her choices were great, i will definitely go back next time I'm in San Francisco.
author: Dan H.

description:
Cafe Claude is back or so we thought. New manager, Amber and new chef have restored this restaurant for me and she who must be obeyed completely agreed.

And then we went back within a week and is wasn't the best experience. 

The food was tasty and appealing.  My dear wife ordered Trout Almondine and I the selection of 3 pates preceded by a house salad.

The gem lettuce leaves were the biggest, widest gem lettuce leaves I have ever seen.  Truth be told, I believe they were romaine leaves. I wanted to eat gem lettuce; not romaine lettuce.

Front of house failed to apprise kitchen that my wife did not want the butter ladled atop her Trout Almondine or front of house did apprise kitchen of wife's request that kitchen simply ignored. Either way, we ended up eating in shifts so late was the second try at Trout Almondine, butter sauce on the side, please.

Not a happy camper, this one.
author: Jay D.

description:
Positives
-wine selection
-healthy alternatives
-kale salad

Negatives
-a little on the expensive side
-waitress uninterested personality
author: Ashley W.

description:
I don't eat French food too often but decided to try this place while visiting SF because of the great reviews on yelp.

The bf wanted to try escargot for the first time so we ordered it.  I've only had it once before and I'm not a huge fan of butter/really rich food so please keep that in mind.  I'm also not too much a fan of the texture.  With that said, I felt like all I tasted was butter and parsley.  The texture was a little too chewy for my taste.  I don't think I would order it again but I think it's just my preference in food that prevented me from liking it.  (*note: no stars were taken off for this dish!)

For main courses, the bf got the faux filet (basically steak and fries) while I got the coq au vin- very typical French dishes right??  Anyways, I thought the steak and fries were pretty standard/nothing out of the ordinary.  The coq au vin was a little too rich/not enough variance in flavors and honestly, the chicken was dry.  Overall, I would say the food was good, but not outstanding.

I will also note that we split a dessert- the apple tart.  For ~$7 it was a lot smaller than I expected but I must say, it was one of the best apple pastries I have had in my life.  I would come here again just for dessert!

The service is above the standard though- our waitress was very patient, very attentive and very friendly.  The atmosphere was very cosy and there was a live band playing that night.

This is a great date place but if you are a healthier eater like me, you may want to stick with a nicoise salad or something not too rich.  With that in mind, please take into consideration the other 1000+ reviews that praise the food here.  I think I'm really biased!
author: Erin H.

description:
They get a lot of things right at Cafe Claude.  That sentence says much, considering that they are small, hidden in a back alley, and require some creativity when finding a place to park.

That said, this place is popular!

I came with a crew of folks working on advance degrees and in need of some serious eats (Long lectures, intense subjects heighten the need for food.).

We started off with libations.  Cafe Claude has that down well  with an assortment of wine and premium spirits.  The Gamay Beaujolais we started with was superb, and the Mouvedre was exquisite!

Since we were a large party, the plates varied: Petite Filet, Coq Au Vin, Monkfish and more were the many dishes served up, and once they were, silence fell upon  our little group save the great jazz music that was served up live by some local group.

Next time, I'll bring my spouse and take my time in enjoying the food and the music! I had to rush out of there because the parking lot closed at 8 p.m. Miss the closing time and your stuck until the next day!
author: Ron C.

description: Hostess wasn't very friendly. Did not smile or greet me. Not super accommodating with our request to move one table over even though the table next to us was exactly the same size. Gave some weird excuse about how they needed to be able to combine tables which didn't make sense because the table we wanted was at the end right next to ours, so it actually couldn't be combined with any other tables since we were occupying the one right next to it. Food was fine.
author: Danny L.

description: Very cute French style ambiance. However, food could be better. Their main courses are not any special. Steak was chew (my daughter could not finish it even though was very hungry) and chicken was simply nothing special. Small dishes/appetizer were pretty good. Good complimentary bread but instead of real butter they serve you spread/margarine in a fancy container. Desert ( we have cream-burley) and coffee were very good. Wine was good too. Service was OK. We probably would not return there again and will try some other French place.
author: Elena M.

description:
Stroll your way down the narrow alley to Café Claude for lunch. I love the hidden French gem that this place is. On this wonderful sunny afternoon, I met a friend for lunch. We started with the French Onion soup - incredible and truly rich. Their soup is made with veal stock. MMMMM
We also enjoyed the asparagus soup. This also was soooo rich and creamy. And, the flavor was so smooth and full bodied. Then we each had the Monday special Boudin Blanc. YOU MUST have this excellently prepared dish at least once here. Boudin Blanc is a type of French white sausage. Very good. Served in a dish with cut haricots and red sauerkraut. The entire lunch was a hit. Good food, good conversation, and good service here. 
.
author: Greg S.

description: We are on a photo safari to capture the most romantic places in the City and just loved the ambiance and service of this beautiful first class restaurant.  This definitely belongs in the category of one of the most romantic spots. Their chevre, frise aux lardon and coq au vin was very classic and savory, seasoned with wonderful pure flavors, read that as not just salt.  Just a little warning do not use your GPS it will take you down some alleys that qualify more as a goat path than city alley street even with some holes that you can lose your car in!  I guess it  just adds to it's mystic, down a little alley with only foot traffic.  just a wonderful time.
author: BGinLove B.

description:
This is such a hard review to write...perhaps I should not have gone to Buchon and CC in the same week. Read 3.5 Stars.

Open Table was great...we were greeted and seated immediately.  Service was business like and efficient.

Sadly only two things stood out:

The beet salad with Crème fraîche and blue cheese was amazing. The beets were perfect, and the combination of cheeses was genius.

Our Viognier was perfect...fruit forward, sweet fig on the palate...wonderful!!

Now the meh:

The Croque-Madame was just not good....skimpy on the bechamel sauce, it missed the mark entirely.

The Coque Camille was watery and lacked any cheesey goodness or flavor at all...it was sadly disappointing.

Perhaps another day, different dishes...but this was a very mixed experience for me and my BFF.
author: Katherine F.

description: We were super hung-over and this place hit the spot for lunch. Fresh salad and soup and a little champagne to take the edge off-perfect. I can't write much else, because, because--damn, I can't remember. Just go to this cozy, elegant, sophisticated see-and-be-seen spot.
author: Cara D.

description: Great ambience, great food. I had the Magret Duck Bolognese and the Pommes Frites and both were delicious. Highly recommended and a nice place to share a romantic meal or a lunch/dinner with friends.
author: Steven C.

description:
My boyfriend and I were visiting San Fran for a little R&R and decided to check out some places near our hotel. We decided to depend upon yelp for a good place and we looked at a few menus but Claude seemed to be the best option. Needless to say I think we should have kept looking but our experience wasn't horrible either. 

We were promptly seated and greeted. Badoit was offered and of course we accepted. I love me some sparkling mineral water! We looked at the menu and decided to start with the Prosciutto Wrapped Figs. When we tried them the figs were pretty horrible. They looked green and unripe. I wasn't sure if it was the varietal of fig or what but they were bland and totally turned us off. The arugula was fine but didn't really match well. 

Fortunately the server was very considerate and removed the appetizer and moved us on to the main course. I had the flat iron Steak Frites. And my boyfriend had the Coq Au Vin. My steak was cooked perfectly and I thoroughly enjoyed the Bordelaise Sauce. I tried to scoop up every bit of sauce with the fries. The slice of herb butter that they put on top of it was ok but I wish it would have been melted on top as opposed to just sitting cold on the steak. My BF liked his chicken but said it wasn't anything amazing.

When offered dessert we thought "why not?" So we got the creme brûlée. I also got a cappuccino, which was amazing. I dunked the little dark chocolate they gave us to make it a slightly more sugar blasted sweet sip. When we tried the creme brûlée it was pretty good. It tasted a little too milky and you could tell that the custard hadn't hardened quite enough to be ready for brûlée. Oh well I still liked it. 

We did have to wait quite a while for our check. The manager/hostess? said that she had to do a tar tar service which slowed here down. One would think that she would help out and bring the check for the server? 

I don't think I'd come back to Claude. It was just ok. I did, however, thoroughly enjoy the live jazz band. Made the atmosphere really chill.
author: Evan M.

description:
I don't know about their regular menu but their restaurant week menu was just okay. Maybe it's because I'm comparing them to Jeanne D'Arc (I went to try their restaurant week menu not too long ago and their food was just fantastic), but the menu was not very impressive in general. First course was the toast with smoked salmon and beets. The salmon was fishy and the bread (pumpernickel) was over powering. The salad was bitter and the braised pork was just too heavily garlic. By the time I finished half of the plate, I was getting really sick of it. Chard also had a really weird texture, like I was chewing on soil. The gnocchi was the only tasty item on that plate. The final course was the creme  brulee. The sugar coating was too thick but the bottom was cold. Why in the world would I want to pay 40 dollars for this emsemble of food? I know that restaurant week meal is provided at a discount but this was....just..like they didn't even want to put any effort in it.

Not worth the money. I don't even know if I want to come back for their regular menu items.
author: Jeong O.

description:
The absolute best meal we've had in a very long time! Escargot is a must, along with their cocktails. Service was attentive, yet not annoying.
Best $200 dollars ever spent!
author: Amy M.

description:
I'm giving it an "okay." The atmosphere was charming though a bit empty feeling. However, as we went at an "off hour" not lunch/not drinks/not dinner time, it made sense. We had a comfy seat in the window (the alley outside was deserted however, so, not much people watching or amusement out the window) Service was fine, not too much or too little; it was just right. My personal preference actually, so service would get a 5/5. Thought the hurried comings and going of the bus people, with staggering stacks of dishes didn't really add to the charm though. 
The "kid" wanted to try escargot, so escargot she got. Had never tried them before, and they must have been great as she ate every last one. If you are fan of these, I have to suppose these would be 5/5? Personally, they haven't invented the drug that would make them (even butter, garlic, and puff pastry aside ...) make me want to try them. Perhaps starvation might work? Though I'd more likely resort to cannibalism if push came to plane crash. Hopefully, I won't find out anytime soon.  The crusty French bread dipped in the tasty butter leavings was delish. 

I ordered a glass of Chardonnay but (as in too many of my reviews I think)  felt I needed to call for a measuring cup to justify the meagerness of the pour. I also noted that it was infinitely less than chilled, and closer to room temp. My imagination said it was as if it were the dregs of that particular bottle? So, not quite enough to serve, but far too much to toss or to justify opening an extra bottle over? Well, picky-picky me. 

So I had the salad Nicoise and was rather disappointed. The tuna was of some tinned variety - a bit too salty, a bit too oily (It may not be "classic," but I've grown used to and fond of the charred on the outside and raw in the middle slice of ahi these days when they say "tuna" ) and the potatoes also seemed "tinned." So salad: 2/5 ? 
The kid had the quiche, which was surprisingly brown considering how almost runny the interior was. Tasty, but 3/5 is the best I could say. 
Would I go again? Possibly - the charm is undeniable. But I'd pick a better time, a better day, pay for corkage and order something other than the salad Nicoise for sure.
author: Mrs. R.

description:
Love love love this place! 

My best friend flew in all the way from the East Coast for my birthday weekend, and I was trying to find a table for Saturday dinner ~a week before. Most of the places in the city with 4+ stars were already taken, but I was glad to have found Cafe Claude! 

The restaurant is tucked away in a little alley in FiDi off Union Square, which unsettled me a little since we were there after dark. Fortunately there was another group of diners who were right ahead of us, so we quickly followed them. There were at least 1-2 other restaurants/ bars in the alley.

We were pleasantly surprised when I walked into the restaurant because it was a completely different world from the dark alley! The ambiance was very European, and the live jazz band made the place a perfect date spot. The food was amazing too. We ordered a cocktail each and the escargot to share. My friend got the quail (it was the day's special) and I got the duck leg confit. My friend commented that "They do their birds very well"! We finished off our meal with the lemon tart, which was also amazingly done. 

For all the food (and live music!), the check only came out to be ~$60 per person all in. Would definitely come back!
author: Mel L.

description: My party of four had a very enjoyable, delicious, and well- priced dinner during SF Restaurant Week last evening. The atmosphere was cozy, and we enjoyed chatting with the table next to us. Service was not rushed even though we stayed for three hours on a busy night. The music was welcome even though a bit loud at times. The Alsatian pork is highly recommended!
author: Kate C.

description:
So, down a dark alley, lies a really good, authentic French restaurant. French staff (though not as surly as the real thing) help lend to the authenticity of it.

But where it really shines in the food.  Very good french onion soup and coq au vin were standouts.  Prices are reasonable and service efficient.  

Enjoyed the meal here and it's definitely worth seeking out if you're around the Union Square area.  French bistro fod isn't easy to find and the restaurant's location shows that hidden restaurants can still be hidden gems.
author: Dan S.

description: We came here on our annual holiday visit to the city. We sat inside and found it everything we could hope for, a warm, inviting atmosphere with good service. The food was great. We split an appetizer, a salad and an entree. More than enough for two and all nicely presented and very tasty. We hope to make it back to this slightly hidden gem on our next trip to SF.
author: Peggy K.

description: Just a terrific lunch...the weather happened to be wonderful, so you could sit outside an really enjoy it, or inside, at a comfortable booth.  We had the BEST waitress(e), she was female, and her French was impeccable.  Mine, not so much, but she delivered the je ne sais quoi--basically, the atmosphere.  My friend had the amazing croque monsieur--ham and cheese in bechamel, done perfectly, and I had the moules (mussels) frites after the classic onion soup.  We blew hours, and the whole thing was just darn terrific.  Go there.
author: JP C.

description:
Convenient location. View of a dirty alley but that in itself kinda reminds me of Paris. All that was lacking was all the dog crap on the walkway common to that lovely country.... But lately, SF dog owners seem to be closing up the crap gap rapidly.

Service, woman was pleasant enough and trying hard. Didn't see her much after getting my food but I was able to easily flag down other staff to refill empty water. 

The food didn't impress me much, especially for a "French" restaurant. Bread and butter was excellent. $18 arctic fish sandwich was a nice piece of fish cooked very well, but the other contents of the sandwich were "meh" and the sauce leaked all over my plate. Small side salad had a delicious dressing and good quality leaves. 

But the stunner was the pomme frites- they tasted about an hour old (and I was there at opening!) Fairly tasteless without their mayo dip, after a few of them I was sorry I fell for her upsell. But when I got the bill I was REALLY sorry- they were EIGHT DOLLARS!!! -basically over $10 for bad fries with the tax, tip and tacky health fee. 

People there were friendly enough and it is a nice venue with appropriate music inside,  but for a $35 lunch (sandwich and fries, no drink) there are many, many better places within walking distance with a better menu and prices.
author: T J.

description: Amazing French food. My goto when I'm feeling like a quick trip back to Paris without spending my airline points. Must find a table outside. Love hearing the neighborhood hustle, the locals and tourist speak of their travels and how wonderful their dinner was here at Claude.
author: Zee R.

description: I love this place been going there for years, yummy food. But I'm disappointed they changed their pomme frites, they no longer have their spicy aioli dipping sauce and I would really like them to bring it back!
author: k l.

description: Cafe Claude is always amazing!! We enjoyed a fabulous lunch yesterday - Greens with Warmed Goat Cheese, Escargot, Mussels and Red Pepper Pappardelle were all perfect!! Our server, Noah was friendly and helpful.
author: Cynthia A.

description:
A very cute bistro nestled in an alley in between the FiDi and Chinatown.  Restaurants like this undeniably make SF feel a bit more on the European side, always a great thing.

I ordered the onion soup and pommes frites, and the onion soup was a bit overwhelming since the bread really took up most of the soup bowl, and not so much the onion soup.  :)  Sitting al fresco, taking it all in redeems that 4th star in my book.
author: Mel G.

description: Spent Christmas Eve here and had a lovely  French meal accompanied by an excellent jazz singer, Mark Robinson and his band.  Definitely will come back again.
author: D M.

description: We were  very disappointed and upset by this experience as my wife - suffering from severe gluten intolerance - checked with the server all items she ordered to ensure they were gluten free. After assurance from the kitchen we had pleasant meal. However as soon as my wife was back at the hotel,  she had major abdomen pains and was several sick with all the very negative  intestinal consequences to endure throughout the night . Don't believe anything they tell you . They are not trustworthy.
author: Philippe L.

description:
I have a colossal crush on Claude. Oh, those Frenchies...one night of indulgence and I'm helplessly smitten. Blame it on the Bordeaux.

This place oozes with romance. I really don't see how you could have a bad date tucked into one of Claude's sumptuous corners, sipping a flowery rose, and being serenaded by some smooth jazz and your waiter's sexy Uruguayan accent (hola Enrique!) God, I wanted to hide under the table and stay here for days...years, maybe. It is that special.
