The food is classic bistro fare - you know, the glamorous artery-cloggers we travel to Paris for: steak tartar, soupe à l'oignon, coq au vin, truffle mousse. And of course, those prettily-named wines that make us feel so fancy. Enrique poured me a tempting line-up of samples before I settled on the crisp Macon-Villages. And then...my life felt suddenly complete.

The service is impeccably classy, with foreign accents galore - French is definitely the dominant force here, in the food, the attitude, and the sensual mood of the place. Although I dined here with a girlfriend, the date-y feel of it wasn't weird. In fact, it was a great spot for a leisurely girls night. The waiters really know how to lay the charm on THICK. Sigh...

We were in such a daze of delight when we left that I forgot to grab my gigantic purse (truly, impossible to miss) and when we were blocks away, nearly at the BART station, Enrique came running around the corner calling "excuse me! excuse me!" in that darling Latin-tinged tongue, and graciously handed over my forgotten goods. My hero. 

I cannot wait to escape to Claude again. If I loved it this much on a Wednesday night, it must be unbearably wonderfully on one of their live jazz evenings (Thurs-Sun). How nice to know I can take a trip down Claude Lane to this hidden den of Frenchiness, sans jet lag and linguistic barriers. J'adore Claude!
author: Nique F.

description: The music was nice; however, based on the reviews, I expected more.  The food was so so.  I had the duck confit which was recommended by the waiter.  He said that was a popular dish and since this was a French restaurant, I thought that was an appropriate recommendation.  I was disappointed in the duck.  It was bland and the lentils was hard.
author: Kim S.

description:
I have been here so many times. It's a go to for bringing family and friends from out of town. Everything is good, never had a bad meal. 

It's a good idea to make a reservation, but you can probably get a table at off-times or weekday nights. I've eaten at the bar too, no problem. They don't have hooks to hang bags (design flaw). 

One of the best things I've had here was a hand rolled pasta dish with peas and bacon etc. It was a special, and a "small plate" so don't skip that portion if the menu. 

Also, the bartenders are usually very friendly and happy to make drinks that used to be on the menu. :)
author: Meredith K.

description:
This was my birthday dinner selection for our trip to San Francisco, and it did not disappoint.  

First, the location is amazing.  It is tucked in this little alleyway that makes you feel like you are in a small French bistro.  The weather was wonderful, and we had dinner out on their covered patio right in the alleyway.  

Second, the atmosphere was superb.  Several nights a week, they have a live jazz band and singer, and it was a great backdrop to dinner conversation, while not being too overpowering because of our location outside.

My appetizer consisted of the escargots en croute, which was delightful for my first attempt at escargot.  My friends had the corn bisque which was also pretty delicious.  

For entree, I had the lamb sirloin.  While good, it could have used a bit more punch of flavor; however, my friends' gnocchi and coq au vin were both top-notch.  

All in all, a wonderful dinner to ring in my birthday with a great atmosphere that left you feeling you were in a Paris for just a little bit.
author: Jerrod R.

description:
I came here on a work dinner and wasn't terribly impressed with the food. The service was great as our waitress was always patient as we decided on things for the table. Also, the bartender poured great drinks and was very generous.

However, the table was small (seemed much skinnier than other tables) and the dishes were underwhelming. The frites with the flat-iron steak were tasty, but I would assume that much. The french onion soup was mediocre and the steak itself was overcooked. The desserts (esp creme brulee), on the other hand, were great. 

With so many great restaurants in SF, I don't think I'll return here.
author: Ami D.

description:
I really like that this place has pretty authentic French food and not California French. Lovely atmosphere. It's a nice alternative if you can't get into Gitane next door. 

I've had good service every time I've been. I don't think the prices are that high. The lunch menu is not expensive at all. The salads are very good. I loved the toast with the lemon infused, warm goat cheese. 

For dinner, I would recommend the Coc de Vin.  And my husband enjoyed the Steak Tar-Tar.

Bon appetite!
author: Andrea T.

description:
To be honest, I didn't actually eat lunch or dinner at the restaurant, but I had a business meeting and the experience was very positive, so I will definitely be back to try it for a meal. 

We did have a fantastic bottle of wine and a cheese plate, along with a plate of frites.  The wait staff was very accommodating (very un-French!), and allowed us to sit for a couple of hours during the afternoon drinking, nibbling, and talking.
author: Frank W.

description:
What a great experience.  From the location, the service, the ambiance - and THE FOOD.  We had several of the classic French dishes and enjoyed each and every one.  The staff were ALL very friendly and attentive.  We only got to hear the beginning of the nightly music - but, will be back to spend more time with the sounds in the future.  I highly recommend Cafe Claude and will return whenever in San Francisco.
Highlights:  Escargots en Croute / Coq au Vin
author: Paddy P.

description:
Food is ok, but the lady at the door is not nice, told us you can only used the table for 30 mins. 
We went there for 3 course lunch, 30 mins is impossible. They didn't tell us there's time limit when making reservation.
After we ordered, food takes forever to come.
We end us sat there waiting for food for long time.
author: Ffyy F.

description:
I would have loved to give Claude 4 stars but can't seem to get around the subpar service for an expensive joint like this.

The hostess told us that we needed to wait to be seated by the window, which didn't make sense since people were still eating there and empty seating was open throughout the entire restaurant. My husband was obviously not having that, so he requested to be seated where it was empty.

The other part of the service that was also lacking was the waitress. She was as personable as someone you'd find working at the DMV. She was not very friendly or accommodating and because of this the tip reflected it.

Now getting to the good part of our meal was the roasted chicken, which was tender and out of this world amazing. My husband had the farm raised trout and a side of escargots, which he raved about the whole meal.

So in a nutshell even though the food was excellent I'm simply dumbfounded by the poor service and can't bring myself to come back again. Finally our bill came to $82 with tax+tip and the dining experience as a whole was not worth it.
author: V W.

description: We've eaten at Cafe Claude a half dozen times since our first time back in 2010. The last few time the menu selection has seemed quite limited and the food was good, but not nearly as memorable as it once was. Ambiance is still great, but unfortunately lower on our list these days.
author: Richard M.

description:
decent food 
great drinks
bar tender attentive and helpful and nice.
author: Caleb Y.

description: Cafe Claude was ok.  Very busy and crowded.  The food was ok.  Presentation was nice.  Service was not that great.  Tiny portions.  Not sure if I would eat here again... maybe.
author: Eric H.

description:
I came here on a Thursday night with a girlfriend and it was the perfect place to catch up (we were there for HOURS! and they didn't try to hurry us or kick us out at 11:15p).  Intimate tables, live jazz and great service.  We both had the onion soup, which was delicious!  I had the chevre salad, which was a generous portion and pretty good for leftovers the next day.  I tried the poulet roti, which was pretty good.  The chicken was cooked perfectly tender and the light sauce was a good touch.  Also, the bread tasted like the one they bake at in-house at Bouchon.  YUM.  We had the apple tart for dessert and it was a tiny portion for the price.  Nonetheless, it still tasted good with the caramel.  I'd probably try something else next time.

I would come back!  This is smack in the middle of Union Square and it's easy to miss.  It's in this alley with other restaurants and if you're walking from Post, it's the last one to the left.
author: Chris L.

description:
My boyfriend and I got dressed up fancy and came here for NYE dinner. We had never been to a French restaurant together so we didn't really know what to expect. The ambiance was not very French-like. I guess I was just hoping to be served by someone dressed in a tight black turtleneck and a red beret but no such luck. 

But ambiance aside, the food was rather decent. They were offering a prix fixe menu for NYE and I had the roasted veal belly appetizer, pan seared scallops entree, and layered chocolate cake with blood orange mousse for dessert. My bf ordered the arugula salad with avocado mousse appetizer, seared venison loin entree, and raspberry mousse with champagne gelée dessert. I loved mine... the veal belly was huge and could have been served as a main entree. My bf however did not care much for his dishes and didn't finish a lot of it. The venison was very very rare and after a few bites I had an urge to eat a huge salad (call it carnivore guilt). What we both agreed on was that the dungeness crab bisque served as the amuse bouche was simply the best part of our meal!! We could have had just a huge bowl of this for dinner!!

One thing that I want to call out about Cafe Claude that's worth checking out is the amazing mural painted on the wall right across from the cafe entrance. It is just breath taking and an excellent visual of street art in SF.
author: Elise D.

description: Okay, This beauty totally made me feel like im back in Paris. Their food is fantastic, european vibes, and service was on point. Merci Cafe Claude xo
author: nicole h.

description:
Our visit there took me back to dining in France......one respect notwithstanding.  The menu and setting (the patio) were redolent of a classic bistrot and even got me to gushing to le garçon a bit too much.   The food?  I believe escargot is a simple dish, but it's presentation here lifted it above other samples in this city, thanks to a puff pastry cap each snail wore.  The salade Niçoise was passable.  The Wednesday special, squid and lardons pasta, did not work sans les lardons (not a pork eater here) and when the waiter learned of our disappointment (and here we are probably leaving France!) the house, similar to les lardons, removed the price of the dish from the bill.  That didn't ruin anything!  I think they did make up a for it a bit in the price of the Sancerre, which was a delightful wine.
The service at Cafe Claude also distinguished the restaurant from France - well, at least from  it's caricature!   French waitstaff might have a reputation for haughtiness (though my experiences in France defy that slur) but here the staff  was tres agréable.
author: Robert L.

description:
2.5 stars 

I was so disappointed with Cafe Claude.  I ate here with my husband for our 7th anniversary a few weeks ago.  We were hoping it would be this great gem of a place based on the reviews, unfortunately it was lacking in several areas.

Atmosphere: The atmosphere is just ok. The back wall is this black window thing with a door to a bright hallway which is distracting since the door opens frequently for the staff to go in and out which messes with the dim lighting in the dining area. The floors and tables were clean but the ledge behind the seating was dusty.  

Service: Our server came on quite strong (perhaps because there weren't many diners at 6:15 on a Wednesday) but was more friendly and less abrupt as the meal went on. She had a trainee with her, which is ok, except in such a small dinning room they each stood on either side of my husband asking him questions looking down at him which just felt weird. However, a big plus is that my husband's parking ticket fell out of his pocket onto the floor which he didn't realize until we got back to the garage and our server had picked it up and saved it in case he came back.  YAY! 

Food: 
We ate:
Soupe a Loignon (it didn't seem to have reduced enough, the broth wasn't as rich as other similar soups we have had)
Frisee Aux Lardons (this was our favorite item, but the bacon was a bit flavorless-which is odd for bacon)
Omble Chevalier (this was good, but not great)
Coq Au Vin (we were hoping for a repeat of the amazing coq au vin that we had at Absinthe, this was not that, the mushrooms tasted like they were dried, the chicken wasn't as tender and the broth was thin)
Pmmes Frites (tasty, no complaints)

The bread and the glass of wine that I drank were very nice.
author: Christy L.

description:
0.0 STARS if i could give

Pretentious, Elitist, and a Jerk.   This is the host who calls himself the co-manager named Seyte.

We made reservations for my wife's birthday weekend and checked in for our reservation 15 mins early with the Manager and Host named Michelle.   About 2 mins after talking to Michelle, Seyte, apparently another host and manager, comes over and asks if he can help us.  We told him we just checked in with Michelle and he gave us a one over look and smiled smugly and walked off.

We stood by the door/bar, waiting for our table.  My wife needs to eat before having some alcohol due to medication, so I forgo drinks as well to celebrate with her.   again, Sr Seyte asked if we needed a drink and we politely declined but with that answer, also gave us the smug look as if we didnt belong.

Flash forward 15-20 mins later, a couple walks in for a reservation after ours(we were only people waiting) and after Michelle walked away from front for about 10 mins, he gave them the newly cleaned table we had been waiting for

I walked up to Seyte and asked how long our table would be,  and he made the look as if he hadnt seen us, the only 2 people waiting for a table.   I asked how that happened and he told me that we had checked in with "the other manager".   All the time looking at me with a smug attitude of I dont care about you or the problem this caused.  I asked how long it would be for another table and he said he would need a few minutes to determine that.  I looked at him with frustration and annoyance and said nice attitude.  He then told me it was me that had the attitude.

I've never heard of a small restaurant, or a big restaurant that you need to check in with both managers.    After asking 3 times, he wouldnt tell me how long a table wait would be and that i would need to give him a few minutes, without even looking at his computer while talking.   It was weird, and we felt like we were being discriminated against.   Ridiculous.

I told him we would just go down the street as this was out of line.   

I got a call 20 minutes later from Michelle apologizing and telling me she was upset about what happened.   I told her how i was treated by the male host and asked what the prick's name was.  She didnt defend him at all and said his name was Seyte, S-E-Y-T-E.    She said that she was the person in charge, not Seyte.   She asked if she could send me a gift certificate to come back or if anything she could do to make right.  I told her the only thing was to fire the prick named Seyte.

We had dinner down the street and gave the waiter a $100 tip on a $85 bill.

Screw this place and screw Seyte.   Dont bother with this place, it has passed its prime with service and attitude given as an example.    Definitely DO NOT use this place for any special occasion lest disappointment awaits.

i've been a yelp lurker for years, but this experience has pushed me into first review.   wish i had written more about my mostly positive experiences now as this one quite frankly was TERRIBLE.   Save yourself some time , disappointment and heartache and try someplace else where you only have to check in with 1 host, and dont have to deal with jerks like this guy

0.0 Stars
author: Dwight D.

description: The music was amazing, the food was bland and horrible. After a $200 dinner, I left to go eat somewhere esle... don't waste your time or your money.
author: Nicholas F.

description:
We started off with the steak tartare which was classically prepared at the side of the table and spiced by the waiter to whatever your preference is. Its very difficult to turn down the double portion for $3 more and it was not a regretted decision to go for the full dish. We also had the pâté platter which was just as good. The martinis before dinner were also very well made.

For mains we had the lamb shank, which was a Saturday special, and truite amandine. It was extremely tender and had an amazing sauce. The trout had a great flavor combination of sweet savory from the raisins and sauce. Everything was classic French cooking and didn't disappoint at all.

The wait staff was competent and friendly. We didn't have any issues all evening. However, the couple next to us accidentally had their two orders of lamb brought to them before their appetizer. When the waiter was informed he apologized, took their entrees and rushed an order for their appetizers and after they finished that brought two more orders of their lamb. The staff handled their situation extremely well.

The decor of the restaurant is very pleasant but some of the tables are fairly close together and make it difficult to relax during dinner.
author: Michael S.

description:
I came here a couple days ago for a date night with a friend and I am so happy we decided to come here! The outside seating was nice, very cool how they are set up in an alley with heat lamps. We came on a Wednesday and there was some live jazz being played in the entrence, definitely set the mood for what could be a romantic night. 

We both started with the charcuterie plate and gobbled it right up. It was small, expensive, but really really good. The snack bread and butter is great too! 

For main entree I got the duck confit and my friend got the trout. Both were absolutely cooked to perfection! The duck confit made such a joyous crunch when you sliced into it! 

For dessert we had the creme brulee and it was also amazing. 

DEFINITELY a great date spot if you want to impress someone as long as you dont mind the prices.
author: Ezequiel R.

description:
(Overall 4.5 stars based on at least 5 dining experiences) Cafe Claude has been a staple restaurant to me for few years. Food, service, and ambiance are all above par; and while their food is not always impeccable and perfect, I never had a bad dining experience there. Cafe Claude is easily one of the most consistent restaurants in San Francisco.

The past two months I had dinner there three times, with visitors from out of town on each occasion. Their soup and salad portions tend to be less generous. Frisee aux Lardons is delicious, with nueske's bacon. I usually have the Soup du Jour since the onion soup, which both my guests savored, is too heavy for my stomach. Soup of the day can be a carrot soup served cold.

Assiette de 3 Pates include country style pork, chicken liver and truffles, and goose liver marinated in sauternes wine. We all agreed that the black pepper slightly overpowers the pork flavor. Goose liver found favor across the table and was the first pate consumed in whole. Chicken and truffles also went well together.

Plats ordered: Angus hanger steak was prepared medium rare up to the liking of my guest from Hong Kong, who is actually French. The cider brined pork tenderloin is just perfect with the roasted apple in mustard-tarragon-cognac jus. I can't help helping myself from my friend's plate.  Coq Au Vin is a safe choice if you like chicken. Mine came with two drumsticks and a thigh cooked in red wine, mushrooms and bacon. 

The meal was brought to a final note with the flourless chocolate cake, the chocolate mousse, and the tarte aux pommes. Skip the dessert wines since they aren't very special, and the portion is smaller than a prosecco.

Dinner for 2 with two drinks each: $165 with tips
Dinner for 3 with a bottle of red and dessert wine: $269
author: Matt Y.

description:
Two words: Super. Cute.

Like I want to put Cafe Claude in my pocket and take it home with me.

It's in one of those alleys you rarely find in America with a bunch of other restaurants. Has a lot of heated outdoor seating under an awning, but we went inside after a long day grinding away at the job (woe is us).

Was able to make a reservation on Open Table via Yelp no problem, which I must say is really nice and I've never had any problem with the service. 

Anyhoo, the meal started with a great tomato basil soup that was spicy but not insanely so. For my meal a fantastic rosemary-encrusted agneau (rack of lamb) with a side of nicely cooked fingerling (?) potatoes. There were pPlenty of wines from totally reasonable prices to the completely insane (i.e. dot-com bubble 2.0) - can't remember specifically what we got, but it was delicious.

And the service was good too - seated super promptly, attended to at all the right moments without being hovered over and didn't fail when it came time to finish paying up. I didn't save enough room to sample dessert, maybe next time!
author: Joshua B.

description: Came here with some girlfriends and really enjoyed the laid back vibe of the place. I had the petrale sole which was fantastic. Would also recommend the duck confit and creme brulee to finish!
author: Linda X.

description:
I like how this place is sort of hidden in a nice alley way.

I ordered the Steak Tartare, Escargots en Croute, Pommes Frites.
They were all exquisite and enough for 2 people.
The total cost was ~$39 and I would say that this price is very well worth it given the quality of the food and the more than decent service.

If you're craving French food and you're in downtown SF, this is the place to be if you're not feeling like a cheapskate.

I like how there are some wines on tap.
This would be a good date spot after a couple hours of shopping.
author: Marlon T.

description:
I've had the same server every time I think (3-4 times now?)!  He definitely is accomodating to ensure we try to best wine suited for our taste buds before we select.

Must haves:  
Outdoor seating under heated lamp in "Europe"
Generous cheese plate, honeycomb, jams, fruit and fruit/nut bread!  Excellent for the price.  
Fries - the best in the city I tell ya! 
French 75 -  must afterwork or brunch cocktail!
BF had the coq au vin - excellent!  

Must try ahi tuna salad and macaroni gratine (mac n cheese) next time.  Simple and always crave to go back.    


Bring back the Point Conception Pinot please??  or will someone tell me where I can get it?  I want 5 bottles...:)
author: Candice H.

description: Six of us dined here for lunch. We ordered a variety of dishes, everyone cleaned their plates in addition to their deserts. The food was excellent, service superb, the waitress was not only friendly and knew the menu, she was also patient with us, as we kept her busy with our questions on menu items. Highly recommend Cafe Claude.
author: Carolyn K.

description: After hearing my friend talk about how good their Croque Madame was pretty good. I like the taste of the cheese that was melted on the bread. When you get towards the middle, the Ham, cheese, and egg yolk mixed together was really delicious. It also came with salad. The dressing of that salad had a vinegar taste which is always good!! Overall I give it a 4/5 !
author: Sophia L.

description: Great hidden spot. Down a back alley but the patios make it nice and cozy. Inside was very nice, service was great and the food was tasty. Great for a lunch date inside or out.
author: Ranee W.

description:
The best dish I have ever had, I kept hushing my date because he was interrupting the mental orgasm I was having from Chef Michelle's food at Cafe Claude. 

Let alone we had the most fantastic server, if you have the time to kick back and relax for 2-3 hours grab a spot on the patio and pretend your in Europe.
author: Jennavive P.

description: The live jazz was great. Service was not bad. However, the taste of food was just so so. Given the price tag, I would expect something much better than what I had here.
author: Helen Y.

description:
This review is for last week's meal here.
Finally got a chance to swing by for a lunch, albeit for a 2:45pm late lunch.

This is classic style French food; not California French.

They start you off with some fine rolls and unsweetened butter. White table clothes are nice.

The Boeuf pom frittes was pretty good.
Generously sized phat slices of Boeuf had some very good flavor and the chopped parsely with olive oil was a perfect fit. The mountain of thin french fries were perfectly fried golden brown, crunchy on the outside, yet hot and steamy on the inside;
and decidedly enjoyed by my mouth. $19.00.

My friend had the saumon with couscous and said it was very delicious.
Very low priced at $15.00

Update: April 3rd: bump one star!
The Trouit plat is quite good. It looks handsome on the plate, all butterflied and perfectly grilled, with flower petals, surrounded with balsamic splashed arugula over a bed of earthy lentils. Nom nom.

I'll be back to try other plats.

Decor: quasi hip, low lights, deep dark woods and cool jazz permeate the air.

Customer service: fine.

Tip: Live Jazz on Thursday and Friday evenings.
author: Bert K.

description:
Food: perfectly French. Authentic. Must try to chocolate mousse for desert  
Service: excellent
Atmosphere: live French jazz band when we were there on Saturday night 
Waitime: none! We can come on a Saturday night and didn't have reservations so we tried 4 restaurants which wouldn't take us earlier than 1 hour wait. Claude took us right away. I think that tourists and many locals don't know about it coz of its alley location
author: Lena R.

description:
We're in San Jose, heading up to the city last Saturday afternoon for my wife to take care of some stuff, so I looked at Yelp to potentially find a restaurant near Union Square we'd not been to. Knowing of the French places near the French Consulte, I focussed there. I'm a former resident of France and appreciate the food tremendously.

Unfortunately, there were so many negative reviews of so many of the places, including Cafe Claude, I just set it aside in desperation, figuring we'd just walk around and pick a place based on a pretty full restaurant (actual attendance speaks louder than reviews). Coincidentally, my wife's hairdresser just a block away highly recommended Claude, so we went.

Superb. Except for them serving bread and butter (unsalted--so I have zero idea of what all the "too salty" reviews are talking about) before the meal for American expectations, it was totally authentic. To wit:

1. The veal sweetbreads were divine. I saw a veganesque review that actually complained about the name. Uh, how do you respond to that kind of utter ignorance? They were succulent, essentially natural meatballs in a preparation that allowed them to stand largely on their own.

2. The Steak Tartare was precisely French. Hand chopped steak like I do at home (it's not hamburger folks) and even in the "spicy" configuration I asked for, it's French spicy, which means more of the provincial herbs and spices, not hot, not salty, not peppery.

3. They know how to serve a whiskey: ice cubes on the side.

4. The Onion soup was actually FRENCH onion soup and not AMERICAN onion soup so many of the ignorant, negative reviews complain about. See, French onion soup is not served such that it burns your mouth (French serve all food not extremely hot nor cold--except ice cream--because you get more flavor when food is in a smaller range from room temp, warm or cool). Nor is FRENCH onion soup thickened with corn or potato starch to make it "hearty." It's a near demi-glace beef broth made from roasting bones & marrow, boiling them for a long time, letting the broth reduce and concentrate flavor, then introducing onions. Many French really don't even eat the croutons or much of the cheese, because it's never a meal. It's all about the oniony flavor of a light beefy broth.

5. They had a lamb shank special and it was perfect. So Frenchy.

In all, a perfect meal where I left invigorated, massaged with flavor, pampered with good service and made the drive back to San Jose without the slightest hint of comatose remorse after so many American styled meals of excess.

Good job.
author: Richard N.

description: Onion soup,  mussels and a glass of pinot gris. Great lunch on a cool day in SF. Good service with a European atmosphere.
author: Bob S.

description: just left here, found it when Google-ing for restaurants near Union Square, it's about 1/2mile walk.  Ordered steak frites and glass of french pinot.  beautiful cut of steak, cooked just to medium rare, fries cooked to crispy with the right amount of salt. Nice, clean, casual interior.  Very friendly staff and a welcoming vibe about the place. I ate at the high top table near the bar.  Did not visit the dining area but saw it from the window, looks very nice, white table cloth in tradition of french bistro. And the little corner of SF seems like a mini french quarter.  3-4 other french restaurants nearby and a french named hotel as well.  I will be back!
author: Henderson W.

description:
My boyfriend and I ate here for one of our anniversaries, and wow, was it amazing! We made reservations ahead of time as it was a Friday evening, and we didn't have to wait at all to be seated, even though we accidentally showed up about 15 minutes late because we'd mis-read our reservation time. Ooops! 

I don't recall the "correct" name, but for the appetizer I had the French Onion soup and he got the bacon mac & cheese. We later joked that we should have had the mac & cheese for the entree also, and again for dessert, it was THAT yummy. But no, for the entree we shared the Coq au Vin which was divine, and had Creme Brulee and Chocolate Mousse for dessert, both of which were just amazing.

Service was quick, friendly and the servers were all very knowledgeable.

Will definitely be back for more anniversary dinners here! :]
author: Katrina M.

description:
I recently indulged with my girlfriend a BART ride into the Financial district and a night out to dinner (as it was our one year anniversary). She decided on Cafe Claude based on a previous positive experience she had here. We had a great time at Cafe Claude! The meal totaled $130 (quite a nice date dinner) which included two soft drinks, three appetizers, two entrees, and a split dessert... Me and my girlfriend can eat! 

We had the French onion soup (I would say 5/5 stars, very flavorful and umami-licious), the beet and goat cheese salad (I would rank this as 4/5 based on the sheer uniqueness of the house blended cheese!), the moules frites (4/5, very cleaned and well prepared mussels in the traditional French way, and the sauce was fine). For entrees, I had the steak-frites and she had the coq au vin. I would give my steak a 3.5/5 due to a vein of gristle that had been left in the somewhat tough meat, but the demi-glaze, the marrow coumpound butter, and french fry accompaniment were the three highlights of the meal for me. Amazing, though I am a bit of a French-fry-fiend (who isn't?). The coq au vin was 4.5/5, several notes of flavor and the meat was moist, dark meat. The dish cried for something to balance out constant flavor of the sauce-we used the delicious baguette. The dessert was the classic creme brulee, 4/5. Nothing special, but consistent and good. Less eggy and more velvety custard.

Overall the meal was nice. Our service was great throughout the night and we left stuffed and happy.
author: Zach G.

description: Good service but food was just okay.  Sounded good but execution was lacking.  Park shoulder was way over cooked.  Disappointed.
author: Denny S.

description:
Oh my, was I happy with Cafe Claude.  

After reading a good amount of Yelp! reviews, I was worried that my friends and I had made our dinner reservation at the wrong place - overly salty soup, bland coq au vin, cramped quarters - so NOT true!   

The duck confit and the trout were phenomenal - and I'm not pulling your legs here - phenom.  The escargot, french fries, and the steak tartare were also amazing, as was the french onion soup, which was so NOT salty (I secretly wanted to add more salt and so did my friend).  

Our waiter was just peachy and the drinks were spot on.  It was a little loud at times due to the live jazz band but, who can complain about a live jazz band?  Not I.  

We finished off the meal with the chocolate cake and the creme brulee.  Fantastic.
author: Rachelle P.

description:
This restaurant has a very intimate and cozy setting. The tables are quiet small so maybe its  french thing, I duuno. I gave this place only two stars because I thought the fries, creme brûlée, and apple bread pudding were really good. However, they were really shady on the prosciutto that came with my honey dew salad, and my entree was not good at all. I ordered the coq au vin and it was not appetizing at all. My chicken was marinated in red wine and was supposed to have some fingering potatoes, but when i received it i got 1/3 of a fingering potato and my chicken was probably soaked in expired red wine, absolutely unappetizing.
Would i ever go back to this place or recommend it? no no no.
author: Crystal I.

description:
Charles Trénet

"La mer
Qu'on voit danser le long des golfes clairs
A des reflets d'argent
La mer
Des reflets changeants
Sous la pluie"

Ah.  I've been on this fantastical sweep after the delightful evening spent at Gitane and now, Cafe Claude.  I was feeling the need to get out and my good friend, who is always happy to oblige, met me downtown for a little snack/lunch.  I chose to sit outside because, come now, it was such a beautiful day downtown.  The sun.  The slight breeze.  Heaven.

The menu for lunch is here is a simple take on French bistro fare.  The linens and napkins add a slight formality to the seating.  The shar-pei in the salon next door followed us with his eyes.  Such a little cutie.  We usually go to Cafe de la Presse but I was out to try something new.  My eyes alighted on one of my favorite sandwiches: Croque Madame.  A thick grilled sandwich comprised of crusty french bread with béchamel, layered ham and gruyère cheese, a sunny side egg, and the perfect amount of pomme frites.  Every time I bit into this lovely creamy effect, my taste buds swooned.  My friend ordered the side of pomme frites accompanied with a delightful spicy aioli and by the end of our meal, both of our plates were finished.

The outside dining patio was packed with mostly people from FiDi and tourists that were not too predictable.  We spent a lovely afternoon chatting casually over bites and I've now given my friend another nickname in addition to the "dating mentor", and now the voice of reason.  Our waiter was splendid and very cute with his accent.  What can I say.  French.  Italian.  Brazilian.  Irish.  It gives them an additional +10 off the bat.  Great service and attention to details.

With that beautiful service and  my friend's advice staunch behind my convictions and appetite satiated, we proceeded to walk down Bush, taking in the wonderful weather.

"La mer
Les a bercés
Le long des golfes clairs
Et d'une chanson d'amour
La mer
A bercé mon cœur pour la vie"
author: Miika M.

description:
The food and service here was solid.  

MUSSELS (curry flavor) appetizer - REALLY GOOD. 
FRIES $7 side - pricey but really crispy and delicious. 
STEAK - smallish portion but really good quality meat. comes with a side of fries
STEAK TARTAR - with quail egg on top. It was pretty tasty but not much flavor
author: Jenn L.

description:
We've been to Café Claude a number of times over the years. We always thought of it as a cozy place with reliable good (though not exciting) food. We needed a place to meet friends and thought "let's go back". What a disappointing experience.

It started with the host. When we got to the restaurant there was one table occupied. The host proceeded to seat us at a ridiculously small table for four. This table would barely hold two comfortably. We discussed this with him and he insisted we sit at this table. We asked about two two-tops that had been pushed together and he said he was saving them in case a bigger group came in and he needed to move things around. So we sat down and waited for our friends. After just a few minutes my wife started getting claustrophobic so she got up and insisted on a new table. He finally relented and moved us to a more comfortable table.

Then a single man came in. The restaurant was still pretty much empty. The host puts him in an adjacent (and I mean very adjacent) table seated so he is facing us. It was like we had an audience for the rest of the meal. Our bar order was messed up (my dry martini came extra dirty). The salads were all watery and tasteless. Entrees were meh. The creme brulee was as stiff as hardboiled egg.

Our server was nice

So the evening was marred by at worst rude and at best insensitive host and an indifferent kitchen. Last time we visit Café Claude. (BTW, I normally don't do these reviews ... so it had to be pretty bad to get me to do this.)
author: Joseph S.

description: Surprised by how tasty the food is. Everything was delicious, including our wine.  Great service, but uncomfortable seating outside. Awkward.
author: Alice A.

description:
Cafe Claude is one of those close-quartered restaurants that you think is intimate because of the friendly, helpful staff & delicious food.  Pierre was our server & gave us good information about the menu choices.

We started w/a bottle of Schmitt Riesling which was pretty good.  Sweetie got the Onion Soup which isn't my fave, but he thought it yummy.  We both gave each other bites of the Porc and the Poulet & were happy with our choices.  We shared the Gratin & finished with the delicious Moelleux.  We definitely recommend this restaurant & hope to return soon.
author: Melanie E.

description:
Such a great French spot and like the other reviews a great place to eat.  For an appetizer I had the special Andouille plate.  Very, very good.  And for the main, the filet mignon and again it was excellent.  Great wine selection, prices were reasonable and the atmosphere inside was lively.  

A great recommend for travelers like myself to get a great French experience.
author: Mark A.

description:
Every time I have been in San Francisco this definitely is my go to restaurant For French food. I  always order the same thing since I am a creature of habit.  I start off with the muscles for an appetizer and then for an entrée I have the Coq Au Vin.  Which is absolutely the best I've ever had anywhere outside of France.

Cafe Claude  is tucked away in a small little alley which you can access only by walking.  It's actually very close to the grand opening gates of Chinatown.  Everything at this restaurant is superb and you will not be disappointed and they have a full bar and make wonderful drinks as well
author: Lisa M.

description:
The pork dish was out of this world.  Not a big fan of pork but ordered it on a recommendation and very happy I did.
Service was wonderful and it is a quaint atmosphere.  Ate at many places in San Fran during our visit and this was by far the best.
author: Adam K.

description: Service is great, music is lively, food is amazing and they have a nice a outdoor patio for warm summer days. We ordered the steak tartare, asparagus soup, escargot, pork chop. And for dessert Tarte au citron. This bistros felt authentic to me, food, ambiance even the waiter speaking to me in French and coincidently a French couple next to us. Felt like I was back in Paris.
author: Ennie L.

description:
Took the BF here for his bday and it was amazing.  The restaurant is tiny & tables are pretty close to eachother, so, girls- don't bring the big purse!  I picked this restaurant because they serve the BF's favorite things--escargot, pate & steak tartare.  We ordered and happy finished all three dishes of course.  We also got wine to go with our meal--he ordered a glass of merlot and i had the rose flight.  The lamb shank was the special that night so we gave it a try, but it was really tough and gamey.  I usually love lamb so i felt bad sending it back, but our server was great and took it off our tab.  And for dessert, another one of the BF's favorites: creme brulee.  I don't even like desserts much and i loved it.

Definitely coming back to try everything else on the menu!
author: Jen D.

description:
I honestly feel this is my go to place if I'm taking anyone to dinner around union square.

Its just so damn interesting it being in a lane and everything. "what's in that alley" AMAZING FOOD!


hahah well i just went the other day down this magical lane and it was awesome.


We had the steak tartare, which i found was tasty and spicy and just pretty great

Then i had the coq au vin. which is solid. The chicken sliding right off the bone, its soo good.

its a great wonderful venue reasonable prices. And a lovely surprise if you have a guest from out of town.
author: Justin N.

description: Service was mediocre and food was ok. Definitely won't be returning. We were served our food before the bottle of wine we had ordered about 20 min. earlier. Huge pet peeve of mine. When we mention we would like our wine with our food it takes awhile til they figure out the wine we ordered isn't chilled. Keep in mind we ordered their "featured" wine which has a huge block on their menu taking up about 1/6th of the printed space. And it's not ready for a customer?  Lol. Hmmm. Ok will give them a pass on that (kind of) but they didn't acknowledge or address it til 20 min later when WE inquired about it. They did give  us a complimentary glass of wine while it chilled. The steak tartare was yummy the escargots not so much. The house salad was the best part. We had duck & coq au vin as our entrees which were not impressive. Skip the desserts. The mousse was not good. Nobody ever circled back to check in & make sure all was smooth sailing after wine snafu. C'est la vie.
author: MJ M.

description: Beautiful atmosphere, charming service and tasty food.
author: Em L.
Jie M.

description:
I love this place for the live music and the ambiance.  It's a killer spot to take your sweetheart.  The service is friendly and thoughtful.  They brought me 2 glasses of complimentary champagne, so why only 3 stars?

The tables in the back can be a bit loud for soft conversation and I'm not a huge fan of the food.  I recently had the New York steak and neither the cook nor the seasoning were great; green salad was 13 or 14 bucks, which seemed a little overpriced.

You'll probably need a reservation or you'll end up eating outside (where you can't really hear the music).  All in all, it's worth swinging by for a glass of wine and some music, if nothing else.
author: Allen T.

description:
Cafe Claude was SUCH a let down! :( 

Atmosphere: Cute and quaint little restaurant. It's a little hard to find so make sure that you search around before giving up. Also I wish I had looked up when they had live music! I assumed Saturday night would be one of those nights, but it wasn't. I hear their performances are really fun and exciting to watch, so I wish I had checked when that would be happening so dinner could have been more interesting. 

Service: My reservation was for 8:00pm but I still had to wait about 15 minutes which was slightly annoying because I had made the reservation a week earlier and it was only for a party of 2. But besides all that, the servers were all very courteous and the food came out in a timely fashion. 

Food: We ordered a french onion soup to start with. This was way too salty, and really made the soup just hard to eat itself. We had to take really small bites (because we arrived really hungry) to take it down. My friend ordered a lamb dish, which unfortunately he said was way too salty and did not have any flavor (besides the salt that is). I ordered the baked macaroni and cheese plate. Unfortunately this place was overhyped. Basic mac and cheese is really easy, but this place did not even live up to that low standard. It again lacked flavor, was way too thick in terms of cheese, and even after dousing it in the only hot sauce they had on the premise, I still did not like it. The part that I did like about it was the baked part, because the crisp was just perfect and it wasn't too hard to break into like some baked mac & cheese plates. 

Verdict: I will NOT be coming back. So ridiculously pricy for food that was either too salty or just not flavored. Only good stuff was the service and the cute ambiance in the restaurant. There are numerous restaurants in the city that are also fancy, similarly priced or even cheaper, and actually have great food!
author: Anu P.

description:
Honesty, I felt quiet disappointed in this place.  Yes, it's a cute little restaurant in some alley in the Financial District, but this place has too many high stars and probably undeserving stars.

First off, our party of three was squeezed into a tiny table, when there were obviously larger tables that were never occupied throughout the night.  I understand the attempt to make the place look and feel like Paris, since one of the best meals I"ve had in France was in a cozy little restaurant with my neighbors a few inches away from us.  That being said, this place didn't need to try to make it too cozy when there was space.  Dishes and glasses piled up on our table that was clearly too small for three people.

Second, we ordered TWO of the appetizer plates to share, the assorted plate and the cheese plate.  Somehow the waiter got it wrong and brought the charcuterie plate as well, for a total of three appetizers.  We didn't bother sending it back, because they all looked so good and they were good.  Unfortunately, that was the best part of the meal.

I ordered the Omble Chevalier, which I thought was the closest thing to a Bouillabaisse, my favorite French soup.  Disappointed, especially after waiting forever for this dish to arrive.  I understand that this may take a while to make, but really a good soup should have been prepared well in advanced, and this clearly wasn't.

Waiter disappeared and came by whenever he felt like it, in really long intervals, meaning that I could not get my water glass refilled in a timely manner.  In the end, we could not find him to get our check and possibly the host took care of us.

Wine list contains only French wine, fine this is understandable, but I found that they tried too hard to mimic a French restaurant in Paris, that they have failed their local crowd.

Maybe I've been spoiled by the NYC food scene, maybe Californians aren't too picky about their French food, but either way I was not impressed.
author: Tina Y.

description: Excellent food, excellent service... at our outdoor table we had fun imagining a secret corner of Paris. Will be back soon - hope to check out the live music, which will probably only add to the charm.
author: Alan S.

description: My daughter and I found this place by accident, drawn by music and ambiance.  Thank you to Noah, our waiter, for being part of her 21st birthday celebration and making it an extra special evening. We'll be back for dinner to go with the amazing sazeracs, creme brulee and mousse next time!
author: Marie J.

description: This was one of my favorite French restaurants in SF. I sadly was disappointed with my meal last night. It started off well as we ordered foie gras and steak tartare. The foie gras dish ate sweet and needed a bit of texture and acidity. The steak tartare could have been cut a little smaller and all the way through, but the flavor was good. The biggest problem I had with the dinner was the entree and service. The pappardelle duck confit, squash and Brussels sprouts pasta was probably the worst pasta dish I've had all year. There was no flavor, absolutely bland. The kabocha squash overcooked and lacking uniformity.  There was hardly any duck in the pasta...But the worst part of the dish was the noodles were all clumped together!!!  I have to say, I don't think even Olive Garden's noodles stick together like that!!!  It's pretty difficult to ruin a pasta dish, so congratulations, your chef did a great job in achieving that. I had to flag down a busboy to refill our waters, and I wanted to tell the server how terrible the pasta was but he never even asked how our meal was. The only reason I continued eating was because I was so hungry and I didn't want to wait another 40 minutes so they can recreate a terrible afterthought of a dish!
author: Cookee L.

description:
My boyfriend and I made reservations at Cafe Claude for our 5 year anniversary.  Flying in from San Diego, we were able to walk from our hotel- near the heart of Union Square and near Chinatown.  We almost didn't find the restaurant because it is located in the back of an alley.  Unfortunately, there was no live jazz band playing on the night of our anniversary (no live music on Sundays I believe).

Romantic, dim-lit ambiance.
Their drinks are fabulous.
Escargot appetizer was delicious- our first time having snail!  A 'must try.'
The Cod plate was the perfect portion and perfectly cooked.
The short rib special was also very delicious and melts in your mouth.
Chocolate mousse dessert was pretty good, very smooth and went well with the dessert wine pairing.

Our server was awesome, attentive, and very nice- along with the rest of their staff.

I would totally come back to Cafe Claude if I lived in San Francisco for some French cuisine!  Great spot for a date, make sure you come in when their live jazz band performs!
author: Phyllis R.

description: The clams and es cargo were fantastic.  Nice vibe.  It's a little hard to find since the entry is in an alleyway, but it was charming and inviting.
author: Sammy O.

description: Nice lunch menu.  Food was delicious & service was excellent.  Bread was fantastic.  $7 for a 750ml bottle of sparkling water is steep, but probably not worth knocking a star off.  Very enjoyable overall!
author: Fern W.

description: Came here for dinner and everything was delish. We ordered the steak tartare to start which they actually prepared and mixed right in front of us. They brought out the unseasoned steak tartare with all the seasonings on the side, then they gave us a choice of which seasonings we wanted to include and how spicy we wanted the dish to be. It was very tasty and plenty for two (we got the large serving). I had the chicken in red wine sauce - really good. The bf got the new york strip steak with a stick of bone marrow herb butter on top that he devoured. We finished with the obligatory creme brulee for dessert which didn't disappoint. They had live jazz playing as well, overall a fun lively place to eat.
author: Queena T.

description:
**************** REVIEW 416 ******************

            Cafe Claude is 1 of my favorite spots for date night, Happy Hour, and also when shopping with mom. Tuck in the ally of Claude lane, invisible to hustle Sutter  & Bush streets of downtown, once you arrive, it likes you transform to a cafe is Paris. Good food, good wine, good service, reasonable price, fashionably casual and all good vibe!

            Beside their live Jazz on Thursday-Saturday, their happy hour is always fun and busy. My mom specially love their cocktails here. 

- Pâte  Plate - 1 of my mom's Fav in the city! 

       - Rillette du Périgord - pork free, shredded all-natural duck meat, 
       duck fat seasoned & cooked confit style. Delicious!

       - Truffle Mousse - a creamy all-natural petaluma poultry chicken 
       livers, truffles and cèpes marinated in sherry. Yum "O"

       - Pâte de Campagne - country style pork pate flavored with black 
       pepper and redwine

- Betterave  - red beets, snow peas, feta cheese - refreshing.

- Soupe a l'oignon - the cheese melting perfectly, the broth is sweet & aromatic. Mom always orders this soup here.

- Pommes Frites - crispy, skinny as a string, with  nice dipping sauce piquante aux herbes!

- Trout special with sauteed mushroom, cherrytomato, spinach & flavored rice with petite pois -perfect entrée to share!

- Poulet Rôti - half roasted chicken with lemon, niçoise olives, rosemary, and sautéed swiss chard - always consistent here!

           After a long shopping day, this is 1 of Mom & I favorite spots to rest over the Bellini & French 75, always our FAV.

P.S. Follow them on Twitter @cafeclaude for special deals too!
author: Manda Bear B.

description:
While visiting San Francisco for Labor Day Weekend, I stayed at the Grand Hyatt San Francisco, and took pains to look for good eats around the area. I knew I'd have to either walk or take public transportation (I don't really like cabs), so I was looking for restaurants that'd be worth the effort.

I planned to have dinner with a couple of ladies so I wanted the mood to be lively and the food to be delicious (we're all foodies). After doing a quick Yelp search around the area, I came upon Cafe Claude. Hmm, "french" food or sushi? Tough call but I felt I'd appreciate the ambience of Cafe Claude more than the local sushi joints.

After a five-minute walk in high heels, I arrived at the alley where I'd have to go through to get to the restaurant. I don't know if it was just dark but I couldn't find it at first and had to walk back and forth a little while until I realized where it was. It's tucked away in between other restaurants. 

When I walked in, I noticed the lighting was nice (romantic, even), and they had a live jazz band playing. Cha-ching! I sat down immediately but felt that the booth had really mushy chairs. Bad for my back, actually. And although I'm a tall woman, I felt a tad short because the table was tall compared to the booth.

Anyway, we ordered some drinks and a side of fries. Mm, the skinny, marinated fries were delicious! Those were gone in a hot minute. Then our main dishes came out. I ordered the coq au vin, and the chicken was really tender. The meat just fell off of the bone! The reason I gave it 4 stars instead of 5 stars is because the coq au vin wasn't as hyped up as some people on this site made it out to be. Also, our waiter wasn't all too attentive, and so the service didn't really stand out to me.

I'd definitely come back here for a date night or something in the near future but heck, if I'm traveling up to SF to try the food, I'll most likely pass this restaurant by and try some of the other places nearby. I guess it just goes to show that the food wasn't all *TOO* memorable.
author: Stace K.

description:
I am glad I found Café Claude on OpenTable. It is tucked down an alley - Claude Lane - so I would never have found it just walking around The City. Overall, the atmosphere was very intimate and the food very good.

The highlight of my meal was my starter.  I had the frisee aux lardons - frisee salad with pork belly and soft poached egg. The saltiness and richness of the pork and egg combined nicely with the sherry vinaigrette and bitter greens. The "Thon" - coriander and fennel crusted tuna, heirloom tomato, corn ragu, and cumcumber sherry consommé - was delicious, and the crème brulee was a nice finish.

The service was good overall, though dining later on Sunday night I sensed my waiter was ready to wrap up and head home. He was helpful in finding us some aperitifs that suited our tastes, but then he took our food order without our wine order and I had to ask for the wine list back. While I was waiting for a refill of my coffee, he was folding napkins behind me. I actually liked his style other than these missteps.

There was also a couple that was quite overzealous in their embrace of the romantic atmosphere. We were close to asking them to get a room. But we can hardly hold that against the restaurant.

I would definitely enjoy eating here again.
author: David Y.

description: Jazz was very good.  It was restaurant week, a Thursday night.  The 1st bottle of wine we ordered "sorry, we are out."  Two in our party ordered the restaurant week tasting special.  The trout on the special "sorry we are out."  So they replaced it with the fish of the day.  The creme brule "sorry we are out."  And this was a 6:30 dinner.  I had the steak frites.  Frites were nothing special and steak was tough.  2nd star for the jazz.
author: Ralph E.

description:
We had decided to spend our anniversary in San Francisco, and had made reservations for Café Claude on Open Table. Our reservation was for 7:45 pm. We arrived at 7:44 pm and were seated by 7:45... Brilliant ! !
Our waiter was very informative, open and a good conversationalist. The music was delightful, reminding us of our honeymoon in Paris. We had escargot as an appetizer and they were delightful. My wife had the Trout and I the Coq au Vin. My food was wonderful, the meat falling off the bone and very tasty. The trout was fantastic as well. We decided to go try somewhere else to have dessert, and after we declined the dessert options to the waiter, he brought us a chocolate soufflé to celebrate our anniversary. Kudos to Café Claude and to Open Table for their communication. Amazing.
author: Frank S.

description: Yummy food, a little pricey but it's worth it if you want to treat yourself. The service is great and there is live music on Friday.
author: Raquel C.

description:
Most -amazing- french food, great experience -  I took my girlfriend here for our 2nd year anniversary, she had SUCH an amazing time. We got the escargot, beef tartare (SO good - get it spicy), and some amazing chicken dish to split. And of course, quite a few scotch whiskeys. We'll def. be back here for more again some day.

Fore warning, it'll cost ya a pretty penny. ;)
author: Ashley F.

description:
My boyfriend took me to Cafe Claude for my birthday this year... it's a cute little French restaurant with a live jazz band near the bar (the music is not intrusive to diners). Some things to note:

1. The food is delicious and rich. Definitely recommend coq au vin and escargots (they come with a puff pastry on top!)

2. The wait staff is snotty.... it's just like you're in Paris. They'll speak to you in French (even though they KNOW you have no idea what they're saying) and they'll pretend not to understand when you order something in the incorrect accent. Our waitress even got our desert order wrong, but we just rolled with it because all the food is good.

3. Fancy atmosphere: great place to go for a fancy meal or date and it's not cost prohibitive. It was about $100 for the two of us, and we got an appetizer, glasses of wine and two entrees.
author: Kate B.

description:
I expected so much more from this place and from all the yelp reviews! We tried Cafe Claude for dinner and we were both utterly disappointed.

A glimpse of our meal:

Pumpkin bisque - very thin soup, I also thought the cookie was too sweet
Macaroni - decent, but not worth it.
Steak tartare - I mean as far as a tartare goes, it was okay. But nothing special.
Bread - not fresh or hot. It's a French restaurant. I expect good bread!
French fries - the one thing I thought wouldnt be ruined. But meh, oversalted to the max!

Overall, the service was excellent. Hence, two stars. The wine was also good. But with their reputation and all of the reviews, I expected much much more.

Bathrooms - out the black doors to the right...uhh not very nice. But they were clean. Only one bathroom too, so expect a wait if its busy
author: Logan S.

description:
Just had an amazing lunch here.  We ordered the escargot, steak tartare, charcuterie, green beans & the flour less chocolate cake.  All of which were amazing -- the service was great as well.  

My favorite thing about this place is its location.  Off the beaten path down a quiet alley.  They had a covered patio and the inside was perfectly decorated.  

Definitely coming here again.
author: Kyla G.

description: I was the group coordinator for a 21-person dinner. Michelle and Mimi did an amazing job in taking care of our group! We had a wonderfully coursed menu for a very reasonable price. The Coq Au Vin was absolutely astounding! As an aspiring restaurateur group, Michelle shared her experience and history of the restaurant with us. The next time we are in the city, we'll be sure to try to catch the live jazz music!
author: Frederick V.

description:
This restaurant is hidden in a small alley. I was staying around the area for a conference and it was my brother's birthday. I wanted to find some place good and not extremely pricey. This place was perfect!

I ordered everything that yelp recommended:

Wine: 
Russian River Valley 2009 Pinot Noir Bottle - Excellent!

Appetizer (Petits Plats): 
Escargot en Croute - This comes on a hot plate with 5 balls with garlic and butter surrounding it. Very delicious

Plats: 
Steak Tartare (large) - The waiter mixes everything in front of you and again it was orgasmic

Coq Au Vin - A chicken thats cooked in some awesome sauce and the meat melts right off the bone

Side Dish (Petites Assiettes): 
Pommes Frites - They have skinny fries that dipped in this spicy sauce which was excellent.

Dessert: 
Chocolate Tiramisu - Delicious!

Total cost was $141 and it was well worth it.

The only reason I gave it 4 instead of 5 was because I asked for the cake to have a candle and say Happy Birthday. This didn't happen.
author: JF K.

description: The waiter served us overnight hard sourdough.  In a real french bistro, we will be having french baguette instead. I ordered the Lorraine quiche with salad on the side. The salad was way too much oil, too wet for to my liking. The quiche was light not too dense, which was alright. The escargot as a starter which was good. The escargots here are small compare to the once in France which are much bigger. The background music was loud. I had to shout to my partner across the table.
author: Wendy L.

description:
I like small places with a select menu where each dish is well prepared. Cafe Claude fits my tastes. We went on a Wed night for dinner and everything was great!  For appetizer we had the nicoise which was very flavorful and plenty for 2 to share.  Our guest had the cold pea soup and frisee and said they were delicious.  

My entree was the rabbit special for Wed over grits and greens.  Fantastic and not dried at all.  Good portions as bistros should be.  My wife had the porc and it was cooked just right.  Our guests had the canard and coq au vin.  They ate it all and said it was great.  None of the dishes were hey on the sauce which I prefer.

For dessert we ordered the creme brulee and mousse chocolat.  Both were good.

The service was well timed and just right, down to the wine service and water refills.  We never felt rushed, even after the check was taken care of as we sat and talked a little longer with old friends.

Atmosphere is very quaint with both indoor and outdoor seating.  We sat indoors.  Outdoor was nice too with the alley view well obstructed by the awning making for an intimate space.

Only wish is for a better selection of scotch. All were single barrel. It would be nice to have had a selection with a second maturation in port or madeira casks.

Good tip on their website to park at the Sutter Stockton garage.  It's reasonably cheap and a convenient 2 block walk downhill (uphill on the return trip to work off the full meal).
author: P.Y. H.

description: Great food and service.  Authentic French food!!  We had escargot, coq Au vin and duck.  They were all great.
author: H M.

description:
Beef tartar and short ribs with Tannat half bottle of wine 
we left ever so happy! this will be happy spot!
author: Der Maibaum L.

description: So we made a reservation here because seared foie gras is standard on the menu. Our waitress told us that there wasn't any available because she had enthusiastically "sold it all last night". I informed her of our disappointment, since that was our motive for dining with them. Big mistake. Super snippy from that point on. Food was fine but be advised that tables are tiny and when your salad plate arrives they remove your bread plate because there isn't room for both.
author: Rebecca W.

description:
I have never been much of a fan of French food until i started going to Cafe Claude!  Their food is just too good.

The location is a bit tricky because it is in an alley off Sutter Street called Claude Lane.  I recommend parking at the Sutter/Stockton Garage or the White House Garage.  Other than that, the food is excellent and the cozy atmosphere is very cute! I highly recommend the Chevre Salad and the Corn soup. The corn soup has pesto in it as well...it is amazing. Their french fries have a really good dipping sauce which is also worth a try! :)
author: Abbey B.

description:
Cafe Claude reminded me of the places you find in Rome or Paris-- the kind of delicious eatery hidden within an alley.  Lit up with a few hanging lights and heated lamps, it is one of those places where if you didn't know where it was, you probably won't see it.  Actually, come to think of it, I probably can't even give you directions to where it is because it's on a street, but not really a street?  It's technically an alley of sorts.

The service was nice, the heat lamps worked great, and the outdoor experience made it wonderful.  And here are some snippets of the food:

We had a pork filet with honey and white balsamic vinegar.  I'm not a huge fan of something sour like balsamic and not a fan of sweet pork-- but this was very nicely done as the dish was distinctly savory with a hint of sweetness.

We also had a roasted lamb sirloin with garlic, bread crumbs and emergo beans.  The lamb was sliced into large thin slices that gave it a nice roast beef texture.  Very tender, not too gamey and the garlic bread crumbs mixed with the beans gave it a really nice side to go with the dish. 

Overall, I look forward to visiting the city again and take a little hidden walk to Cafe Claude.  The service was wonderful, the ambiance was perfect, and the food was well prepared as well.
author: Siao J.

description:
saturday night, party of 4, we made reservations for 7:30p.
the place is in an alley and kind of hard to find, but i figure this is part of the adventure.  besides, it's worth finding!

live jazz singer and she was amazing.  
very dark, but that's the ambience they're going for.
excellent service.  

pate & cheese: sampler.  we asked the server to choose and she chose well.  we loved it all.  
escargot - needs more butter and garlic, but it was well cooked, topped with a little puff pastry.
steak tartare: this was the best appetizer.  the steak was tender and very well spiced.  they make it for you right at the table so that's kinda neat.  
french onion soup - not that special.  which is kinda crazy, since it's an upscale french restaurant, so i was surprised.  i'd recommend skipping it and saving room for the other goodness.  

devil's kiss - get this drink.  and i'm not a big drinker but this was a great cocktail.  light, refreshing, not overwhelming.  

trout with roasted cauliflower: by far, the best presentation of all our dishes.  it came out splayed in half with cauliflower, raisins and almonds bursting out of it.  and it was perfectly cooked.  it does come entirely on the bone, so if you're not good or patient at that kind of thing, then this dish is not for you.
pork chops: great flavor, not overcooked (like pork usually is).  adding apples and butter beans is a genius move.  
coq au vin: i know it says "au vin" in the name but it seemed really heavy on the wine. haha.  it was still good, and the chicken was only a little firm, but still good overall.    
duck confit: great flavor, also a little firmer than i would have preferred but good stuff.  normally not a fan of lentils but they were really soft and flavorful.  

generous portions of everything, even if it's a french place.  

soft chocolate cake: this was seriously amazing.  it's a very very very very decadent cake and comes with creme anglaise, so be prepared for a party to explode in your mouth. 
apple tart: my friends liked it and ate it all before i tried any.  but it's ok, b/c i was licking soft chocolate cake off my face.  

overall, a great experience, definitely worth trying.  while some of the food was a miss, the ambience/atmosphere is still fun.
author: Jamie E.

description:
You can't get much more authentic than this Parisian-style bistro -it felt as though the entire interior was shipped over from France.  

My lunch of steak Kobe tartare with a croque monsieur was absolutely delicious.

I can't wait to return for the dinner..
Coq au Vin, with the accompanying Jazz.  MMM yes!
author: Ty T.

description: Came here for an after dinner drink recently, and it was quite a nice little place.  Very "French-ish" without being Parisian snobbish. (Although when I was in Paris I only got snobbery when I was at a very high end dress shop...probably due to my casual walking attire!) I digress.  Nice little Wine menu and sophisticated cocktails...forget the maraschino in the Manhattan...they have a special Cherry. Lovely alley closed to traffic allows for seating outside.  I would like to get back here for an early dinner before the chill rolls in.
author: Kai F.

description: Came here on a Saturday night. Live music, good food and great ambience.
author: Karishma K.

description: Rude hostess. A very nice waiter who went home half way through the meal. I had to get up and LOOK for a waiter to finish our meal. Steak that was tough as a boot. No idea why this place has a good rating.
author: Tony S.

description: The Croque Madame is as good as it gets: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/cafe-claude-san-francisco?select=YwwFAVJ_tKbOEaYXUCN7Pw#YwwFAVJ_tKbOEaYXUCN7Pw
author: Scott F.

description:
We stopped at Cafe Claude tonight for dinner, and what an incredibly lovely experience it was. We were a little early for a table so we had a delightful wine at the bar suggested by Derek, the bartender, we explained that it was my birthday. He is the most attentive bartender I've seen, and I am a musician making my living in bars, so I know!
We were seated promptly, and had a most exquisite french dinner! The service, atmosphere, music, food all fantastic. Then we ordered coffee, and we received two beautiful birthday deserts, compliments of Derek. This is such a classy, pampered experience, live jazz music most nights, a most attentive staff and amazing food, take yourself out, it's worth it!
author: roberta d.

description:
Bottom Line - We didn't think that the food here reflected the average 4 star-rating on Yelp! I thought the quality of the food was just A-OK (3 stars) at most.  I would definitely not wait in queue to eat here next time.

I came on Tuesday, 24 May 2011 for dinner with a friend. We made reservations; however, did not need them.  We ordered the following:

French Onion Soup ($8.00 x2) - I was so underwhelmed by this soup.  I wanted to return it, but was too lazy and didn't want to offend anyone. I would not order this again, and I suggest you avoid it yourself. 

Pommes Frites ($6.00) - We ordered this as a side. They were actually not bad. I enjoyed them.

Seafood Stew ($23.00) - My friend ordered this and said something was off about it.  I didn't have a taste, but he said he'd avoid this if he ever came back. 

Grilled Trout ($21.00) - I ordered the grilled trout... the fish was a bit over-cooked, so it was on the dry side.  Otherwise, the flavours were fine. 

Along with a glass of wine ($10.00) and a bottle of Badoit sparkling water ($7.00), our bill came to $83.00 + 8.21 tax + 3.32 Healthy SF tax + 20.00 tip = $114.53 total for the two of us.

Service was okay.. our server came across as cocky (but I'm sure he didn't mean it that way). Speaking only for the food... I would not come back and would opt to check out other restaurants next time (but would not cringe if I absolutely had to come back).
author: Rick S.

description:
Love the location, atmosphere, staff and the jazz band. Was very unimpressed with the food overall. Escargo: lacked flavor and were dry. Foia Gras: cold. Tartar: excluding some heat flavorless. Duck Confit: good

We have had wonderful meals in the past and were so disappointed. Had a great evening out in spite of.
author: Anne T.

description:
4.5 stars!

I'm so glad that I got turned down at Bouche and ended up here where we just randomly decided to walk to. We had to "settle" with this place, but you never know when you're going to stumble upon something you might really love. 

Often times at French restaurants, my brother and I get weird looks or we'd get seated in areas where we aren't seen, like a tucked away room with no one else in it.  Discrimination is no fun, but we got none of that here!  Is it 'cause I'm young n' I'm Black n' my hats real low? Do I look like a mind reader sir? I don't know. 

The waitress was super nice and she speaks French, definitely legit. She recommended that I get the Bouillabaisse as it was the special of the day (Thursdays). I've been meaning to try Bouillabaisse for a long long time now and sadly, the other entrees they offer didn't seem very appealing so this was a pretty easy choice. Well...IT WAS THE MOST AMAZING SOUP/STEW/BROTH/WHATEVER HANDS DOWN. The Mussels that came with it were just alright, they were small, but tasty. The Rockfish Fillet was just alright too, but it went well with the flavorful stew. The bread they had laying underneath was simply perfect, it soaked in everything and became this concentrated flavorful bread brick of good eats! I have no idea what I just said, but this dish has got me speaking jibberish! Get it if you show up on a Thursday!

I also tried the Steak Tartare and it was pretty good. It's mixed with a few items: capers, shallots, anchovies, and horseradish. I might pass on it next time though, but it was definitely worth trying. The Faux Filet was not bad at all, but let's just say my brother fell in love with my dish and not his.

Our server was attractive, speaks French, and was polite and not at all giving us the cold shoulder like we have now come to expect at these types of places. Yeuh.

Give this place a chance, it's less pretentious than others and you don't leave starving hahahaha.
author: Elvin C.

description: This restaurant is nestled in an alley on Claude street.   Very sweet place.  My husband took me for our anniversary and we had a pleasant time.  Our starter was the escargot and it was delicious. Our soups were quite tasty. I believe the celery soup was much more tastier than their signature onion soup.  The roasted chicken tasted fine but not phenomenal.  My husband ordered the flank steak, according to him it was very good, but he mentioned there was no originality.  Now for dessert the chocolate cake and creme brûlée was sooo delicious!!! They also had a live jazz band that started playing at 7:30 until 10:30.  Quite enjoyable.
author: Yesenia L.

description:
Disappointed :(

I was visiting San Francisco for my big 3-0. There was no other way I wanted to spend my birthday than in my favorite city, eating French food and listening to live jazz. I found the perfect spot. I made reservations for 8:00 p.m. because the live music begins at 7:30 p.m. and ends at 10:00 p.m. I planned to spend the whole evening there.

We walked there from our hotel. It was tucked in a cool alley with some other cool-looking bars/restaurants. I liked the outdoor eating area. The place was small but packed and happenin' which was a good sign. The lighting was low, moody, and romantic. It was an awkward layout though and a bit cramped.

I got there exactly at 8:00 and our table wasn't ready :( It seemed as though they gave it to the two girls in line in front of us. And it was a nice table by a window facing the alley activity. I didn't verify, I just assumed and it bothered me a little. We had to wait about 15 minutes to get a table, way in the back by the bathroom...

The food was OK. I had the Truite Amandine. It was pretty tasty. It was a complete trout fish, split open (butterfly style) with the bones removed. It had good flavor with an interesting mix of small cauliflower, almonds, capers, and raisins in a Meunière (brown butter) sauce. It was very good. The meat was soft and I didn't find any bones. Though it was not filling at all. That's why the French are so thin! lol My friend had the velouté (garlic and cauliflower soup) and the Porc (sliced pork chop with sweet mustard jus and onions.) Aside from cuisine, the French are also known for their pastries. For dessert we split an apple tart which was not fresh and tasted like those packaged pastries from the gas station. 

My biggest gripes are that initially our reserved table wasn't ready and we were seated by the bathroom way in the back and the fact that the band took their break during my ENTIRE meal. It was a real bummer. Practically the whole time I listened to nothing or non-jazz music on the house speakers. We ended up leaving after we ate and of course, the band came back but I just wanted to return to the hotel and crash for the night. 

I figured the meal and drinks would be expensive because 1.) It's French food, 2.) It's San Francisco, and 3.) I was also paying for live music. But overall the experience was "meh" and not worth the $112 I spent.
author: Catalina V.

description:
Cafe Claude is my guilty pleasure.  No it isn't the hippest place, no they don't have pork belly on the menu, and yes your foodie friends will give you that "I've never heard of it so it's probably not that cool" look when you tell them where you ate.  

BUT, every time I step in this place I'm happy.  No attitude, 1980s NYC french bistro vibe, live jazz, great lighting, lively atmosphere, good wine, and tasty dishes - in a sea of artisan foodiness, it's a welcomed respite.  

And yes, parents love this place.
author: Em S.

description:
Honestly dont see where all the hype is coming from...i have had way better french food. It must be the patio - very pleasant, oh and the service is decent. 
I ordered chilled pea soup and it was only ok. The peas were tasteless/bland. The starter bread was cold and felt like it was a day old bread not freshly made. The butter was good though! For the main course I had the cod with mussels in a broth...also on the blandish side...everything just lacked color and taste. Maybe I ordered all the wrong things. I shouldve gone for the steak tartAre - that looked finger lickin good! 
Anyway i had the hopes of writing about this place in my blog but i dont think i will. I think SF has much better to offer. 
Ce la vie!
author: Galina M.

description:
I surprised my husband with a date night here last Friday. Right away, we fell in love with the ambiance. Claude Lane, the alley street where it's located is such a hip spot. I made reservations for 6:15pm. We arrived around 6:00 and we were seated immediately.
