Its oh So Very French here and that's a good thing.  Shared a cassoulet with my BFF and it was rich, intensley flavored, simple and adorable in its little iron serving dish. Started with a terrific Chevre salad with apples and crunchy sweet walnuts.

The service is efficient. Our food and wine were whisked on and off the table quickly-maybe too quickly but why complain about such things? I appreciate the classic French waiter uniforms with the long apron. Everything about it screams, "You're sitting in a Bistro in Paris!"

The harsh restroom lighting in the rear will brutally slap the romance out of you but its otherwise charming. I will return with snobby Francophiles and impress the heck out of them.
author: East West Coast Girl C.

description:
Had dinner with a friend on a Tuesday night. Place was pretty empty.

French Onion Soup was average.

Coq Au Vin was good, but not very filling.
author: Andrey L.

description: This was my first visit to Cafe Claude and didn't know what to expect, but was pleasantly surprised.  My date and I walked in and were greeted by the very pleasant hostess who seated us immediately.  Our waitress, Elam was very nice and she suggested the wine flight, which was wonderful and a very good deal.  We ordered the Escargots en Croute, which were delicious.  They were served in an Escargots plate with individual groves for the Escargots.  We also ordered the pate, yummy!  The Coq au Vin was wonderful!  We loved this wonderful restaurant!
author: Vida K.

description: Everything was good but nothing was memorable. After spending a week in Montreal the serving of foie was laughable. A hint of foie with some toast points. Not enough for the price point but still well delivered on taste. The main on the prix fixe was yummy. Well cooked beef, tender, with a great balance of salty and richly wine "sweet".
author: leyla a.

description:
Came here yesterday and thoroughly enjoyed the experience.  We made reservations for 8 people and our host graciously accommodated a ninth person.  She also spoke French (!) and painstakingly split our bill 9 ways with amazing memory, remembering what each of us had ordered.  

The food was delicious and the live jazz floating to our table out on the patio was not too loud for conversation. I would highly recommend making reservations in advance though.
author: Alethia M.

description:
Arrived ~10 min early for 8pm reservation. Full dining room on a cold and rainy Saturday evening in SF... Sipped refreshing la Gitane while waiting to be seated (seated ~8:15pm). The drink menu is missing "é" at the end of words for some reason, but the food menu is fine. 

I can die happy and fat now after eating their macaroni granité. :-) 

Didn't care much for the selection of charcuterie (hard to find really good charcuterie in the US, so no surprise there). 

Other foods we had include salade Niçoise, tartare de thon rouge, truite, porc, coq au vin, filet mignon, et crème brulée. All were very tasty and we came out happy.
author: j. k.

description: A really nice relaxed ambiance. An authentic French server it seemed. Great food, awesome service, fair prices. Jealousy looking at the mac and cheese at the table next to me.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Excellent French restaurant. I have been there many times and I was always very pleased with my food.

I can recommend you their coq au vin and their Moelleux au chocolat! Delicious!
The ambiance is also very nice. I particularly enjoy their outdoor patio and their live Jazz band.
author: caroline s.

description:
We had a large dinner party of guest from all over and I was charged with arranging dinner since half the group was from out of town.  I tired making reservations at various places but there was all these freaking rules, like signing a contract and putting down half the deposit, a group our side needing a private room and we wouldn't be able to dine until 8:00pm.  UGH.  But when I called Cafe Claude, they were very nice about making sure they could accommodate our group, and were very polite after I had to change the date and time from the original reservation.  They asked if we could pre-order our food, which wouldn't work out too well with our group and agreed to allow us to order off the menu.

We got seated and half the group disappeared to go shopping, but the very sweet waiter was accommodating and took the drink orders for the few of us that were at the table.  We were still waiting for other to arrive from the airport so we settled in with our drinks and ordered appetizers.  We got the Fromage (cheese plate) , Charcuterie (cured meats) and Assitte de 3 Pates (assorted pate) to share.  We really enjoyed all the appetizers.

Now came time to order the food.  Half the table ordered the special of the night, Florida prawns on a bed of polenta.  They were the biggest prawns I have ever seen, sweet and delicate.  The dish blew us away.  I didn't take note of what other people ordered, but everyone was more than pleased with their food.   Their Pommes Frites was served with a good spicy mustard, and the French green beans and sauteed spinach was well done.

 For Dessert, we shared the apple tart and creme brulee.  I love their creme brulee, light and not too sweet.
author: Twist' D.

description:
Yelp ratings have failed me again. 

Food: Bread appears to be Acme Pan Epi from yesterday. I had the porc. I really liked the crab apples and brussels sprouts that came with it. The porc was marinated in cider so it was sweet as expected, but the mustard-y sauce was sweet too, so it didn't provide contrast. However, it was cooked properly and I did enjoy it, but it could have been more savory. My date's coq au vin was so-so. 

Service: Sloooooooooooooow. The staff seemed distracted - it took 5 mins for them to even get us water and tell us the specials. They were quick with the bill after we refused the prospect of dessert though.

Ambiance: Very very loud. About as loud as a dim sum restaurant on a Saturday. Tables were a bit squished but I've come to expect that from any place in the city. I don't think it was particularly romantic. 

Is it too much to expect real service and thoughtful food? At this rate I'm just going to have to go to Berkeley every time I want a decent night out. I will not come back again.
author: Greg M.

description: Delicious! Cute atmosphere and charming staff who spoke French with us the whole time. There was a jazz group that included Christmas songs that was very good. The food was yummy, including the mushroom soup and warm chèvre salad. My mom had the best coq au vin ever! And the chocolate mousse to end was superb!
author: Cathleen R.

description:
A little slice of the EU in a tiny little alley downtown.  This place, particularly it's locale and exterior evoke memories of long holiday lunches abroad.

On the day I'd arranged to meet an acquaintance I'd not see in some time for lunch I walked in a few circles before finding the tiny alley-way I'd embarrassingly passed at least twice trying to locate it.  See, this is just it...the surrounding streets of San Fran bustle and teem with activity...folks rushing here and there...then you turn down Claude Lane and it's like you arrived on your Parisian holiday without having to take an airplane!

2 Vespas parked in front of the covered outdoor seating reminded me of many a trattoria in Rome. 

Nicoise salad for two, wine for one (me) - my friend was on her work lunch break so I enjoyed the delicious Sancerre...lingering for a while after my dining partner departed I really got to feel like I was on holiday!

I would like to go back and visit during the dinner hour to catch the evening vibe.  They offer Jazz music at night which I can only imagine adds to the ambience.

Service was attentive and swift - just what you want at lunch.  Perfect!
author: Lisa D.

description: One of my favorite places in all of San Francisco this beautiful restaurant is tucked away in a small alley it has a great ambiance amazing food great specials and the desserts are to die for.  When in San Francisco make sure you try this restaurant out because it's just a great experience.
author: Shawn L.

description:
One of the better French restaurants. I may have been there on a good night, as both the food and service were excellent. Live jazz in the background was quite good, although the noise level at times competed with the music. We did not mind that the food arrived slowly, as we enjoyed the jazz. The waiter apologized several times and did not charge us for our double espresso. The extended meal combined with music and conversation reminded me of dining over several hours at meals I had while in France. They actually serve Absinthe which the local restaurant of that name does not.

Correction-Apparently the restaurant Absinthe does now serve that drink 3-14-15
author: BS M.

description:
Stopped in for  lunch.  Very impressed with the ambiance and the decor.  Tucked away on Claude Lane near Bush @ Kearney, you feel as if you are stumbling upon a secret enclave of French dining. The curved bar is just downright beautiful.
Reservations were necessary for a workday lunch.
Having never been to Paris, I will refrain from commenting on the authenticity of the parisian cafe dining experience here.  However, I can tell you that the service was good, effective, and non-intrusive.  This is just a very cozy place, good for intimate dining or business lunch.  Food is well prepared and served fairly promptly.  Can't go wrong with any of the fish dishes.  I had the last of the Ahi Tuna specials of the day and....oh my god.....culinary heaven.  
Honestly, for the money, this is one of the best bets around.  I'm definitely going back for the live music, and for future lunches.

4.5 total

Food: 4.5
Value: 4
Service: 4.5
Ambiance: 4.5
author: Ethan R.

description: The place is very nice, well served, food is original and skillfully done, wine list is good. I have to say that my Yelp reservation was not in their system at all two days after it was confirmed to me by mail. They dealt with the issue very nicely but I am still left with a feeling of uncertainty towards future Yelp reservations
author: Arturo C.

description: Excellent service from actual French people, as my friend, who's also French, proudly proclaimed. The Prix Fixe lunch pleased her French sensibilities enormously, and the Toulouse cocktail (ask for it extra cold) pleased my craft cocktail-tune tastebuds sufficiently as well. I enjoyed my croque Madame, but the lentils with the white sausage were by far the best thing we had. After a fail at Rouge et Blanc and and a huge fail at Cafe de la Presse, Cafe Claude makes the other two look like chumps.
author: Matthew M.

description: Holiday mother daughter dinner and it was fabulous.  We were headed elsewhere from shopping in Union Square when a very charming Southern gentleman overheard our conversation and insisted that me and the twins go to Cafe Claude--his favorite restaurant in the City to cap off our SF shopping day. He was right, the restaurant was intimate yet lively, engaging and very San Francisco.  We had charcuterie of cheese and cured meats, the steak frites, coq au vin and French soup and finished up with the Vahlrona mousse. The steak (perfect char, seasoning and medium rare) and frites were the biggest hit, but the coq au vin was a close second (I rarely order chicken in restaurants, but this was very good), we would order both again and the charcuterie.  It was the perfect conclusion to a fun festive day, and fun making memories with my daughters!
author: Patty M.

description:
Never knew this place existed.  my buddy and I were just walking aimlessly through San Francisco trying to decide where to go, and accidentally saw a bunch of restaurants in an alley.      

They all looked great, but we decided to try Claude's and we where not disappointed.     The ambiance was great, the live music was terrific and the food was very tasty.    I did not give it 5 stars, only because when it comes to food, I reserve 5 stars for restaurants with food that blows me away.  They got close.     highly recommend it though
author: Sam S.

description:
Incroyable!!!
They had an amazing Steak Tartar made table side and everything was top notch.  Atmosphere was great, quiet.  Very classy!  I can't remember what else we ate but I do remember raving about it days after.  

Great place for a business dinner, date, or classy night out.
author: Allan H.

description: Love this place. Have been here 4-5 times. Always good. Service is professional. I'm finding that when I'm in SF, I want to eat here.
author: Kim W.

description:
Cafe Claude is one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. Food and service is top notch not to mention chic yet unpretentious decor. Location is also ideal -- in Union Square in a cute romantic alleyway. 

The cocktails, Escargot and the Apple salad were especially unforgettable. I would highly recommend it to anyone and would take out-of-town visitors to Cafe Claude for an awesome French dining experience in San Francisco :)
author: Joyce C.

description: Jazz adds some romance and liveliness to this local restaurant. Good food and great wine selection.
author: Anna Z.

description: First time for lunch but been here a few times for dinner in the past. Never disappointed. Cafe Claude is one of the better options in this area in between Union Square and the FiDi. Service is friendly and efficient and the ambiance is quite nice. The outdoor seating in the alley is a good option. Today I ordered the burger and it didn't disappoint. All the French classics are executed well. Solid choice every time.
author: Michael E.

description: I had an ultimate experience at this restaurant. With live jazz music and good French food you will have a wonderful night.
author: Bob D.

description:
I was concerned when I saw Cafe Claude. I have difficulty with steps and there was no sign, that I could see, that said there was an accessible entrance at the back. Yes, the outdoor seating is accessible, but I did not want to sit outside on a cold day. The staff could see I had difficulty but did not tell us about the accessible entrance. My first impression was that it was poky. The tables were far too close together for comfort. It felt like a bistro squashed into a cafe. 
The wait staff were pleasant, but not really professional. I'll let them off that one because they seemed sweetly shy. 
The menu was not interesting but the escargots were good. 
I wish I liked it better, but it clearly is popular with a younger set and if that is their target audience, ok, but it's not for this arthritic older lady.
author: Margit C.

description:
I had high expectations of Cafe Claude with its rating and number of Yelp reviews. Unfortunately our meal here fell short. I was in the mood for a nice juicy steak after a long day of shopping at Union Square. We originally cancelled our 7pm reservation thinking we wouldn't make it but we did and they gladly took us in anyway. 

The bread and salted butter were good but that's where it ended. We ordered the onion soup (all cheese, no broth), frisee salad (lardon was not crispy so it tasted very gamy). One entree that did stand out was the roast chicken. It was the perfect combination of crispy skin, juicy meat and light but flavorful broth. The filet mignon sounded promising but it was a disappointment (not properly seasoned and no crust from searing). The pommes frites I subbed for the gratin were good however. 

Service was a little slow but they only assigned one waitress for our entire section.

Not sure if we're coming back.
author: Bernadette A.

description:
I'm not a French cuisine aficionado but I do recognize quality, and I give Cafe Claude a thumbs up/gold star/smiley face for being absolutely satisfying.

The service:I've been here twice and and each time the service was exceptional. Hats off to Roberto and the hostess (didn't catch her name), they were very accommodating and checked up on us frequently, refilled water, returned with bread many times etc. The French accents added to the restaurant's authenticity.

The wine: exquisite selection and perfect pairing with the various dishes. Ask the server which wines are appropriate and he or she will guide you without trying to twist your arm into buying an unnecessarily expensive wine. 

The food: Something for everyone. I ordered the special for a Saturday lunch--a glass of Sauvignon blanc 2009 with a smoked salmon salad and a carrot-tomato soup (no cream). My girlfriend ordered a glass of rose wine with steak tartar and goose liver. The goose liver was a win and the steak tartar had various groupings of onions, cilantro, and other plants.However the coup de gras was sitting atop of the dish; a pour-ready raw quail egg waiting to cascade down the mountain of raw meat and make sure one realized it's possible to be classy and barbaric at the same time. My girlfriend said she felt like a monster eating all the raw food yet loving it so much.

The ambiance: tucked away in Claude Ln in the financial district this is easy access for bridge and tunnel crowd, as well as the locals. It's a 4-bloc-walk from the Muni/Bart station but only takes about ten minutes. On a good day, you could choose to eat outside under the nice awning and enjoy the fresh air of SF.

Bravo Cafe Claude, Bravo indeed.
author: James T.

description:
Impeccable French food! 
Fantastique et délicieux!
author: Deanna P.

description:
I've had lunch here with the firm a few times and it was always pretty good. Had dinner again recently by accident - not the first time something like that has happened to me - when I was really looking for Le Central.

Anyway, I ordered the coc au vin and my friend ordered the steak. Decent fare, nothing to really get excited about. I was craving a roasted chicken breast with mashed potatoes type of dish (cooked in that lovely french way) and was disappointed to find that the only chicken they had was the coq au vin. It's still good if that's what your palette is longing for. My friend's steak, on the other hand, was on the small side and barely took up 30% of the plate. I could only assume that it wasn't very filling.
author: Jenny T.

description: Not worth the money. Its rated high and in FiDi so I thought it would be an easy place to stop by for a nice dinner. The food leaves much to be desired. I would recommend The Hidden Vine a short walk away with delicious food, wine, and a cool bocce ball court in a sleek downtown vibe.
author: Elena F.

description:
It's ok. For the price I wasn't too impressed.

The goods:
Affordable booze
Nice ambiance
Great service
Dessert was delicious

The bad:
The food was good not great, at $30 (without sides) a plate  I kinda want my socks blown off. Ordered a salad, green bean side, both things I could make at home just as good and I cook healthy (they have the advantage of butter).  My steak came out room temp which was disappointing, the sauce it was drizzled in was really nice though.

Would I go back? No way, with all the good eats in the city there are half a dozen french places I would rather frequent.
author: Chris M.

description:
This is an almost, but not quite, 4 star rating. None of the dishes were standout or orgasmic.  Overall, everything was just good, but I'm not pining away for anything I had there, so 3 stars seems most appropriate. 

The French Onion Soup was delicious. Not too salty. 

We had 2 pates: Campagne Black Pepper and Truffle Mousse. I liked the campagne more because it had a stronger, more robust flavor, but it was more on the dry side, so it crumbled a bit when I tried to spread it on the cracker. The truffle mouse was smooth and glided across the bread nicely. It had a nice delicate flavoring, but I still preferred the campagne. 

As Cafe Claude was the 4th stop of me and my friend, Angela W's hunt for the best beef tartare in town, we obviously ordered the steak tartare, which was better than the tartare at Gamine or Chez Papa Resto, but it didn't come anywhere near Bix . . . 

Pommes Frites fries were nothing exceptional. They were yummy, but it's pretty hard to screw up french fries. Well, I guess some places can screw it up when their fries get soggy before serving, so kudos for getting it to our table while still crunchy and hot! 

We also had their wax beans special were nice, but Angela W. loved them, so my ambivalence to them might be due to my slight aversion to vegetables. Butter lettuce salad was nice, but unexceptional. Plus, some mushroom pasta. 

Our server was very helpful, and checked on us with enough regularity for us to ask for extra condiments, crackers, and cocktails, but not so much that he almost became another dinner companion. 

The bartender, however, might need to take a refresher course on making drinks. We had a clear view of the bar from our seats, and could tell there were no other orders, but ours . . . and it still took FOREVER for him to make 2 simple cocktail concoctions. 

Total Bill after being stuffed to the brim and 2 cocktails each: $122.94 (not including tip).
author: Christina L.

description: I love Cafe Claude and have been there for lunch many, many times.  I usually get the mussels or the Nicoise salad.  The service is excellent and it is a beautiful restaurant.  Also, outdoor seating!
author: Tapedeck B.

description:
I ate in this place a little over two months ago as a 2nd date, of his selection.
We sat in that little booth in the corner, right by the window, kitty corner....our first kiss, I know...awwwwww! So awwwwwwwesome.

It was cute. What was better than cute is my date order me a glass of wine of a varietal I had never heard of, forget about tasting. It was Tannat Berthoumieu, a drier delicious French varietal, normally a blending grape. This impressed me because I found it to be confident and smart to go out on a limb and impress the girl who knows a little something about wine and food and all that jazz.

We ate a few things: Brussels sprouts, Quinoa salad, Pommes Frites, the kitchen even made me some spatzle that came as a side for one of the other dishes. 
This alone I would DEFINITELY return for...those little starchy thingys were perfectly cooked and sauteed up making them the star of my dinner. 

My date, who is now my beau (YUP), had the Coq Au Vin. Never liked the stuff and this did not change my mind. Still don't like it. Which is fine, because I didn't order it. Other people like it just fine and that's cool. More spatzle please!

I have to say the Tarte aux Pommes was a little on the smaller side, and there was no ice cream to be found...maybe it's just my arrogant American ways that I want my tart and Ice cream too. 

Oh well, four stars for charm, SPATZLE, a new wine experience and our first kiss. 
I'll say yippee-ye-ki-yeah to all of that that Cafe Claude has to offer.
author: Violet J.

description: This was a tasty meal. Out of everything we ate I like the French onion soup the best. It was perfect. Not too salty and just bursting with the right flavors. Yum yum. Will definitely be back.
author: Natasha Anna A.

description:
When the weather is cold and there are no outdoor seats, this place is definitely cozy.  The drink list is extensive and creative while the food menu is not.  What they do offer are traditional standbys done well.  Perfect for a FiDi workday power lunch with personality or an escape from Union Square madness during the weekend.

Soupe a l'oignon: A fancy name for French Onion Soup.  Nice crispy cheese layer with a savory broth tasting heavily of red wine.  Solidly ranks amid the better French Onion Soups out there.

Potato & Leek Soup: Reminded me of a warm vichyssoise.  There was some sort of oil drizzle on top, perhaps truffle oil?  Creamy and subtle, perfect for a chilly winter evening.

Steak Tartare: Boo for using flank instead of the better filet mignon.  Yay for delivering the plate unmixed allowing the patron to assemble the cornichons, capers, egg yolk, mustard, parsley, shallots, worcester sauce, tabasco and black pepper to taste.  Not the best (yes, that's you Bix or Harris) but a nice runner up for offering high user engagement. 

Truffle Mousse: You had me at truffle.  Chicken liver by itself is nice, but it totally becomes my favorite in the pâté plate with the addition of this wondrous tuber. 

Sauternes Mousse: Not as great as the truffle mousse, but I believe that goose liver is inherently richer and more sophisticated than chicken liver.  A nice contrast to the plate.

Pâté de Campagne: Seems like every other pork pâté I get at French restaurants.  A little fatty tasting so best doused in mustard.  Would have preferred them to use the unripened green peppercorn to the more common black peppercorn.
author: Adam B.

description:
Everything we had over here was amazing! The main course was great, appetizers even better!!! The service was good, there were attentive and friendly! Their wine selection was great as well.
For appetizers we had the escargots en croute & steak tartare and the Bone Maro all of which were amazing! Main course We had the Seafood Pasta of the day which was great, and the agneau which was good, but I think The Quail, Chiken or the Filet would have been a better choice compare to the agneau.
I have heard they have live music on the weekend, which should make the experience even better...
It will be back for more for sure!!!
author: Arash H.

description: This little gem was recommended to us and we are so happy we tried it!! They actually messed up our reservation but accommodated us anyway and were super nice and apologetic. The food was very unique and delicious! We had the goat cheese salad, corn bisque, and a baked chicken with mushrooms. Our server was very attentive and very helpful with choosing what to order. They had live jazz music which was nice in the background (not too loud or intrusive). This little place is kind of tucked away down an alley so if you don't know where it is you might miss it. Highly recommend!
author: Vanessa B.

description:
Almost a five, after repeats might be. My wife and I really enjoyed eating here, and the only reason it's not a 5 already is we generally like to go a few times, but living in Seattle, it's a little more challenging.

We're excited to return here on our next trip to San Francisco. Our server was fantastic (and was visiting Seattle soon, and was thrilled to let us ramble on about things to do, places to go, food to eat), the food was fantastic, and the warm June dining on the patio was delightful.
author: Marc S.

description:
After the glowing reviews, I had high hopes for cafe claude. The two stars given here are only for the atmosphere. The dimly lit ambiance and jazz music created a relaxing environment for our ladies dinner. Though on a personal taste level, the little statues of Eiffel towers everywhere seemed a bit much. 

Unfortunately, I was not able to enjoy my meal because of an increasing stomach ache which began shortly after eating one of our first appetizers, the escargot. The experience was only worsened by the slow service--after the first hour we still had not received our entrees. I'm sure the pain has colored my judgment of the coq au vin but it was very heavy and oversalted. I doubt I will return to this establishment.
author: Christina L.

description: Lunch with girlfriends and we were all happy.  The service is fast but not rushed. The fig appetizer was delicious!  I had the quiche and it was very good. A little too much dressing on the salad, though. One friend had the trout and she loved it. The other had the vegetarian pasta special and also liked it very much. The bread is boring....basic French bread, but I guess that's typical.
author: Veronika G.

description:
Honestly, they have the best dessert ever!  I loe their Creme brulee!

Great place to visit and take friends who are visiting the city for the first time.  The people who work their are also very friendly and easy to talk to!
author: Scott H.

description:
So, this was the place my parents settled on for one night of their trip because they heard it was a jazz club.  I tried to tell them otherwise, but they insisted.  And, they were disappointed.  The jazz was limited to a 2 piece band stuck in the corner between the bar and the door.  Once inside the restaurant, you could barely hear them.

And, things didn't get much better from there.  First, our table was super crooked and when we pointed it out to the waiter, he basically said it would have been such a hassle to try to fix it, since the table was already set.  So, we just left it, but it was really weird.

I was excited to try the spring pea soup, which is one of my favorites.  But, it was weird.  It tasted like peanuts.  The pate was also just okay, but they probably don't even make it on site.  The only thing that earned them 2 stars was the steak tartare.  It was excellent.  It's mixed at the table and big enough for 2 people to easily share.  It was tasty and spicy and I loved it.   Too bad everything else was such a let down, because I would like to have that again.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Cafe Claude was amazing!

As we turned down the alley, we were instantly transformed to being back in france. We started with the escargot and the pate with the black pepper, and a carafe of the Bordeaux. All were delicious, the escargot was not overly buttery like in some places i have had, it was nice with a pesto feel. 

For dinner i had the Gnocchi with corn, tomatoes, green beans and brown butter! Oh my gosh this was the best gnocchi i have ever had, and i order gnocchi everytime i see it on the menu. it wasnt a traditional gnocchi, it was much more soft and ooey gooey delicious.  it came with this great corn that was nice and crisp for the crunch and these little tomatoes that were so juicy when you bit into it that the whole bite was this tasty explosion in your mouth! My boyfriend got the steak, asparagus, and fingerling potatoes. he ordered it medium rare, and it was exactly that, not overdone like everywhere else. It had a nice red wine sauce i believe, but i only got one bite because he ate it too quickly to share!

For dessert we went with the creme brûlée, and the poire cognac, which is pear flavored. the creme brulee was just as it should be with soft center, nice and crispy top with a little dusting of powdered sugar, and the cognac went well with it. this was my first time having a cognac, but i sipped slow and actually quite enjoyed it. 

Everything here was an A++, especially the service. We were i think the last customers seated, and had a bit of a wait for our food, but the wine came out quickly, and we were not in a rush to eat anyways. our server was very apologetic, even where it was not needed, and she also shared with us that she is from bordeaux where our wine was from! The place is defenetly $$$ but well worth every penny spent! I will definatly come back next time i am in San fran!
author: Nicole H.

description: Wow. Great ambience, well priced wine, fantastic service and the mussels were a treat. But don't stop there, the chicken was incredibly juicy.
author: Martin C.

description:
The food: sampled four different plates and a desert.  Enjoyed all four: escargot, confit de canard, french onion soup, and some kind of a salad.  And yes, I realize the selection is very trite. However, these are the cornerstones and getting them right is very important. To that end, Cafe Claude succeeded, delivering a well prepared French meal. The wine list looked interesting, but I brought my own wine and was charged a $20 corkage fee.

The ambiance: it is in a small "alleyway" with outdoor, partially covered, seating available. Inside there is a small bar, and two seating areas. The cafe has a clean but well executed interior.  Further, seating is spaced as it would be in Europe - tight.  It can be intimate on a slower night, but a little hectic otherwise. On weekend nights there is a live band playing theme-appropriate music, not quiet Jazz, but laid back nonetheless.

Service: we were there on a busy night; service was attentive without being annoying. 
However, had to wait ten minutes or so when ordering apéritifs at the bar.
author: Oleg A.

description:
This place was by far the best place I've eaten at in a long time. And I just got from Napa Valley, so I've eaten at some decent places lately.

This place has been in San Francisco for 20 years, and some of the locals don't even know about it. It's a secret little Parisian restaurant with live jazz and great service. We went here because we missed our other reservations, and I'm so glad we did. I can't wait to come back to San Fran just to eat here again.

We started out with the steak tartare, which was prepared for us on a rolled out cart right by our table. Delicious. We also had escargot, which had tiny little puff pastry on top and was very good. We had the trio of pate, which isn't exactly my cup of tea, but my husband loved it. We split an entree of the gnocchi, which was PHENOMENAL. I couldn't stop making noises as I ate it. I wanted to get 10 orders to go and eat it in my hotel room. We finished with the dessert: the bread pudding was fantastic and the creme brulee was good. 

Our server was very knowledgeable and even helped us pick out a good bottle of wine for our meal. The jazz music and general ambiance was gave the place a very nice cozy and intimate feel. Very romantic place.
author: Naomi H.

description:
Delight: the steak tartare
Disappointment: the live Jazz band.  It was fair, but not great.

Overall I think this is more of a restaurant than Jazz/blues bar.
author: Kristen S.

description:
I'm not a foodie and I'm the first to admit it.  I'm too calorie-conscious and frugal.  That said, I did enjoy my nicoise salad quite a bit.  I wouldn't ever pay $18 for a salad (again, not a foodie) though.

Waitress had a great knowledge of the wine menu, which I appreciated.
author: Sona P.

description:
Very good food and a great atmosphere. I tried the braised rabbit and it was amazing.

First time having Rabbit and it was really, really, good.
author: Jay F.

description: Ehhhh everything we had was mediocre. Nothing terrible but nothing to write home about. So I won't. Better places to go.
author: K K.

description: I've always liked this place.  I used to live just a short walk away.  Good first date spot!  Nice ambiance.  Good food.  Good service.  Unfortunately, it was one of the first places I took my ex girlfriend and was the last place we ever went out together too before we separated.  I hope the place isn't cursed....But don't let my experience prevent you from going there...
author: Spidermonkey J.

description:
This was my first time eating French food and I must say, I am a total fan! Boyfriend took me here for a special date night and everything was amazing!! The setting was romantic and the server was very opinionated and knowledgeable. 

We ordered the "egg and bacon salad" to start. The poached egg and pork belly was INCREDIBLE. Although the greens were a little difficult to get into my mouth. :-/

Next was the escargot, it was actually really good! Maybe a little salty but still exceptional! 

Our entrees were so delicious! I ordered the lamb (rare) and boyfriend ordered the cauq au vin (chicken). Everything was amazing and my lamb was perfection! 

Can't wait to go back again!
author: Jamie S.

description:
We were the first ones here at 5:30 pm, and I was starting to have second thoughts about this place, but it was totally swinging by 6:30 pm and the place was packed!  It was my first visit, and it won't be my last.  I wasn't going to get a salad but since everyone else in the group did, I quickly added on to the order.  We got beet salad and goat cheese salads.  The goat cheese salad came with bread and it looked good.  The beets were a little orange in color and looked like ahi tuna slices.  i was afraid to try them initially but it wasn't bad at all.  Golden beets are still my favorite, and now I can say I've had 3 kinds of beets - golden, red, and orange. 

I ordered the rainbow trout as my main course.  The moraccan lentils under it were too salty but the fish itself was good - moist and not too flakey, also fresh tasting.  I should have asked for a lemon slice to drizzle over it.   It would have enhanced the flavor.  I ended with an apple tart which was okay.  I've had better at trader joe's (sorry to say).  Maybe my taste buds aren't refined but at least you know that theirs was made and not store-bought. 

Service was excellent.  Someone in our party wasn't sure which wine to get - she was in between 2 choices, and the waiter not only made a recommendation but  brought out a little sample of each for her to try.  She went with his recommendation.  Not too many places will do that.  Also, since they have been in business for more than 20 years, they have perfected their menu and the waiter said he could wholeheartedly recommend every dish.  Other people in my group had roasted chicken, seared salmon, and the pasta special and they all thought the meal was good.  

meals come with bread but I'm watching my carb intake so I didn't try any this time.

It's in an alley and a little hard to find.  I wouldn't want to be in the alley too late in the night and glad we came early and that it is daylight savings time so it gets dark later.
author: Bebe W.

description:
Reading over the other reviews, I am thinking I must have gone on an off-night.  I had awful service, my soup was luke-warm, my waiter didn't know what kind of cheese was in the cheese plate (and then the cheese that arrived was not the cheese he had said would be served), my waiter put in a side of french fries instead of the fish entree that we had ordered, the fish was not so good, the Cannelloni appetizer was waaaay too much cheese (and trust me I love cheese....heck, I ordered the cheese plate) and luke-warm.  

Seriously, everything was luke-warm to the point that I thought about asking them to stick my dishes in the microwave.  Not cool.  

Nice ambiance and live music though.
author: Naomi P.

description:
Great location off the beaten path.  Sampled a few different items; fromage platter, salmon on bed of couscous, and their delicious version of mac n cheese (not really named that on the menu but essentially that's what is was).  Would have given it four stars but the salmon was surprisingly bland.  Everything else was worthwhile, although a bit pricey.

We were casual from a day in the city but you could also make it a romantic evening either inside or out.
author: Marcus G.

description: It was OK. I have had better French food in the city. The flat iron steak and the Quail were so average... The duck confit was better than those two. Overall average.
author: Siavash N.

description:
Disclaimer: I'm not a francophile, nor do I know anything in particular about French food. :-D

That said, on this particular Thursday night I started with a drink at the bar ("The Liberte") before our table was ready. Delicious and citrusy. $10 or $11 I think.

At our table, we started with the truffle mousse which had a nice flavor. I forget how much it was, but the portion was so small our group of 4 only had 1 or 2 bites each.

From there I had the trout with green lentils, which was ok. The trout had a nice flavor but was a little dry to me. The lentils were plentiful and cooked just right.

We had two desserts: mousse au chocolat and creme brûlée. Both were delicious.

Its location down Claude Alley is cute. You're downtown but feel away from all the hustle and bustle of Union Square and the touristas. 

In the end the bill came to $50 each after tip. Kind of expensive (in my opinion) but maybe that's how French restaurants are? I don't know.
author: Shawn C.

description: The most delicious croques monsieur I've had since Paris!  And a perfect Parisienne mood nestled a quaint little alley.  What more could you want?
author: Marina Y.

description: This place is absolutely wonderful.   We HIGHLY recommend the duck! It was perfectly cooked, perfectly paired, and perfectly portioned.  Everything comes in good sizes and you can really taste the artistry in their food.  Dishes are very well thought out and the service was excellent. We'll be back every time we go to San Francisco.
author: Courtney W.

description: Great French restaurant its tucked away in a alley, our hotel recommend that we should have lunch here!!! Great choice!! Definitely coming back :)
author: Kimberlee H.

description:
I went there this past Saturday with my girlfriend and proposed to her at the Cafe. So you can say it was a special night for the both of us. 

Did the Open Table reservation and they knew my intentions for the night. The staff was very accomodating and the service was top notch.

To the food. What can I say? It was exquisite. Everything was great.  The Tuna Tartar was delicious. The Escargot was wonderful. Putting a pastry on top of the Escargot in pesto sauce was neat. 

My girlfriend had the Lamb Chops. It was cooked to perfection. I had the Coq au vin. The flavors were just right. The wine did not overpower and the bits or bacon on top made it just right. The meat fell off the bone as advertised by the other Yelpers here. 

The portions were great. We're both eaters and we both did not feel that the dishes were too small. 

Got down on my knee after dinner and asked her to marry me in between a live session of Jazz. She said yes! Did I mention the staff was great with everything that went with it including free bubbly at the end.

Food, atmosphere, and service. All five stars in my book.
author: Chris Y.

description:
Honestly, if I had not gotten dessert this place would have earned 5 stars.

We started with the escargot in their cute tray and scrumptious butter and herb sauce with the most adorable little pastry puff on top!  Definitely a winner.  I had the trout which was out of this world!  so light and flavorful.  An excellent recommendation by the waitress.  My companion had the pork loin which was pink and juicy  with an amazing sauce.  

Here is the rub:  after three blissful dishes we order the Creme Brulee ( which we both have a weakness for).  It was disappointing.  The flavor was uninspired and a little lumpy.  And the top *sigh shakes head* that beautiful sugar crust that you crack with your spoon - it was rubbery and chewy.   I don't even know what they did to make it that way.

I'm sorry.  If you are a French restaurant and you can't make a good creme brulee.  Just stop.  you are doing it wrong.

anyway, the atmosphere was quiet and intimate.  I might go back; maybe, in a year or two when I have forgotten how sad that brulee made me.

For dinner: Aya says "Yea."

star deductions: 1 for the dessert itself and 1 for the principle.
author: Aya M.

description:
Oh, Cafe Claude...how I love you! The BF and I came here for Valentine's Day because it's a tried and true. Cafe Claude never fails us with their dependable service, stellar steak tartare, romantic French bistro atmosphere and live jazz..

Don't you change on me!
author: Veronica C.

description:
Cafe Claude is the kind of place you can trust. The food is delicious - consistently - and the ambience is like a little trip to France. 

Their onion soup is really good, as is their salmon. 

The place is darling, great for a date (and even a business lunch).
author: D Z.

description: Dinner was delicious as always,service usually great except for last night 1/3,the server Natasha was non existent we ordered appetizers which were delicious except Natasha never took our main course orders after our appetizer plates were picked up then she finally took our orders after that she was non-existent and the manager Amber was also very inattentive she walked and looked at my empty plate numerous times but was too busy talking to other employees to pick up anybody's plates oh she did come over to pick up the check when the credit card was out.To top it off it was unusually slow so it wasn't like either lady was busy.. Great food shitty service
author: Vlctor U.

description: We had a pretty good time here, the ambiance was good and service was good. As far as the food, the best parts were really the salad and desserts. I had the salad with goat cheese and my wife had the beet salad. We may have played it too safe with the roasted chicken and steak and frites for entrees.  Desserts were Crème Brule and the flourless chocolate cake, both excellent.
author: Zachary C.

description: Took my girlfriend here for her birthday and had a great experience. The food was excellent as was the service. Our waiter was very attentive and explained all of the dishes and his recommendations. Would definitely recommend.
author: Jeff L.

description: Had a wonderful New Years Eve date with my wife. The scallop course was a little weird with raw scallop with micro veggies with something very salty in it. Then our fabulous soup and salad came out. Unfortunately our next course, our savory filets came out one hour later due to a kitchen mix up. No worries as the maiter d picked up on this before I had a chance to comment with an offering of complimentary champaign. The live jazz along with our perfect 2nd and 3rd courses made for the perfect start of our New Year's eve celebration. I could not have experienced better service as out water and wine levels never went below half. It also helps to have great fresh bread and butter... a lot of them anyways while waiting for our delayed main course. Definitely a return is warranted for another special occasion when it comes up.
author: Mark M.

description:
Took a chance on Cafe Claude but given the excellent Yelpers information I felt I was making a well informed venture.

After attending a small amount of the Chinese New Year on Saturday night, my girl and I tried Cafe Claude and were not disappointed. I e-mailed the manager a week before requesting a reservation and even a reserved table since this was a special evening and she was more then happy to accommodate my request - very appreciated.

The Escargot En Croute (our snails were topped with a very delicate puff pastry with liberal amounts of garlic and butter (w/ plenty of bread for dipping) was delicious and I enjoyed the evening special of pasta a rock shrimp while she had the trout. Both dishes were nicely balanced proportions and the service was attentive and quite knowledgeable.

For example. My girl was looking for a not too sweet, not too dry white wine to go with the trout and the waitress made a recommendation. Turns out my girl loved it and the waitress did us the favor of writing down the name of the grape, vineyard and wine label, and even imparted the knowledge of the various tiers of the wine and how its character changes during the aging process. All in a 'for your information' tone and not the 'let me snub you with my massive amounts of vino knowledge'.

Between the special accommodation, light live jazz in the background, fresh cuisine and authentic 'Monsieur, Madame, Bon Appetit!' we left with a smile on our faces are are looking forward to our next visit.
author: Jason M.

description:
This is the highest of 5 stars, I believe, that I have ever had the privilege to give. 

Simply put; Cafe Claude is why you go out to eat. 

Start to finish, this is a class act. CLASS. You walk down the charming alley of Claude Lane and you just know. There's the Vespa parked in front, the heated covered outdoor seating, up the stairs and the atmosphere envelops you, the people are smiling, the aroma is intoxication, the full bar is a promise. 

We were seated near the window by a cute Parisian-esque girl, our server, cute as a button and friendly as could be told us the specials, was sweet as pie and even in a high-scale place like this, we were right at home. 
Signature cocktails are strong, and truly, not to be missed. Mine was the Aviator and let me tell you, it was the only drink I needed. 

Down to the heart of it, the food. I chose the Pork Tenderloin with green beans and a gorgeous, gorgeous honey buttery sauce that just fills the plate with luscious viscosity of appley-honey warm sauciness. The deciding factor for me was that this came with caramelized apples, Lordy, was I not disappointed. 

My Mom got the Crouque Monsieur with their legendary fries, BEST in show. Crispy thick, but very light bread, bechemel that was creamy and accented the beautiful ham perfectly. Cheese on top, of course and you're biting into all worlds of taste. The fries, these are everything you want them to be in a shoestring frie. Not at all greasy, never limp, just crisp with a bit of salt and puffy potato inner. 

Dessert - Creme Fraiche Cheesecake with rhubarb and strawberry compote, fresh strawberries and a sprig of mint. But it doesn't stop there. Bits of a flour, butter, brown sugar mixture that must be fried to make crunchy bits were strewn on the plate. It was like a crunchy delightful little crust to accompany the cake. And of the cheesecake. So very extremely light and lovely on your tongue. 

As we were devouring the last course - just like everything else - our server brought us each a complimentary glass of muscat, as a toast to it being my Mom's Birthday. Class. 

I can't say which is better - the service or the food. We fell in love with the first step across the threshold and I know we will be back. We even contemplated staying in the city just so we could come back for dinner. 

Tip: order what we did and share. You will not BELIEVE how amazing the Crouque Monsieur and the fries are when dipped in the sauce that comes with the tenderloin. Ridiculous.
author: Katie W.

description: I am french and this place was nice, la soupe à l'oignon was good but tartare was small and it's not a true french tartare so a little disappointed about that, and expensive for small part, but was good... And please don't buy cheese plate and charcuterie plate : it's not good french cheese and charcuterie moreover the price is a steal !
author: Cécile D.

description:
I had the apple brined pork - which was truly spectacular!

The vegetables and potatoes were great, and the waiter suggested a nice French Burgundy that paired well with the meal.
author: Brent M.

description:
This hidden gem is worth checking out in the alley for its French food and location for hanging out in Union Square.  Not only was the coq au vin tender with a thick and flavorful sauce, the cheese plate was a great way to start and/or end the meal.  There are a lot of delightful choices on the menu that will make you hungry again to try this place some other time.

The service is friend and helpful especially for suggestions and interesting tid bits of trivia.  Although street parking is tough, the garage on the corner of Sutter and Stockton is conveniently located nearby.
author: Jenny L.

description:
The food was ok, the jazz music which was playing live in there was too laud and not that exciting for a little restaurant though i like jazz and was one of the reason we went there!
The worse was that our waiter while serving us slipped and throw the wine all over of my husband back ,shirt and west where he was sitting! We went out on my birth day and had dressed up,can you imagine that,he was lucky to wear a black west otherwise we couldn't go no where after that and he was totally wet .
To make us happy all they did was offering us to pay for the dry cleaner after we do and give them the receipt .....
We didn't accept it, instead they take some price off our bill base on dry cleaner cost!
What do you think?Was that fair????
author: bette R.

description:
This place looked so promising. Came here for the live jazz music during dinner - totally my thing!

Then...
The good: environment. It's really a nice place
The disappointment: the food was just ok. Nothing special.

Probably won't come back. There are so many good French restaurants in the bay area, this one just isn't as good in my books.
author: Jessica W.

description:
I've been wanting to see some live jazz plus I had a cute date to meet there so what could go wrong right?  Coming from the east bay, what was supposed to be a 45 minute drive turned into an hour and 45 minute drive due to the silly amount traffic.  So I called ahead to inform Café Claude to please save my reservation because I am on my way and running late.  The girl tells me that she can only hold my table 15 minutes past reservation time.  So I find parking and run 5-6 blocks to the restaurant just in time so they don't give away my table only to find out I'm being seated outside where I won't be able to see the live band (which is the only reason why I picked Café Claude in the first place).  So I'm all sweaty, out of breath and pissed off for the trouble I went through to get here and I don't even get a table to see the band.  But I had a cute young lady meeting me there so had to conceal my disappointment, pull myself together and dry off from my Olympic sprint 6 blocks to save our reservation......

Pros:  I had the steak and it was excellent, cute set up in the alley, small tucked away place.

Cons:  You are not guaranteed a table indoors where the band is even if you do make a reservation 6 hours in advance, kinda pricy

Keep in mind that this was a Saturday night.  Weekdays may be different.
author: Joshua N.

description: The manager contacted me asking if I can remember which staff member was rude to us. She even offered a gift certificate to try and make it up. Which was very nice! But it's been a few days now and she has not responded back (it might be bc we were visitors to the area and would not be back for a while). Still a nice gesture.
author: Matt L.

description:
The food simple and deviously prepared. Me and my another half tried every item on their menu and never been disappointed . Excellent bar drinks and good wine selections. The service is always consistent and attentive. 

Excellent Friday night dinning spot in the Fi-Di of San Francisco.
author: Xela H.

description:
Cafe Claude is a dainty French restaurant nestled in an San Francisco alley. While the location is decently central relative to Union Square, the restaurant is also a quiet and cozy restaurant. 

My favorite dishes at Cafe Claude are the frisee salad, tarte a l'oignon and the chef special cod. The frisee salad striked the perfect balance of acidity and the bacon just worked so well with the salad. As for the onion tarte, I loved the pear on top of the tart and the pastry itself was crisp and delicious. Finally, the chef special cod was cooked perfectly and I loved the sauce that came with the cod. The top of the cod was also seared nicely. My friend's entree, clam linguini, was made really lightly as well so it wasn't too heavy of a lunch.

I would stay away from the mussels because they are not the freshest batch out there, but everything else is worth a try! I saw that the other diners ordered Cafe Claude sandwiches and everything.
author: Erica J.

description:
The wifey and I tried to get in last year on our anniversary but couldn't get a table (we neglected to make reservations), so headed to Belden Lane instead. This year however, the lil missus made reservations for us on a Saturday night to celebrate our 17th, and it was worth it.

Great ambiance, very good for a nice romantic evening, and the other reason my wife wanted to go was for the music. There was a jazz trio playing with a lead vocalist who was very reminiscent of Astrud Gilberto ("Girl from Ipanema") and they were great.

We ordered light and shared the Betterave (beet salad) which was very good, the Escargot which was tender and not too chewy, the Charcuterie which hada nice selection of cured meats, and the Couquilles Saint Jacques, which was my fav! The scallops were cooked to perfection, and the light crust from the bread crumbs and cheese was amazing. I could make a meal of just the scallops!

We got pretty good service and enjoyed our dining experience there. It's worth a try but make reservations to insure you get in. There is also outside dining (similar to Belden Lane).
author: John R.

description: Dinner was excellent, but for the cost I'd have liked a more updated interior.  I think that they're getting a premium for the location and for the long tenure in the SF dining scene.  Steak tartare was super, my first time.  And the table side preparation was fun.
author: Patrick S.

description: Food is decent, though I 'd say it's not the best in town. What's outstanding is their decorations, service, and LIVE jazz. OMG, I would definitely want to come back again just for the music ;) lol. Duck leg confit is my favorite dish of the day, with perfect balance of crispy and juicy taste.
author: Ren D.

description: The atmosphere was great for a chic and cosy dinner out in san francisco, but the food was just soso.  I would skip the french onion soup, but the coq au vin wasn't too bad.
author: Laci G.

description: French onion soup, awesome! Great live Jazz music not over powering and pleasant!
author: Aida N.

description:
Not the best French meal Ive had, the menu was lacking and not very original
I ordered the onion soup...severely disappointed.
Coq au Vin was really good but not great.
Wine selection was also lacking.
Cant say I would return

I will say the staff was great.
author: Bernardo M.

description:
Likes: agneau (lamb) with the butternet squash puree, filet mignon with wine, pate de campagne (reminded me a bit of salami spread but hey, it's pork so i'm not that off) and the pickles were miniature but sweet, apple tart mm, chocolate cake mm, creme brule was dee-licious, service friendly

Dislikes: the french bread was kinda hard (a mon avis).  on the pricey side for me.
author: Karen M.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in the city.  The service is top notch and waiters/waitresses are more than happy to explain to you about the dishes if you need further clarification. They have strong drinks and a good wine selection. I love the ambiance and interior of the restaurant. The fact that they have live jazz on Fridays and Saturdays even adds more to the restaurant. My girlfriend was a big fan of their steak tartare. She wasn't too big of a fan of the Coq Au Vin since it was heavily marinated with red wine (although that's probably more so a personal taste of hers). The Confit de Canaro was a big hit for the two of us. One of the best duck I've had. Their deserts are good.
author: John H.

description:
The food was below average.  I had the lamb, it was hard.  I couldn't chew it.  So I returned it and ordered the roasted chicken.  It was blah.  My bf ordered the coq au vin, it was also flavorless.  My friend ordered the steak.  It was edible, but we all agreed we would not order it again.  

The music was nice, but I could't see the performer.  The "stage" was on the side of the bar by the entrance.  It was out of view.

Very disappointing.  Will not return.
author: Melissa L.

description: This places is small but very cute. I recommend it for romantic dates. The food is pretty good but a little pricey.
author: Daniel K.

description:
I recently came here because of the Jazz band I heard about. Parking was about 11 bucks at the garage then really close walking distance to the cafe. I pictured the place bigger and I was disappointed because I felt that they cram you in with other patrons and you are literally rubbing elbows with people. That makes it very hard to have a nice private conversation. Also I couldnt see the band playing so I could only hear them which took away from the experience

Food:
That they hit on point. The chicken dishes we got were made very well. Good flavor and moisture.

Price:
not worth what they charged on drinks or food because the ambieance is lacking. I didn't feel that it lived up to why I was going there. Very pricey drinks.

Conclusion:
If you like Jazz (thurs-sat only) and dont mind sitting super close to others then try it out but I wouldnt recommend it and I will not be going there ever again.
author: Eric S.

description:
Can you say "overrated?"  First of all, "cafe" is a misnomer.  This is not a cafe.  Formal restaurant?  Sure.  Bistro?  Maybe.  Cafe?  Certainly not.  Apparently the person who opened the restaurant had "cafe" moved piece by piece from France, but you sure couldn't tell.  It looks just like thousands of other places.  Except that they have an awning over some tables in an alley--which could be charming if it wasn't in an alley.  There are dumpsters literally feet away.  Gross.

The service was polite, but we felt as though we were being rushed out even though the place wasn't busy at all.  Our drinks disappeared from the table before we had finished them and we did not receive replacements until we asked for them.  The descriptions of the menu items sounded fantastic, but the food itself lacked (good) flavor and was overpriced.  When I went to use the restroom, I had to make my way through a maze of chairs on which the staff sat, chatting, in the bar.  They looked at me as though I was intruding.

Boo.
author: Keely B.

description:
This place was very nice country french
The food was great and our experience there was just fine
Definitely recommend going here
author: Zil M.

description: A very cozy French inspired establishment tucked away in an alleyway.  Easy to miss, but its like you enter a different world when you're here.  You're greeted by dim lighting, live music, and warm chatter.  A great selection of wines, and very traditional French dishes make this place a winner.  I was especially impressed by the appetizer of steak tartare, which is prepared right in front of your eyes with raw beef, a raw quail egg, some mustard and seasoning, and spread over cut bread.  Awesome to find such a gem tucked away in the heart of San Francisco.  Perfect place for a date.
author: David C.

description:
Thurs, Fri, Sat Night Live Jazz 7:30-10:30 was the draw for us...but this restaurant offers much more than just jazz. The classic french restaurant ambience with the warm wood interior and horizontal mirrors around the restaurant for people watching. But most of all, the food was excellent!

There were several things I would love to return to Cafe Claude to try, like the escargot to name one.

I highly recommend these dishes:

The classic coq au vin was my favorite!!! (To die for)

The pan seared salmon, green lentils, smoked bacon, spinach, horseradish creme fresh was also very good.

Creme Brulee for dessert was fabulous!
author: Terri V.

description:
Lovely venue, nice ambience. Very busy and noisy.

Staff great, attentive and keen although the hosts were confused and could do better.

Food was poor.  The onion soup was abominable.  One of my favorite dishes, and one that I make a lot at home, this was one of the worst I've tasted in a long time.  Large chunks of onions with no evidence of caramelization at all.  Looked like they'd just chucked in some chopped onion into some bad stock. Very strong mushroom taste (stock?) when they should have used a good, beef stock.  This is a relatively simple dish which relies on good cooking and patient caramelization of the onions for flavor.  Not evident here at all.  OH said the pate was okay.  Complimentary bread was hard and a bit stale.  The toast with the pate was good.  

Coq au vin was better.  Much more like the real thing but portions were very small.  It apparently came with fingerling potatoes but I counted only one, thumbnail sized piece.  It was absolutely edible and average. If I'd gone to a friend's dinner party and they served it, I would have thought, good effort!  It was very amateurish.  The dessert was better but still not quite right. Oh well.

Really disappointed.  Claudine, next door with the same owners, was much more interesting with better cooking.  Next time, I'll go there.
author: Steven R.

description: Great service and atmosphere.  My beef sandwich and fries for lunch were very good.  I like the nice subtle flavor of the iced tea.
author: Patrick H.

description:
Horrible horrible service! I was craving for escargot so I found this restaurant on Yelp. The restaurant has a small patio which is inside a little ally. It was a wrong decision to sit there.  For the whole time, we had a hard time to get the waiter. First, they didn't bring us any bread while other tables had it. So we thought it might come later with the food but NO  they still didnt bring us any bread. WTH I was gonna eat escargot and goose liver pate without the bread. It took us 15 mins to get the waiter attention to ask for the bread. By the end of the meal, the waiter never brought it out.

For the food,
The escargot is ok, it was not in the shell as i usually saw in other French restaurants.
 Goose liver pate is so so. 
Moules ( mussels): worst dish, the dish was cold and  flavorless 
Sandwich: was good. Surprisingly it was the best dish of the meal
author: N N.

description:
This place was great.
I had heard about this restaurant through yelp and had to check it out when I heard they offered Live Jazz.

I was really looking forward to both the jazz and wine.
The food was prepared exceptionally well.
The wine on the other hand was fantastic.
After our waiter told us that he was somewhat of a wine connoisseur, I had to test his skills out.
He brought us out a fantastic carafe. 
If only my memory served me right and wasn't so blurry (the wine was good) I could remember what it was.

The food on the other hand, was good.
I ordered the steak tar tar and my date ordered the chicken dish.
The steak tar tar is geniusly made in front of you which gives your date a little excitement along with the people sitting next to you...
I think as Americans we expect a ton of flavor to overwhelm your tongue. Don't expect that from Cafe Claud, the flavors are very subtle, but I really enjoyed that.

That was the only thing we both disliked about the place, it was a little to tight. I hate sharing a conversation with the person next to me when we want to be private.

I definitely hope that others enjoy Cafe Claud as much as I did.
author: Anthony G.

description:
This place a little more than hard to find.  It's right off of Sutter St. in a side alley.  Although the location is a bit tough, it more than worth the adventure to find it.  The inside of the restaurant is not only quaint but has a very kind of romantic atmosphere.  People and staff are on point and they know when to pay attention and when not too.  I will say definitely try the Trout, the Bone Marrow, and the Steak.  All of which have excellent flavor, but not overpowering.  A great balance of rich flavor with something mellow to flatten it out.  

All in all a great experience.  Prices are a bit steep, but worth every penny.
author: Daniel R.

description:
Why why why!! Such a cute little place and such inattentive service.....
Ok so a great little place for perhaps a date, it is small and cozy and not to mention very classy, food is good maybe a little over priced but still tasty, I just wish they were a little friendly BUT its is a french restaurant after all ;)
author: Kajal P.

description: Had a great experience. Manager and the waitress were friendly and very accommodating. The food was great. I had the chicken and it was made perfectly. It was moist and flavorful. We also had the fish - artic char. The fish was perfectly. Took my wife here almost 5 years ago and still think highly of this place.
author: George H.

description: Just had dinner! what a beautiful location in a little alley so romantic small and cozy! beautiful live music on the weekends. got the coq au vin per yelpers recommendation and it was delicious huge mushrooms and shallots best part was the chicken legs and the yummy sauce! ordered a French kiss which was a very refreshing and sweet cocktail also tried the onion soup which was great. best part was our server aaron who made the experience that much better, so kind and welcoming! a definite must for anyone visiting San Fran!
author: Milana K.

description: What a lovely french cafe this is! I showed up for a 9pm reservation, on a Thursday night, with my sweet mutt, hoping, as in Paris, she would be welcome at an outdoor table. Welcome is an understatement. Everyone was exceptionally kind and attentive to both of us as we waited for my husband (his flight back into OAK was running late). The service was impecable and the food was delicious- a very fresh house salad with a tangy house dressing and a tasty paparadelle pasta with mushrooms. I also enjoyed the live jazz band- what a touch of class. My husband arrived and we finished out the evening with an appetizer and desert. The service continued to be attentive but never rushed or pushy. We look forward to returning.
author: Mishka L.

description:
Think this a 3.5

We went here for brunch because Yelp suggest this place for brunch, but this is more a French lunch/dinner place.  You will not find your typical brunch dishes here except for maybe croque monsieur.  

The location is very interesting in the sense that the street is blocked off as a walk only street, so the restaurant actually has this outdoor section in the alley, you definitely don't see that everyday, it's a tad weird.

I had the crispy pork belly salad with soft poached egg which was delicious.  BF had the ahi tuna burger that was the special of the day, which he said was okay.  

Would not suggest if you are looking for a typical but good brunch place, but probably for a lunch type place.
author: Li Y.

description: Always a cheerful experience, with classic French food in a suitably French atmosphere.  Perfect for lunch outside on warm days.
author: Niland M.

description:
French restaurants bring out snobbery in people. Not here. The food is delicious, well presented, fresh, and modern. The service is warm and efficient, and orders are expeditiously served. The atmosphere is young and tasteful with an eye to detail. The place is spotless. Very San Francisco, so don't expect a formal, French dining experience.

The saint jacques provencale was a too peppery, but everything else we've tried has been mouthwatering.
author: Jay C.

description: Wonderful food and service.  We always get the beef tartare and pomme frites.  Their main dishes are wonderful with daily specials.  My wife loves their roasted chicken and drinks.  It is our neighborhood favorite.
author: Stan V.

description:
Encountered to this cafe when I was tired wandering around Union Sq. But it somehow turned to be pleasure sitting there, writing and reading alone in a warm haze.

Tea is fine, dessert is cute. the biggest selling point is their handsome, abercrombie and fitch style French waiters. They are cute with some accent that my American girlfriends find very 'sexy', and of course friendly all the time.

Food is fairly good and tasty. Whatever you choose, you won't be disappointed at all. Even though personally I don't enjoy reading complicated menu without pictures :P
author: Angela L.

description:
3.5 stars. This restaurant is in an alley in the Financial District/Union Square area and has an appealing European feel. 

We enjoyed the chevre salad, which came with mesclun greens, nuts, tomatoes and apples. The salad was crisp with a nice balance of salty and sweet flavors.

We also shared the Coquilles Saint Jacques, a mini-casserole of scallops, shrimp, mussels, and mushrooms in a creamy bechamel sauce topped with melted gruyere cheese and bread crumbs. This was good but could have used a little more herb or something to elevate the flavor. I also felt the seafood pieces were cut too small.

For my entree, I enjoyed the coq au vin, which had a deep, red wine flavor. The chicken was extremely tender and moist. 

My husband ordered the filet mignon, which was a let down. The filet was a little bland and tough. 

We did enjoy our desserts, creme brulee and a flourless chocolate accompanied by a sweet cream that we poured on top. YUM. Dessert hit the mark. 

Overall, we had a very nice evening and dining experience.
author: Jenny K.

description: Cozy date atmosphere, good cocktails and great live jazz.  I'm going to dream about the chocolate soufflé dessert until my next visit.
author: Katherine C.

description: Loved the setting. Felt like we were in Paris. Very nice food. We had a charcuterie and cheese platter along with escargot. They were wonderful. Also tried the onion soup. I bit thick. The crime brûlée was excellent. Would return and try a full meal next time.
author: Patti A.

description:
Ate here last month and it was delicious! We missed the jazz sadly since we went on a Sunday night but the location is very romantic, a nice quiet and warm setting in a back alley. The food was outstanding- we ordered the pate' sampler for an appetizer, lamb for dinner and creme brulee for dessert. The waiter recommended an amazing wine to pair with our dinner too. It's a bit pricey but worth it for the quality, service, etc. I would definitly go back for another romantic date night:)
Oh, and they have a nice outdoor heater patio in the alley that was very nice.
author: Little O.

description:
The Croque Monsieur here is absolutely delicious. It was cheesy and the bread was thick enough that it had a nice bite to it. The bechamel sauce was creamy and the ham nice and smoky. The fries that accompanied the dish were crispy and perfectly salted. For dessert, I got the chocolate mousse. I was expecting something light but it was really dense and chocolatey. Very rich and surprisingly not too sweet. 

I had a wonderful experience here and wish I lived in San Fran so I couldn't frequent this cute cafe often. I recommend making reservations because it can get full. They have additional seating outside and if it's a cold day, they have an outdoor heater.

Highly recommend this cafe!
author: Lilly T.

description:
Romantic, yes for sure. Live music, absolutely stunning.
Food is very Paris like, the steak and fries for instance. However, they are so many exceptional French restaurants in the city that I took away one star for the food did not really have that "wow" factor. It was great, just not "wow".
author: Elif U.

description:
Delightful, cozy, romantic, charming.  I absolutely adored Cafe Claude!

A perfect little restaurant that is perfectly tucked away on Claude Lane.  Let me first start with the service, which was swift and friendly.  My French waitress was such a nice lady.  Now, I shall move onto the food...

For me, the food was amazing.  I don't know how "authentically French" it was, but I will say that it tasted authentic--the flavors were so simple, yet so complex.  The cherve salad won me over completely.  And don't even get me started on that molten chocolate cake with creme anglaise.  Absolutely divine.   

Can't wait to return to Cafe Claude for lunch, dinner, whenever.
author: Angella S.

description:
délicieux . ..


+ :  nice ambiance . .. delicious food: . .. nice drinks . .. live music . .. in or outdoor dining . .. 

-- :  kinda hidden from street, plan on walking through alley of restaurants . ..


my faV drink here, Chartreuse, which is a French liqueur made by the Carthusian Monks . .. ;P
author: Y I L I W.

description:
Tucked away on a small alley away from the hustle and bustle of Union Square, Cafe Claude is a hidden gem. Be sure to dine here on Thur-Sat between 7:30pm -10:30pm, when they have local jazz musicians performing. 

The bistro feel of the restaurant and live jazz music is a wonderful compliment to their French cuisine.  I usually order the Coq Au Vin, which is flavorful and falling off the bone.

I highly recommend Cafe Claude if you're wary of all the overpriced tourist traps and expensive restaurants in Union Square or looking for a different kind of dining experience in SF.
author: Monelle A.

description:
Tucked away on claude st. which is a cute little alley, with a French vibe without the attitude. 

My server was very friendly and helpful. He knew the ingredients and dishes well. Words were chosen carefully."The Coq Au Vin is our best seller." Note, he did not say if it was extra special. Thanks Roberto!

I had the French onion soup, then the stake tartar with the sauteed spinach. 

The soup was above average, but very cheesey. Not something to eat on a date ;)

The steak tartare is made table side and is great. Next time I'll ask for less spicy mustard. 

The atmosphere is great, not toooo dark or pretentious.
author: Kortni S.

description: I haven't been here in 3 years (life whisked me elsewhere), but my experience as a patron was fantastic.  Amazing food, chic ambiance, French staff...  I've not yet visited France, but friends who have tell me this is the real deal.  Si merveilleux!
author: Charis S.

description: Amazing, intimate ambiance, the small plates and cocktails were fantastic! The snail with puff pastry was easily my favorite.
author: Chet M.

description:
I used to come to Cafe Claude 3-4 years ago and the food was soooo good. After moving away from SF, I decided to go back to my favorite restaurant while visiting the city for work. 
I started with the onion soup, one of my favorite.
I guess the chef has changed as the soup was not at all as my taste buds remembered it. This one was too salty, with not enough bread and barely any cheese on top. It used to be with a crispy cheese layer, that became a half layer of not that crispy cheese.
The bread brought to the table was cold. It was not bad but I feel like bringing hot bread to the table is such a delicate touch.
Next was the frisée salad which was really good. The potatoes were warm, the poached egg still runny and the sauce perfectly balanced. That was a hit.
For desert I tried the creme brûlée. It was really good. The top was crispy and it was warm. It could have been slightly more hot but that would have been to make it perfect. It was close to it enough.
Overall the meal was really good but not as it used to be a couple years ago. Just because of the onion soup, I removed one star.
author: Yannick B.

description: I wanted to LOVE this place and give it 5 stars, but the cocktails ruined the experience for me.  The food is definitely great here, I had some beef stew that they marinated in the crockpot for several hours, and it was very tender, juicy, and delicious.  I've been told this is only available on Sunday nights. :)   The service was good, my waiter was hot, and very friendly.  The drinks just didn't hit the mark, I tried 2 different signature cocktails from their menu and they were both like $12 bucks each, and I couldn't even finish the 2nd one.  I usually never send a drink back, but I did send this one back, and ordered a manhattan instead, but it had too much bitters in it.  Oh well, I should know better then to order cocktails at a french restaurant, I should have went for the wine instead!!
author: Rob K.

description: The gal and I had a Friday night date here last weekend. It had been a few years. The experience was, in a word, perfect. The ambiance is relaxed but there's a glamour and sexiness to this place owing to the live jazz, perfect lighting, artful decor, and Parisian sense of joie de vivre. The food is classic and well executed. We especially loved the steak tartare prepared tableside and the incredibly savory coq au vin. The service was professional and unpretentious without a hint of stuffiness. We plan to make this a new regular spot.
author: Mark R.

description:
This place has changed a lot over the years.  What remains consistent is the mouth-watering, excellent selection of French cuisine.
