The service is just right--not too imposing and there when we need it.  The ambiance is intimate, reminding me of another restaurant I loved in Paris that is also secretly tucked behind an alleyway.  

Perfect for:
- catching up with an old friend
- dinner with un amant
- a random Wednesday night



(How did I miss the live Jazz??!  Oh... Thurs-Sat only.)
author: Linda T.

description: Food and service was good, the lamb shank was a little too salty.
author: Ariel H.

description:
Great food.  Perfect service.

We decided on Cafe Claude after reading the reviews on Yelp.  We were celebrating a birthday.  I am pretty familiar with French cuisine and Cafe Claude does not disappoint.  

My wife ordered the fish special.  Good balance of flavors with just the right accompaniments.  My coq au vin was perfect.  The sauce was  perfectly savory.  The only minor complaint was the dipping sauce for the frites was unremarkable.  
Yes,  if that is all  I have to complain about.... a good meal.

The restaurant is cozy ( ie you can hear the conversation of your fellow diners.. if you choose).  It adds to the romantic atmosphere.
Yelp isn't wrong... enjoy!
author: Christopher C.

description:
Cafe Claude was the happiest discovery in awhile.  I went there about a month ago so unfortunately i do not remember exactly what i got, but the quality and taste of the food is still fresh in my mind!

I took my girlfriend there for our anniversary and we each ordered an entree, i got the pasta special and she got one of the chicken dishes with a side dish.  When the food came out we were both in heaven, the side dish was a cheesy sliced potato dish that was absolutely perfect for our meal.  The atmosphere is very nice and if you go on certain nights they have live music, i would highly encourage people to go here if they don't mind paying a little extra for some amazing food!
author: Johnny A.

description:
I've been to Cafe Claude two times in the past 4-6 months and have experienced extreme inadequacies in both food and service. Let me get right into it.

1) One one occasion I ordered the Coq Au Vin. Everything about it was pretty delicious but, about half way through, I realized that there were no fingerling potatoes in the dish. So, I asked the waitress - "Does the coq au vin come with fingerling potatoes?" The reply - "Yes! Does yours not have any?" Me: "No, no fingerling potatoes found." Her: "Oh I'm so sorry about that!" Then she walks away. I was expecting to receive some potatoes after that. Nope. Nothing and no further acknowledgement. Weird. 

2) We stood at the bar once while waiting for our party to arrive. I ordered a Manhattan. A couple sips in, I realize there are two floating gnats/flies in my drink. I discreetly let the bartender know. He quickly takes the drink away and five minutes later produces another Manhattan. He does not say "Sorry" at least once. No "Terribly sorry about that! Your drink will be free of charge." There are a lot of people I know out there that would FREAK OUT after this - he was lucky I don't take much mind to such things. 

3) On another occasion I ordered the Faux Fillet. I ordered it Medium Rare and it came to me Medium Well. The steak was chewy and lacked flavor. The only thing good about the dish were the fries. 

4) Ordered the Steak Tartare - it was so heavy with mustard that I couldn't taste anything else. Good thing I was hungry and didn't mind so much. 

5) Service. Just some general thoughts here. It's not really a big deal, but it seems like a lot of the service people accidentally step on each others toes. Bussers will take some plates, the waiter a few, some people get waters, some don't. One person brings the bottled water, while another brings something else. It just seems a little amateur at times. 

Don't get me wrong though, there are definitely some great things about Cafe Claude, but they don't really make up for all the bad that has occurred. But, I'll mention them anyway!

Good stuff - the live music is great. It's always very entertaining, but not too loud as to make it so ALL you're doing is listening to the music. It's still very easy to have a conversation. It's subtle, yet present. Despite my bad experience with the cocktail above, I really do think they mix up a great cocktail. I also really like their glassware. If anything, maybe Cafe Claude is a great place for a cocktail and a couple appetizers, or maybe a cocktail and desert. The service, despite a bit on the side of amateur, is very friendly. They are always smiling and charming. This is a joy. The ambiance is nice. I enjoy the lighting, the table settings and decorations. The outside seating is enjoyable. 

To conclude - I will not be coming back to Cafe Claude for dinner. I won't be opposed to going if someone else plans a dinner there, but I won't be recommending it or going out of my way to eat there anytime soon!
author: Matt S.

description:
Really cool location. Felt like I was in a different country. 

Steak was good. Chocolate lava cake dessert was also amazing!!
author: Ryan L.

description:
My mom and I were looking for a place to eat in the financial district on a Saturday. After looking for a while I found Café Claude on Yelp. As it isn't on a Main Street we didn't just come across it, however it was well worth the detour. 

Inside the restaurant you will be welcome with a warm cosy ambiance. It is very clean and warm with gentle lighting. The bare steel structure of the building adds spirit to the restaurant. 
My mom chose the asparagus salad (salade d'asperges) while I went for one of my favorite salads, the chèvre (commonly referred to as "salade chèvre chaud" in France). On top of that, we ordered some charcuterie on the side. 
We were both very pleased with our fresh, tasty salads. My chèvre salad was definitely above par and as good if not better than many i've eaten in France. The charcuterie plate was good as well, it was more Italian than French but there is absolutely no problem with that.
In terms of service, we didn't have to wait at any point in time. The waiters had our full attention.

In the end, as two French people, we were impressed with the quality of the service as well as the food. I will definitely come back again, probably to taste the tartare as I am a big fan. I would definitely recommend Café Claude to someone who wants to eat good French food at a very decent price. And I would classify the restaurant as above average in comparison to French restaurants.
author: Scott G.

description:
Great place for a date! Casual and chic at the same time. The French Onion soup is to die for! Also ordered Mac n Cheese (of course it has a fancy name, but I dont remember what is) - which was very filling and tasty.

The restaurant is on an alley which gives it a French feel. They have a great outdoor patio. I could see this being very nice when it is warm and Jazz playing in the background.
author: Tania D.

description: Appetizers were amazing escargot and cheese plate oohhh! Main dishes good, but nothing special. I liked the music it was not not very loud so we were able to chat and even my baby slept through whole dinner. Not children friendly restaurant because simply not enough space, 4 people table and we were very close to each other! Food comes out super slow, so if you in a hurry don't bother.   All staff were polite and experienced. If you pay paypal you can get free desert!
author: Daria M.

description:
Like most special unique snowflakes, I like to tell myself that the reason why people don't "understand" me is because I fancy myself a European under the guise of an American citizen. It's mostly just an excuse to wear really mismatched clothing and act bitchy to everyone I meet, but as any of my friends would tell you, I'm not really that mean. I just wish I was. Just like I wish I was truly french.

There is no better way to spend an afternoon than with someone who is very special and important to you. Drinks at a bar is one thing, but lunch is different. Perusing the menu and ordering a St. Germain cocktail, while wondering if a Sex on a St. Tropez Beach is as uncomfortable as the act itself sounds, you chat lightly about your friends and how Saveur had a wonderful issue about butter. After deciding on the soupe à l'oignone, the conversation turns to why it's not more acceptable to just shovel food in your mouth because obviously, that is the most comforable for the two of us. We decide against it to spare the embarrassment of the establishment.

As the sandwiches are brought out, the things we complain about suddenly stop having so much impact; that yes, this in life shall pass as well, just like I will on the menu when I come here again with my pan poulet. Not to say that it wasn't good--the egg was different and the butter lettuce and mayonnaise was the perfect accoutrement to the bread's buttery outside, but the chicken itself was bland and unsavory. I'm almost positive that they have much better dishes on the menu. 

Typically this would have ended with a cigarette, coffee and dessert, but you can't smoke in restaurants anymore and I'm sure my dining companion wouldn't have appreciated me slowly killing his beautiful vocal chords with my bad habits. Instead, we shared a flourless chocolate cake with a vanilla bean creme anglaise, and a cafe au lait to sip along the way. 

I've mentioned this before: there was something *missing* in that cake. For some reason there has always been one ingredient that is left out--don't say flour, it's not that. One of my dear friends, a pastry chef, decided to make a recipe specifically for me so that it wouldn't miss anything; and it didn't. But it's worlds away from being sold in any restaurant, so for now this was the best subsitute. Two raw sugar packets in my coffee later, I am now completely ready to stay up all night.

When we were done, a friend of his called and he mentioned a childhood story about how his friend would shove his face under the water in the pool. Then I shared the one about how my brother ran up to me while I was sitting down and farted on the back of my head and almost broke my neck doing it. My friend says, "Well..with that kind of thing, there is that whole time issue."

And this is how we know Jaime is truly supposed to be french; because there is nothing more classy than telling each other embarrassing stories from our childhood after a wonderful meal.
author: Jaime L.

description: Great little French placed tucked away on a side street in the heart of downtown SF. Highly recommend it!
author: Tina M.

description:
Visiting from Austin, finding this French fair restaurant was a pleasant find.  The service from the waitress, Maren, was top-notch, and the food was very authentic.  I ordered 3 small plates (prosciutto wrapped figs, escargot and steak tartare), each was prepared very well and would definitely recommend.  The creme brulee' for dessert was also very good.

I went early (6:00) on a Thursday night, and seating seemed to be fairly available.   Prices were not cheap, but very reasonable for what I ordered.  When visiting the Union Square area again, I will definitely try to make it back to Claude's.
author: Stephen R.

description: Second best Tuna Nicoise Salad in the city. (My boyfriend's is the best). Love coming here on Sat for a lazy quiet brunch.
author: E ..

description:
Cafe Claude is French Restaurant. Just walking distance from Union Square, down a small alley , you'll find this amazing hole in the wall restaurant. The restaurant is small and quaint. There was indoor and outside seating, but we chose inside due to the chilly weather. 

We had the 3 choice pate with goose, chicken and pork. I thought the pork was the most flavorful. The main course I had the Coq au Vin. It was absolutely delicious! The chicken was cooked perfectly and just fell off the bone effortlessly. Lastly, we had the dark chocolate mousse, that was the best mousse I've ever had. I almost had to lick the cup clean!

I thought the service was a bit slow, but good nonetheless. The food definitely makes up for this. Expect to pay $30 to $40 per person. The restaurant had a nice cozy atmosphere excellent for dates and small parties. I will be back again for sure!
author: Daniel C.

description:
J'amie Cafe Claude.

Especially the french onion soup. It is the definition of onion/cheese/beef goodness. After the soup I ordered the pasta special. A wondrous butter,  penne, & parmesan concoction mixed with fresh al dente vegetables that tasted like a little bit of heaven. Drink menu was extensive and well made. If I was here for dinner I would have loved to have selected from the extensive wine menu. Since it was lunch time we went with cocktails. They were great. Perfect kick and mixed with precision.

The service was casual but very helpful. The hostess was a wonderful French lady that checked in with us before and after the meal to make sure we enjoyed our experience. 

Go here ..... you must order the onion soup !
author: Mark B.

description:
Excellent French Bistro/Cafe.  Oh yes, a restaurant with a great wine list at moderate prices.  This place rocks it!

My auntie lives in the City and chose this place for us.  Myself, a foodie and wino......errr, I mean oenophile, and my aunt is a pastry chef so for us to choose a restaurant can be tough at times.  Well, she nailed this choice for us.

The service was excellent.  From entering the restaurant and being sat to our server Roberto.  It was first class all the way.  The wine list was excellent and the food matched perfectly.  The selections contained many French options but also had a few Cali's in there.  It was great. The restaurant is warm (not temperature) and friendly and is a place I would recommend to anyone.  

Here is what I ate with comments...........

Soupe a l'oignon - a french onion soup on steroids, I mean HGH, no no no not like that Barry Bonds scandal.  It is similar to a french onion soup which was the best I have ever had.  I will add that I have not had many french onion soups, but of the 10 or so that I have had, it was easily the best and we all agreed.

Croque Madame - a french white bread, béchamel, ham, swiss cheese, 'oeuf miroir' (basically a fancy term for fried egg), sandwich.  it aslo came with near perfect french fries (shoestring and crunchy).  The sandwich was yummy and the outside of the bread I think was fried which gave great contrast and taste with the fried egg on top.  It was devine.

I would eat there all the time if I lived in the City.  :-)

I am getting hungry as I write this.  LOL

Gonz, over and out.
author: Chris G.

description:
I spent 47 bucks here last night on onion soup, an ounce of rillette, and 2 canelloni with heavy thick cooked floury mournay-type bechamel sauce with an unexpected spicy kick (because of fresh nutmeg, which was not as pleasant as it sounds.)

I thought the rillette was bland, and not fatty enough (it WAS rabbit after all), but it was nice enouch with a teeny bit of the thick balsamic/mustard schmear.  Little kids would love it.

I make a seriously good onion soup, and I thought this one was lacking.  I also found a brown onion skin, which I removed from my mouth and placed on the saucer.  The cheese was very melty, and overpowering.  There was no beefy/wine flavor, and no thyme, and not enough savory.  Eh.  For 8 bucks, you can make your own and be a LOT happier.

My dinnermate ordered the lamb shank.  It looked very stewy to me, but smelled good.   He also ordered dessert, and I had two bites of creme brulee.  This is my favorite dessert, and it was eh.  Not what I was expecting, and the caramel bent, did not crack, even though it had just been heated (the caramel was warm, the custard was very cold.)

Creme brulee is just okay, skip the bechamel sauce, order two rillettes and a salad, and if you're not pregnant a couple of glasses of wine, and check for skins in your soup.

Couldn't hear my dinnermate over the live music even though we were over by the bathroom exit.  This could work for or against you...waiter was okay, not too annoying.
author: Pippi L.

description:
Meh.  Food was good, not that exceptional. Service was excellent though.

For cocktails, I wanted a Grey Goose and Tonic. - What no Grey Goose?? Isn't that the french vodka?? No they had Ketel One. :( already sad.

Maison Salad was good.
The cheese plate was alright.
The Filet Mignon was on the dry side. Meh.
The Pork Belly had a delicious wine reduction.

For a night out of town and splurging, I had higher hopes for Cafe Claude.
author: Riza T.

description: I ordered French Onion Soup and it was good, REALLY cheesy! I love cheese but I had to remove some, couldn't eat it all, too rich. The broth was very rich and tasty. Also got the potato Gratin, I think I would pass on this, it was literally swimming in oil but good. My only complaint, the bread was HARD and nasty and my friend didn't like his lamb steak, they were nice enough to remove it from our bill. oh I also had a taste of my friend's steak tart tar, real good! they make it at the table for you. And the flourless chocolate cake was yummy. We really wanted ice cream on the side of our cake but they didn't have any, boo.
author: Karen T.

description:
Nice enough cozy atmosphere, although I would never confuse it with a real Paris bistro or restaurant.  Onion soup broth was very bland - nothing to recommend it at all.  The Coq au Vin entree was better and Creme Brulee was basic, but very good.  My wife had one of the fish dishes and it was good, but nothing amazing.

If you just want to try a new place and like French food, it's worth a try, but don't expect to be blown away.
author: Kirke C.

description: I'm usually able to safely rely on Yelp reviews being a good indicator of what my experience will be at a new restaurant, but this was a major exception. We went on a Wednesday night recently. The tucked away location is cute, but the weak service and poorly done food cannot makeup for that. The server seemed impatient with our basic questions, which may have been tolerable if the food had been better. We got the coq au vin and the duck confit. The veggies in the coq au vin were undercooked, and the duck was extremely overdone. It's possible they were just having an 'off' night in the kitchen, but for roughly $25/entree, I'm not willing to take the chance here again.
author: Melissa M.

description:
Cafe Claude is adorable.  Tucked away in a little alley near the hustle and bustle of downtown San Francisco, the moment you enter it you are transported to another world.

My husband and I decided to go one evening after shopping in the city, and we were not disappointed.  

Why the 3 stars?  Well, perhaps it is affected by the heightened expectations I entered into the evening with ~ the food did not live up to the expectations.  I ordered the "ravioli" which was raved by the table next to us, and although extremely tasty, I found it a little one note (of dark brown sauce) and did not have much variation.  I also had the onion soup to start and while the soup and the cheese were both delicious, the toast layer tasted like it had been frozen before (you know, that taste of freezer burn), which slightly ruined the dish all together.  DH ordered the lamb and it was cooked perfectly, except the garnish of tomato topped with something was more pretty garnish and less complementary to the dish.  

All in all, the experience was wonderful... Just did not blow my mind and I was really hoping this little French bistro would.
author: Cindy C.

description:
I heart Cafe Claude! My friend, Greg, introduced me to this gem a few years ago, and am so grateful to him for doing so.
There's so much to love about Claude. It's in a hidden alley, with outdoor tables, and you feel like you are fine dining in Paris.

We had the cheese plate to start off with along with our bubbly (yup, ordered a whole bottle). I can't remember all of the cheeses, but my fav, of course, was the goat cheese. The basket of bread was finished almost immediately with the scrumptious cheesy goodness.
My entree was the 'flat iron steak, flambée au cognac, white wine, green peppercorn and gratin dauphinois.' The translation - abolutely, divinely DELISH! Steak was cooked to perfection (medium) and the sauce was so flavorful (and not salty), and the potatoes were scalloped and cheesy (double bonus).  
There was not a bite left on my plate... well, ok I lie, there were some green beans....

Of course, for dessert was the creme brulee. The texture of the brulee was just hard enough and the creme was tasty and smooth. You could see the bits of the vanilla bean. 'Twas good to the last spoonful. 

Service was good and prices aren't terrible. You are paying for the delicious food and great ambiance. It's just so lovely!

I'll be coming back for more Claude...Au revoir for now..
author: Gill C.

description:
Loved this place, great for lunch.  The french onion soup is so good, but it has A LOT of cheese, so be prepared for that.  The Croque Monsieur was good, but I wish I had ordered the sister sandwich, the Croque Madame, which comes with egg.  French fries are really good.  

This place is easy to miss.  It's in a little alley which I accessed off of Sutter.  It's really close to Union Square, so this is a great place to grab a lunch before shopping.  It is not open for lunch on Sundays, however.  

Note: Tables are squeezed really tight in there.  Be prepared to sit very close to a stranger.  Or make reservations and request a decent table.

2 glasses of champagne, 2 glasses of cab, 2 french onion soups, 1 sandwich, 1 creme brulee = $90 before tip.  Seems fair for location and quality.
author: Jessica J.

description: Great space and very good food.  I had been meaning to come here forever, and it worked out on a night before ACT.  Server was very nice and accomodating of my friend's diet requests.  The menu is pretty basic, but I always trust that a bit more than an extensive menu.
author: Robert M.

description:
Awesome dining experience at a fair price. ($10 appetizers, $25 entrees)
First, when I asked about 2 wine choices, the waiter recommended the lesser-priced one "Because it has more body and will pair better with the chicken." The down side?  Almost all of the wines are French and carry no description other than the name and region.  (No designation as a "Pinot Noir" or "Cabernet", etc.) But as I said, the waiter was quite helpful! $9-12 by the glass.

The escargot was good for beginners - a baked pastry version.  My wife and I, having sampled escargot at several restaurants (Including in France) were not impressed.  BUT...

The Chevre salad was INCREDIBLE. A variation on the "spinach, apple and walnut" salad, this is a must-try if you like the normal versions.

My wife ordered Coq Au Vin (chicken in a wine sauce) and it was delicious (dark meat).  I had the "pork  in apple cider" - I always order pork as my wife isn't fond of it so we never have it at home - and this was the best I've ever had. Highly recommended.

This restaurant is not exactly "quiet", but still romantic.  That could be because we were in the same room as the bar.  There are 3 separate dining areas:  The bar area, the side room, and outside in the alley!  (The heat lamps are excellent, I hear.)

Oh - and the jazz singer was excellent, too.  She started at 7:30pm on a Saturday. 

We WILL return!
author: David H.

description:
I saw a main dish recipe consisting of mussels in this week's New York Times at http://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/25/dining/spicy-coconut-mussels-with-lemon-grass-recipes.html that I wanted to make, but thought I'd try a plate of well-prepared mussels at a restaurant first.

Decided to come here for lunch since the French have a reputation for cooking mussels.  I wasn't disappointed at Cafe Claude.  Their "Moules" mussels consisted of over a dozen mussels cooked in a creamy yellow-orange sauce consisting of creme fraiche, shallots, saffron and white wine accompanied by 2 toasts with a drizzle of rouille sauce. The sauce was savory and velvety and the mussels were cooked to perfection with each morsel being plump and sweet.

They also served complimentary sliced french bread and butter which I had with my starter "Maison (house)" salad of medium sized leaves of little gem lettuce in a creamy whole grain mustard dressing and chopped dill.

Service was good and the prices were moderate to high, but defintely worth the splurge.
author: Bodhi D.

description:
I truly enjoyed the food we had.  The Trout was lovely as was the butter lettuce salad. The steak tartar was nice but a bit bland. 

I give this 3 Star due to the fact the service was lack luster at best.  The waiter was nice but slow and didn't seem to pay much attention to our table.  The Manager was filling in it looked like and was attempting to be nice but in the end was not.  

Our group of 6 arrived at 6pm and told them we had an 8pm show.  We brought a bottle of wine that was opened by them and decanted only to be poured out entirely into 6 glasses - 2 with large pours and the last two with a small amount.  They brought the food out slowly at different intervals (ie some got their appetizer and then finally other did a while later) and just didn't seem to check back in.  Example - Steak Tartar came with 5 small bread pieces and we had to ask for more (6 people at the table not to mention enough tartar for 12 people) but our server didn't come around again until the main plates were almost ready to arrive. 

The main plates were enjoyed by all as was some more wine but when we asked for the check and reiterated that we needed to get to a show by 8pm, they did not bring the checks until we asked again.  Then we gave them our credit cards only to wait even longer at the table.  We finally were pressed for time and all walked up to the front and told the hostess we needed to go!  Just then the Manager appeared from the back with our checks and made a snippy comment towards our group and having to make change for some cash.

After almost $100/person, we all felt the food was lovely but service made for a disappointing experience. I would most likely not be going back.
author: Terry C.

description:
Random evening, I was with a friend walking back from work, dressed in jeans and thought of looking up a restaurant nearby Union Square, I don't usually feel good about eating in Union square area its a little too touristy and food eehh..  OK at best.

But then again, if yelp said 4 stars, I had to try, we walk over, walk-in, and the first thing that hits you is the ambiance! I thought to myself, I didn't come for a dressy dinner and here's the beauty, you can be dressed up and sit inside or dressed down and sit outside.

We sat outside, got Au Gratis, Pomme Fritte, Saumo(Salmon) and the pasta of the day. The main course dishes were a amazingly flavorful but a little bland. Sides more than made up for that.

Definitely get the Gratis and Fries, this is a gem whether you wanna just hang out or go in for a more formal occasion!
author: Sumit G.

description:
A neat little place hidden in Claude Lane just on the side of an art gallery.
The decor was pleasant but the service was typically French.

The food was inconsistent. The ravioles were the finest. The steak frites was below average. 

Overall, at that price, you would expect a better experience than Left Bank
author: Patrick M.

description:
What a cute place. A great little find, hidden away from the crowded Union Square area. The atmosphere is dark and intimate, and the food is elegant, yet comforting. The Pommes frites are absolutelty delicious, flavorful and crispy, with a creamy dipping sauce. The French onion and cream of carrot soups I have had here are both about as decadent as soup can get. 

The cliched "Hole - in - the - wall - French  - bistro" that everyone claims they know, never tasted so good. Bring a date. Get hella romantic all over that shit. Bon appetit, bro
author: Angela S.

description:
I really underestimated this place and went back for a more recent
visit. It is an unusual sit-down sit-down place for lunch or dinner
or after-work meeting place. They work very hard and are very
gracious and really aim to please. They have some exciting menu
selections. The setting is a bit quaint, which is good, you can sit
inside or out. I prefer out for lunch and inside for dinner.
author: joan b.

description: Steak frites...when you siri "best steak frites in sf" Cafe Claude pops up in the top of the list. I was very excited upon arrival.  They do a great job presenting the place and there's alley seating that is very inviting. The mussels were great,  adding the frites is a must.  The portion size was a little on the small side but the fries filled the void.  My gfs goat cheese salad was the tastiest of the evening,  and my steak frites was ok. I'm pretty sure I was knocking on $30 for an entree so expecting a large steak with some marblization I was!! I got a small portion that had some gristle. Compared to the best steak frites I've ever had; we were off the mark here unfortunately. I'd say smaller crunchier frites would have been a better addition. The bonemarrow finishing sauce is great! ...it's unfortunate they have to share restroom space with the rest of the businesses in that building,  it's a harsh transition from dining to washroom!
author: Brock L.

description:
A nice Cafe where I actually left stuffed.

I love trying out new places and Cafe Claude was no let down. I met up with a dear friend and his new fiancee to celebrate their good news and catch up on life. Cafe Claude offered an intimate environment that allowed us to chat, laugh, and enjoy the food.

My friends and I ordered:

-escargot in puff pastry (which was excellent) 
-tartar (also wonderful)
-the lamb entree (yes, all three of us)
-cheese platter
-chocolate cake (I think it was a Gateau Royale but I may be mistaken. It was very dense)

We were very pleased with the meal (they had just been in France earlier in the year) and had very high compliments about the food.


I can't wait to come back and order the escargot again!
author: Hannah N.

description:
OVERALL: Great dishes, all depending on what you order. Lacking in flavor for French Onion, but the porc and Cauliflower soup made up for it, at least for me. Just make sure you get the right dishes (according to Yelp, I guess?)  and make little room for dessert because it's a great way to finish off the meal. 

It's located in a little alley that looks like it came right out of an alleyway in Paris. The outdoor seating looked nice but we opted for indoor seating. I came here on a Sunday night with my family, and we had already made reservations, but it was not too busy and we were seated immediately. The ambiance is warm and nice, and we missed the only day that they don't play live jazz (darn!). Many people just had jeans and regular shirts on. Being a teenager, I thought it would be too grownup for me, but it wasn't extremely weird. Our waiter was super nice too.

We ordered the cauliflower soup (not on the menu), French Onion Soup, and the Truffle Mouse for appetizers. Cauliflower soup was amazing, but the French Onion wasn't the greatest. A bit of a muddled salty taste, but its hard to compare after having that soup in France. I also prefer Gruyere cheese, not Swiss. Also, my parents liked the one at Cafe Central better. I personally loved the Truffle Mousse, so full of flavor and a great combo with the dijon mustard and little pickles. 

I got the cider brined tenderloin. Had an amazing jus and the pork was moist and flavorful; probably the best dish I've had in a while. My sister got the salmon with Israeli couscous. The salmon was lacking in flavor, but the couscous tasted great. My dad got the lamb sirloin medium-well (we don't like pink meat too much). It was a bit dry, but had good flavor. The chickpeas and vegetables were a bit odd, but tasted pretty good. My mom got the coq au vin (chicken w/red wine, bacon, etc). She wasn't too crazy about it, and didn't really expect the chicken to be on bone, but the sauce was really flavorful. 

Dessert was moelleux au chocolate (flourless chocolate cake). Perfect amount for the 4 of us after being super full from appetizers and entrees. 

I'm not sure if I would come here again, not because the food was bad, but because I would like to experiment with different restaurants. But if there would be a reason to come back, it would be for the Porc, possibly Truffle Mousse, and the dessert. And try the gratin (I love gratin, but we didn't order it, grr)
author: Anika B.

description: I had a very disappointing meal here last Wednesday. The beef for the steak tartare was improperly cute. I got oversized chunks that were hard to chew. I had 2 bites and stopped eating. It's texture was not unlike what I feed my dog. I suggest the person cooking that night try expert versions at Bouli Bar or Urchin Bistro. The flavors were good but ground beef would have been way better. The jazz was way too loud for us and a famous composer seated near us. Our waiter didn't ask if I had a problem or if there was a problem.
author: Peggy K.

description:
What a hidden gem. After a wonderful meal @ R & G Lounge, we decided to walk around for a place for dessert. Since it was Sunday, most places around the area were closed. That's when we "bumped" into this place.

After walking through an alley of sorts (one of the cleanest "alleys" I've ever seen in my life), we saw that Cafe Claude was open and decided to try it out. We sat outside in the alley, but honestly, the atmosphere of this place made me feel like I was in a cafe in the back streets of Paris. This place really knows how to pull it off. It wasn't just a run of mill type of place either. Our waitress spoke to us in English with a really heavy French accent (not that I or anyone in our party minded - it is the language of love). It really added to the feel of the place.

The place was quite fancy, but did not have that snobby attitude that most places that rank high in the fancy mark are diseased with. Brulee, souffle, just about anything was ordered for our dessert and it was more than eagerly shared among my dessert companions. 

I'm not really a dessert person, but this place opened my eyes more to the possibility of enjoying dessert. Especially how it was made, how everything tasted. My Creme Brulee even had fresh raspberries and it was just one of the best ever. 

I would highly recommend this place for desserts and light drinks. The staff was more than accommodating and the prices were VERY wallet friendly. All I have to do now is find a companion when I'm visiting to come with me and enjoy some dessert.
author: Wes S.

description:
We had a pretty lousy experience here. He were in town celebrating our 10 year anniversary, we couldn't get reservations at the other French restaurants but this was easy enough.

Now I know why...

To keep it brief there is a dark brown haired waitress who works though who we got stuck with, she was so unpleasant and abrasive. Very abrupt and before she was even assigned to our table I tried to find the hostess when walking in and pleasantly tried smile and ask her and she literally looked right through us after making eye contact and walked away without a word. Even my wife thought it was really weird. Then of course she becomes our waitress and the rest of the meal still the same. I think she' s just an unhappy human being but that's not how I wanted to celebrate our evening. She never outright told us to "$*&^$ ourselves so I just give her credit for that lol.

The food while very high priced was over cooked and dry, both meals. The music while  a nice idea was so loud for the space its over powering to have an intimate conversation or even speak normally.

Lastly they charge a 4% San Francisco mandate tax because instead of paying for their employees health care they pass the charge onto the customer instead of incorporating it into their prices (which are high for the food quality anyway.)

The pros are the hostess was very nice and so were the bus boys.

Do yourself a favor and make reservations ahead of time if you want one of these restaurants on a memorial day weekend or other major holiday.
author: S K.

description:
Date & Time:  Monday July 14, 2008 @ 11:30am Bastille Day
Company:  Sara & Justin & Michael
Crowd:  International Fidi Professionals
Vibe:  Celebratory & Lively
Decor:  Outdoor Seating.  Sleek Interior.  Bar.  Two Dining Rooms- One w/ Neatly Spaced Tables & The Other w/  Parallel Banguettes & Chairs.  Mirrors all Around & Paintings.
Service:  Superb!
Imbibe:  Vouvray Petillant Brut
author: Genevieve Y.

description:
Cafe Claude is similar to a nice street cafe in Paris; sidewalk tables front a walkup to a higher-than-street-level restaurant tucked into square footage efficiently. And similarly, the fare is some of the stuff you'd see at that cafe - onion soup, frisee salad, cheese & charcuterie, escargot, scallops, pasta, trout, and other standard fare.

But the food isn't cafe-standard. It's definitely cooked by a chef with creativity in the air.

My beet salad was the dish of the night. Chioggia beets (red/white striped) are cooked gently, sliced thinly and served over a blue cheese creme fraiche puree that's to die for. Garnish with chopped hazelnuts & tarragon and your taste buds will thank you. (The menu says there's banyuls somewhere in this; maybe in the puree?)

My charcuterie plate was what you'd expect. No surprises here, though the tastes were very nice & balanced.

My scallops were terrific. I'll let you read the menu (mornay sauce as primary feature), but I eat - and cook - a LOT of scallops, and this preparation will definitely rank high on the list. VERY tenderly done scallops, the cheese sauce very light & fluffy, fresh mushrooms adding great texture & flavor. Just good.

I ordered an Aviation cocktail; not on the menu, but the bartender got it right. And a 1/2 carafe of a good rose wine that went well.

The female waitstaff & hostess all appear to be France natives, which lends a really nice feel to the place. The server I had was very happy & friendly, and gladly assisted me with my poor attempts to use as much of my "tourist french" as I could when ordering (just for fun). The table (bus) person was also nice, and very quick to fulfill my requests for things like a couple extra toasts for the charcuterie (which is important to do fast when you're actively eating).

I'd go back here anytime. The menu isn't huge, and isn't "grand cuisine". But it's artfully and flavorfully done, a well-run restaurant, and a good stop indeed.

(Note: This is also the review I left on TripAdvisor.com.)
author: Jay B.

description: Lovely place, very romantic ambiance, and the live music is a really nice touch. The escargot was outstanding, as well as several of the other dishes. Service was impeccable. Pacing was on the slow side but I think that's to be expected at a French restaurant. I unfortunately had to deduct one star because my pasta dish was only so-so and was too salty. Still, a great place to go on a date.
author: Moses G.

description:
My hairstylist from Paris suggested to go to Claude.
So yesterday me and my husband went there and had great great time!!!!

The food is delicious. 

 Live jazz band makes the atmosphere super romantic.  

People are nicely dressed...

If you are a chocolate love like me, you must try their moelleux au chocolat!  It is suuuuuuuuuupppppppper     delicious.........mmmmmmmm

Overall,we had a great experience and will return again!
author: Julia G.

description:
This is such a cute little place buried in an alley near Union Square. They have patio seating, friendly waiters, and delicious Croque Monseigneur sammies.

I can't wait till I'm back in SF so I can frequent this place more often.
author: Jess C.

description:
This is one of those 'tucked away but great to find' places that once you visit  you feel compelled to go back. We arrived late for dinner (around 9:300pm) but despite it being quite busy for a Monday evening, they still managed to find us a table without any waiting. We asked for Kir Royals (not on the menu) which were delivered promptly, followed by the escargot (to share), we both had the trout with a single side of pomme frites. If I had any comments about the way the fish was served it would be that there was maybe a little to much oil. Despite that it was delicious. The service was distinctly French, with our waitress only coming over the once (thankfully) to check that we were enjoying our meal. 
The following day we returned for lunch. A light soup and salad, which along with a glass of wine was enough to confirm that the previous evening was not a fluke and that the meals and service are consistently high.
author: Stephen C.

description: This hidden gem is worth finding. Hidden in an alley, this place is great for food and conversation. Limited seating inside but outside was pleasant, service impeccable and food good. The filet mignon was a bit dry so I will try the specials next time.
author: Gene V.

description: I kind of love how this place makes me feel like I've been teleported out of San Francisco into a beautiful and warm Parisian restaurant with great service, amazing food and stellar desserts. Very French, very unpretentious. Plus they often have jazz on weekends. I'm a fan.
author: Joshua K.

description: Cozy restaurant, friendly staff nice ambiance. Food was delicious and drinks were great. I'm still craving the creme brulee.
author: Stephen E.

description:
Amazing! I had the excellent Coq au Vin (chicken marinated in red wine, bacon, mushrooms, pearl onions, fingerling potatoes, baby carrots, parsley) for my entree. The chicken was cooked to perfection, incredibly tender and fell right off of the bone. The red wine/bacon/mushroom reduction was wonderful. My date had the nearly as good Thon (coriander and fennel seed crusted tombo tuna, corn succotash, smoked bacon, tomatoes, verjus reduction). The tuna was slightly seared and cooked perfectly. Very tasty, indeed. We opened with a nice bottle of 2006 Savennières, and split the melt-in-your-mouth'esque escargot as an app. All of it was fantastic. 

As for the restaurant itself, the service was great, the ambiance was very cool/chic, very cozy, and the jazz music not too overpowering or loud for conversation. I will definitely be going back here for special occasions.
author: Shawn W.

description: Restaurant was small and felt cramped. Food was mediocre. The one good thing was the service.
author: Nary K.

description: Although it is necessary to walk through a kind of murder-y alley to get here, this place is very snazzy. I came expecting the jazz thing to be a little more prominent (as there was a live band), but it was actually extremely quietly and not intrusive. I would recommend sitting at the bar if you come for the music. The food was great though! I had escargot for the first time and learned that even a gross thing can taste good if covered with sufficient butter, garlic and pastry dough.
author: Michael B.

description:
Based on tonight's experience:

Is the food good?: YES

Is the service good?: YES

Should you go?: YES
author: Bobby J.

description: Shortly after writing my review for Cafe Claude, I received a message from the manager Leila Seppa apologizing for our experience and informing us that it has been brought to the attention of their kitchen staff.  Such great follow up deserves an extra star put back on.
author: Annie D.

description:
It's a decent French bistro in Union Square. Very small, intimate, and noisy. 

We stopped by for dinner before our reception.

Ryan ordered the onion soup and New York steak. I ordered the escargots and skirt steak with fries.

My snails were delicious, piping hot with butter but not enough garlic. The steak was solid, not enough for me to say wow though.

We skipped dessert since we were pressed for time. The couple sitting next to us was loud and annoying, considering the fact the tables were packed so closely together.

Service was good and the staff very attentive. Our waitress spoke French which was a plus.

It's a decent bistro but not good enough for me to return.

Appetizer, entrees, and 2 glasses of wine = $97
author: Betty N.

description:
Such a small restaurant tucked away in an alleyway, but you'll be pleasantly surprised with your dining experience here. 

The live jazz band and dim lighting inside the restaurant makes for a laid back romantic dinner.  The french speaking patrons sipping on wine as we entered was def. a good sign that this place had some potential (if french people choose to eat here, it must be decent right??)

We started off with the french onion soup and beef tartare that others have recommended, both were top notch and delicious.  The waiter was nice enough to recommend to us the larger portion of beef tartare, warning us the small portion was probably not gonna be satisfying enough (he knew from the look of me what was up) The server prepares the tartare right in front of you, which was pretty awesome.

On to the entrees. I got the coq au vin and she got the trout, both were tasty, but not the best I've ever had.  Also the waiter failed to bring out my glass of wine even after reminding him once.  That aside, still made for a satisfying dining experience!

5 stars for the ambiance
4 stars for the appetizers
3 stars for the entrees/lapse in service
author: Ngoc N.

description:
Enjoyed a yummy lunch there today with my sister, in from out of town.  She and her husband had been here before so it was her pick and treat.  Excellent service (a model for all to emulate), great food and a lively crowd.  Though it was raining, it was full to the gills.

I recommend to foodie and social-seeker alike.  

Will dine there again - and soon!
author: Bowagenous U.

description:
I had lunch here one day - the food was good but the wait (for our server to get us menus, take our orders, bring us our food) was getting ridiculous, even after peak lunch hours. It was like the feeling you get when you start to think that they forget that you're sitting there. The service we got obviously did not match up to that of other French restaurants, so I was a bit disappointed.

The croque madame was tasty (looked beautiful with the egg on top) and it came with fries. I had some type of smoked salmon sandwich (I forgot what it was called) and they put a lot of different fancy kinds of leaves and lettuce in there, which I love. Their French onion soup was really good.

This place is located in an alley and had outdoor seating. The outdoor seating doesn't have the greatest view because it's... in an alley. The inside is nice, though.
author: Anna V.

description:
This is a really chic place with a very unique patio. Words can't do justice to describe it, so I won't try. Walk by the alley entrance and see for yourself! :-)

I had the Truffle Mousse (chicken liver) and Salmon. The mousse was pretty potent and every bite came with contradictions that would challenge any palette. Simply delicious! The salmon was crispy on the outside but mouthwateringly soft on the inside. Impeccable, although the base and risotto like side was quite forgettable.

Overall, this place gets two thumbs up!
author: Vishal A.

description:
I made a mistake by ordering the Pan Boeuf Roti. This dish is essentially a steak or beef sandwich. The flavor was great but after seeing other dishes come from the kitchen, I realized my mistake.

Don't settle for comfort food here. Stretch yourself and order outside of your zone. Everything looked delish! Be sure to ask their friendly staff if you're having trouble making a decision. They will be happy to give a push in a tasty direction. 

$12. pan boeuf roti
house-cured top sirloin, vidalia onions, tomato confit, horseradish crème, dijon aioli, french fries
author: Gregg M.

description:
Perhaps it's the walk down a cute, brick-lined alley...but this was attraction at first sight.

If you don't pay attention, you'll pass right by Claude Lane. Lane, in fact, is perhaps a bit extravagant in describing this little alley that leads off of the main thoroughfare of Sutter. Just getting here is a small adventure. So, I started off smitten.

As is appropriate in a French restaurant, the waiter was attentive, efficient, and just polite enough. He seemed to be there just when we wanted him.

For the three of us, this stop was more about catching up with long lost friends. However, good food is always a compliment to great company, right?

My bf ordered steak tartare. That was a bit of a risk. Perhaps he was feeling the romance in the air. After all, a good steak tartare is fantastic. A bad one...well, fortunately this was a good one. While it wasn't amazing, it was classic, fresh, and nicely plated. All of the appropriate accoutrements were there and plentiful. Perhaps a higher grade of beef would have pushed this over the top.

I ordered the pork filet with carmelized apples, white balsamic vinegar, and honey cream sauce. The filet was moist, cooked evenly, and obviously paired beautifully with the apples. 

This is traditional French cuisine prepared and served just like it should be. I am a bit biased after having eaten many times at a local bistro that is simply astounding. So, really, I'd like to give this place 3.5 stars. 

Ambiance, a hideaway location, proper French food...this is a lovely place for a date or a chat with a friend whose company you have missed for years.
author: Lori M.

description:
We had reservation at 6pm. we sat down right after we got there. However, we waited 15 minutes before our waitress came. The appetizers, Escargot en Croute, and Steak Tartare were very yummy. First time needed to show my ID in a French restaurant when we were ordering wines.Two of my friends ordered Fillet Mignon, I tried their steaks. Both of the steaks were a little chewy (worse than the steaks I cooked). However, the Agneau and Coq Au Vin were very good. 

Overall, this is a ok place.  with their prices, I rather try out other French restaurants.
author: Evan L.

description: Excellent service and fabulous food. The French onion soup was perfect. I loved the Cod and my wife had the short ribs which were outstanding .
author: Harvey F.

description:
FANTASTIC.

Why?
It's cute.
It's tucked away and not screaming for attention (but still busy as can be, so you know they must be doing something right).
It's casual and unpretentious, but very still very classy and oh-so-French.
It's delicious. The food was so well-prepared, with flavors that were not too heavy or overdone.
The portions were just about the right size.
They have both indoor and outdoor seating.
Our server was French, had a delightful French accent, but was not snobby, and did her job flawlessly with great timing.

I sometimes hesitate to give 5 stars based on just one-time experiences, but the fact that I cannot wait to go back for more says enough for me.
author: Felicia C.

description:
Where in the world IS this place?!

Oh, THERE it is. In some seedy looking alley way in the middle of downtown. Hmm.......

My two buddies and I were meeting up with an old friend who recently moved to SF. She had us scavenging for this place and we finally found it thanks to our handy SF tourist map and GPS system ( I heart my blackberry). 

We sat outside right by the window of a hair salon and we saw the CUTEST big dog sleeping right by it. ADORABLE! Then a very pleasant French waitress came to wait on us. The word "friendly" and "French" normally don't go together, esp, if it's towards Americans, but this place defied that stereotype. 

The food was grrrrrEAT! Our waitress recommended the Quiche Lorraine to me since I wasn't in the mood to eat something hearty. She said it was her favorite and I trusted her judgment. Let me tell you it was SUPERB! It's the size of a small candy dish and it was very moist on the inside, with a nice flaky crust on the outside. It came with a light side of mixed greens. Quite easily the best light lunch I've had in a while. The rest of the folks enjoyed their Croque Madame (a staple at any French restaurant) which was not bad. The crust was a bit hard, but that's how most open-faced sandwiches are. I think the other fellas had a pork sandwich which was really good, too. 

Come here. It's cute. It's good.
author: Melody W.

description:
3.5 stars

Not bad, but not exceptional.  The restaurant itself is very cute and conveniently located in Union Square, with outdoor seating.  However, the food was just mediocre.  I didn't hate it, but I won't be back.
author: K V.

description: Enjoyed a lovely dinner.  They were booked, so we had to come in a bit late....so, make reservations in advance.  Love the alley-way dining.  Will come back.
author: Reesie B.

description:
Freaking fantastic. I love French food and this is the best that I've experienced in the city. Whenever I go to another French restaurant, I compare them to the standards of this place. It's pricey but so worth it. I like the laid back atmosphere. Don't come here if you're in a rush. This is the kind of place where you just have to sit back, enjoy a glass of wine, and savor every morsel of your meal. Great for a date or celebrating a special occasion. Make sure to call ahead for a reservation though. It gets very lively here at night. 

Just thinking about Cafe Claude is making me salivate. If only every day were a special occasion...then again maybe it's best that I reserve this for once in a while because my wallet would be slimming down and my ass would be getting fat. It's just all so decadent and rich, so delightfully French. Les sigh...sugar mama where art thou...
author: Nancy C.

description:
My husband and I decided to go out for a New Years Eve Eve dinner to avoid all the crowds. We picked Cafe Claude because we've heard a great review from a good friend; and she right on! Cafe Claude is a cute and romantic place to go on a date. 

On the night that we went, there was a live Jazz band playing and it just enhanced the atmosphere of the restuarant. We order the escargot which was delicious! The onion soup tasted just like it did when I had it in Paris. My husband's ordered the Porc au miel, which was to die for! The sauce in that dish was creamy, sweet and decadent, complimenting the pork like no other! My dish, the Coq au vin was also equally delicious; the chicken bone easily falling away from the meat. It was cooked to perfection! I would definitely come back again and highly recommend it for anyone looking for a romantic setting and deliciously wonderful food.
author: Angela T.

description:
Cafe Claude brought me back to Paris!!! Tucked in the ally, Cafe Claude emulates the classic French cafes. I recently returned from Paris and have not had great French food until my recent visit to Cafe Claude. 

I highly recommend their porc (pork). I'm always hesitant to order porc, since many places tend to overcook pork. Instead, the porc was cooked to perfection. The cut was large and tender. The cognac jus was sweet in the mouth. My mouth is watering just thinking about it.
author: Zoe B.

description:
More like 4.5 stars. We stopped by spontaneously last night and we got a table outside right away. It's been a few years since I've been here but last night reminded me how special this place really is.

The endive salad to start off was just right. I've never tasted endives that were so crips before - they had the texture of pears. The lady had the coq au vin which fell right off the bone. And boy did she sop up that sauce with the extra bread. I had the roasted lamb with fava beans which was devoured immediately. The hearty sauce for my dish was quickly soaked up as well.

Oh yeah, the house chardonnay was well balanced and hit all the right flavor spots and the jazz band was accompanied our meal with  some tres cool melodies.

The only downer was that it took forever to get the check. I almost had to get up to ask the server a second time. 

Overall, however, it was a wonderful meal and next time, I won't wait years to return.
author: Art O.

description: A little piece of Paris in San Francisco - wonderful meal!  We had the mussels and escargots - great flavor, good portions, hot food and constant attention from multiple wait staff.  The Monk fish is my favorite! Reservations were easy, but felt like I got lucky because the place was totally filled with customers and more waiting outside.  Fun, unique place to visit!  Didn't feel rushed.   Highly recommended.
author: Brad A.

description: What a darling little restaurant tucked in a little alley. You'd never know it was there at all if my colleague had not suggested it for a work lunch. Everything was delicious, the waiter was very patient with our lack of mastery of the french menu. I wish it was a dinner where I could sample the wine list and I wish the place was a trifle bigger, quieter. Lovely place otherwise - the croque madame was divine.
author: L L.

description: If you're in SF, definitely check out this restaurant. You will not be disappointed. It's a quaint spot on a side street that has indoor and outdoor seating. Went here for my husband's birthday and we loved our dinner. The trout is amazing!! The service and live music playing in the background were superb! We will definitely be back.
author: Nichelle S.

description:
Exquisite French Restaurant.
It is located on Claude lane together with other good restaurants.
Their escargot is amazing. Basically, you will love anything you order there. The atmosphere is super romantic, even though it is located in the financial district between tall buildings.
author: S ..

description: Chill ambiance. Good for dates. Nice restaurant, so the food is on the pricier side. The food is pretty darn good though, although I've had a few misses. Catch it when there's jazz playing--it's pretty good. Staff is usually pretty friendly.
author: Thuan N.

description: I dropped by this place for a late lunch and didn't have a lot just a tartare and a salad with a glass of wine. The service was really friendly and professional. The decor is appropriate but you can see it's a bit aged. The food was ok, my warm chevre salad was correct, salve for having my cheese served on slices of bread instead of a warm slice of breaded chevre itself, as the menu stated (I don't eat bread so this was a surprise). Tartare seemed a little different from my expectations ( this is obviously a personal preference), but fresh and you could mix it yourself with a variety of condiments. The glass of cremant was a little expensive at $14, and also, I have ordered another wine but was too hungry and in a hurry to exchange. So overall this is just 3 stars as I wasn't impressed and would probably try another place next time just to see what's out there as the experience doesn't promise that I would miss out on something.
author: Aga K.

description:
This is a restaurant I've been frequented for man years. The food has always been above average and it location has made it a very convenient place to frequent whenever I am hanging out downtown. 

It had been a couple of years since I eaten here and I was pleasantly surprised as to how the ambiance had changed. Gone was the pretentious and oh so french snootiness of the last decade. There was still a strong french presence but without the attitude. Well done mon ami. 

We ordered some coquilles St. Jacques for starters but found the scallops to be underwhelming. I ordered the Thon and my wife ordered the salmon as our main dishes. Both were hardy and tasty. We both agreed that we would order them again.

Lastly, I must admit that I had a very memorable experience. I ordered a glass of Beaujolais and it was the first time that I understood why everyone gets so excited about this wine. I quite liked it and I hope I am developing a taste for this french classic.
author: Juan V.

description:
Cafe claude is the definition of a hidden gem. Situated on Claude Lane right around the corner from Union Square, this european style alley is the perfect setting for a cafe. Seated inside or out, you will be served by attentive staff who know their craft, and their menu. Listen to the recommendations provided you can describe things you like and you cannot go wrong. As a french fry lover, I had to try the French cafe's fries, and I was not disappointed. 

Do not be fooled by the 'Cafe' in their name, however. One of the most amazing features of this place is their bar. The bar manager created the drink menu from scratch crafting each drink with the precision and expertise of a true mixologist. I cannot praise him enough for the amazing concoctions that he creates. Ask for an after dinner cocktail that will amaze you and be ready for a coffee-esque martini that will blow your mind. 

I love this place. Can't wait to go back. Perfect for intimate nights, or group get togethers, Cafe Claude can do it all.
author: Ryan G.

description:
Love this place! Have had many a gathering here.  Great ambiance, great food and service.

Favorites include the Croque Madame, Croque Monsieur (I admit I'm a fry and cheese addict)...this time I was on a 'diet' so I opted for the nicoise salad - mighty delicious!

Lovely to sit al fresco on a sunny day.  Suggest making reservations.
author: Cathy K.

description:
I am from the land of commercial fine-dining glitzy restaurants, so something quaint at first sight such as Cafe Claude immediately warmed up to me.  The restaurant entrance is very charming, being located on a street with its own namesake.

I have been here a few times over the past four years.  And the experience has been consistently pleasant.  The wine selection is diversely French and the waiters have recommended all good wines to me in my experience.

The steak tartar is the famous signature and I agree that it is very good.  They have a good French onion soup also, I would give it a 7 out of 10.  The creme brulee is all right.  I prefer the custard to be less cold (although they do complete the burnt sugar as you order it).  Prices are also reasonable for the quality of food and service that you pay for.  It is a lovely stop, but perhaps is missing that jene sais quoi
author: Anhdao D.

description:
We walked here from our appetizers at Pouf and our expectations of a French cafe were met. Small place ( aren't most of them here) with a lovely jazz vocalist. Typical French cuisine - was warm and cozy. Service was friendly.

I would stop by if in the area not sure if I would make a special trip though.
author: Lala C.

description:
Nice French bistro tucked in an alley. People know to come here. Charming is about what best describes this place. Friendly staff and great dishes. You can't go wrong with food. 

Escargot en Croute - 4
Coquilles Saint Jacques - 4 - crab cake things were good...
Steak Tartare - 4 raw meat perfection
Brochette - 4 - fat tiger prawns
Fusilli with Tiger Prawns - 4 - pasta!
Coq Au Vin - 5 - order this...
Crème Coconut - 4 - like a flan...
Tarte Tatin - 4 apple tart...
Crème Brulée - 3.5 ... ok...

4 stars for the food alone.
author: Mike W.

description:
I LOVE this place! You pay for quality and you get nothing less! I came here for a business lunch and it was absolutely delicious! I defintely reviewed multiple reviews before deciding to come here. I ordered the trout with almonds, fingerling potatoes and green beans. Trout was flavorful and there was plenty of it! The potatoes went well with the trout, and green beans were simple but it all went so well together, I was in food heaven. My co workers got the steak frites, seafood risotto (special of the day) and a sandwich. They all enjoyed their entrees and we even ordered dessert! Two dark chocolate mousse and two creme brulee's. CHOCOLATE MOUSSE was so so so DELICIOUS! You must try it for yourself!

It's a very cute place and also cramped but if you have ever went to Paris, things are much smaller there. I loved the decor inside. It made me feel like I was in Paris again, its romantic and the paintings were pretty. The waiters come evey now and then to refill your water. Although one downfall is, service takes long so make sure you have time to spare! I came here for lunch and I look forward to coming here for dinner when the jazz band is playing!

CHEERS!
author: Jennifer D.

description:
These stars are all about service quality and ambience as I didn't eat here today.  I've found that I have a tendency to study better if I get out of my apartment so I've been exploring my neighborhood and environs for nice places to plonk down my little laptop and do some quality reading/writing.  Today, I ventured out of the typical SF cold into the welcoming warmth of Cafe Claude.  

First off, Claude Lane is just PACKED with beautiful, exciting looking restaurants!  I went into the cafe at about 5pm to find that the tables out front were set but empty, inside seemed about the same with two French accented men chatting amicably over a couple of pints at the beautiful bar.  I asked the pleasant bar tender if it would be ok for me to take a table for just a coffee while I studied and he smiled and said I could use one of the two up front in the window.  It was cozy, charming and perfectly suited to my needs!  The coffee itself was ok: I got a cafe au lait which was a little watery, but it came with a dark chocolate square, which I liked.  

I studied, undisturbed until about 6:30.  By then lots of people had ambled in for drinks and dinner and it was getting pretty noisy.  Not unpleasantly so for a restaurant, but a bit much for concentrating on my assignment.  

As I got up, the lead maitr'd or manager (couldn't tell) asked me if I'd like to stay for dinner and explained that there would soon be live jazz.  She further elaborated that from now on there would be jazz every night, and not just a few nights a week.  I thanked her ~ her hospitality was warm and genuine ~ but declined.  It was quick and easy to settle the bill and I was on my way.  

I will likely return here to study and/or for drinks/dinner.  I didn't look at the menu, but could smell wonderful things coming from the kitchen.
author: Margret C.

description:
Had a delicious lunch here with my husband and two friends yesterday. 

The croquet Monsieur was yummy, the roasted beet salad was excellent, and the mussels came in a mustardy cream sauce that was great to sop up in the crusty baguette.

Service was very friendly and unobtrusive. 

We sat outside, and I only wish the table had been level. It was on a slightly downward-sloping angle, which made it less comfortable to eat on.
author: Lu D.

description:
My husband and I had great experience at this tucked away, cozy spot last week. The restaurant has an authentic, warm vibe. Our waiter was friendly, attentive, and had no problem chatting about the menu with us.

Chevre salad: fresh, delicious. Good start to the meal.
Raviole: Fireworks in my mouth! (in a good way!) I have never had anything like this dish, it was very fresh and tasty.
Croq au vin: Fantastic! Fall of the bone tender chicken.. the veggies and chicken tasted like they had been cooking for days, perfectly infused with the delicious flavor.
Trout: I would give this entree 3 stars. It was heavier and less flavorful than we expected.

The serving sizes were decent. We left stuffed and we can really put down some food.  My one and only gripe is that my french 75 tasted like pink lemonade.  I would highly recommend this lovely little piece of dining heaven!
author: Mollie E.

description:
As I was walking down Claude Ln (think tiny alley) from the Loehmann's end, I was pleasantly surprised to find some cute boutiques (one of them being the Margaret O'Leary store) before I arrived at Cafe Claude. 

The cafe had a nice vibe but the food was just mediocre. I ordered the  trout with almonds and it was very bland. I do recommend the  raviole de champignon though it looked more like a small plate of sauteed shitake and wild mushrooms covered by a wide noodle. I had expected little raviolis filled with mushrooms but there's only one gigantic ravioli if you could even call that a ravioli. 

The service was good -- everyone was friendly and all the waiters were sporting Lacoste shirts haha
 
However, my dining experience was severly diminished by this one annoying guy at another table. He kept laughing unbelievably loud that even with the muffled noise of the cafe, no one could miss it. It was deafening!

A nice touch was finding a Yelp flyer when the bill came. Go Yelp!
author: Helen Y.

description: The food was nothing short of deelish-ness. We ordered the Friday special duck breast and the Chicken roti with fries. Fan-furkin-tastic. And the live jazz the background only added to the feel and mood. The atmosphere is very cozy and intimate. Granted that I'm biased towards French cuisine and live jazz, but really, the experience was just magnifique...and all that jazz.
author: Reema M.

description: lovely and popular French restaurant. Not cheap but worth the money. Be in time to make reservations, this place is busy!
author: Dirk d.

description:
No available reservations on Open Table, but I went anyway hoping for the best since I was dining solo (in town on business) and the nice hostess found a way to seat me.

Good by the glass wine selection, both French and Californian (but nothing under $9). Crusty French rolls with good butter to start. The waiter was a bit of a snob, but I didn't take it personally after I noticed the same condescending tone being used at all of his tables. 

My food came out super quick and was delicious: Trout Almondine with tender fingerling potatoes and thin, crisp green beans. The trout seemed very fresh, just a few tiny, tiny bones that I saw, and the mushrooms on top seemed weird, but just avoided both of those and was happy. 

If you're not familiar with the area, it is a bit hard to find, tucked away in an alley with several other restaurants. There's a modest size sheltered outdoor dining area and the ambiance indoors is lovely and very romantic. Tables inside can be a bit close to each other, particularly 2-tops, which does detract a bit from the experience, but is fairly typical for a place like this.
author: Sarah F.

description: Came here for lunch with a best friend on a Friday. Great food, great service! Only gripe was that the inside tables are packed tightly together which made it pretty difficult to get up and away from the inside seat to use the restroom without knocking over your neighbor's drink or brushing up against their food but aside from that, an excellent French restaurant! Highlights were the escargot (of course), steak tartare, onion soup and their frites. The flight of Rose that they're offering at the moment was pretty spectacular too! Enjoy!
author: Shaun F.

description:
Some of us have a 'Mr. Big'. I have mine. He was in town and he took me to Cafe Claude. Perfect 'Mr. Big' situation.

Cafe Claude is a gem tucked in an alley near Union Square. I had meant to go there in a long time, and I picked the right occasion to give it a try - what a captivating place!

The restaurant is relatively small, with a nice patio area. The interior looked more appealing to me, with its dimmed lighting, jazz band playing and sensual decor. We sat at the very back of the restaurant, where we could still enjoy the music, but at the same time carry a good conversation comfortably. Yes, that was the most important thing as we had a lot to catch up on.

I ordered a glass of Sancerre, a French white that went really well with the special: seafood risotto. What an entrancing experience! Maybe it was the fact that I had the worst seafood risotto in my life a week before (see previous review), or maybe it was the ambiance or circumstance. But all I can say is 'wow'! The perfect texture, the perfect flavors, fabulous presentation!

Big ordered the Truit Aux Amandes (pan-seared trout, almonds, white mushroom lemon sauce, fingerling potatoes, romano beans). His dish was also delish, and although he was a little hesitant about going to a French restaurant, he was really happy with my suggestion. ;-) 

The service was attentive, and I really appreciated that they gave us time to just enjoy our meal and conversation without interruptions. That was definitely a plus.

It was one of those  nice warm week nights in SF, and the situation didn't allow me to focus 100% on the restaurant experience as I would like to. However, I am looking forward to coming back, maybe one of those cozy foggy nights, and have staples like the steak tartare and my favorite - French Onion soup. I have a feeling I will update the review and give it a 5. ;-)
author: Simone W.

description:
I feel utterly negligent for not reviewing Cafe Claude yet. I have eaten here a number of times for special occasions, dates, casual lunches...you name it. The prices are not the usual exorbitant sums for French bistro food that you expect to pay in other places that are poor excuses for modern French. 

I absolutely love the soupe a l'oignon, and the steak tartare is to die for. I usually get the tatare with a side of pomme frites to share with my table mates. The menu and wine list are fantastically edited. 

And the live jazz...oh my. That is the icing on the cake here. Of course many places have live jazz during dinner, but here it just adds to the charming, casual ambiance that they project. 

My final suggestion - weather permitting - eat outside. It's typically heated to fend off the San Francisco breezes and the alley has awesome murals. Especially for lunch, it feels like a quintessential cafe on a street in Paris.
author: Carolyn B.

description:
A piece of Paris in SF.
We go there almost every Saturday after my acting class.

My favorite dish is the Croque Madame and their Chevre Salad.

Service is nice and clean. Waiters are pro. and each one of them has their own style and personality. 
I like this place!
author: Sandy B.

description:
The food and decor made me feel I was in a cozy bistro in Paris. In a good way!

It was supposed to be a quiet, intimate and above all tasty dinner for two and with all the pressure inherent in that last sentence, Cafe Claude truly fit the bill. 

We had two starters, both were great: a creamy and comforting tomato soup and a wonderful tuna tartare (from which I would have removed the goat cheese but that's me being picky).

My partner's main was the day's special, a pasta loaded with mussels and fish in a wonderful sauce. I had the salmon on couscous which was simple but very well done.  We were too full for desert.

Overall, a good dinner at a good price. Well deserving of 4 stars.

As Julia would say: bon appetit!
author: Hagit K.

description: The food was so-so.The tables are packed in close.It is very crowded and noisy.Way too pricey for what you are served.
author: Victoria S.

description:
I had a hankering for escargot...yup...snails. I love them. I had a layover in the city so I yelped "escargot..SF" I looked at a lot of french rest. in the union square area and decided on this one. SCORE! 

We arrived at 4:45, they were only serving pate or cheese plates at the bar....purrrfect. We had Lillet on the rocks and the pate plate and great conversation. At six we asked to be moved to a dinner table, we got the best table and the best server "David from San Clemente" ( We love you!) 

We ordered a great Syrah and I had my escargot, the were so good with puff pastry and tons of parsley, not as garlicky as I have had and I appreciated that! She had the trout and I had the tuna...delish and we both saved room for dessert. Creme Brulee and Chocolate Mousse, of course. The mousse was so creamy, like melting a piece of fine chocolate in your mouth!

Oh Claude I miss you already! XOXO
author: Penni P.

description: Cafe Claude seems to be lost. Sad. It was very good in the past, for many years. Now its French charm is gone, the food quality deteriorated -- it's French in name only. Oh...
author: Sergei B.

description:
With their alleyway location and French music filling the air, you might feel transported just a bit.  The waiters are definitely French, which brings you even closer to France.  With seating inside and out, the place does tend to fill up during the weekday lunch crowd.

Starting off, they are generous with their bread and I agree, it's yummy. I couldn't stop eating it either.  I chose the Pan Poulet  ($10) - roasted chicken breast, tomatoes, butter lettuce, egg, mayonnaise, and mixed green salad.  The sandwich was on a Ciabatta type bread and it was average.  The dressing on the salad was nice and tastier than the sandwich unfortunately.  My companion had the Quiche Lorraine  ($8.50) - pate feuillete, crme fraiche, bacon, and egg.  We also shared the Tarte Tatin ($6) - upside-down apple tart with caramel sauce and whipped cream.  The dessert was simple, I had hoped for a little bit more sweetness or a wow factor.  

Overall, the food was decent, service was fine. Nothing really spectacular or horrendous either.  Perhaps their other dishes might fare better.
author: Teri C.

description:
After reading the glowing reviews, i had high hopes for this place.

Too bad they weren't fulfilled.....

Parking was easy, (there's a very reasonable lot nearby.) 
A plus, and another reason to hope we liked this place.

Upon ordering my appetizer, (the Tartare de Thon Rouge) i asked if it had onion of any kind in it, (I can't eat onions.) I was assured it didn't.
When the dish was brought out, i could smell the onion before it was even set in front of me.
The server was fairly nice about it, and the chef offered to make me a new one, sans onion. I was impressed by this, and excited to try the dish.
Unfortunately, the dish just didn't work for me. The goat cheese totally overpowered the tuna, and the quail egg added nothing to it whatsoever.
I still held out hope for the entree portion of the meal.
Another let down....I had the Truite aux Amandes. I've had the equivalent of this dish at several other places, (all of them doing a better job with it.)
The dish had no taste, no real flavor at all. I rarely complain about food being too bland ,but this definitely was.

After the replacement appetizer, the service was lacking.
We were never asked if we wanted another drink, or bread refilled. (We didn't want either one, but it's still proper service to be asked.)

When someone brought out our drinks at the beginning of the evening, we practically had to flag her down after watching her offer our drinks to another table.

We decided to skip dessert, nothing looked very interesting.  We also didn't want to give them anymore money than we already had.

With all the stellar French restaurants in the city, don't waste your time and money on this one.
author: Amanda G.

description:
The restaurant is located out in an alley area, not easy to find. You have a choice of eating outside by the closed road or inside. 

We decided to eat inside. Ordered the New York Steak medium with a glass if cab. The steak was good but the fries was a bit too salty. The cab was good. 

For dessert, ordered the chocolate cake and creme brûlée. Both were good. 

Service was good.

Good place for dinner.
author: John N.

description:
The owner of Cafe Claude has transformed this little hidden alley over the years, especially with the addition of their sister restaurant Gitane, in order to make it worthy of being renamed "Claude Lane."
