I then ordered the pork with gratin on the side and my husband ordered steak with fries and the gratin as well, being that it is one of our favorites side dishes. For dessert, we shared the crème brulée and it was very scrumptious. Everything was very high quality. The pork was a bit undercooked for my taste but even if, I ate every last bite. I had a bite of my husband's steak and the sauce was just right, not too rich not too bland. Our waiter was french and spoke french to us and english to our vegetarian friends. (We'll make it a habit not to bring them along with us next time we go to a french restaurant being that two of them only ordered fries and a salad, this resto is not vegan friendly). Anyway, we always enjoy it when we can have a nice convo in french with our waiter without the parisian attitude. The location is alright. I had to park in the garage nearby but it wasn't too pricey. The staff was also very professional and kept their cool even if the noise made it hard to hear. 

The down side was that the decor was a bit average. Not at all tacky just boring and predictable. Having worked near la tour eiffel and seeing it daily, I'm sick of seeing it plastered everywhere outside of France. I know it is the symbol of France but there is much more to France than the tower and I think for those who have never been, it would definitely be appreciated if those best kept secrets were to be shared. Anyway, I feel that they could have been more creative with that. It's quite noticeable because the place is a bit small (to no fault of their own) and (I don't know if it was because of Bastille Day but it was crowded. I guess for all these reasons it didn't give you much of the desire to want to hang around longer than you needed to). 

I will sum it up by saying my husband and I both agreed that despite the price for the wine and being just a bit jipped for the price for the food in comparison to what you could find in a little brasserie tucked away in Paris for a more reasonable price, we'll take into consideration that this SF and say we're definitely coming back and are sure to be regulars (ou bien, pour ceux qui parlent français: les habitués) ! 

au fait, c'est dommage que les prix sont un peu chers, on aimerait bien y aller plus souvent.. !
author: Lana I.

description:
As others have said, this is a true hidden gem situated in a little alleyway. We met friends visiting from out of town here for a drink after having dinner somewhere else, and I never would have known about this place had they not been recommended to it by one of their friends who used to live in SF. 

From the moment I walked into the little red tent that is the covered HEATED patio area (it was raining outside) and up the stairs, I felt like I could have been in France. I loved the whole ambiance of the place. We just sat at the bar for a drink (and the service at the bar was great) but I wished I would have had the time to have a full meal here. I did look at the menu and the food looks awesome.

There was a live band playing, and they were great. Just the right volume to be heard but not overpowering, I could still carry on a conversation.

I WILL be back here to try out the food!
author: Stephanie D.

description:
OVERALL: 4

FOOD: 4
SERVICE: 4.5
AMBIANCE: 4
VALUE: 3.5

Great place to play dress-up & grown-up....tucked away in a hidden side street, cozy, dark wood, candlelit tables, very Paris-bistro.  Smallish space, but apparently live Jazz Thursday-Saturday.

Started w/Steak Tartare which was assembled & presented tableside: UNFORGETTABLE concoction of rare ground flank steak, cornichons, capers, egg yolk, mustard, parsley, shallots, & Tabasco served with crostini.....first time ever, and mourning the 26yrs of missed opportunities!

Other dishes were well-done, but not nearly as memorable.  Coq au Vin was hearty, Vegetarian Lasagna was cute in its personal size terrine, but slightly bland.

Will be back for the tartare, and also to try the yummy-smelling French Onion Soup.
author: Amy K.

description: My friend asked me if I thought Cafe Claude was more like Annie Clark or Jenny Lewis, but after careful thought I'm thinking she might be more like Amber Heard.  There's a lot to like here: A trendy atmosphere, pastry puff escargot charisma, and some serious smoky goodness coming from the coq au vin.  Yes, CC is very much like Ms. Heard, by that I mean it has knock-you-off-your-feet style.
author: Michael D.

description:
As a French, Cafe Claude was my first trendy/dress-up I went into since I move to San Francisco in 2008. This French restaurant is really good! The service was amazing and the food was delicious. 

We got the best onion soup we had so far. We also try their Lasagna and it was a success! They will give you bread and butter at the beginning, which is a good way to get introduce to French culture ;)

Located in Downtown San Francisco, near the French Embassy, Cafe Claude is a kind of hidden spot in the city since it is in a very narrow and quiet street.

The place provides both inside and outside seating. I'm not sure their layout is the best to accommodate group (you should call them first) but for a date this place is simply perfect ;)

They provide also live performance during the week, but since we went there on a Sunday we were not able to take advantage of this. 

The ratio between quality/price there is very good. Though if you go there for dinner you will end up paying 15-20$ per person for an entree.

I will definitely come back. Especially since I would like to try their Steak Tartare and enjoy some of their jazz musicians (Thurs to Sat) :D

==============================

Pros:
- Real French food
- Service is great
- Good place for a date

Cons:
- None :-)

Cedric's secret advice:
 - Best time of the day to go there? 6pm, on Sundays (to avoid the crown if you plan to have dinner there). I would rather suggest going there for lunch if you look for a cheaper option.

Cedric's favorite option:
 - Lasagne!
author: Cedric L.

description: Food was good, nothing spectacular. Though, I really enjoyed the pomme frites. Also, our waitress, Ilhem, was very knowledgeable about the menu. 3 members of my group had food allergies, and she was able to help us select palatable options.
author: Albert R.

description:
Cute little French Bistro in an alley.  There are a couple of alleys in San Francisco with nice restaurants, so don't confuse this with the other ones.  This alley only has ONE nice restaurant.  

So, date and I drove around and around and around.....but we couldn't find the restaurant.  We gave up, parked in Chinatown, came close to hitting a motorcyler who tried to steal our spot (but we both fit), and wandered towards Union Square.  Cafe Claude was located  near Banana Republic, around the corner of Loehmann's, and in an alley where no cars could get through.  You better not get lost!

The space is tight with many small tables.  It is also loud, so no need to keep a hush hush voice.  Foodwise, I recommend the beef tartare, and let them mix it for you.  Do not mix it yourself, that would be bad.  It's not as good as Jeanty's *sniff*, but probably the best one in the city now that it's competitor left.  Escargot was okay, I don't recommend it, but it wasn't bad.
author: Carrie-C N.

description: Cafe Claude is very cute tucked away from the main streets. The food was excellent. Make sure you make a reservation though and I suggest sitting outside.
author: Ashley C.

description: Love Cafe Claude! Amazing food and great service. The cocktails were well balanced and the main courses are soooo good! Perfect for a date night in SF.
author: Dandy O.

description:
In a nutshell:

Food - 4 stars
Service - 4.5 stars
P/C (bang for the buck) - 4 stars

It could have been very awkward (I was setting up my friend with my friend's friend), but the food, the service and the ambiance of cafe claude made it very smooth and appealing.  We went here on a Saturday night and it was still a bit early (6pm) so the restaurant was just getting cozy and chatty with people.  The server came within seconds offered us water and drinks.  We were studying the menu for quite a few minutes and the server took our orders - we got a filet mignon, a tuna dish, a pork tenderloin dish and of course...the steak tartare (I've done some prior research and found that this seemed to be the signature dish).

The food came pretty fast - I'd say in 10 minutes, so that was always pleasant for a person such as myself who's born impatient.  The steak tartare was prepared tableside and looked delicious - and it tasted delicious.  I'd say if I had to compare this to the Bistro Jeanty steak tartare, this tasted much more light, smooth and tangy.  I still do like the bistro jeanty tartare, but if i had to choose, i'd go with the cafe claude tartare...

Then the dessert round - we shared a thing of the tarte tatin and the creme brulee.  Creme brulee is just one of those desserts that i don't get into so i wasn't blown away by it.  The tarte tatin was good and cleanly prepared, but I am not sure that it was mind blowing either...Compared to the entrees, I feel as if the restaurant had some room for improvement in the dessert department.  

Overall, service was pleasant and efficient, the food was great and the ambiance was also very good - we stuck around for a little bit of the live jazz performance and it was such a nice touch to end the evening!

Conclusion:  Will definitely return to this joint to satisfy my steak tartare cravings!
author: Mike P.

description: Great for date night... cosy table, jazz music and good french food...
author: Zubin V.

description: Small, marginal, over priced food with in attentive service.  Will not go back.  The surrounding French restaurants like Cafe Bastille, Cafe Presse, and the Central are so much better.
author: Tracy F.

description: Small and quaint French restaurant in a cute alley downtown. I give this restaurant a solid rating, but I am not running back anytime soon. It is a solid restaurant but if you are looking for a gem, go to l'ardoise close to Duboce park. If you cannot make it there OR you can't get reservations, Cafe Claude is a solid choice.
author: Melanie S.

description:
L'amour!!!!!

A good friend sent me here when I stayed a night alone on business right by in the city. 

Eating in an adorable, romantic, and dimly lit French restaurant is super great- unless you were alone like me that evening. 

Luckily, the food and atmosphere KNOCKED my socks off!! 

Live Jazz was great. Incredible wine list. Great table layout (I'm a nit-pick for where they place people who eat alone, but they nailed eat and gave me a prime people watching table.) 

FOOD!!! OMG!!! Pomme Frites- YUMMMMM to the max. mouthwateringly delishhhh!

Seared Ahi with onion and bacon confit and lemon zest- GOOD GOD. WHOA. I wasn't even hungry half way through the huge fillet, but it was just TOO good...!!

It's in an adorable little alley way right in downtown SF.

I highly recommend it, especially with a date!! I can't wait to go back, with my man of course!
author: Dixie B.

description: The food was good, but our table was pretty close to another table and the two girls there kept taking pictures and it was pretty distracting. I think we would have had a better meal if that wasn't the case. That being said, I had the duck breast which is the special on Friday and it was very good. We also had the chocolate mousse for dessert which I would definitely order again.
author: Rachel W.

description:
Hidden little gem down an alley that you would never see if I hadn't found it on yelp. My husband, a former chef, loved the food and thought it was amazing. He had the duck and the pate. I'm not a huge fan of traditional French, so not my type of menu, but charming little place with great service.
Loved the crem brulee!
author: Tracey K.

description:
French restaurant in the heart of financial district, not a bad option but food Is ok, bad service though, so I wouldn't be there if not working downtown!
I think Friday night happy hour there is a jazz band, never been though.
author: Ada W.

description:
The best dinner i've had for a while. And the bill was not bad at all. Nice little place to pamper your taste buds, and talk intimately over wine. There is a live jazz band that is not too loud, just perfect.

Escargot
- Perfectly rich with garlic and butter, just the way it should be.

Trout
- Smooth and soft. The almond flakes really add a nice tone to the bite.

Coq au vin
- The best I've had! It was just perfect.

Creme Coconut
- Very coconutty, but i enjoyed the vanilla bean ice creme more than the actual main component.

Red wine
- 2001 Chinon it was about $50. Great wine, highly recommend. Medium body with well-balanced earthy taste, then a second level of fruit after.

Service was impeccable. Ambiance was nice but relaxed. The live jazz was very nice. Compliments to the chef, owners and staff.
author: benjamin c.

description:
In search of a watering hole close to where I parked, my friend and I decided to come here because the large "Live Jazz" sign conveniently located on the outside of this little alley way.  

I ordered a 'Sex on St. Tropez.' It was deceptively sweet at first and the real dranky drank didn't kick in until midway through the drink.  Needless to say, it was rim lickin', hold the glass so the ice doesn't spill, yummy.  Sidenote: you know it's good when someone who really only orders beer says it's good. 

Unfortunately, I didn't order any food because we were on a time crunch but everything looked awesome.  Maybe next time.

The live music in the corner was such a treat! (Aka I think I found myself winking at the piano player subconciously-I've been told I have this uncontrollable affinity to those inclined to keys). But it was such a treat that added to the overall charm of this hole in the wall.  

I would totally recommend this place to someone visiting the city.
author: Stacey A.

description:
This place is very romantic. Why did I go with my girl friend? Where the heck was my boyfriend? Oh wait, I broke up with him a long long time ago... 

Anyway, we ordered steak tartare, which other yelpers highly recommended and man, it sure didn't disappoint. I asked the waitress to mix the ingredients (dijon mustard, 1 raw quail egg, tabasco, salt and pepper, etc . sorry I couldn't remember all of them. It's been 2.5 months since I went to this place) for us since I was so clueless. She REALLY took her time even though she saw me drooling. After 4 mins (yes, I timed her), I finally got to eat it. The toasted bread complemented the tartare really well. That was the first time I ate raw beef and even though I brought Pepto-Bismol along (just in case), I did not have food poisoning. 

Don't forget to try the French Onion Soup with the melting cheese on top and pieces of bread soaked in delicious broth. I've tried onion soup from a few places before, but this one is by far my favorite.

For the main course, I ordered seared tuna steak (forgot the name of it) with the creamy sauce. The tuna was perfectly cooked, but the sauce was a bit too sweet for my taste so I asked for salt and voila, problem solved!! 

For dessert, we ordered the flourless chocolate cake (sorry again if I have the name wrong), which was light and fluffy. It came out warm with a sauce on the side. I would order more desserts from this place, but I could imagine my uber hot trainer's disappointing look saying, "Don't you dare!!" so there I went...back to the hotel..
author: Parim A.

description: Food and service both very well worth the price. Fabulous ambiance. My friends and I all had a great time here for dinner this past weekend. I've come here a couple times with co-workers and it's a lovely place for lunch, too. Definitely worth the stop if you're in the area and looking for a warm and cozy fine dining experience.
author: Dara G.

description:
Good restaurants abound in Union Square, but they're easy to miss. Take Cafe Claude, which hides in an alleyway called Claude Lane off Sutter St. You'd never know it's there, what with the nearby Cheesecake Factory's glowing facade drawing you in like a moth to flame. But break out of your hypnosis, and treasures like Cafe Claude will gradually reveal themselves to you. 

This restaurant has the atmosphere of an authentic Parisian bistro, and the food to match. I went with the moms and one of her friends after work one evening. We had a nice citrusy bottle of Chablis to set the foundation for the meal. We started with a delicious -- I mean, unusually flavorful -- beet salad, plated in the fashion of a poke or tartar. We followed with delicious, simple "salades de la maison", which I believe were butter lettuce or some similar leaf that the chef had dressed in a very spare but holy-schnikes-delicious mustard vinaigrette, with a little diced tomato and some herbs on top. 

My entree was outstanding -- a simple vegetarian lasagna with bechamel. It was light and pillowy with the right balance of savory from the tomato and veggies and sweetness from the cheese. A true winner.  The rest of the table had the trout, which got high marks as well. 

Dessert was an apple tart that I strongly recommend (served a la mode, of course). And, no joke, this might have been the best coffee I've ever had. Just get a plain old cup of decaf and resist the urge to load it with sugar and cream -- I swear this coffee tasted sweet and rich served black. 

Oh yes, and the live music on Thursdays is perfect. Jazz that gives the evening a bit of rhythm without drowning out your conversations at the table.
author: Andrew K.

description: a real french treat , very attentive service , restaurant managers should actually go there and learn some lessons on how service and dealing with customers should be , food wise , coq au vin , poulet , trout and the special was pappardelle with cream sauce , the winner would be the trout with green beans ..and not over priced at all compare to other french restaurants around ...
author: NAEL K.

description: This place is a major tourist destination. I would go here only for the ambiance because it was mellow and definitely a pretty evening dinner hidden from the busy Union Square. The food is so-so for it's price - escargot was tasty. Probably not going back again.
author: Erica H.

description:
My friend really wanted to go so I decided to go with her even though I'd been there once before because it is good.

Me and my friend ended up sharing an appetizer. 

Steak tartare with cornichons, capers, quail egg yolk, mustard, parsley, croutons, shallots and Worchestershire sauce. It was really yummy, much better than the steak tartare from Chez Papa. We saw another waiter mixing it for his table but ours didn't. I guess that worked out for the better seeing as my friend didn't really like mustard. They have a small size and a larger size, I think the larger size is meant to be a smaller entree? But the price is only $3 difference. 

For my entree, I got the pasta of the day.

Penne pasta with spinach, tuna and salmon. It was pretty good, more light than heavy which I liked, even though it had a creamy white sauce similar to Italian alfredo.

I really like Cafe Claude though, I had been there once before and I really enjoyed their creme brulee as well but I was too full this time to get it.
author: Constance C.

description:
Oh my my!  The hubby and I went out for a date in the city and this is the spot I picked out because we wanted some French bistro type cuisine on a descent dollar.  There were numerous good reviews so we decided to check it out.  Here is our take:

We made reservations for 6pm and we asked to be seated by the window.  Yes, indeed - although the place was very intimate and they had many, many regulars we were still able to sit right by the window!  

Upon arrival we were greeted warmly and promptly sat.  The place is gorgeous inside and the ambiance was great.  

Now for the food!!  We had some bread and butter on the table which we nibbled on but we were eagerly looking over the menu at the goodies.  We ordered a great glass of red wine to hold us off till the meal.   Our first course was the french onion soup and boy was it SUPERB!!  I have tried it at a couple other spots but this has to be the most memorable one.   It was hot, cheesy and very bold in flavor.  for our main course we ordered the Fillet Mignon and the Seared Trout.  Exquisite.  The trout was delicate in flavor, fresh and moist.  The potatoes had a beautifully light citrus flavor to it.  The Fillet Mignon was a flawless, medium rare with a scrumptious black truffle sauce to die for!!  For our third and final course we have the chocolat mousse...perfect!  With a rich cocoa flavor and a light cream. Mmm still dreaming about it!

The service was very good.  Our server was very attentive with beverages and all else.  Th greeter/Maitre D were very polite and unpretentious.

I love love loved it and I cannot wait for my next meal journey there!  I wish we lived closer!  The Cafe also has a great live jazz calendar which we were able to enjoy a little bit of before we were off to our show.  Next time we will hang for a while longer.   Also wanted to note that this spot is tucked away in the SF streets which we LOVED!  This is what keeps the best kept secrets a secret...well until they read about it in YELP that is!

I hope your experience will be just as good as ours.  I will be sure to update on future trips!!  Hopefully they will all be consistent in positive experiences!!  Keep it up Cafe Claude!
author: Joy R.

description: For our last night in San Francisco we decided to go to Cafe Claude based off of Yelp reviews.  It was an excellent choice.  I ordered the coq au vin, a suggestion from our server, and it was delicious!!  The alleyway to get to the restaurant is also very cute and romantic!
author: Andrea C.

description: We came here on a rainy Saturday afternoon. The was a short wait - which was not bad at all. The food was 3 stars but the wait at the table was 1 star. It must have taken us 2.5 hours for something that should've taken 1 hour.
author: Ross H.

description:
Cafe Claude is a good solid French restaurant.  I've eaten there a few times now, and the food and service are consistently good.  I'm always a boring diner at French restaurants and invariably get the french onion soup to start.

The soup was good - a little bready and a little less oniony than I typically like - but still a solid effort.  Though they had a cold special soup that sounded more inspired that I ended up regretting not having.

I *did* get away from my steak frites this time to have the scallop special which was nice and inspired - perfectly seared and fresh, and the cream sauce nicely complemented the dish.  I finished up with the tarte tatin ... of all the ones in the city I've had, it was a good effort, with fresh whipped cream instead of ice cream ... again a solid effort - paired with the suggested muscat - it was very nice.

I'll be back again :-)
author: Joe S.

description: Food was amazing. Perfect place to go on a date. We started with the Steak Tartar and had the Lamb Shank and Steak. Everything was fantastic. Only downfall was really service and noise. I guess there was supposed to be music playing (i.e. - Jazz bar) but I couldn't hear anything from our seats. Although the service and noise weren't 5 star I would certainly go back.
author: Jonathan H.

description: Enjoyed a wonderful dinner for 5 on recent Sunday night. Service was excellent, food great, and all was good in the world. We had salads, coq au vin, truite amandine, and desserts. All wonderful! We enjoyed a leisurely dinner. Waiter was great--just enough attention to feel well taken care of, and then some.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
I am a huge fan of Croque Madame. Whats not to love - french white bread, cheese, ham and sunny side egg on top...nom nom with herb fries on the side. DELISH! I prefer the lunch menu over the dinner menu. The lunch menu has many tasty sandwiches such as the tuna salad and chicken breast. Both comes with a side salad. I always choose arugula :) 

The tuna nicose salad is really good but depending on how you like your tuna. I like mines seared and this one is a bit cooked. So make sure you state your preference. 

I HIGHLY recommend the Gratin Dauphinois - sliced potatoes, gooey cheese and herbs so rich and creamy. Tastes great with the complimentary french bread.   

You cant leave this place without having dessert! My top three favorites are:
- chocolate moose (so light and fluffy - comes with a cigarette cookie) 
- Crème Coconut (flan - not too sweet and very light and refreshing)
- Creme Brulee (its on STERIODS! - HUGE so good! I suggest sharing with a friend.

Service wise its a hit or miss. 

Be prepared to be in a dim light room and tables are really really close to each other.
author: Rose L.

description: Had a wonderful birthday dinner for my wife, with our daughters and boyfriend.  Wonderful food! Sweetbreads for hors d'oeuvres. We all had cauliflower soup, and a variety of main plates: My wife had the ling cod, I had the trout amandine (killer!), My older daughter had the rabbit, her boyfriend had the New York filet with bordelaise & My youngest daughter, who is vegetarian, had a baby lettuce salad with a wonderful vinaigrette, walnuts, apples & goat cheese on toasted levain (French for bits of sourdough). I tasted them all! Magnifique!  Leave room for dessert! We had the créme brulée (excellent), chocolate mousse (good) & wonderful bread pudding with crème anglaise (to die for)!  We are going back on one of the Jazz evenings this summer!
author: John S.

description:
we dined here for another holiday dinner and boy was i impressed! claude lane itself is so quaint and charming, and the cafe is as captivating as it gets. we walked into main room, filled with live music and folks at the bar chatting in french. talk about atmosphere! it was like we was transported to Côte D'Azur, and we're about to dine in a speakeasy by the french riviera.

the waitstaff are very kind and knowledgeable (and very good looking, especially with the french accents). savoury fine food and wine, nothing overly flavorful or fatty. all elegantly served in an intimate low lighting. i think i'm in love~
author: krys s.

description: I have been to this restaurant for lunch or dinner at least ten times over the past decade and generally have enjoyed the food and ambiance, but today's experience was by far the most disappointing. I arrived with four co-workers for lunch and we were offered seating in the covered outdoor area. Although it was chilly outside, the heaters were working so we were reasonably comfortable. Our server arrived after about 10 minutes to take our drink orders. I asked for hot tea and when it arrived the water was tepid.  Another in our group requested a glass of water and had to ask for it twice over a lengthy period. It took about 30 minutes before our server came to take our food orders, then over 45 minutes on top of that before the food arrived.  With one steak frites order the steak was practically raw (only seared on top) and had to be sent back twice before it was cooked enough. My quiche Lorraine was watery.  Someone else's fries were saturated in oil. When we brought the raw steak issue to the manager's attention, he did give us a credit on our bill, which is why I'm giving this review 2 stars instead of 1.  I'd like to give Cafe Claude the benefit of the doubt on this visit and think that they were having an off day. Hopefully that was the case.
author: Judy J.

description: I've been here a handful of times now and each meal was great.  Live jazz on  a few occasions, definitely adds to the ambiance.
author: Chris O.

description:
For the ambiance, I will go beyong 5 stars, but since it's about food so Imma go with 4.

The Onion Soup is very cheesi-ly delicious and I loved it!
I ordered the selections of Pate, 
I have to say that I am not so much a Pate Pate person, 
So I didn't like it. Next time, I will order something else.
But if you like Pate, then you gotta try them~ 
$16 for 3 Pate is very reasonably priced. 
Then I had the Flourless Chocolate Cake, 
gotta be the best part~ I love the cake!
My friend had the Steak Tartare and she liked it~
They have great selections drinks, a long wine list.
You can almost find anything that goes with your food.
Our server is a 3 stars, but other servers were 4stars + 
Will definitely come back for more!
author: Marlis T.

description:
Love this place! 
Great service, cool jazz, onion soup and ahi were amazing. And the absinthe with sparkling wine was potent!
author: Jim M.

description:
Awesome and fair priced French food is probably oxymoronic. 
I would've never stopped by Cafe Claude had it not been for the awesome reviews. 
Tucked away in an alleyway in Union Square, this place is a total gem!
The Coq Au Vin and Porc Au Miel was tres bien.
This is going to be that one spot I will go to everytime I am in town.
On a side note, the owner of Brendas French Soul food used to be the chef at this location.
author: E C.

description: Yum! Ate here upon a tip from a local relative, and boy am I glad I came here. Made rezzy's with ease and the  meal was great!
author: Sevag S.

description:
Great service.
Friendly staff.
Delicious food.
And the woman in the video is just as charming in person.  She requested that I tell everyone to look at the pictures of the restaurant instead of her in video.

Thank you Cafe Claude for providing a weary business traveler a fabulous dinner.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
I came here for lunch with coworkers. I would recommend making a reservation even for lunch. The patio is nice when it's chilly, it's covered and has heaters. 

I had a wonderful croque monsieur (it puts Cafe Bastille's to shame) and delicious absinthe cocktail. For a pricier restaurant, the sandwiches are a bargain coming in around $11. The cocktail and wine selections are excellent, and the service is friendly and efficient. 

We shared desserts, a chocolate mousse and some kind of coconut cream dish, and they were both great. I look forward to coming back for dinner.
author: Beth D.

description:
Very very good food,  great ambiance and very nice servers.  

I had the special duck something with pears, the duck was just absolutely fantastic.  Overall just terrific place, pricey but terrific.
author: Leo L.

description:
What a cute little hidden gem!  Claude Lane does NOT have a sign so before you hit Kearny, you're gonna want to walk down that dark alley.  
Friendly staff, good food, good specials and great drinks.  What's not to love?  

Keepin this one short and sweet.  You really need to check this one out for yourself.  It's a new fav of mine.
author: Gina K.

description:
Café Claude is such a nice little restaurant, with a lovely atmosphere, and very good live music if you are lucky. And we were lucky :) discovered this very cool band called Trio Garufa, I bought all their cds when I went back home :)

Dinner was good too, haha. We got the escargots and seafood terrine, then the lamb dish. All was really good food, and I wish I could go back to try more dishes.
author: Catherine L.

description:
This cute French cafe is a hidden gem! Tucked back away from the loud main street, it's a must try for city goers. 

I took the birthday girl here for a little dinner. We strolled in without reservations and totally lucked out. They had one table available- YES! We were even entertained by the live jazz band. It's brilliant that they funnel the music on speakers throughout the restaurant. 

The birthday girl had the French Martini which was *SO* yummy. I ordered the Hemingway's Death in the Afternoon (Absinthe and sparkling wine). It tasted just like black licorice. That would be fantastic if I liked black licorice but I don't. I knew I wasn't going to be able to finish it so I asked if I could get a glass of wine instead. Our server obliged and I was content with my perfectly dry yet crisp glass of Sancerre. I wasn't charged for the black licorice which was even better. 

Onion soup - I'm not a big fan of onion soup but this experience has changed that.. I'm sure this is how onion soup should taste. Perfect!

Pasta of the day - penne with tuna, salmon, cherry tomatoes and olives. Such a light and refreshing summer pasta dish. We also tried the Truffle Fries with an aioli dipping sauce and they were scrumptious. 

We noticed that the back up servers to our main server gave us more love and genuine attention. In busy restaurants this is usually the case. Luckily our server was a hottie and had the sexiest accent ever. So I won't hold his server short comings against him.

I totally feel like I hit the jack pot when I find places like Cafe Claude. Unique, quaint and full of charm. Such a lovely French experience ~ Bon Appetit!
author: Kelly M.

description:
Came here tonight with the boyfriend for my belated birthday dinner!

Started off with cocktails. He had the French 75 and I had the Fraternite. The French 75 was pretty good, and had a strong wine taste/smell. On the other hand, I thought the Fraternite was absolutely amazing. The alcohol taste was minimal, and didn't taste very strong, but it definitely was quite strong. I have low tolerance and I already felt a buzz before I was even halfway through my drink. Smells amazing too - can definitely detect the pear liquor in it.

Had bay scallops as an appetizer and it was so, so delicious!! We shared it and we were sad that it was gone so quickly. Boyfriend ordered the Coq au Vin as the entree and I ordered the Truite. The Coq au Vin was definitely the winner here. Boyfriend started using the bread to soak up the remaining sauce so he could keep savoring it. The Truite was good, but not overwhelmingly exceptional. The greens that came with it was delicious though, and so were the lentils! Skipped on dessert because there wasn't anything on the dessert menu that we felt extremely compelled to order.

Overall, service was decent, and our waiter checked up on us a few times, though we did have to flag him down to get more bread and the dessert menu because he didn't come around for a while, but I think that was mostly because they were slightly understaffed. The waitress explained to us that they only had two servers that night so they were trying to be careful not to overwhelm them. That said, the only available walk-in seating was outside, so be sure to make a reservation!

Wonderful experience :]
author: Sharlene C.

description:
Classic, romantic, unpretentious french food tucked away in an alley near Belden Place. The ambiance is warm, the service friendly, and the food (while not particularly fancy) is done very well. Bistro food at its best.

My boyfriend and I started with the rillettes du perigord - duck meat prepared confit style with french mustard, salad, and cornichon garnishes. My entree was the porc au miel, which was absolutely amazing. The pork was tenderly cooked to perfection in a honey-cream sauce with a white balsamic vinegar reduction and a side of haricots verts. I'm not usually a fan of sweet entrees, but with a glass of Vouvray Sec, the pork managed to balance the sweet and savory flavors of the plate wonderfully. My boyfriend had one of the daily specials - a tomato-based fish stew with ahi, mussels, and scallops, which he thoroughly enjoyed. For dessert we shared the mousse au chocolat with fresh whipped cream, which was a bit traditional, yet ultimately satisfying.

They have a good wine list, as well as house cocktails creatively combining french ingredients - pastis, elderflower liquer,  and sancerre, to name a few.

The service was friendly and the atmosphere welcoming. The reason for my one-star deduction was for the poor timing of the drinks - despite ordering everything at the beginning, our cocktails arrived after we'd already finished our appetizers and our wine after we were about 1/3 done with our entree. The waitress was nice and apologized on behalf of the bartender, but the timing was a bit of a bummer.

Overall, a great find near the usually tourist-y Union Square area.
author: Britt M.

description:
We were here on a Saturday night with a reservation for 8pm, party of 2.  The restaurant was 90% full when we arrived on time and we were seated right away.  Service was excellent.  Our server was very attentive and had a cheerful smile.  Throughout the whole night, our glasses were never out of water and empty plates got removed in a timely manner.  Also, it always adds some cuteness to a restaurant when there is live jazz band. 

We ordered 2 appetizers, 2 entrees and 2 desserts.  Appetizers we had the Cod and Potato Souffle and Frisee salad with Bacon and Poached Egg.  Both were delicious and came in good size.  The souffle tasted like a fluffier version of a potato puff but it was not heavy at all.  The frisee salad was a great way to work up the appetite, given that the vinaigrette dressing was very refreshing and simple enough to prepare your tastebuds for the upcoming flavorful entrees.  

We picked Saturday's special, the Lamb Shank, and the Trout for our entrees.  Again, they came in good portion, not a big dish but just enough for fill the stomach.  The Lamb Shank was perfectly cooked.  Meat fell off bone once the fork stuck in.  It was very flavorful.  The trout was neatly done, with it being folded open and sauteed on the side with the skin.  Bone was all taken out.  The buttery and lemony flavors from the sauce kept the fish fulfilling but also refreshing to the stomach and the taste.  For desserts, we went for the cream brulee and the chocolate mousse.  They were no surprise compared to the standard cream brulee and chocolate mousse, but we liked them more than the others because they were a little less-sweet relatively.

What we did not like about this restaurant was that, the dining room could get pretty stuffy and warm, maybe a little too warm.  The dining room also wasn't very spacious and tables were kinda close, with a full bar and a 3-people jazz band.  Noise level was moderate to loud, with the live music and all the chattering.

Overall, this was still a cute and quality restaurant to go for a romantic date or intimate couple dinner.
author: Charcoal B.

description: The food was absolutely amazing here! My wife and I are hardcore foodies from out of town and absolutely loved it. If you want real French food without the trip to France, this is the place to go. We had the pork loin and trout amandine. Service was excellent as well.
author: Graham G.

description:
Three words:

Flourless Chocolate Cake.

You're welcome!
author: Tori S.

description:
A friend recommended Cafe Claude when we were looking for a restaurant reasonably close to Yerba Buena Gardens for a pre-performance dinner. We had a 5:30 reservation and at first did not have a great impression because after we were seated it seemed we were ignored. However, after awhile (I'm not really sure how long it was - it seemed like a long time - 10 minutes? 15?) our waiter came over and expressed profuse apologies. In the lull between the lunch and dinner crowd he hadn't realized we were there.

After that, the service was attentive and the food and cocktails absolutely delicious. And they served us a complimentary tuna tartar appetiser to make up for the wait. I had a special - scallops with a porcini crust - wonderful! My date had the trout, which was also delicious. We finished with the classic tart tatin for dessert - flawless.

We will definitely go back again.
author: Denise G.

description:
Overall the food was good. I am just not used to my beef actually smelling like cow. Of course this must be the French or Western style of preparing beef. if this is the type of food you like then I'm sure it would suit your taste. 

The creme brulee was really delicious, and the pomme frites were tasty.

The tables are a little bit too close to each other to be comfortable.
author: Stephen S.

description: An impromptu dinner for 4 was accommodated on a weekday evening without reservation, and without a long wait. It _is_ an intimate place inside, where we were seated, but it wasn't bothersome in the least (I thought it would be a bit cramped, but it wasn't).   Service was prompt and attentive, all entrees were quite tasty.
author: Julie M.

description: We have eaten here for years and the food is always good .We had not been back for a few months and things have changed on the wine front .They have a new wine director and want to go more upmarket.We wanted a bottle of S.B. or Muscadet and we were sitting at the bar .$50 and up or $12 a glass!!!!!!! for house white .The pours were small . We own a Winery in Napa and know how the pricing works in Restaurants .This is a rip off .We left and went a block up to another French Restaurant and got a nice S.B. for $35 .
author: mark B.

description:
a very cute restaurant but just mediocre food

the pomme frites and french onion soup was pretty good but the entrees were pretty disappointing

the pan roasted tombo tuna was very bland and the side salad it came with was really bitter and gross. the angus hanger steak was pretty good but definitely not worth the price

maybe i just ordered the wrong thing... but i wasn't impressed with this place at all
author: Katherine C.

description:
Was looking for lunch place and came across this nice little place in the alley. There are two tents extending outside the restaurant onto the alley. 

We were surprised about quality of the food. The "Porc" (Pork loin) is really tender. The Duck leg is nicely done. The cod is cooked just right. The place is not cheap. ($18-$22 for lunch entrees). But the quality is there.

Service is a bit slow but polite.
author: Chun L.

description:
Red wine!
Fancy, pricey three cheese plates with fruits and honey!
Steak tartare made at the tableside! 
Ohhhh quail egg!
Fancy music!
Footsie!
More red wine!
French onion soup, without condoms! http://ow.ly/hXxl
Pate! 
Port!
Chocolate cake!
Love it!
author: Lauren S.

description:
Nice ambiance, good for a date (but not with a foodie).

Ambiance: I was mostly impressed with this place because they managed to have live jazz at a reasonable decibel.

Service: Very good. The waitress did a lovely tableside steak tartare.

Food: the flavors need refining. The steak tartare needs half the mustard. The duck confit dish is duck sitting on bland lentils with a pile of frisee covered in grain mustard with some hard boiled egg. Mustard is not a sauce. It is incredibly overused in this dish. The faux filet was cooked excellently, but its sauce suffered from being jam packed with dried herbs. It overwhelmed the poor steak.

I would return and try other dishes. Plus, I can always ask the waitress to mind the mustard on the tartare at least! It was certainly a nice time regardless and a good place for a date.
author: Becca S.

description:
Nice place, with a nice atmosphere and good service. We loved the asparagus salad (though it was very small) and one of the fish dishes that we had. The creme brûlée was classic and tasty.
Overall - the food is great, but a bit expensive.
author: Tal Z.

description: This tucked away neat little French place was quite the treat for our San Francisco trip. We had the sweet corn bisque and the co au vin which was delicious! We wanted to try something where we would gamble didn't know the menu at all, plus both my wife and I have never had any type of French food... Wow did we hit the lotto with this French cuisine! The ambiance was very pleasing and perfect for my wife and I to just stumble upon, I think even the waitresses spoke some French so it felt like we were in an alley of France or something:) They even had wine to pair with every single dish on the menu:-) I would definitely recommend this little place who wants to eat something fascinatingly delicious!!
author: Manny G.

description:
Very nice place. Great food and surprisingly very good service!

Have gone there 2 and both times (personal and business) it was very good. Will go back -- esp. had the same waitress both times and she was great. very informative, attended to our table with just the right amount of attention and service.
author: John G.

description: Went here for lunch. Service was excellent. My glass of rose was lovely & the gnocchi was amazing. Will be back. :)
author: Mela P.

description: Good food (maybe slightly overpriced), but a nice atmosphere. Very romantic.
author: Andrew L.

description:
Yum!!!!!!!
An all around fantastic experience. Food, service, and ambience all delivered.
Would definitely go back if i was to be in the city again. The standouts were the filet mignon (the peas!!!), the steak tartare and the tuna tartar. The way the chicken was cooked in the coq au van made me like chicken again if only for a dish but the sauce was a little overbearing for my taste. The wines were excellent. The service was really impressive. Winner!
author: Mo. S.

description:
Spectacular!  Great steak tartare.  This place is tucked away in an alley and has great character.   It has an extensive wine list, great service, and outstanding food.

I had the agneau, which was very good.  My girlfriend had the porc au miel and it was amazing.
author: Lynn P.

description:
One of my favorite bistros.

Causally & unpretentiously tucked away on Claude Lane.

Magical each time.

Makes me feel like I've been transported to...
http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/2/2c/Paris1.ogg

LUNCH Must Get: 
French Onion Soup + Croque Madame + their cute individual pitchers of Ice Teas!

DiNNER Must Get:
Duck Pate, Carrot Soup (of the day) + Escargot en Croute + Steak Tartare

Wasn't too impressed with their hyped about coq au vin.

No entree really stood out for me yet -- but surely I'm going to go back to try some others until I find my fav. 

Plus, I need to return when they have live Jazz on Thurs - Sat.
author: Sue Y.

description: Spent $100 plus tip here and loved it. I got lamb and she got the steak. The restaurant is very cozy inside and friendly staff. Very good service. We dined on a friday evening at 9p.m. There was live jazz but not loud as to overwhelm the room. I got a glass of cabernet and then we split a chocolate dessert which was awesome. Portions are on the normal side, smaller by fatty standards but perfect for my skinny butt.
author: Mo A.

description: impeccable service and some of the best french cuisine i've had in the bay area. on par with la floret which i'm in love with as well
author: John T.

description:
Still so delicious, after all these years!  Hooray!  I have been dining at this spot forever and it never disappoints.  I love cozying up inside or sitting outside and sipping a fresh squeezed lemonade (citron presse) under the heat lamps in the alley. 

At lunchtime the Pan bagnat (if you like tuna) is excellent.  The Croque Monsieur is tasty with any of the salads.  My most recent meal there was the flank steak with the sauteed spinach and beet salad to start.  Oh, you can't go wrong with any of menu items if you like French food.  
Rule: Pommes Frites MUST accompany every meal!
author: moodyfoodie m.

description: great place for a first date or several post dates. In the heart of financial district off the beaten path in terms of small alley way, cobbled street really quaint. will remind you of one of the streets in Old Montreal minus the harsh weather (though I find the weather part of the Montreal charm).  Live jazz nights just brings the ambiance up several notches and the seating is for a small crowd.  Love the restaurant for its feel and the food is superb as well. Great french place for food lovers!
author: Sadia A.

description: Once again the little spot down the alley hits it out of the park.  Surprisingly unpretentious and charmingly understated this place will have you coming back for more.  Our waitress (French, of course) was superb, the food was fantastic and the wine was delightful.  It's not cheap ($195 including tip for a party of 3) but you get what you pay for.  The excellent steak tartare was made right at our table, just as it should be, the local cod was cooked to perfection, and you must try the veloute.  Oh, and the brussels sprouts - baked to just the right amount of  crisp.  Very happy with the food, the service and the wine.
author: Leigh Ann D.

description:
This place is great. The food is just delightful and the service is awesome. Their cocktails are also really tasty.
I had reservations early in the morning for brunch and was extremely late, ended up being a late lunch but the hostess was really sweet and seated us right away. 
I ordered the special sea food stew which was perfect. 
I would definitely make my way out there again.
author: Feuy S.

description:
Today is my first vacation day. Last night I drank so much excellent cotes du rhone at cafe claude that when I got home and went to put in my eye drops, I fell backwards. Great way to start the weekend!

The coq au vin here is simply excellent. A table mate had the lamb, also great. Of the two creamy pates, although the truffled one is excellent, I lean towards the sauterne. Ever so mildly sweet, the sauterne rounds out the liver flavor so nicely. We also got two desserts - one complimentary - but they didn't rock our worlds. I don't think I tried the creme brulee but it did look very good.
author: Roxmarie M.

description:
I really love this place. The best fish I've EVER had in my ENTIRE LIFE! It was the day's special: Herb crusted Hawaiian Walu with potatoes and fried leeks. I actually hate fish and I don't eat it - at all, but something in me wanted to try my uncle's dish. After my first bite, I fell in love, with Hawaiian Walu. I literally had a party in my mouth. Cafe Claude, props to you, you made me give fish a chance and I LOVED it. 

Everything else was great from French Onion Soup to Coq au Vin (chicken dish)...it was ALL TO DIE FOR! The wine was also AMAZING. I ordered the champingons (mushrooms in a veal demi glace topped with fresh egg pasta) and it too was AMAZING. Keep up the great work!
author: Cristina D.

description:
Great for lunch!
Great place to take your lady for romance, great food and service

Food - 4 
Service - 5
Ambiance - 4
author: lance i.

description: Descent food. my favorite place to have lunch after I get my hair done in downtown.
author: Monica R B.

description: Cafe Claude is very cozy, very good food, very good service but a bit noisy inside.  We enjoyed our escargots very much and the salad, and main courses were very tasty and generous.  This is very much like the food you get in France.  Oui, oui!
author: Paula S.

description:
Excellent food and ambience (inside). Attentive service. Good wine, prices not cheap but fair for the quality and quantity.
I used yelp reviews to select this restaurant and am glad I did. It is not easy to find since it is at the end of a little alley or side street and not really on a main drag, but the search is rewarded by the find of this great place to eat. The food is really excellent and the wine list extensive and widely varied. I ate outside which is not the most charming of surroundings, but the beautiful San Francisco evening (they have two or three of them every year) made it silly to eat inside (and it was full anyway). I had the marinaded chicken which is served in a nice juice or sauce and accompanied by vegetables, much like a stew. It was superb! The herbs and spices used blended to create a flavor that was a work of art and a reminder of why the French are famous for their cooking. When I first ran my eyes over the price list, I debated leaving (I am a retiree on a fixed and dwindling budget), but am very, very glad I decided to stay. I chose a wine I did not care for as much as I had hoped, but that just made me glad I bought a glass instead of the whole bottle.
At the end of my meal, the restaurant hosted a live band and I enjoyed the couple of tunes I listened to before leaving. They offer this only on certain nights and the group varies from one night to the next, but I thought the music was a nice complement to the meal that I had just completed and I was glad I came.
I get to San Francisco two or three times a year and have eaten at many great places, but this is certainly one of the best.
author: Paul L.

description: Great modern decor but cozy atmosphere down hidden alley reminiscent of Paris. Escargot, french onion soup, cog au vin, trout, duck, gnocchi are all great choices. Live jazz Thur-Sat. Near stockton garage so parking wouldn't be issue.
author: Ha T.

description:
I chose to eat on the basis that it was one of San Francisco Travel websites top 11 restaurants.  Man was I disappointed.  I was there for a romantic date-like dinner and  we were crammed in so close to the table next to us that the table had to be pulled out to be seated.  We were the only couple in the front dinning room, all others were 3 and 4 tops.  Not a date place.

  The first thing we ordered was the French onion soup and it was fantastic.  It gave me great hope for what was to come.  Next we ordered the steak tartar and although it was very good, it was NOT made tableside as others have mentioned.  I had the Agneau.  The lamb sirloin was alright but had a fair amount of grissle in it and the  braised endive was not only braised but literally burnt to the point of being inedible.  My friend had the filet mignon which he enjoyed pretty much.  The bite I tasted was ok but not great.  We finished with the chocolate mousse which was like eating a basic pudding.  Very thick and heavy , not light and fluffy.  Yet another disappointment.  As for the service, it was adequate but the waiter never once smiled.  In conclusion, if this is the best French restaurant San Francisco has to offer then the city should be ashamed.  For a city this large with a plethora of fine restaurants, this is a huge disappointment.
author: Tim R.

description:
Cafe' Claude is as good as it gets for downtown San Francisco French restaurants... and one of my most favorite places for an enjoyable weekend dinner. 
- the food is fantastic
- the service is excellent
- they have a full bar: aperitifs and mixed drinks are awesome
- good wines even by the glass
- live jazz that you can hear throughout the restaurant (and not cheezy)
- the lights are low
- the atmosphere is happening and energetic, but also cozy, and romantic
- desserts are suprisingly good (how can you make Creme Brule' that good?)
- it's not too hard to get a reservation, even though the place it always full... and they seat you on time
- there is a heated outdoor seating for warm days, in a cool alley, like in Europe
- friendly staff....

...what else can  you ask for? We always, always leave happy, satisfied, feeling that it was worth the money, and feeling that we had a great time, as a date or with friends!
author: OcchiDiGatto S.

description:
This is the cutest little French restaurant, tucked away in a back alley behind all the traffic and fuss outside. Beautiful decor on the inside, but we had a seat outside. 

My friend had a small lentil salad which she loved, and I order the penne pasta of the day. It was perfect for my taste; carby and filling but light and drizzled with a tomato sauce. And when I say drizzled, it's just lightly lightly coated. The ahi tuna was amazing as was bell peppers. Definitely not the cheapest, but quality was top notch!
author: Emily C.

description: I took a date here once and the only thing I remember was the beef. Good but not as memorable as I had hoped. Loved the ambiance and location. Will be going back again sans date.
author: mj m.

description:
The only reason cafe claude gets any stars at all is due to our first visit which was great!  However, the second time around was reason enough to not go back.

So the first time my girlfriend and I went to Cafe Claude I was floored by how good the food was, the waitress was greeting us in french and was very knowledgeable with good food and wine recommendations, made for a nice evening.  

However the second time we went the waiter just agreed with any question I asked about the menu, and had the worst recommendations, I almost sent back a nice bottle of wine, but I am not one to waste things. The quality of food was far worse than before, I mean everything to a T was just worse than our first visit.  We had one of the same apps we ordered the first time and it just sucked (for lack of a better word).  Even the choco mocha I had for desert tasted watered down and was slightly worse than starbucks quality.

Basically my gf and I left cafe claude and wished we had gone some where else.  I hate that feeling of when you spend $175 and after just feel like you took money and feed it to the paper shredder with nothing good to show.  

In conclusion, I would say that on our first visit we hit Cafe Claude on a night with the star chef, and on the second night, well maybe thats just how they normally do business?
author: Brandon B.

description: Not sure why I've never eaten here before - its so close to my work and to my hair salon! Cute restaurant in Claude Alley. We lucked out and sat outside on a gorgeous day! Drinks all around and I tried the burger special - burger, brie cheese and grilled onion and fries of course. Delicious!!!!! Ate everything off my plate. Great food cool spot. Will be back.
author: Julie F.

description:
Delicious meal. Menu had some nice choices and made it difficult to choose what I wanted. 
I got the scallops and they were done perfectly. Soft, but not undercooked, on the inside and lightly crisp on the outside.
Atmosphere is very nice and service was great. The waiter made an error on describing one of the specials, but to make it up gave us a complementary glass of port with dessert, so I actually consider this as a plus. Everyone makes mistakes, but it is how you handle them that makes the difference.
author: Samuel L.

description: The owners of Modern Book Gallery told me about this place, I never would have found it with out them!  It is down a tiny alley.  It is expensive, as Aditya M. said in her review, so wouldn't do it very often if I lived in SF, but it was great for my short holiday.  Made lunch with my sister feel like we were in France together.  Great wine list, great espresso, food is fab.
author: Stacya S.

description:
If only I lived here, I would be a regular.  Although I tried my best by going here 3 times in 2 days.

Great atmosphere with live jazz some nights. Extensive wine list with great French wine selection.  Many materials including the zinc bar are imported from an old bistro in Paris.   Even the alley where it's located feels tres Parisienne.

Another couple highly recommended the steak tartare... didn't get the chance to try it, but that gives me something to go back for.  

I'm a little stingy with my 5th star - but the service warranted the bump.  I liked the bartender Alex who is not only totally cute, but charming as well.   One night we decided to get for dessert and sat outside.  I was incredibly impressed with the server there (I only wish I remembered his name!) He was quick, professional and ultra efficient.
author: Caroline C.

description:
God there are so many things that I love about this place.
First off I LOVE steak tar tar. I know this is kind of a weird thing coming out of a ladies mouth, but I love this shit. I could eat it everyday until I die. Cafe Claude also offers a tuna tar tar that is equally amazing with chunks of goat cheese in it.
OK, now that I got the tar tar review out of my system, the escargot is amazing as well. I can also kill an order of these bad boys by myself.
The service is great, the wine list is good and offers some great bottles under $40 and sometimes they even have live jazz music to groove to.
author: Kathleen E.

description:
Alleys are so hot right now, just like cupcakes and Pabst. 

I knew right away when I walked in this was my kind of place. The ambiance was dark and the restaurant louder than typical. I like both these things. 

If you get past the tables being inches from one another (I do this by talking one decibel higher than the person next to me), you will really enjoy yourself. We ordered a special app of French Chèvres Goat Cheese rolled in herbs and then slightly deep fried. I would go back for this dish alone in a heart beat.

Took one star off for the prawn salad dish. The prawns were good but the lettuce was very dirty, grimy almost. It tasted like sand in our mouthes. 

The service was very good and our waiter was very attentive even though he had the whole room of tables. 

Dessert was the Apple Tart upside down. It was really good and a nice way to end the meal. Also great wine selection!
author: Natalie N.

description: Business lunch for 5.  Waiter trying to upsell us at every single opportunity was totally annoying (how about some sparkling evian for the table?  how about some charcuterie or frommage to staret? how about some wine?  how about some creme brulee or chocolate mousse?).  Food was quite good, but too pricey given the competition in the area ($18 nicoise salad e.g.).  Charming atmosphere.
author: Doren M.

description: The filet mignon melts in your mouth.  Ambiance was nice. Location was on Claude lane, seemed like an alley but very well worth the walk to it.
author: Esme C.

description: Tuna was pretty amazing.  Pretty good selection of absinthe.  Coq au vin was also good.
author: Michael E.

description:
I should have gotten the filet mignon instead of the Pan Porc (pork).

My pork was a bit over cooked, steeped in a sauce that had it's odd taste and a slight reduction, but really peaked my buds. I think I could have just licked the plate instead of eating the pork and I would have been equally as happy.

But the filet mignon was on spot at medium rare. We also had the steak tartar and a few other dishes not as noteworthy such as the lobster bisque and the duck pate. Still, the dishes are worthy of a tongue thrashing.

The place is tucked away in a small street right next to a few others, so don't get discouraged when you think you can't see it!
author: Alfred Y.

description:
This place is a gem. Love the ambiance and the food. A little pricey but hay its worth it. 

Great place to take a date!
author: Stephan J.

description:
This is one of our favorite restaurants in San Francisco!  We ate there 3 times over the past 5 days.  Their service is excellent, their cocktails are spot on, and their food is amazing!  Anything lamb seems to be their specialty.  They make their steak tartare table side and spiced to order.  It's very fresh and delicious!  The Tarte Tartin is to die for!
Also, the live jazz bands never disappoint!
author: Khani Z.

description: Great service, great ambiance, small but well thought out wine list, ok food.  The prices are actually not bad for San Francisco.  I just wonder what's happening in the kitchen.  I had the Steak Frites, and was not impressed.  I ordered the steak medium, which usually means a warm pink center...it didn't just come out medium well with light pink center...it was well done, browned all the way through.  How do you go from an order of medium and get well done?  The Chevre salad...not a good balance of flavors.  Too many walnuts and apples, not enough cheese.  And finally, the side of green beans is a fennel bomb in your mouth.  I like a little something to spice up the vegetable, but they over did it with the fennel.  So, not really sure what's going on in the kitchen.  But I love the location, the space, the service.  When I'm in the mood for a little French terroir and ambiance I'd rather go to Cafe de la Presse.  But I'll give Cafe Claude another try with some reservation.
author: Kurt L.

description:
To enjoy an evening in the city after a long day downtown, to which I actually seldom venture, I was quickly convinced to try Café Claude for dinner with the promise of Crème Brulèe made with 'bourbon' vanilla bean for dessert.  Conveniently located in between the Financial District and Union Square, Café Claude is hidden on what feels like a Parision alley (Claude Lane).  The bustling tiny yet comfortable café with a curving zinc bar, vintage tables, and period travel posters imported from France is a nice retreat amid the San Francisco skyline.  

Entering the dimly lit restaurant with beautiful live Jazz music, I was prepared to be transported ...  After asking for water that the busboy had already managed to slip in front of me while I was immersed in the menu, the waiter good naturedly joked with us about their methods of teleportation (needless to say I am a geek and went with a geek).  He was patient and very helpful as we scoured the way too enticing menu.

The food, which was actually not as over-priced as one might think, was fantastic!  To start, we shared an order of Rillete du Perigord, shredded all-natural duck meat Pate, and Escargot, smothered in yummy butter garlic pesto sauce with cheese on top. Making sure to save room for dessert, for my main dish, I ordered the carrot crème soup with gruyere cheese, which was nicely complimented by the house bread, and stole a few bites of perfectly cooked lamb ...  For dessert, in addition to the crème brulèe, we shared the Tarte Tatin, an upside-down apple tart with caramel sauce and whipped cream.

Needless to say I was in heaven for what we both considered a belated birthday treat.   We did not need to talk much as we indulged our appetites and enjoyed the ambience, even though the vintage table with a large base was slightly awkward and uncomfortable.  The jazz music, which is live Thursday to Saturday, made the evening.  On a warm day, I can imagine the outdoor seating would also be relaxing and can imagine that Café Claude has equally enjoyable yet different atmospheres for lunch and happy hour.  I will have to go back ... but will try to remember to make an Open Table reservation given Café Claude's growing popularity and positive Yelp reviews.
author: Anne K.

description: Time-honored classic French cafe in a San Francisco alley.  Steak tartar is a winner!!!
author: Shannon S.

description:
My boyfriend and I were visiting SF, and decided to come here for his birthday dinner.  It was a Monday, so there weren't any Jazz performances, but we still enjoyed ourselves.

Ambience was lovely. Situated in a small alley, the restaurant seemed like the perfect little secret.  They have some tables in the alley with the main restaurant seating up the stairs.  After seeing some other reviews, when I called for reservations earlier that day, I asked to sit by the window (not exactly knowing what we'd be looking at. Gotta be adventurous, right? :o)).  The guy said he'd put in the request, and, upon arrival, guess where we sat!?  Yup, by the window indeed.  While we waited for my bf's friend to arrive, we ordered a glass of wine and relaxed with the light music playing in the background...overlooking the patrons sitting outside.  Almost seemed like I could be sitting at a cafe in France...almost.

Service was attentive but not annoying. Two thumbs up.

Food was delicious.  I had the French Onion soup, and the two boys had the special Tomato Soup.  Good start.  Ordered two apps - some clambake thing which tasted like New England clam chowder and steak tartare.  I've had better steak tartare at EO in NYC.  For entrees,  my bf had the pork, his friend had the filet mignon, and I had the coq au vin with a side of spinach.  The pork was a nice savory sweet, the filet mignon melted in your mouth, and my coq au vin had a nice, intense sauce.  I will say that my chicken was a tad on the dry side.  I was hoping for a melt-in-your-mouth experience with the marinade, but I was a bit disappointed.  Dessert was basically a coconut flan (but they called it something else for some reason), and it was wonderfully light with just the right amount of coconut.

The bill was not so light, but it was my  man's birthday, so who cares! :o)
author: JaShin T.

description:
My family was visiting and we went there kind of randomly on a whim, last minute reservation for 5. We had a FANTASTIC time! It's a little gem in the middle of downtown.

The specials were great saffron pasta, seared tuna in a cream sauce and candied lemon zest that made the whole dish into a party in your mouth.

We were kind of unruly and had them bring everything out at once, and ate more family style than you would at a place like this... but they were VERY accommodating and really friendly. 

I highly recommend this place for a nice dinner out or an awesome date night!
author: Danger R.

description: Great music. Not great but damned good steak tartare.  Friendly and excellent bartender
author: Honest M.

description:
This lovely little restaurant is tucked away on one of those very European alleys that are popular near Union Square. Outdoor seating under heat lamps and an awning can be nice in all but the nastiest weather, while inside definitely reminds me of my trip to Paris.

Food and service were both delightful. My "concerns" mostly revolve around personal preference, so don't take them as complaints. I found the duck pate' a little course, though still delicious, and it came with a pair of cornichons and other pickled vegetables--always a pleasant counterpoint. The escargot sauce was not as strong as expected, though that did allow the quality of the already de-shelled snails to shine through. The sauce over my lamb was delicious but somewhat overpowered the lamb flavor; however, a combination bite of lamb/sauce/bacon/beans (the components of the entree) blended perfectly and was truly outstanding! Rounding off the meal, my bourbon creme' brulee was excellent. The bites I had of the soup de jour (carrot) and the tart tartine were also quite good.

A live jazz trio began performing around 7 or 8 in a tiny alcove next to the impressive bar. Even when it got crowded, which it unsurprisingly did given the quality, conversation was reasonable. Unless you're coming early in the evening, I'd recommend a reservation.
author: Bill B.

description: My friend and I came for lunch on Saturday.  I liked that it wasn't too busy or loud but mellow.  I had the burger special with fries which was very good.  Our server -- and really, everyone that worked here -- was very nice.  I will have to come by on another visit to San Francisco!
author: Yuli B.

description:
Just came back from dinner here.  The food is impeccable and quite authentic.  I've been to Paris numerous times.  The French food here will never taste quite as good as the food you'll find in Paris, probably because the produce and the ingedients are quite different.

Nevertheless, the food here is pretty authentic.  I ordered the French onion soup.  It was rich and a bit salty, but very good.  My entree, the trout, was also a really good pick.  It came with a lemon butter sauce that didn't overwhelm but perfectly complemented the delicate fish.  It's so rare to find a restaurant that can serve up such a delicate filet without overpowering it.  The fish came with green beans and a side of boiled but sweet fingerling potatoes.  

The menu is small but typical of a Parisian bistro.  Coq au vin, streak and frites, lamb and other typical bistro items round out the menu.  

I've heard that service here is quite snobby but I guess the management found out about that reputation and took it to heart.  Our French waitress was attentive and polite.  

I ordered up a cafe creme to end my meal.  It was a rich, perfectly brewed cup of coffee with wonderful crema. 

On a side note, I was really really surprised they have cafe noisette on the coffee menu.  Cafe noisette is an espresso with a touch of hot milk that brings the color of the espresso down to the color of a hazelnut.  I've never seen cafe noisette on any coffee menu in California, so that's a nice reference to a real Parisian cafe.
author: Audrey Y.

description:
We had been to Café Claude four or five times-- each time I was not that hungry; each time I ended eating a lot.

It was hard to find, I have to admit, especially the first time.  It did, however, remind us of Europe: a few bistros tucked in a small alley; music flowing in the air with happy patrons sitting outside under umbrellas (or in this case, heated lamps.)  I was also pleasantly surprised that they had live Jazz on weekends.  

I love their small plates.  In fact, I believe most of times I ordered two small plates in lieu of an entrée.  The beef tartar is good, so is the escargot.  The rosemary-skewed shrimps are delicious, so are the pates.  My father-in-law, who claimed that he was not a fan of French food, had his first bœuf bourguignon  here and loved it.  And last weekend, the rich onion soup and pork with caramelized apple made my husband very happy.  

Café Claude is always busy and often crowded, yet that's part of the charm-- knowing there are many people in this town sharing the same appreciation for delicious food and good service, just like us.
   
My girl friend suggests that we go there for lunch.  I am pretty sure it will happen soon.
author: S M.

description: Fun lunch or dinner spot at the back of an alley off of Union Square! It gets pretty packed so make sure to get a reservation (especially at lunch). I'd been wanting to try it forever and finally had a chance...the food was so good and the service was great. This would be a good spot for a date or a nice dinner with girlfriends.
author: Gina C.

description: I love this place and I try to eat here every time I'm in town. I know there are plenty of other French restaurants in SF, but Cafe Claude has a special place in my heart. I first tried escargot and steak tartare here so many years ago. I love their pate and their charcuterie offerings. Main dishes are nicely done and the specials are very good. I had a delicious lamb shank once - huge and hearty. Solid wine list and French regional wine flights make the meal! The setting on Claude Lane feels so European and the ambience is great. I highly recommend a visit to Cafe Claude for fantastic French food, good wine, and an overall lovely lunch or dinner.
author: Nayiri B.

description:
Good service - but not impressed with what really matters - the food.  We ordered a couple of appetizers and decided to skip on the main course because what we had was such a let down. We were still hungry and ordered a couple of desserts, which were yummy. 

Unless you really like flavorless gooey french food, skip this or just stop by for dessert.
author: SoCal G.

description:
Hidden location down an alley. We started with a Caesar Salad which was large enough for 2.  Croutons were very crisp and cheesy.  
I had the Pasta du jour which was the pasta special.  A penne pasta in pesto sauce with peas, olives, chicken, some cheese, and zuchinni.  Eric W.'s Croque - Monsieur sandwich order came with mega fries galore on top of fries.  I'm guessing with any order of the sandwich entrees, they'll give you lots of fries - enough that it spills over onto the table.  
The service was attentive. Merci Beaucoup. Just an FYI, they provide live music from 7:30 to 10:30 p.m. Thursday thru Saturday.  De Rien!!
author: Marzan W.

description: Food was great but the service was missing.  The server forgot a number of items we had order; tea, wine, etc.  Still we had a nice time and the music was great.
author: Alex S.

description: During my business trip, my feet took me to Cafe Claude, located in an alley. I had coq au vin with a glass of red wine from Cote du Rhone. The Coq au Vin is a bit salty, but it goes well with the baquette and wine. I wish I can get a little mixed salad on the side.
author: Ann K.

description:
Steak Tartare, an Egalite Cocktail and I'm happy all evening. 
Lighting is always perfect - creating that cozy romantic mood, good looking bartenders, wonderful music. Consistently wonderful : )
author: Kheng Y.

description: On past trips to SF, we have enjoyed dining at Claude's to get our "French fix." It features a good location, lively menu, and fairly-priced wine selections. Malheuresment, we visited Claude's on a recent Sunday evening...big mistake as the live music was absolutely awful...loud and inappropriate for a Euopean style bistro. Two acoustic guitars and a flugelhorn can work but not if one of the players is an aggressive singer. . We felt bad for the staff who were very sympathetic but could do nothing. We were told that the owner selects the entertainment and this group was here every Sunday night. We left aroound 8:30pm and the bar was empty and the few remaining tables were leaving, too. My wife and I both enjoyed our food and wine, but what I had hoped would be an intimate evening collapsed into a boho coffee-house concert. Music can make or break an atmosphere, so check out what band is playing before making reservations.
author: MC B.

description:
The alleyway, the bar, the cramped together tables, the dark ambience, the food.
It all reminds me of Paris. Ok our Australian waiter didn't quite fit the part, but he was very attentive and helpful with suggestions on wine and food for us and others around us.
The bride and I came for a leisurely holiday lunch. Disappointed that there was no stew type dish (cassoulet, pot au feu etc) as I was so up for it. Went with the old standard steak frites. Great bistro sauce, thick and totally old school French. The bride had salmon which she enjoyed and we shared a pate de campagne and rilette. Rilette a bit too moussey for mine, but the campagne was as good as I've had outside France. Downed a nice Cote du Rhone with it. Not too pricey but hit the right note. 
For a French fix Cafe Claude always fits the bill.
author: Tony S.

description:
My aunt took me here to welcome me to working in SF.  Since I don't know where to go I tend to rely on those who are around me to take me to great places...and my aunt is definitely one for knowing great places to grub!

Cafe Claude is cute and quaint in one of the infamous alley ways Downtown.  We went at 1, so we missed the normal lunch rush, and were seated right away.  ACME bread and some ice water was served to us while we decided on what to eat.  We both ordered the Pasta special of the Day - Penne with Salmon, Ahi and Shrimp with Peas and a light tomato sauce!  It was deliciouso! 

The waiter was attentive for the most part...and even spilled some coffee at the end, but the dining experience was still very good!
author: Christine C.

description:
So right off the bat I must admit that I am no authority on french food. But. I do consider myself a reliable sounding board for what is good. As such, I declare Cafe Claude to be very good. Worth a visit, and a return visit after that.

We went on a chilly Saturday evening, around 6p, and since we didn't have a res sat outside. I found it to be adventurous ("outside" is in an alley, dressed up, but alley none the less). As for the chilly night, the bottle of wine took care of that. 

We had the french onion soup which very good. I'm not a soup fan in any case, but how could you pass up trying such a staple of french cuisine. Along with that we had the Rillette du Périgord. Again it was good.

For the mains we had a Lamb dish with dark sauce and cassava beans. It was outstanding. Along with a Pork with a light cream sauce and sauteed pears, again outstanding as the creamy savor sauce complimented the lightly sweet pears.
