The desserts were also good, in line with the appetizers, but it was the main meat dishes that truly stand out. I would absolutely recommend having a meal here.
author: Dave A.

description:
this place is located in a cute alley way off bush and sutter street. you have an option of sitting and eating outside. no need to fear the cold deary san francisco weather though- there are heating lamps to keep you and your food toasty! i also like the very intimate parisian vibe that this restaurant gives off. i can definitely imagine this restaurant located on the streets of france. 

while I enjoyed my food (they make a good french onion soup and mac & cheese) and the ambiance, i can't really justify more than a 3 star for this establishment. it was good overall but not mind blowing like some of the other restaurants i have been to. i wouldn't mind going out on a date here but it wouldn't be my first choice.
author: The Hangry Chef O.

description:
After reading a lot of reviews my wife and I decided to try Cafe Claude. You will not be disappointed. This small cozy restaurant is a delight.

The service is excellent even if they make mistakes (told my wife they had different flavors of sorbet for the daily special but personally corrected the issue).

Our courses were as follows:

Petits Plats:
Escargot en Croute (4/5) - I have had some stellar escargot in my day and the only thing lacking was the lacking of baguette served with the escargot. But very flavorful and visually appealing.
Coquilles Saint Jacques (5/5) - "Tres Manifique!" a must have when visiting Cafe Claude.

Vin: Sancerre - White wine paired very well with our meals. ($48 / bottle)

Plats: 
Coq Au Vin (4/5) - Out of the 3 pieces of chicken in my Coq au Vin the first was perfect, the second slightly dry and the last was dry and hard. All of the vegetables were spot on and the sauce was incredible. 
Truite aux Amandes (5/5) - The wife raved about how well her trout was prepared and judging by how she cleaned her plate it would be hard to disagree.

Dessert:
Crème Brulée (5/5) - Simply unreal. Perfectly done. Crisp on top and soft custard underneath.
Sorbet du Jour: got the daily flavors wrong but personally corrected the issue.

Ambiance: Jazz playing through the night and a chic crowd populating this small restaurant.

Service: The service was top notch even with the small mistakes. 

Overall: A definite must. We will most certainly will go back and enjoy the atmosphere and dining again. Worth the price ($35 / person) + wine which is a must with this cuisine.  Do not pass on the secluded Cafe Claude!
author: Phillip K.

description:
12/17 and 1/1/11.  Superb for a dining experience and live music combination.  
Musicians were friendly and accommodating to special request, both times and did a grand job of filling the room with a an authentic touch.  
Sea Bass and lobster bisque were phenomenal! 
Proximity allows for conversation with your dinning neighbors and non-private conversation.
Staff was friendly and great at describing expectations to assist in food, wine and cocktail combinations.  
Bar staff was attentive, friendly and took the extra step to make the experience "just right".
author: La C.

description:
Terrific atmosphere, good food.

Cafe Claude is a very cozy, tucked away in tiny Claude Lane. I like the atmosphere a lot. And it's enhanced by a small jazz combo, replete with French-influenced accordion.

I had a pate sampler: 3 types. I liked one, not so much the other two. The steak tartare ('mild' in my case) was excellent, prepared table side. It's fun to watch, and delicious. My main dish was rockfish prepared in paper -- very moist and flavorful. Decent pinot noir by the glass.

The menu looks quite interesting -- I will come back to try some other dishes.

Both outside and inside seating is available and pleasant, with a very cozy bar as well.

Prices are very reasonable.
author: George F.

description:
this was the best steak tartare in the city.  It's prepared tableside.  The woman who mixed up all the lovely ingredients made it JUST right.  The other food was not so good.  

In the future: large steak tartare and a side of pommes frites.
author: Christina C.

description:
Came here after dinner to brainstorm with the always fascinating @dachesterfrench, had French onion soup (good) and a bizarre mint pastis drink that, in retrospect, I have no idea why I ordered.

Seem to recall this alley has fun Bastille Day celebrations.

Look forward to updating this review once I've taken the time for a proper meal here.
author: Jon F.

description: I think I had really high expectations of this place, when I made reservations there to celebrate a special occasion. The service was great but the rest of my experience was kind of blah. I don't know whether the decor has changed much since the last reviews but there wasn't anything that seemed specifically French or Parisienne about it. Pretty generic. I'd say Cafe de la Presse a few blocks away is more French and cute. The food was good- but nothing out of this world. One of my friends had a soup which was too sweet, the chicken liver pâté was average. The only dish that was outstanding was the gnocchi. Our experience was also marred because we were sitting outside on a cold night and the heaters weren't good enough for a group of 5. All in all, decent enough but nothing out of this world- totally pass worthy. I prefer Gitane down the street much more!
author: Sreejita D.

description:
Once in a blue moon comes along a restaurant that perfects ambiance, food, and service. Cafe Claude nailed it! 

We came here on Friday night to hear Lori Carsillo sing beautiful jazz while enjoying dinner and cocktails. We arrived a bit earlier than our reservations so we sat around the bar (fyi the space is very limited so coming here for just cocktails can be hit it or miss it with space). We tried the sex in st. tropez, fraternite, and dirty martini. Everything was good but the fraternite stood out - tasty, refreshing, and dynamic. The bartender was very friendly and knew about customer service. 

When we were seated our waitress greeted us in French (a nice touch) and was very knowledgeable about dishes and specials. We ordered tuna tartare, steak tartare, the special bass, and lamb. With every dish the ingredients were quality and prepared to perfection. The veggies in the bass dish were cooked but still retained their crispiness and flavor. The lamb had a delicious reduction on top. The tuna tartare was YUMMY. The steak tartare is mixed right in front of your table - our only issue was that it had too much dijon, which killed the flavor of the actual meat (fine by me as I still can't get used to eating raw meat...fish yes but meat no). 

For dessert we had espressos and the creme brulee - one of the best I've ever had. 

Also the bread and butter they give is for some reason extra tasty...maybe the butter is made in-house? 

The ambiance is also great - people sitting around enjoying conversations, wine, and food. No one is in a rush and the mood is very European. Especially since this place is tucked away it escapes the downtown san fran vibe of yuppies and tourists. 

One thing to mention is that this place does end up being pricey - I believe for us it came out to roughly $200...but if you're looking to treat yourself (or your date ;) ) this place is TOTALLY worth it. 

Great food, great service, great ambiance, and great music.
author: Sasha B.

description: This place is adorable!  I popped in there with a date because it was close by where I was staying; it's tucked away so you can walk right past it if you don't keep your eyes peeled.  The service is great, it's not too loud and it is actually pretty spacious but feels cozy because it's sectioned off.  The prices are reasonable, the food is delicious and the wine list is long... Oh, and it's right in the middle of Union Square.  Highly recommend!
author: Lindsay C.

description:
Damn this place is hard to find. We missed the alley a couple of times so my friend had to call a friend to ask where it was until we ran into it.

At least it was LOLDORABLE when we ran into it.

+++ FOOD

Appetizer: Truffle Mousse

Good palette starter. The truffle mousse is definitely exquisite, served with some small greens, mustard, and pickles. Feelin' fat already - PERFECT.

Entree: Roasted Quail Stuffed with Sausage and Figs

It was the special of the night, so I happily got it. Served over kale and some roasted potatoes, the lil' bird was delicious!

Friend's Entree: Lamb

This was good as well. I was debating between this and the quail, but got a couple of bites (see: half) so I was really feeling fat after eating this.

Dessert: Flourless chocolate cake

Tasted like a volcano cake with mostly molten chocolate in the middle. It was served with some condensed milk (I think?) but nothing special here. I just wanted some dessert. And chocolate is always good. RAWR.

Good date place overall. About $30 per person if you get a 3 course meal and share some food as well. Definitely would go again to try out some more items.
author: Charles L.

description:
Friday, 9:10PM.

Tucked away in an alley way. If she didn't know it was there, I would've never known. 

+Classy place
+Nice ambiance
+Live mus-AK
- Long turnaround for food

Waitress was nice and impressed us with her German and French. Euro setup, Euro staff. 

And then...?
We sat next to a couple who were screaming at each other. The band music mitigated their argument but since our table was adjacent to theirs, we could still feel their tension. Good thing I had jovial company! Scanty portions but the creativity and aura requires another visit. Get dressed up and get ready to stroll down the alley.

**********
Stuffed our faces in:
1.White bean soup
     +Creamy and thick without being heavy
2. Sauterne Mousse (creamy all-natural petaluma poultry chicken liver, truffles and cepes marinated in sherry)
     - Truffles a little overwhelming
3. Raviole de Champignon (shiitake and oyster mushrooms, garlic,
red wine and port sauce, puff pastry)
     +Pastry is flaky and a nice cap
4. Coquilles Saint Jacques (scallops, shrimp, mussels, mushrooms,
bread crumbs, gruyere)
     +Delicious seafood mix
author: Chuck N.

description:
I live most of my life as if I'm in a movie.  In my voyeuristic fantasy, my friends and I have the most interesting lives and people look at us in envy.  Maybe that's not so fantastical.  In any case, I felt like a queen dining here last night.  

I love this restaurant.  Tucked away in an alley dancing the line between FiDi and Union Square, Cafe Claude is seductive, urbane and Euro.  

I will be very honest, I'm new to wine.  I can hold my own with California varietals but don't know much about French wine because it is based on the region not the grape...blah blah I don't know what I'm talking about.  Our waiter was awesome and helped us choose a Mas des Bressades Rouge 2007 - Medium-bodied, aromatic and spicy.  I'm such a poser.  

We started with the Cheese Plate and the Charcuterie Plate.  I had the Mahi Mahi special, which arrived on a bed of infused mashed potatoes and two types of asparagus (asparagi?).  Delicious and perfectly portioned.  My friends ordered the pork with honey and white basalmic, and the flat-iron steak which arrived with gratin dauphinois - a delightful baked pillow of potato deliciousness.  

Vocalist Belinda Blair crooned in the front corner to strum of a jazz guitar as we danced off into the night pretending we were on the streets of Paris.  I couldn't imagine why anyone wouldn't want to hop on Air France after dinner here.  Maybe in a movie...
author: Kerry D.

description: Really cute place on a tiny little "lane" (really just a sliver between two buildings) in the financial district.  Nice ambiance, feels very European sitting with the windows open overlooking the terrace with a live jazz trio in the foyer.  Service was friendly and attentive.  Food was very good, not excellent -- my duck confit and lentils were perfectly cooked, but perhaps a little over-salted.  Great place for a date or a night out with friends.
author: P L.

description: Food was decent - French onion soup (a little too cheesy and way too salty), pâté (kind of wish the bread that came with it weren't so hard), salmon with couscous was good. I liked the atmosphere. Service was slow; they were pretty busy, but it took almost half an hour to get our food.
author: Rina L.

description: This restaurant is tucked away so well, even the cab drivers don't know where it is. We had to map it on our phone for the guy, even then it was a hunt. Once we found the place, literally in an alley past a divider that said Cafe Claude, we felt as if we were transported back to Paris. Dark walls, cozy booths, jazz ensemble, good wine list and a nice selection of meals. My husband enjoyed the escargot for his starter, I had the grilled asparagus wrapped in prosciutto. Then onion soup for him and black quinoa salad for me. Very refreshing and tasty. He had the steak and pomme frites (delish), I had the roasted chicken. Dessert was good, however, I was misled and informed there was no dairy in it. My stomach said otherwise at 3 am, 4 am, 5 am, etc, which is why my rating is 4, not 5 stars. Food intolerance and allergies really must be noted, especially when the guest has informed the server up front.
author: Sharon B.

description:
I absolutely love this place. Everything from the ambiance to the service to the food was great!

My boyfriend took me here on Valentine's Day and I gotta say this was the perfect choice.

SETTING: It's a cute little restaurant in a little alleyway so I like the seclusion of it. If you've never been here, just a note, it's off Bush Street in between Kearny and Grant, closer to Kearny. The street is pretty small so you might miss it if you drive by it. We only found it when walking on foot. The restaurant isn't big but it's very cozy. There was live music the night I went so it made it that much nicer. 

SERVICE: First of all, I expected service to be somewhat shitty since it was Valentine's and it was ridiculously busy, even at 9pm (we had a late dinner). However, our service was so great. Our waiter Roberto was so attentive and friendly but still gave us our space. He also gave us great suggestions since we had never been there before. He even asked us if we were big eaters and suggested that we order less since we wouldn't be able to finish it. He seemed to know the menu inside and out and gave us a full breakdown of each and every dish we asked him about. It was the most informative service ever haha. If you ever come here, I hope you get him because he just makes eating there so much better. 

FOOD: 
First of all, I think the portions are pretty generous considering the prices. It doesn't look big at first but trust me, I was STUFFED before the entree had even come out. I think our meal came out to about $80 for 2 but considering the generous portions and the quality of food, I think it was totally worth it. Plus, I left with mad food coma. 

They had a 3-scallop special (it's not on the menu) which was really good but they don't make it that often so if you want to try that, come on a big holiday or something. It's basically 3 huge scallops in this buttery sauce. The scallops are scallops but the sauce is what makes this great. 

Steak Tartar was great. They prepare it right in front of you and it FILLS you up. Be sure to ask for more bread because trust me, you'll need it. 

3 pâte plate was SO good. I've never had pâte in my life but we got the chicken, duck and goose liver. Let me just say, the goose liver is SO damn good. I've always heard good things about it but damn, it's like heaven in your mouth lol 

Lastly for dessert, we got the creme brulee. It comes out in a pretty big dish so hopefully you'll have room to finish it. It's pretty good, it's not spectacular but at this point, I was so full that my only goal was to finish this. 

Anyway, I definitely recommend this place. Bring a date here or even come here with friends. The food is worth trying and I recommend sharing all your food so you can try a little bit of everything. You won't regret it.
author: Diana Y.

description: We took our out-of-town friends to Cafe Claude on 3/17/13 for dinner.  One of them was violently sick after the meal of duck confit;  he was feeling very well when he went to Cafe Claude, and after the meal was sick like a dog.  What does that tell you?  I called Cafe Claude and told Manager James what happened and what he ate.  He said he would get back to me.  Two weeks have gone by and he has never gotten back to me.  What does that tell you?  Kelly Howard
author: K H.

description:
Oui oui monsieur, this place is magnifique! I haven't had great quality cuisine like this in a really long time, glad to know they still exist. 

The location is a quaint small alley which would be very charming to sit outside on a sunny day. Great date, business, or cozy dinner spot.
author: Crystal C.

description:
A French cafe tucked into a little alley with live jazz playing? What could be more romantic and charming?

Well, the food for one.

In short: skip this overpriced, salty-fooded, bad wine tourist trap.

------

I had high hopes for Cafe Claude and was looking forward to having a nice dinner with my girlfriend to celebrate our year together. The outdoor seating area was packed full as was the restaurant inside (in sharp contrast to its neighbor, Gitane, just down the alley which appeared empty at 7pm). The ambiance was nice - dark, small tables, intimate.

We ordered a plate of charcuterie, the coq au vin, the bouillabaise, and a side of pomme frites. The waitress seemed very informed when she rattled off wine to pair with our entrees and we went with her suggestions.

The first red flag was the bread placed on the table. Sliced baguette that was stale. Oh, it's probably a fluke, I chided myself. Slather on some more butter!

Our pathetic plate of charcuterie turned up. An uninspired selection of 3 cuts. Not particularly flavorful, rich, or interesting, served with cornichons, 3 dabs of mustard and 4 slices of bread. For $19. Ouch. Still, I convinced myself that the entrees would be better.

The wine arrived, huzzah! That excitement fizzled when I tried my "bold, full bodied white wine" - it was boring, that kind of bad wine that's been open and sitting around funky. My girlfriend's red was no better. 

On to entrees! My bouillabaise seemed promising - the monk fish was cooked well and the mussels were bouncy perfection. Unfortunately the dish was ruined by being almost unbearably salty. I ate the seafood because I hate to waste food and I think I was still trying to convince myself that it was good. But I could not finish the bouillabaise or the hunk of bread soaking up what should have been delicious broth. For $26 how could it be this bad?? 

I hoped the coq au vin would save the day but my girlfriend said it was average at best. I tried a taste - the chicken and sauce were decidedly sour. Not that unctuous sour tartness that results from cooking meat with wine and animal fats but the funkiness that comes from food starting to go bad. Ugh.

Even the pommes frites were ruined from being way too salty!

I regret not speaking up when the waitress hurried by to ask "how is everything?" I could only manage to squeak out "Oh, pretty good..." when I meant "it's too salty, it tastes unpleasant..."

Offered a selection of desserts, I quickly declined any more food from this establishment.

Based on other reviews, this place seems to have a Jekyll and Hyde personality. For hit or miss food I am not willing to pay $60+ per person.

Next time I will remember that golden rule of dining out in San Francisco: always avoid dining in tourist areas, no exceptions, not even for cute-sounding romantic French cafes.
author: j s.

description: We made reservations easily (about 30 mins prior on the day before TG) online and were seated right away when we arrived. We ordered a few glasses of French wine, not really knowing anything about French wines. For appetizer we ordered the frisee salad w/ fried pork belly. It was interesting. A little "bacon-y" and a little too much vinaigrette. I ordered the pork, which was good. Soft, not dry and the sauce was fruity. BF ordered the Coq au vin which he said was okay. Not the best but okay. We shared the Crème Brule dessert and it was just okay as well. Overall the food was okay. Not the best, not the worst but okay. Nothing stood out, not even the wines. The décor is beautiful and the bar area is great. Service was attentive. I probably would come back to have a drink at the bar and would give the food another shot. But there are plenty of French restaurants that "wow' me the first time around.
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
Solid flavors, classy experience.  I'm a fan.

My brother and I wanted to take our dad out for Father's day.  We were looking for a place that said "special outing" but not pretentious, and when I asked a friend of mine for suggestions, he suggested it right away.

When we arrived, the beautiful hostess seated us right away.  Unfortunately, my family is big and tall, so when we sat down I felt a bit uncomfortable due to the size of the small table.  But this wasn't a problem at all as the plates were cleared after each course in a timely manner, and things felt spacious enough.

We started off with the cheese plate (which is offered both as an appetizer and as a dessert).  It was great.  They served a slice of good brie alongside two other interesting cheeses, one goat and one sheep cheese.  The plate came with three crostinis and candied walnuts, and a very good port/honey reduction drizzled and smeared across one corner.  The slightly pungent flavor of the sheep/goat cheeses along with the deep sweetness of the reduction was a pretty tantalizing experience for $16.

I ordered a french onion soup... perfect.  My brother had a house salad (the "maison" for those who are looking for the name of the salad on the menu), and the salad had a great flavor and just the right amount of dressing.

We each had a different entree: roasted lamb, flat-iron steak, and I had the special for the day, Beef Bourguignon, aka Beef Burgundy.  We each sampled each others' dishes, and I thought the lamb was very tender and moist, and the sauce was exquisite.  The flat iron steak was a perfect medium rare, and had a wonderfully caramelized crust.  Again, the sauce was right on.  The French just get it right when it comes to sauces, I guess.  The beef burgundy got a little dry where one of the pieces I had was well-done.  The sauce on my dish was too rich, and the flavor dwarfed the vegetables in the dish (peas, carrots, and potatoes) rather than bringing them all together and accenting them.

We each had a glass of Macallan's, and sipped throughout our meal.  It was a nice touch... a good call, brother.

One very cool thing about the night was when I made a trip to the restroom and stopped our server to ask him if they could do anything special for Father's Day.  He explained that they never did anything for Mother's Day nor Father's Day, but he thought about it for a moment and said, "How about a little glass of muscat wine for everyone after the meal?"  I thought it was perfect.  It came out in little shots and it was just a nice way to end the evening.
author: Warren L.

description:
Great lunch at this hidden San Fran gem!
I was having lunch alone while shopping and found this popular-with- the- locals spot.
Very happy I did!
My waitress, Marie, was very sweet~knew the food and wine and handled a busy room well.
Even the manager(owner) came over to chat with me about my meal, which is always nice.
I had the pate plate : wonderfully done and a great bargain if you are a pate lover like me. 
The wine list was exceptional for the variety of by the glass options.
Love it!
author: Karin G.

description:
A lovely little French place in the Financial District. The bar is above par - house rye manhattan was impressively without fault. The tables are a bit close together but the noise level remains reasonable in spite of it. 
Service is above average although far from stellar - our waiter was kind enough to remedy his bringing dessert menus before we'd received our main entrees (??), as well as forgetting a side order of spinach -  by comping us a lovely sorbet and muscat.

Truffle mousse was tasty although not as memorable as the pate that can be had Le Central or even Olive. My companion had the butter lettuce which was fresh and delicious albeit mildly overdressed.

For our mains we enjoyed the house trout and tuna. The tuna was superior of the two - while the trout was good it was less notably high quality than the tuna which was sushi-grade and of an excellent texture and mild taste. 

The atmosphere was pleasant and perhaps more notable for the lack of negatives than anything else. 

It did seem that the outdoor/sidewalk/alley dining was pleasantly warm in spite of a chill in the air. Makes me want to return for an excellent bottle of wine, some jazz, far too many cigarettes and a cheese plate.

I suspect this would be the "ideal" Cafe Claude experience...

Overall, a pleasant dining experience I am neither dissatisfied with nor compelled to repeat.
author: Excelsus S.

description:
We found Cafe Claude on Yelp and decided to give it a try.  We made a reservation but we ended up being extremely late.  It was the weekend so we knew we would probably lose our table.  They were really great when we arrived and still seated us immediately.  

The best thing about this place is the food.  I a pesto special.  We also had the chicken and the meat.  It was all very very very good.  The portions were on the average size.  With a salad and a dessert it was a perfect meal
author: Esther Y.

description: Below average French food.  The menu was very typical bistro food with very little imagination.  This would be fine except the execution was not very good. The fries were crispy, which I do appreciate, but overall the food came out barely warm and quite bland.  Atmosphere was fun, so go for drinks, but come in with low expectations on the food.
author: Scott C.

description: Good food, great jazz!
author: L. E.

description:
Just had dinner for a birthday and enjoyed it very much the food was well prepared and arrive hot! Something, that is missing from many restaurants. We ordered Duck, Chicken Coq Au Vin, Maison Salad and Pomme frite. The menu is on one page so choices is somewhat limited but very good! My only issue was the wine list that seemed too expensive for a bottle, which is usually what I prefer to do when buying more than 2 glasses. 

It was also, nice to have staff that spoke French and English that adds to the ambiance of a French restaurant when you can speak french too.
author: Marc V.

description:
Took some co-workers to lunch here the other day and man was it wonderful.  In fact now that I'm thinking about it, its time to go back again!  

I had the quiche Lorraine with a salad and we got french fries for the table.  They have the BEST kind of french fries, skinny and not too crispy with just enough salt.  Yum, yum, yum!  Fabulous waiter who was entertaining and perfectly attentive the entire time.  Great ice tea - I like that they brought me my own carafe of it because I drink the stuff like water.  Nice atmosphere and not too noisy, which was nice.

Two things could be improved: at lunch I felt the lights were a bit too low and the booths were tiny for four of us.  Not much you can do about that I know, but something to note.

And now...I've decided to go there tomorrow.  Yum yum!
author: Erika M.

description:
A very good bistro, you usually can't miss with either the specials of the day or the classics: coq au vin or steak frites.  

The ambiance is relaxed, comfortable, and makes for a very nice casual night out. The wine list is alright, and once in a while we find a real gem from Loire or Bourgogne.
author: Jason R.

description:
This was an amazing dining experience.  My husband and I went for our anniversary last November.  We made our reservations through OpenTable.com and had no problems when we got to the restaurant.  

The setting was very intimate and romantic.  Like other reviews have said, the tables were close to each other but didn't make you feel like you were intruding on other people or vice versa.  

We went on a Friday night and listened to the live jazz.  They were very pleasant but not a main attraction.  I would say not to go just based on the jazz (which is what I was looking for when I found the restaurant).

We took our time eating and had a long meal.  We had 2 cocktails before dinner and a half-bottle of wine with our meal.  For a first course, we had the endive salad with blue cheese and walnuts, paté de rigellard, paté de campange and the steak tartare.  Main course was the Agneau with scalloped potatoes.  To finish dinner, we had the créme brulée.  All of this was shared between the both of us and we hadn't eaten all day.  Even with that, we ordered one dish too many.  

The utter satisfaction we felt after leaving this place was enough for us to rave about it for the next 3 months.  I will definitely be going back to Cafe Claude - however, it will have to wait until I get my waist back as the meals are super-rich!  Still, if you want to indulge yourself and experience complete joy from a restaurant; this is your place.
author: Rebekah C.

description: Oh my gosh - everything was unbelievable. Steak tartare was ridic and I cannot review more highly. Order this. Husband got the filet mignon, and although on the small side, was supremely yummy. Come here.
author: Alyssa C.

description: I am in love!! I am in love... with Cafe Claude!!! Never been to a french restaurant that does not have pre-fix menu with decent prices. Love it!! The place is cozy inside and out, and the waitress that we had was friendly and knows what the place offers. TWO of my favorite dishes so far... STEAK TARTARE- VERY VERY GOOD!!, but I still think it could be better.. if they just put little more of that worcestershire sauce.. seriously!!, and the PORK CHOP- hmmm... the sauce melts in my mouth like butter!! Awww... I am really in love!!
author: Daisy S.

description: This place is very special. Off of the main road and through a small alley is the Cafe. It has a great selection of cocktails and wine. We started with an order of the escargot en croute and this was very good. We then ordered the French onion soup and Nicoise salad. Both were excellent. For our main courses, I ordered the cow au vin, and my husband ordered the pork with apples. The dishes were outstanding! The sauces had so much flavor. We topped it off with the flour less chocolate cake. This was fantastic. Overall great experience!
author: Susan B.

description:
Warmth has no edge.  It is not:

on the cusp
forward thinking
innovative
non conformist
independent
confrontational
avant garde
single minded.

Warmth ushers in familiars:  soothing, sharing, nestling.

For warmth, you come back.  For that hearty Onion Soup, or that hefty wedge of creamy Sauterne Mousse, and irreproachably for that warm Chocolate Cake cushioning one muthaf'in sweet molten chocolate inside.

Seek warmth; find it at Cafe Claude.
author: Natasha S.

description: You cant beat good food and this restaurant is just that and then some. Tucked away in a quite Alley in the FIDI, the ambiance is nice, upscale, classy, quite a few window seats and an outside patio. Great service and again Awesome Food!
author: David H.

description:
Definitely a gem tucked away in the middle of the city.  Really nice atmosphere, friendly attentive service (without being pushy or annoying), great food and at a great price point.  Highly recommended.

Solid restaurant for any occasion.  Oh and fantastic cocktails too.
author: Jonathon W.

description:
I met up with Euni and Zel as one last rendezvous for food and good company before they headed back down to SoCal before I did.  Coming out of the Montgomery BART station, reminded me of why Skid Row remained "Skidded out."

Cheap Chinese Food, Crackheads screaming out obscenities, and your fashionable Hipster Business Consultant all on the same block, go figure. Back on topic, we finally got here after drifting about, discussing which streets to turn on and such. A notable restaurant on my bookmark list for a good year and a half, I get to see why so many people enjoy and appreciate this small French Get Away in an SF Alleyway!

Going inside, it is it dim with splash of bright red and an authentication of location (Euni says this place is as legit as French can be in the Bay Area, go figure). After waiting for several minutes, the waitress sat us down and urged us to order in 10 minutes otherwise we wouldn't be able to order brunch (boo, for lack of compromise). I hate being rushed to order stuff, so it made me a bit disappointed. Looking through the options for a good 5 minutes, here's what we decided to order:

Drinks:
-Waters all around
-1 glass of ($15.00 for a glass and $60.00 for a bottle) Lalande De Pomerol  Château Haute-Goujon, Bordeaux 2002 

Dishes:

Sandwiches:
-1 order of Quiche Lorraine; consists of: pate feuilletée, crème fraiche, bacon, and egg

Entree's:
-1 order of Paleron De Flanchet ; consists of:
flank steak, marchand de vin sauce, served with pommes frites

(I couldn't recall the third entree that my friend Zel ordered but it was also delicious)

Desserts:

-1 order of Crème Brulée; consists of: 'bourbon' vanilla bean
-1 order of Sorbet du Jour; selection of Ciao Bella sorbet (plum and mango flavors chosen)
-1 order of Crème Coconut Cafe Claude's house flan


Let's start with the missing entree, although I wasn't able to recall which one it was. The mysterious green dish escaping my memory banks served its purpose by fulfilling my appetite, probably my more preferred dish to order over my Flat Iron Steak any day of the week. Apologies for the lack of detail on that note.

Next, the Quiche' was decent and size and of course filling for my friend Euni. Although just like my mother, she too has an inability to take a lot of rich food within a short period of time. Therefore, I guess unlike her I can continue enjoying the culinary delights the French can offer at a greater magnitude. Then comes my dish the Paleron De Flanchet, was alright. Tender (as it was served medium, but preferably medium-rare per suggestion of the server) but not enough to satisfy my love for steak. The sauce, was good with the pomme frites, and I decided to decline the use of ketchup.

The wine, my god for $15.00 I considered it a bit of highway robbery initially. If, Euni didn't mention to me that any wine from Bordeaux was worth the price hike I probably would have cried foul. But no, alas it did its job in pacifying my post-economic recession rage. I was smitten and smothered with the smooth rouge hitting my tongue. No spice, no fuss, all nice (another bottle to add to my ever growing wine collection).

Lastly the desserts, the sorbet (consisting of plum and mango) that Euni ordered was splendid. Sorbets not being my thing since the invention of "Push-Pop creamsicles" made me appreciate tartness. Then came the coconut flan of Zel's, very creamy. I actually wish my mom and other dessert specialists were to re-create this masterpiece for me personally in the future. And of course, my Crème Brulée was outstanding (much better than Shin Sen Gumi's in Fountain Valley, Ca. and Bijou's in Hayward). 

So even with all this good food, why such a mediocre rating? Service...I can't stress that enough. Like Somerset, I felt our table was a bit overshadowed, although our waitress apologized the delay in our receipt and change after paying for the meal ($85.00 altogether with tax and tip). I can't believe their detail in service is lacking. Maybe it's because we came in at a time when they were transitioning shifts from Brunch to Dinner...I'm willing to give them that. But until, I come back for a dinner experience my rating still stands.

Otherwise, I really enjoy what you brought in terms of French cuisine as far as my experience is concern. I'm definitely willing to give this place a shot again, and maybe with another Lalande De Pomerol on hand.
author: Ryan M.

description: We love Cafe Claude! My mom and I stumbled upon it about 12 years ago and it's our go-to place when family and friends come to visit. Delicious food, wine and desserts. Friendly staff, cozy atmosphere, and lovely street seating with heat lamps- it's almost like we're dinning in Paris.
author: Emily H.

description:
I've been to this after work-ish French bistro three times and still haven't formed a strong opinion about it. I've never had anything at Cafe Claude that stands out. Good or bad. It's just very average. 

Food/Drinks/Decor/Service/Price = average
author: Han C.

description:
OVERALL
Nothing to get excited about... 

SOUPE A L'OIGNON
I was stoked to see what looked like a proper French onion soup.  But,  too cheesy and not enough onion... mostly watery soup.

TRUFFLE MOUSSE
This was really good!  Tasty, well prepared chicken liver on a little bed o greens.

RAVI
Lots of mushrooms, lots of sauce, and some slices of noodle... not so tasty. :(

PASTA SPECIAL
Bland, soft noodles with a few meager bits of seafood... :(

CREME COCONUT
Slap me for having flan (and pasta) at a French place.  Not tasty.  :(

BREAD
Tasty, warm, fluffy, chewy bread... all you can eat.  :)
author: Dan M.

description: Great food, great wine, great service, great ambiance, a bitch to find.
author: victoria c.

description:
I'll try and keep it short and succint.

Found Cafe Claude on the Opentable NYE listings, and they were offering an outstanding prix-fixed menu.  It offered an amuse bouche (salmon mousse), an appetizer (foie gras or lobster bisque), entree (filet mignon or bouillabaisse), a palate cleanser (lime sorbet), and dessert (soft chocolate cake w/creme anglaise or creme brulee)... all for $75.  That, and a jazz trio was playing live jazz.  

The experience was memorable because the food was well executed.  The flavors worked, the timing of the dishes was excellent, my filet mignon was cooked in exactly the way I wanted it (no less & no more), the portions were perfect (we were stuffed at the end of the night), the environment, the music, the location (I've have yet to visit Paris but I hear that it is located in such a place that you feel as if you're in Paris)... it all just worked so well together.  The staff was attentive (we had one person taking our orders, another refilling our drinks, another clearing our plates, etc.) and knowledgeable in the wine list; she helped my friend find a delicious wine.  

When people asked how dinner was, the 4 of us couldn't say enough good things.  I look forward to visiting again.
author: Desiree V.

description:
Went for dinner.
Had the steak and puffed potatoes, mussels, and Penne bolognese.
Returned the meat once, was rare instead of medium rare, second time around it was medium. I left most of the middle of the steak since I'm not a bloody eater.
Clams were great, specially the sauce that was over it. Penne was good.
Service is diner type at best, but since it was a slow Wednesday night you can't excuse it.
Pricey for three meals, over $138 tip included, no drinks.
Repeating myself once again, but I go to restaurants for the food first; service, ambience and view are just French benefits (no pun intended).
author: Douglas L.

description:
Just so you're in the know, I don't do French cuisine. Non j'adore.

That in mind, my friends surprised me for my birthday by taking me here, DESPITE knowing my opinion.

Interiors: There's something that flows to my aesthetic eye when a restaurant uses oranges and reds in their design. Tall ceilings and an awning outside (for diners who want more of an authentic cafe experience). Different dining areas sectioned off make for interesting architecture, and the tall glass windows are great to peep out if the conversation at the table is lacking.

Space between tables is average. Nothing to brag about.

Drinks: Bonjour maman! I had a couple of the same cocktail (the St. Germain whatnot with elderflower liquer and sparkling wine) and it was pretty damn good. Prices are a bit higher, but the quality of the drinks justify the $$. My friends all enjoyed their varied cocktails.

A great, but not ravishingly impressive wine list (oui, Francais).

Food: I'll admit it; I'm biased. French cuisine doesn't do it for me (in fact it's my least favorite). I find it bland and I usually get really bad acid reflux from it. That in mind, the menu was all right. Not a huge selection that was interesting enough to inquire about.

The goose pate was fantastic. Props to a smooth texture and just the right amount of herbs. The menu is split into starters, small plates and entrees, allowing guests with lighter (or heavier) appetites to pick and choose.

The scallops were basically the only thing that sounded swallowable to me and were cute but uneventful. A friend had the raviole (not a typo) which was somewhat of a joke; a pasta "wrapper" sided with the mushroom filling on the side. She didn't even know how to eat it.

Dessert-wise, we all split the creme brulee (which was generously given to me gratis as a bday thing), which was decent and authentic. The other desserts didn't really pique any interests.

Service: EXCELLENT. Considering that it was busy, our server was extremely attentive. Even though he was fantastic, the wait between dishes was really long. Once ready, the food presenters knew whom had ordered what (a nice little service). The hostess was also totally on game. Kudos to Cafe Claude for great staff.

In sum: food = meh, drinks = tres bonne, service = tres extraordinnaire.
author: C. P.

description:
This is possibly the best French restaurant in SF.  The key to this is that they don't try to be what someone thinks a French restaurant should be.  They just focus on running a great restaurant that happens to serve French food.  It sounds simple, but most French places in the city don't get it.

Cafe Claude is completely lacking in pretension.  For example, the wine list isn't a book - it's a list.  And it changes regularly. And it's cheap.  And it's good.  The menu is likewise relatively short and to the point.  It's a fine mix of standards with some creativity reserved for the specials board.

We typically do three of the following: a charcuterie plate, the steak tartare, onion soup, pommes frites, escargot or cheese plate.  We also tend to jump on their specials.  There is nothing on the menu that I think twice about ordering.

There isn't a better way to spent a drizzly night in SF than in Claude Alley under the awning and the heaters, if you know what I mean.  And I think you do.  But I'm not gonna say it because it'll ruin it for all of us.
author: Michael F.

description: Very good French fare with excellent service.  To be truthful, I was expecting a bit more, but maybe it's because I'm spoiled with my local French offerings (Angele and Bouchon, for example).  At any rate, the food was quite good and there didn't seem to be anything on the menu which I likely would not have enjoyed, so there was certainly variety.  Nice bar with a good bartender and, although a bit pricey, was overall a good time.
author: Ben G.

description:
The price to experience had was not worth it.  The food was average, the service was nice and the tables were pretty tightly packed in there.

We ordered two apps and two entrees.  Started w/ the soup of the day, a creamy leek and potato soup with a slice of melted swiss.  Too bad this soup wasn't seasoned.  Once that was taken care of it was pretty tasty.  The escargot was the best dish.  The escargot were sitting in butter and garlic and had puffed pastry tops.  The fillet was chewy and overcooked (wanted med-rare rec'd it med) and swapped the scallop potatoes, or the equivalent there of, for the fries.  Fries were great.  The Coq au vin was delicious.  

The jazz was nice, the waitstaff friendly, cleared plates quickly, kept water full.  I just felt that it was rushed.  The appetizer was taken, and rather quickly the entree arrived.  I suppose I was happy it was warm, but would have preferred better timing b/w courses.
author: Heather S.

description:
Thank you, Yelp iPhone App! 

I was looking for a place where I could grab a quick bite solo near my digs at the Mosser Hotel. The reviews for Cafe Claude appeared and it seemed to be exactly what I was looking for.

It was relatively crowded when I arrived but I was able to snag a seat at the end of the bar. Be warned: this bar is pretty small and isn't really designed for eating. I would think that only 3-4 people could dine here due to the entrance of the place/hostess stand being right up against it. The bartender quickly poured me a gin and tonic and I was on my way.

The french onion soup was very good and perfect on the chilly SF night. The goat cheese salad was simple, clean, and perfectly fresh. The environs are cozy and warm: this is a perfect spot for a date or dinner with a few close friends. For me, it was a much needed wind-down from a long day of traveling.
author: Kathleen M.

description:
Tasty tartare! Fabulous French food! Sit in a San Francisco alley!

I'm not really sure what the ambiance is like inside, given our interesting location, but I'm glad we got to sit and eat here instead of it being full and having to choose somewhere else with inferior food.
author: Chris E.

description:
What a great spot...a bit of France in downtown SF (although, there are quite a few "bits" of San Francisco that seem French, come to think of it).

Cafe Claude is small and cramped like a good French bistro. There's covered, heated sidewalk tables in the pedestrianized street outside. Tiny bar too. The food is dependably middle-of-the-road French and, given the central city locale, not overpriced.  I can give a thumbs up to the Coq au Vin, and my dining companions liked their filet of sole, pasta special, excellent pommes frites, and pate too. Desserts were good, not stellar. Carafes of red wine were not bad either, although the wines are a bit pricey.

All and all: a nice evening, with good food, and atmosphere.
author: Dave W.

description:
This place was GREAT!    

The place was buzzing from the moment we got their.  They had live music which was nice, service was good and the food was fabulous.

We even got a complimentary glass of champagne for my bday.  

We really enjoyed our dinner.
author: NM R.

description:
It was so perfect. I was really pleasantly surprised by Cafe Claude.  I had heard about it a while back but never really followed up on the hype.  I went on a Friday around 6pm with my friend and was seated immediately.  From beginning to end I thoroughly enjoyed my experience.

I think what added to it's charm was the fact that it was tucked away in a little alley.  It looked tiny and welcoming, just like a little bistro you'd find in Europe.  The wine list is on point (it is a French restaurant after all).  Our server recommended a delicious white that was only $9.  That says a lot that he didn't try to upsell us on the alcohol.

Nice, freshly baked French bread and butter.  One teeny little issue was that we ordered a French onion soup to start and it never came. Don't know how the dish got lost there since we ordered all of our food at the same time.  However, everything else we sampled was great.

One dish that I unfortunately can't remember the name of, reminded me of oysters rockafeller because it was twice baked on the half shell.  A delicious mix of shellfish in a cheesy, cream.  Yumm... it's heavy, so I suggest it as an appetizer to pass around.

The vegetable lasagna was quite possibly the best I've ever had at a restaurant.  Admittedly, the veggies didn't come out too much (I think there was eggplant and zucchini somewhere in there?), but the noodles were cooked perfectly and it was so comforting, cheesy and satisfying.  I liked the fact that it came in it's own individual ramekin, clearly showing that these are made to order.  You could tell because it came out piping hot and soft.

Lastly, we had the creme brulee for dessert.  Since we never got our appetizer we decided to do dessert instead.  It was very simple and elegant - but not unlike anything I've tried before.

We left just as the band got started.  Could not believe they crammed a live show into that teeny place.  Just goes to show how much they put into the full experience.
author: Virginia L.

description: Really good French food, Period
author: Brent V.

description: Lovely service, really good food, reasonable price.  We had a terrific time.
author: Cathy S.

description:
Fantastic.  And to think, I was seriously considering canceling dinner plans here because I was tired during the day.  

This meal, this little establishment, was absolutely fantastic, in every little way.  I am grateful that San Francisco has many of these little treasures, just waiting to be discovered.  It makes me feel like. . . I never want to leave this city by the bay.  

I came here with a friend tonight, thanks to a recommendation from Betty W. (spanks much!), and we ate up a storm.  Almost everything we ordered was excellent; it was like they could do no wrong.  And my favorite part was that they didn't stop surprising me with the food.  Surprising you in the best kind of way.

What was surprising and good?  Aite, here we goes:

+ I started out with the endive salad, and my friend ordered a special that they had this week, a fondue dish.  My endive salad was delectable, probably one of the best-tasting salads I have ever had.  The creamy dressing was light and flavorful; the bleu cheese, walnuts, and apple slices were a nice complement.  I enjoyed it immensely.  I also tried my friend's fondue dish, which was basically a bunch of toasted baguette slices in a big piece of brie.  It was quite good, a little too heavy for my taste, but my friend seemed to enjoy it.
+ Next, our main dishes came, along with a side order of pommes frites. I got the pork filet, recommended by our wonderful hostess, and my friend got the roasted lamb sirloin.  The pork filet was FANTASTIC.  Tender, slightly sweet, tender.  Did I say that twice?  Well, only because it was so. . . tender and delicious.  I loved it.  I also tried my friend's lamb dish; he really liked it, but while I thought it was good, it was still a little too...strong in flavor for me.  The pommes frites were a bit disappointing; there was nothing spectacular about them and I've definitely had better ones before (Chouchou's has some great pommes frites with mussels!).  That's why the review loses a star.  Those fries were just kinda meh. 
+ For dessert, we ordered the sorbet du jour.  It comes with two scoops, so I chose strawberry-basil, and my friend chose lemon-rosemary.  OH. MY. GOD.  It was INSANE.  It was an EXPLOSION of herb flavor.  Really got some punch!  The fruit flavors were really subtle, but the herbiness was, just, as said before, INSANE and strong - in a good way.  That was one big, very good surprise.  Talk about being creative and inventive in the best kind of way!  It was a nice, light, clean finish to a meal.  Definitely recommended after all the other heavy foods!

I also wanted to add that the service was impeccable; they changed our plates and everything between every course and were so friendly, gracious, and warm.  Very much appreciated.  The place is also cute and intimate, located in one of those little alleyways that are so popular around Union Square. 

I think this review loses points only because the pommes frites were so generic, and the bread at the beginning was just okay.  I was expecting Ratatouille Bread, and although it made an ever-so-slight crunchy sound, it didn't live up to expectations in both the sound and taste categories.   

Nonetheless, it was a fantastic, delicious meal.  Come for the food, the ambiance, the great service.  Places like these are part of the reason why I love living in San Francisco.  Eating in a little French place in an alleyway.  How awesome is that, right?  It's a really good food city, and I'm realizing it more and more.
author: Vivian C.

description:
Cute little place in a small alleyway.   Our first time at a French restaurant and we enjoyed it.  The server was lovely and the service was very quick.

I was happy to pick this place on our visit to San Fran.
author: Kelly S.

description: Good but not great. Had the coq au vin and the open face ravioli. Both were good but you can probably fine the better french in SF. The atmosphere, service, and music were not that great. A nice place for a date but if you want to impress you should look elsewhere.
author: Michael H.

description:
Ooh la la la...  Cozy quarters, low lights (and waitstaff with lovely French accents.) And this was at lunch time!

Besides that, the food has complex flavors & such nice depth. My friends and I dined on onion  & butternut squash soups, nicoise and beet and goat cheese salads & quiche lorraine.   Our tummies loved us.

I highly recommend reservations (open table.com is easy & free) for a decadent meal that won't break the bank.  Merci beaucoup!
author: Jen L.

description:
Party of 2 @ 8:30 on 6/13

The restaurant manager started us off as our waiter. Wished he took the time to use a pen as he screwed up our order.

Wife's G&T was flat. Took 10 min for them to replace her drink.

My chevre salad was very good. Wife's endive salad was underseasoned.
My trout, potatoes, and string beans were oversalted.

During dessert we overheard another waiter explaining the day's specials to the adjoining table. Would have been nice had the manager told us about the specials as they sounded better than the dishes we ordered.

Good creme brulee.
author: Art V.

description: Holy crap best sauce on a seared ahi tuna filet ever.  Don't even remember what is was called... and my salad was really unexciting... one of those things where they put some exciting things in it but not enough... but oh that tuna's sauce, yeah six stars for the sauce brings it to five.  Definitely a good date place but also some business types and maybe a foodie having dinner with his brother in law.
author: Aaron M.

description:
Why am I giving this place 3? Our RUDE waitress.

Place is pretty small and cozy. It was a little difficult to find, but not too hard. LIVE MUSIC IS ALWAYS A PLUS!

I made reservations for 2 at 8pm for last night. Got there 15 minutes early. The hostess was nice, but very quiet. We were seated right at 8 in a cozy little spot.

---------------------------------------------------------------

- Pâte Plate $16.
choice of three pâtes:
1. Pâté Campagne
country style pork pate flavored with black pepper and red wine
**my favorite. can really taste the pepper but still you can taste the pork**
2. Rillette du Périgord
pork free, shredded all-natural duck meat, duck fat seasoned & cooked confit style
**This was pretty good also. It was my boyfriend's favorite**
3. Truffle Mousse
a creamy all-natural petaluma poultry chicken livers, truffles and cèpes marinated in sherry
**This was our least favorite. Taste was odd. Could've used a bit more flavor**

- Ahi $21.
seared ahi tuna, onion confit, bacon, soy green peppercorn sauce
**this was originally my boyfriend's dish, but after I tasted his and he tasted my dish, we decided to swap lol this was AMAZING. I don't know what was on top of the fish, but it tasted like candied lemon or orange shreds of some sort. It was VERY refreshing.**

- Agneau $23.
roasted lamb sirloin with garlic, bread crumbs and emergo beans 
**I expected better flavors. It gave the impression of some sort of comfort food, but didn't meet my expectations. It lacked strong "comfort" taste, but my honey liked it so maybe it was just me. It was cooked PERFECTLY (medium rare, the way lamb should be cooked!) I just didn't like the sauce. I wouldn't pay $23 again for that dish though.**

- Crème Brulée $7.
made with 'bourbon' vanilla bean
**can anyone say YUM-O???? Besides the creme being super cold underneath the sugar shell, it was AMAZING. I absolutely LOVED our dessert. the vanilla was really rich**

-----------------------------------------------------------

SERVICE:
First impression of our WAITRESS?? She didn't look very friendly, so I got the BITCH vibe from her. Her name is SOPHIE. I did NOT like this SOPHIE girl a bit. As we were finishing up our bowl of bread and butter (which was also very tasty), our pate plate came out... without any kind of crackers or bread of some sort... I don't know about you, but I can't eat pate but itself. So my honey asked her for more bread and she said that it will take a few minutes because they had to get more. OK understandable, no rush. As we waited with the last of our first batch of bread, she walked by and for no reason said to my honey something along the lines of "I'll get you your bread, you don't have to be so stingy about it".... WTF??? are you flippin' serious?? How do you say THAT to a customer? That TOTALLY ruined the mood. What could've possibly made her say something like that? I have NO idea. Oh and everytime we said "Thank You" to her, she NEVER EVER said "You're Welcome". WHAT IN THE FREAKIN HELL IS WRONG WITH YOU?

As we finished up the pate, we left the last pate behind because it wasn't our favorite one. She comes back and is VERY adamant about us finishing the last pate. FIRST, she suggested adding some salt and pepper to it... So I did and we tried it after she left our table. Still didn't like it. She came back and was ATTEMPTING to suggest something about the salt grinder, which had NO point. Something about the salt crystals being so huge and she even OPENED up the grinder to show us.... I'M SORRY, BUT WHAT EXACTLY WAS THE POINT IN THAT? There WAS no point. You have just wasted a good few minutes of mine and my boyfriend's dinner time together to talk about your DAMN SALT GRINDER.

You don't freakin push a customer to finish something if they don't want to. I did not like her A BIT.

I left 15% tip anyways because of the food.

-----------------------------------------------------------------

Come here. This place is pretty good. I'm sure other servers could've given us better service and would've been much NICER.

Freakin Sophie, man. UNBELIEVABLE.
author: Heidi C.

description:
We live in San Jose but my husband and I were up in the city with a few friends for a spontaneous day looking for a place to eat and thanks to the Iphone and our fellow yelpers who posted raving reviews about this place, we decided to give this place a shot. 

And so without going into a longer review, this place was a great find for us.  Here are a few lines to describe what we experienced that night:

Great ambiance, reasonable pricing, good customer service, San Francisco feel, seafood bisque with a great creamy taste, pork medallon with a nutty sauce (and I mean that in every sense of the word, literally and hypothetically ;), great conversation, great company, friendly neighbors sitting next to us, and overall an experience we wouldn't mind repeating.  

Hope this review helps you as the previous reviews helped us make the choice of eating here. 

Enjoy!
author: Karla A.

description: Had lunch before a play recently.  The service was attentive and prompt.  The food was just OK.  I had the Frisee salad with lardoons, poached egg and a sherry vinaigrette.  The taste was just off.  Not sure why.  My friend had the steak sandwich which she reported as very good.
author: Suzanne O.

description:
It's a French restaurant, and you can order French fries if you want to.  

After a visit to the Macy's flower show, we dropped in for dinner at 5:15 pm.  The kitchen didn't open until 5:30 pm, but a lovely French waitress seated us with a smile and started serving us immediately.  

A server brought us baguettes throughout our sitting, which was a blessing, given what we were about to order and consume.  

We started with two glasses of Gloria Ferrer brut, and had a bottle of Perrier set on the table.  Then we shared the Salade Maison (My Lady's idea of a real French salad), a pate plate with pork, duck, and chicken, black olives and cocktail onions on the side, and coq au vin.  Ah, the coq au vin!  What a delight!  A thigh and a drumstick, with a delicious sauce, with mushrooms, fingerling potatoes, and onions.   I could have stayed and eaten coq au vin all night, but we were full!  This was complemented with a glass of Montagne St.-Emilion Bordeaux, which delighted My Lady.  

Dessert consisted of mousse chocolat, paired with a Cuvee Parce Freres Domaine de la Rectorie Banyuls -- a red sauterne.  Yes, wine and chocolate are a marriage made in heaven.  Or, as I noticed, "If heaven is on earth, it must be here at Cafe Claude."  

The bill was $104 + a very grateful tip:  a "You've been Yelped!" card.  Yes, we left a monetary tip, too.
author: David D.

description:
Excellent food, atmosphere and friendly, attentive service.  I really couldn't have been happier with my experience at Cafe Claude.  

My boyfriend and I started off our meal with a specialty cocktail from their extensive list.  Both were made perfectly, not too sour, not too sweet.   For our meal we ordered the endive salad, pate, steak tartare and filet mignon and finished it all off with the tarte tatin.   Everything was excellent, but the endive salad and the filet were the standouts.  

During our dinner a jazz band was playing in the corner of the restaurant, which added to the pleasant and romantic ambiance.  Our waiter was warm and friendly, very attentive without being overbearing.  This is a great date spot, I won't hesitate to go back.
author: Amanda W.

description: I eat here once or twice a year when I'm in town for Christmas and for work. Every meal I've had has been great. They have a lovely endive salad, good soups that change daily and their coq au vin is my favorite. This time, it wasn't as moist as it has been in the past, it was more like a cassoulet, but still yummy. Service is always good, and most speak French. It's a tiny little place, but a nice intimate feel.
author: Nancy B.

description:
I love raw meat so I couldn't pass up the opportunity to eat steak tartare with some friends, one of whom hails from Paris. 

We happened upon Cafe Claude after a confusing run around at Cafe de la Presse who were advertising Steak Tartare as their special on Wednesday nights, but in actuality, the raw beouf dish is only served on Tuesdays.

Honestly, I didn't mind. I'd rather go to a different restaurant and be served fresh raw meat than stay at a restaurant where the freshness could be questionable. 

So, the server at Cafe de la Presse recommended Cafe Claude for Steak Tartare and we headed over, resigned to the fact that we were probably going to end up eating cheap Chinese in Chinatown.

We were mistaken.

Cafe Claude not only has one of the cutest outdoor alleyway set ups in San Francisco (with heat lamps), but the interior of the restaurant is a very good replication of what you would find in Paris on a warm summer's night, complete with warm incandescent lighting, fans rotating overhead and a dark wood bar near the entrance. You can almost feel Toulouse-Lautrec, Balzec or Verne hovering over their French comfort food in the warmly lit and secluded corner booths.

The BF and I shared a large Steak Tartare, complete with a raw quail egg, diced cornichons, relish, finely chopped parsley, shallots, and mustard. We added a couple of drops of Tabasco and worcestshire to the mound of boeuf and mixed our own with glee. 

This was the first time he had tasted Tartare, and he loved it. The chuck was very fresh, with a good amount of fat mixed in. The seasoning was perfect. I think my only comment would be to have either more quail eggs or just one good large cage-free chicken egg to bind the ground chuck more. 

Yet, I still say YUM.

We also split a Coq au Vin, which is a homestyle chicken stew braised in red wine. Although I highly doubt they pick out roosters for this dish, it was fragrant and hearty, with the chicken meat falling delicately off the bone and chunks of mushrooms and pearl onions. My friend who sat across from us used the last of the French bread and wiped the sauce clean off the plate and into his mouth. 

The delivery of the cheese plate after dinner was timed a little off, but the cheeses were pretty good. One goat, one Brie and a mild bleu. 

Cocktails. Best name for a French cafe cocktail ever: Zidane Coup a Tete. Binky had this, and I believe it had 3 or 4 different alcohols mixed in. I had a classic Gibson, where I asked for well vodka and they gave me Ketel One.

Let's just say the dining experience was very satisfying, and I realize how much I miss good French cuisine. Service was a little strange, I don't think I've ever had a server write "18% tip not included* by hand onto the check or forget the last course of the meal, but I'm over it for it was an overall positive experience. 

Allez les bleus! 
Vive la France! 
Mangez plus de Steak Tartare!
author: May T.

description:
Cafe Claude always brings joy to my taste  buds!  This little slice of awesome has been sitting in my bookmarks for who knows how long.  "I'll get to typing out your review one day" I would promise but the day never seemed to come.  Well lunch today reminded me of why I love the Cafe Claude experience and moved me to finally express my feelings for all to see.

I really had no idea where I was going to eat today so I started my usual stroll by places familiar in search of the right spot to fill my belly.  However, I did not want my belly too full.  So as I was walking along I started to think to myself, "where can you get something that has amazing flavor in a relatively small package?"  Being that I was now walking along Kearny it hit me...CAFE CLAUDE!!!

So I walk up to the little alleyway in which the cafe is located and was greeted with their signboard listing today's specials.  I was actually a little heartbroken when I saw that I was going to have to chose between two items that I knew would be wonderful, either the pasta bolognaise or the pan seared scallops with mashed potatoes and a hollandaise sauce.  I knew no matter which one I picked I would have my mind on the other one, wondering if I made the right choice.

Lucky for me, there was no wrong choice.  My waiter, whose name I unfortunately did not memorize, recommended the pan seared scallops.  Not because it was better than the bolognaise, but because I had let him know that I was hoping to eat something a little less filling.  He also suggested that I have the endive salad, which was delicious and a great preparation for the scallops.

The pan seared scallops, the hollandaise sauce, the mashed potatoes...what can I say about something so close to perfection?  My goodness when I took that first bite of the scallops I was so happy.  You couldn't possibly sear them any better.  They had a nice slightly firm texture and the flavor mixed beautifully with the hollandaise sauce.  I thought that I would pass on the mashed potatoes since I didn't want to leave with a heavy stomach but they were whipped wonderfully.  They weren't runny or too dense.

I'm usually obsessive about brushing my teeth after lunch but today I want to savor the flavor in my mouth.  I don't care if I run into one beautiful lady after another, I'm not trading my cafe claude flavor for kissable breath anytime soon.  I will most definitely be back soon to hopefully have another chance at the bolognaise, which I am sure will be just as tasty.

Aside from today's lunch Cafe Claude has some tasty sandwiches.  The most memorable was a crab sandwich I had the first time I stopped by Cafe Claude for lunch.  I don't think you can go wrong with any of the sandwiches on the menu.  Items that I have had my eye on but have yet to try are the soupe a l'oignon, quiche lorraine, and the gratin dauphinois.

The staff here is pleasant to outstanding.  They are all warm and friendly and manage to serve you well without hovering over you while you enjoy your meal.

Cafe Claude is also an excellent place to grab a drink and/or listen to some great live music.  The alleyway location and the warm interior are major pluses also.
author: Luis M.

description:
Beautiful little French cafe, c'est bon. Great place to grab a croque madame or monseiur (an 'ouevre being the difference) and a cote d'rhone on a chilly winter's day. A great place to have lunch downtown on a Saturday, taking a breather from the hoardes of post-holiday shoppers. 

Not a place for vegetarians.
author: Suzanne R.

description: We had a wonderful romantic dinner.  Server was very attentive even though the restaurant was very busy.  The place is very small so tables are positioned quite close to one another.  I would recommend requesting outdoor seating rather than cramming inside.  My husband really enjoyed the escargot and I thought the onion soup was good.  We would recommend steak and frites over coq de vin.  Overall great experience and would return.  All wait staff worked very hard to ensure a pleasurable experience which was great.
author: Jennifer V.

description:
After reading all the great reviews of Cafe Claude I looked forward to bringing two out of town friends to this place and after our meal we couldnt believe it was so highly rated. 

The service was inattentive and maybe because of it the food came out cold as if it had been sitting out for fifteen minutes. This could have been forgiven had the food itself not been so uninspired and mediocre (for the record we had the steak tartare, asparagus soup, poulet roti, pepper steak and a salad all of that for about $100). 

Word of advice for those who want to eat french, save your money and go to fringalle, bisou, chez maman or chez papa.
author: Stefan D.

description: As a person from LA, I have to give it to SF for being on top of their food game. I wish I could see this alley in the day time to see the atmosphere surrounding the restaurant better. The ambience was really cool with a live band performing next to the bar. Goddamn, their food was the shit! Excuse my French. I ordered their escargot and beef tartare for starters and I've never had escargot presented the way they did and I've never tasted escargot that tasted that great before either. Their beef tartare is made right in front of you. I highly recommend both appetizers. I had their steak as the main course and I was blown away. Here in LA, we have Bouchon and they also offer a dish that is nearly identical to Cafe Claude's Steak and Frites. Dude, Bouchon is in the heart of Beverly Hills so one would expect their dishes to bring their A game especially at those prices. Cafe Claude, tucked away in some random alley in the heart of SF, blows their steak out of the water. Their potatoes were on point. Th HYPE, ladies and gentlemen,... it's real!!!!!!! Please, please, please don't skip out on this restaurant next time you're in SF. OH! and their staff and service was great, too.
author: Lawrence Y.

description:
Hands down one of my favorite restaurants in the city.  The place is cute and quaint, the atmosphere is always welcoming, and I have yet to experience a bad plate of food.  Their wine list and their cheese selection (two of my favorite things) are just lovely.

Some of my favorites:
--the ahi tuna tartare (half plate): with goat cheese, balsamic reduction, and duck egg.
--Escargot en Croute: garlic, butter, parsley... amazing!
--the Filet: pommes dauphine, brussel sprouts, foie gras black truffle sauce
--the creme brulee: simple, yet amazing.
author: Lauren W.

description: Very good, but Gitane has a more creative menu and a better atmosphere. I'd come back, but only if I couldn't get reservations at Gitane next door.
author: Leah L.

description:
Chocolate souffle. French bistro. Great service. Open Sunday. Awesome decor and look and feel of eating in a different country.

As we rounded our UYV, we descended upon this place for a quick coffee/dessert and a final sit-down session of enjoying what Yelpers do best: Eating and drinking.

Upstairs area reveals an interior similar to that of being in France and is dimly-lit. Old cherry-wood partitions and a beautiful patio well equipped with heat-lamps for those chilly days. Even though we did not order the main courses here, the coffee and dessert was outstanding. I bookmarked this place to make it a point next time I'm here to enjoy a wonderful meal. Wonderful service and prompt attention is abundant here.

Note: Keep an eye out for those that try to be "sneaky".....(inside joke)
author: Mike F.

description:
French onion soup I had here 2 months ago that I am still dreaming about......

Even though our bartender that Sunday morning may have partied too late the night before, since he broke my glass first cocktail, and the redo took forever and he forgot the mixers...finally round three was drinkable, I was tortured!

Oh and the gratin of potatoes, dripping with butter yumminess were definitely worth an hour or two at the gym!
author: Jessica F.

description: Cosy French bistro with outdoor seating. Great place for a first or second date. Its not super formal, but not casual, I'd call it relaxed elegance. The real French staff adds to the allure. Service during lunch hour was slow, but dinner service has always been good. I like how the restaurant is nestled away in a back alley, it makes you feel like you've discovered something secret.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
I had high hopes for Cafe Claude, especially after reading so many stellar reviews on Yelp. Unfortunately, it was just not meant to be.

The only thing I really remember enjoying during the meal was the steak tartar. But J thinks that the portion was too large, and that halfway through the dish he felt like he was only consuming raw beef, and not a delicious appetizer. 

The one thing that makes my experience at Cafe Claude truly memorable was the free "entertainment" J and I received courtesy of the people dining at the table next to our's.
author: Susanna W.

description: Good food and service  in a cozy environment for a fair price.
author: Jose Geraldo V.

description:
Great food, great service, reasonable price. (Entrées are very reasonable ~$20 each, but first course and dessert a little pricy ~$10 each.)

My friend and I split the goat cheese salad, which was tasty and large enough for two. He had the coq au vin, which was very rich and traditional with strong red wine flavor. I had the trout which was a lovely light and lemony dish. It was cooked perfectly: neither dry nor underdone. Portions were just right. We split a dense chocolate mousse for dessert, and it came out to ~$40/person. Maybe not the most fancy or outstanding, but the quality of the food is solidly in the excellent range. Five stars.

Service was excellent, noticeably better than almost all restaurants I frequent. Definitely five stars.
author: Elika E.

description: I don't like to give out 5 stars, but this place is a gem! The alleyway in which it hides enhances the experience. Order a bottle of wine and have a romantic dinner. Everything I had (soup, pasta special, wine, dessert) was incredible! The live jazz was a treat I did not expect.
author: Sarah F.

description:
Being that I haven't had French cuisine in such a long time, it was a nice treat to visit Cafe Calude's for a mid-week dinner with a friend whom I haven't seen in ages.  

This quaint little restaurant, tucked away in an alley in downtown wasn't terribly difficult to find.  And being newbies to the place, my friend and I decided to enjoy a nice dinner with a bottle of wine, shared appetizers and our main courses.  Dessert would have been the perfect ending to our dinner, but honestly, after eating all that food, my tummy just didn't have room for it.  But no worries, I'll definitely make up for it the next time I visit, since so many visitors seem to rave about the desserts there.

We started with 2 appetizers.  Escargot en Croute (garlic, butter, parsley, almond nutmeg, shallots and anchovies)  & Coquilles Saint Jacques (scallops, shrimp, mussels, mushrooms, bread crumbs, gruyere).  Both were delicious!  Although I would have appreciated the escargot more if they were served in their original shells, the preparation and the flavors in this dish, along with the little puff pastry shell on top truly made me appreciate this delicacy.  The mixture of the seafood in the Coquilles Saint Jacques along with it's creamy texture made it a wonderful delight to eat.  All the flavors dancing in my mouth had me savoring every bite.

For our main courses, we ordered the Ahi (seared ahi tuna, onion confit, bacon, soy green peppercorn sauce) & and Agneau (roasted lamb sirloin with garlic, bread crumbs and emergo beans).  Both dishes arrived exactly as we ordered it.... lightly seared for the Ahi and medium for the lamb.  

All in all, I would have to say that the food and the service turned out nicely.  Our waiter was extremely nice and helpful and the pace at which the food arrived was timed perfectly.  The only reason why I subtracted one star from this review was because the wine which we ordered took forever to come.  Never make a girl wait too long for her alcohol =oP
author: Vindy C.

description:
Another place that yelp did not steer me wrong.  So, the first night we stayed in SF, we were in Union Square.  I decided to make a reservation at this little French joint.  It is kinda hard to find when you have a crappy map, are not local, and when your cruddy Hilton hotel rips you off on internets.  

We finally find this cute restaurant in this side street alley.  This was the perfect place for a romantical evening.  We were led to our table where I was sandwiched between my chair and table.  We were greeted by a waitress who had the most severe of haircuts and most interesting accent.  Nevertheless she knew her stuff and it was obvious Café Claude runs a tight ship--our waitress was on top of it all.  

We were happy with everything we ordered.  We chose the chevre salad, charcuterie plate, pomme frites, and gratin dauphinois.  Our grand total was less than $50.  Kinda a steal if you ask me.
author: Tanya S.

description:
Not sure if I had high hopes because of the reviews, but I didn't think Cafe Claude was all that.  Love jazz, but band was super loud.  We had reservations, but the hostess was frantic, which created a hectic and kinda stressful entrance.  

Server was very attentive.  He must have come by every few minutes to check on us.  Started off with the french onion soup.  Good, but I've had better.  The pan-seared trout, toasted almonds, white mushrooms, lemon butter sauce, steamed potatoes and green beans was decent.  All in all, it's a good place, glad I tried it, but it didn't leave me with that 'omg, i have to come back here' feeling.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
I've tried every French restaurant in San Francisco, and sampled a fair number of restaurants in France, and have to say "CAFE CLAUDE" tops them all.  Why, you may ask, am I throwing around these bold statements with such confidance?

The answer is simple, really:

Cafe Claude exceeded all my expectations of what a restaurant can accomplish this side of the Atlantic.

1) Delicious cuisine
2) Great service
3) Perfect ambiance.
