I could produce a menu full of reason why I love Cafe Claude, but words are not enough.  Go there yourself, taste the food, drink the wine, listen to the jazz, enjoy the friendly service, and don't forget the zinc bar.  I'm sure you'll find multiple reasons to love Cafe Claude.

If you like wines, check out their selection of French reds.  I especially recommend their choice of Bordeaux wines from Saint-Emilion and Pomerol.  Not to be outdone, they have a killer selection of wines from Burgundy and Rhone.  You can never go wrong asking for a recommendation from their experienced and knowledgeable servers.

Some snapshots of my favorite moments at Cafe Claude:

September 2003:   The first time I tried the Bavette Sauce Poivre Vert at Cafe Claude.  They cook it exactly the way I like.  I'm hooked.

Bastille Day 2006.  Claude Lane was jam-packed.  Marcus Shelby Trio was playing.  I was waived past the security guards and found a place at the bar.  Probably the best jazz and wine pairing I've ever experienced.

September 2006:  Best first date of my life.   I order her the Moelleux au Chocolat.  Her eyes roll back in her head and she almost has an orgasm in the restaurant.  The desserts at Cafe Claude are THAT good.

November 2006:  My jazz trio plays at Cafe Claude the Friday after Thanksgiving.  On our last set, Kate sings "Don't Know Why", "Corcovado" and "Lover Man". 

September 2007: Most recent visit.  Had the Truffle Mousse and a couple glasses of a yummy wine from Saint-Emilion, listening to a jazz trio play Miles Davis' "Solar"

My Personal Favorite menu items:

Soupe a L'Oignon
Endive (salade)
Truffle Mousse
Pate Campagne
Escargot
Coquilles Saint Jacques
Steak Tartare
Coq Au Vin
Bavette Sauce Poivre Vert (Flank Steak)
Pomme Frites
Haricots Verts
Creme Brulee

and yes, the Moelleux au Chocolat...
author: Justin C.

description:
We came here Sunday night after realizing that it was after 9 and the restaurant we'd planned to go to had closed.  The waiter we talked to at the closed restaurant recommended Cafe Claude, and I'm very glad he did.

Not being very hungry, I opted for two appetizers: a paté sample and steak tartare.    

The paté was, as expected, rich and tasty, but I didn't think any of the three were anything special.  My sister and I both liked the chicken best.

The steak tartare was the best I've ever had, and I've had tartare at an actual sidewalk cafe in Paris.  The server prepared at the table to taste, and he left me the bottle of tabasco in case I needed more (I didn't: he did it perfectly).  The meat was bright red and looked so good I could have eaten it even before he mixed it up.  I can't wait to come back here and get more of this!

My sister had the steak, which was also quite good, but we agreed that the tartare was the best thing there.

A friend and I both got the Bouquet to drink.  It was very complex and interesting (muddled lavender!), and I was in general impressed with the variety of drink choices they offered.

Minuses: If you're vegetarian, there aren't a lot of options.  This is apparently normal at Parisian-cafe style French places.  However, the three vegetarians in the party claimed that the french fries were phenomenal and ate two orders even though two of them had already had a full dinner and were just joining us for drinks.

Also, there is a street-level entrance in the back, so don't let the stairs scare you!
author: Avani W.

description:
Went here for lunch with an old friend and the atmosphere was really nice.  It's in a little alley but it's still attractive and sheltered enough from the main streets that you can sit outside and still carry on a conversation.  

There were a few little hiccups when we arrived; the hostess who was very friendly initially got distracted by a phone call so we ended up feeling foolish waiting in the middle of the action while she finished up and ignored us.  Not a big deal.  There was also a little friendly rivalry going between our waiter and the manager; they kept trying to outdo the other with knowledge of food and the menu.  It felt like there were a couple barbs under the smiles but again it wasn't mean spirited and was a bit entertaining albeit unusual.  

I was all set for the Croque Monsieur until I heard the specials.  Hmmm, mini scallops with summer squash?  Done... that's probably healthier anyway right?  Oh, they're drowned in butter?  Never mind about the healthy, but very tasty.  

The restaurant was very clean, and has a welcoming atmosphere.  Definitely worth a hit if you're in the area, I think I'll have to eat here a few more times by convenience to get a better sense of the place.
author: David K.

description: Lovely classic French spot down a little alleyway. I had the trout with almonds, capers and raisins. A really lovely combination. Value was good for the area as well.
author: Joseph T.

description: Nice secluded location convenient to many other places. Ate there on a Sunday night. Service was attentive. Food delicious. And ambiance very pleasant.
author: Jonathan W.

description:
Oh food, how I love thee. 

And love thee I shall!  

...And for cheese lovers, one word: Fleur de Vert w/ Cranberry. GOD. Heaven. 

And in a nutshell: 

I've waited to try both lunch and dinner from lovely Cafe Claude before sharpening my critic's pencil in anticipation of some review writing so I'll have to say that I have nothing (save a few pointers) but praise for Cafe Claude.  

In order for you to understand the sheer size of my belly that now needs  stretchy pants, please see the following list of what I consumed (greedily and without guilt - well not TOO much guilt) during two occasions for lunch and dinner:

Pigging out - First Round - GO! (Lunch)
French 75 - This has got to be the tastiest champagne cocktail ever!  I forget exactly whats in this but I believe its rosee with grapefruit and lime juices - packs a nice punch and fizz, especially for an afternoon lunch or brunch.  I really liked this one, plus it looks pretty!

Cheese Plate w/ Fleur de Vert w/ cranberry, pica portuguese, Runchon - This was such a GOOD deal.  Cheese plate was only $16 and had huge slices of fabulous cheese.  The Fleur de Vert w/ cranberry was soft, creamy and absolutely, RIDICULOUSLY yummy with a hint of sweetness on the tongue; Pica was very creamy and had a brie-like texture with a nice milky smell, and the Runchon was fabulous with the dates and honey supplied on the plate.  

Croque Madame w/ Pommes Frites & Salad - HOOOOOMG.  The Croque Madame PWNS any sammich out there. Straight up... PWNS.  Crisp toasted bread with ham, and grueyre cheese melted with a lovely sunnyside egg on top?  What the F*XOrz.  It was so good.  The pommes frites were thin and crispy but the insides were not soggy and the dipping sauce was just right! This plate even had an accompanying salad, that was drizzled with olive oil (I presume). PERFECT. 
 
Quiche Lorraine - only having a bite of this. I'd have to say it was pretty damn good. But i really did prefer my Croque Madame much better :D

-----------------------------
Pigging out - Second Round - GO! (Dinner)

Le Petit Ecolier - Tasty little bugger, but not much alcohol in it.  I would suggest something else if you're interested in a *real* cocktail. 

Pommes Frites - Very good, same rating as above in the Lunch portion of the review.

Escargot - Okay, snails - probably not exactly the food you'd eat everyday, but hello, if I can eat cow tongue and not flinch then I think I can handle some wimpy little snails.  F-A-B-U-L-O-U-S!!!!  Kinda expensive for $10 for 5 little snails, but damn were they good.  Baked in some sort of special crockery with five little holes topped with round disks of baked bread or some sort of flaky pastry all broiled under a tasty oily concotion.  It was like SUPER MINI SNAIL POT PIE.  YUM.  YUM!!!
 
Flank Steak - Very very well done "medium rare" steak.  Cooked on the outer edges with a good rare on the inside, this steak was yummy though I wish I would have had the Coq au Vin for my main dish. 

Coq au Vin - What praise I have for this dish.  Fabulous, hearty, rich and absolutely satisfying any time or place.  Soft, falling off the bone chicken with pearl onions, bacon and a wonderful wine sauce.  Not too salty, not too bland, just perfect!  Loved this; I had to stop myself from stealing it all from a hungry bear! 

------------

Result: Me= KO and Cafe Claude = WINS AGAIN!


Really though, a fabulous bistro with great atmosphere and better than average service.  We were seated as requested and it is a very cute, romantic restaurant; love the outdoor seating and the windows allow good ventilation though I could see it getting really hot in the summer.  Nice live jazz music and a very comfortable noise level.  

All in all a four star experience, could get expensive fast, but definitely a cute place to take a loved one or someone special for a nice dinner out.  :)
author: Linda C.

description:
Cafe Claude is the restaurant equivalent of the perfect black cocktail dress. 

It's versatile - you can stop in for a glass of wine after work or go there for a romantic date or to celebrate an occasion.  It's great for lunch too.

It's classic - I've been going to Cafe Claude for over 15 years and it's not changed at all and I hope it will be around for years to come without changing

It's dependable - no need to make reservation months ahead like with most of the trendy hot spots.  I'm always surprised how easy it is to get a table there with short notice.

It's flattering - the lighting there is very forgiving and after a bottle of wine, we all look good, right?

You feel sexy in it - it's French!

The food is exceptional.  I love the steak tartare prepared for you table-side.  The french onion soup is always good as is the cheese and pate plates.  The salad nicoise with the seared ahi is both healthy and scrumptious.  

The bottom line is this.  No matter the time of the day, it just feels good to hang out there.  Share a bottle of wine and a cheese plate with someone special and pretend that Claude Lane is somewhere in Paris.
author: mia s.

description:
This is a nice and atmospheric downtown lunch solution.
They have daily specials and also well known French evergreens.
The food is good and the service is friendly and prompt.
author: Alexandra D.

description: The ambience was quite nice, waiters were kind, barman was really careful about people who were sitting in the bar. Actually, even he asked what I was thinking about every dish I tried which was quite fascinating. I tried the onion soup, but it disappointed me, since it was too liquid, there was not enough onion in it, and the bread was giant inside the bowl, but they were really generous about the cheese on top of the bowl. They have really good salads, I definitely recommend. However, my expectations were really high for cream brulee since this is a French place. It didn't turn good, because the dessert was really cold, but it's cream bruleee, right? it supposed be kind of warm after caramelization of sugar. Another thing was, all the vanilla beans were sitting on the bottom and I realized that they actually use real vanilla beans instead of vanilla flavor when I finished the dessert, which was pretty sad. On the other hand, the barman said they changed the dessert chef, they are kind of trying different things, and it's good to hear about comments. Overall, it was good, but I was expecting more from this price since 2 out of 3 dishes turned out unsatisfactory.
author: Tugba K.

description:
I love this place. I think that this is my most-frequented restaurant of all time. The service is authentic and so so friendly. The food is incredible. The atmosphere is fabulous. I love walking down the alley and walking up the stairs into this romantical bistro. I love the jazz. There's nothing I don't love about this place. 

My favs are the Charcuterie Plate, the onion soup, and the pate plate. Every main dish has been wonderful, but they change those quite a bit. My husband loves the Moules Frites and the escargot, but I can't comment as that's not my thing. 

Thanks to my hairdude at Chakra that told me of this place many years ago! It has been the setting for many good times for me.
author: Leah A.

description: I've been here twice since my previous review.  Have to deduct 1 star because they do the annoying "SF health surcharge" thing.  Please just add it to the bill and spare me the politics when I'm out to lunch!  I have been boycotting places that have the "surcharge", so I may re-think Cafe Claude in the future - sad....
author: Michael H.

description:
Cafe Claude, je t'aime!  Grosses bises!  I read in someone's review that when she goes to Cafe Claude, it feels like she is having an affair.  I am having an affair there too...with the restaurant!  Dining there makes me feel that I am being totally taken care of and enveloped in sexiness and deliciousness.  I know I am going to have a great meal, and that the server will of course reccomend things that will tantalize and delight my palate.  The lighting is so flattering that when I catch a glimpse of myself in the mirror, I am instantly turned on.

Here are the sordid details for you:  charcuterie plate, coquilles st. jacques, steak tartare (prepared tableside with the cutest little quail's egg on top), coq au vin...and a lot of red, red wine.  

This is a lovely spot for a date, dinner with a friend, a meal alone (seriously, it's one of the few places you can do that and not feel freakish - instead you feel like a person of great intrigue and mystery), or a casual lunch.  It's great for a quickie before the theater, or a long and lingering dinner.  Afterwards, you can stroll down the alley and smoke a cigarette, feeling totally satisfied and longing for the next encounter.
author: Liz S.

description:
Nob Hill?  Really?  And only a couple of blocks from Union Square...  hum.

I was strolling when I found this one.  I had never heard of Cafe Claude before and now I know that I should have.  The restaurant was fantastic and perfect for that semi-formal meal downtown.

It is the kind of place that has really good butter... I know that is weird, but true.  The butter they served with the bread was so creamy and tasty, it set the bar for the rest of the meal.  I had the endive salad and the onion soup.  Both were delicious and perfect for an elegant but non-pretentious light lunch.  There were so many other amazing looking options on the menu, but my pocket book wasn't prepared for such a lunch. 

I plan to come back and bring someone that I am hoping to impress.
author: Hayley W.

description:
I think the measure of a good french bistro is their fries (pommes frites).  I had the Paleron De Flanchet (basically steak frites with a sauce over it) which was just ok.  Their frites were just average.  My wife had the poulet roti which, of course I had to have a bite of, and it was excellent!  I've had poulet roti at Thomas Keller's Bouchon before and Cafe Claude's was waaaaay better.  We also had the pate plate and that was amazing.  

I know, I know...I started this review talking about the frites and yada yada and I would rate Cafe Claude 3 stars, but 4 stars is about right considering the poulet roti and the pate were great!  I'd go back just for that.  Decent wine list and service was outstanding and friendly.
author: Emmanuel B.

description:
Everything I've ever had at Cafe Claude has been amazing. I have only been there for lunch, and its always a special treat!!
The French onion soup, croque madame (that egg on top...makes it so much extra special!), the french fries are the thin, semi crunchy, nicely seasoned ones I can't stop popping in my mouth, and OMG the DESSERTS!! are all to die for. The Mousse au Chocolat is so thick and creamy, and the Moelleux au Chocolat with the moulton middle! I love when the waiter comes in and pours the creme anglaise on top! 
Soo yummy, please stop by for a nice lunch, you'll thank me later.
author: Whitney F.

description:
I've been to Cafe Claude for drinks, dinner and lunch and have always had a nice experience.  It's where you go when you want that french bistro feel.  The wait staff is always friendly and professional and, you guessed it, oh so french (somehow the frenchiness seems to have even rubbed off on the American ones).  I also like that there's outside seating that is not adjacent to major car exhaust, a big bonus for a sunny afternoon lunch in the financial.
Now if I just hadn't dribbled bright green pistou on my beige top, all would be right with the world.
author: Kiki R.

description: It is tough to find a nice restaurant in San Francisco with live music.  Cafe Claude fit the bill.  Jazz trio was nice for musical backdrop while still allowing normal conversation.  Wait service had long lags and needed slight prodding to get our food orders.  Our cocktails took surprisingly long to mix, but my martini was nice and dry.  Food was good. Escargot and pate appetizers were excellent.  Chevre and tuna nicoise salads were fresh and presented well.  Coq au vin was very tasty but the porc tenderloin was nothing special and could have used stronger seasoning or sauce, a wine reduction perhaps.  Had creme brulee and the apple tart at our table.  Both were excellent.  Overall, would go again based on the good food and live music.
author: Kenny G.

description: Good food, great wine selection and wonderful Jazz! We went on a busy Saturday night. Had reservations for 8:30, didn't get seated until 9 and we're told they stop serving dinner at 9:30. Def not a place I would go for a late dinner to sit and catch up but worth the visit.
author: Malak M.

description:
The French Onion Soup here is delicious!  

I'll keep it short and simple.
author: Justin C.

description: Work lunch on a Friday...We sat outside and it was comfortable with the heater on. I had the special soup - cream of carrot. It was tasty. I also had the maison salad - simple & the dressing was great. Someone at the next table over had the onion soup which smelled delicious. I'll be back to try that with a croque monsieur. My co-worker had the coq au vin which looked amazing and I would definitely get if 1. I liked chicken on the bone 2. I could eat that much food at lunch. My boss had the steak tartar, "the best in town". To finish it off we split a chocolate mousse. I want to come back, order every dessert and not care that my pants won't fit the next day.
author: Sara P.

description:
This has become the only restaurant I go to for lunch when I'm in the Union Square area. It's almost pathetic. I can't even count the number of times I've been here, and the number of people I have brought. It's very hard for me to find good brasserie food like the kind I was used to eating in Paris, and let me say, this place does a fantastic job. 

I've ordered the croque monsieur/madame far too many times and I have never been unhappy. It comes with an ample amount of delicious french fries (seasoned so well, I don't even need ketchup! it's so un-american of me!), and salad. This is a very fulfilling lunch to say the least and I usually feel somewhat guilty for finishing the whole thing. 

Additionally, I've had the quiche lorraine, the mousse au sauterne, les epinards, your mom, the potato gratin, and the steak tartare. That last one is probably my favorite (apologies to your mom), as it is very hard to find steak tartare for a decent price and now I've started to crave it! Doesn't that sound arrogant? "Ohhhh dawwwling how I crave steak tartare!" Sad, but true. The best part is the menu is amazingly cheap for the amount/type of food you are getting. How can you pass up a great $10 lunch!?

The staff has been very good on all occasions, and are especially friendly when you start speaking french! The only downside is that it is in an alley, so there isn't much sunlight and you can't watch people walk by. But other than that, I have never been even slightly disappointed and intend on going back until I have tried everything on the menu!
author: Kelsey E.

description:
yum, yum YUM! i have only been to cafe claude a couple times. last time i went, i tried this interesting gin drink that was quite nice. my friend and i shared the cheese plate, a salad and the haricots verts. i've never had a full-on entree, but they sound amazing. 

i LOVE the haricots verts. i could probably just order those and a glass of wine and be happy.
author: Kate W.

description: Feels like your in a European alley that only the locals know about. Nice setting and jazz music in the background. I had a pasta dish with salmon and tuna which was excellent. The French onion soup was disappointing, good but not great. Cheese was clumpy and not very flavorful, that's the only reason for not giving this 5 stars.
author: Nico F.

description:
Went for a pre-theater dinner with a couple colleagues on Friday night, and really enjoyed my first-time experience. The ambiance was very warm and intimate, and live jazzy music started about halfway through our meal.
We shared the escargots to start. The snails were deliciously drowning in garlic-parsley butter, with little "croute" hats on top. I wish there had been more than six - very tasty!
It took us a while to figure out what entrees to order as both colleagues are limited eaters at the moment (one is gluten-free) and the server was a little fussy about substitutions. Which in a small kitchen on a busy Friday night, I suppose I can understand. 
Being delightfully food issue-free, I immediately went for the pan-roasted salmon, which turned out to be a good idea. The seared-to-medium fillet was perched atop French lentils with bacon, and dressed with a tangy horseradish cream. The dish was rich enough to stand up to the bottle of Cotes du Rhone that we shared.
I stole a few bites of the white bean and artichoke ragout from the lamb plate, but was unimpressed. My favorite entree turned out to be my friend's trout aux amandes - perfectly cooked trout was slathered in lightly toasted almonds and a white wine lemon sauce (that inexplicably contained mushrooms?). The green beans were somewhat uninspired but the butter-drenched fingerling potatoes were very good, as butter-drenched items tend to be. 
I also had a bite of the moelleux au chocolat, which was soft and chocolaty good.

The special was described as a blue-nose sea bass and it sounded really good, but it was 29 bucks! My salmon was only 19, and I just can't see another fish entree as worth those extra 10 bucks. I was also surprised that steak frites were not on the menu.

I can see myself coming here for lunch occasionally, as Claude Lane is basically across the street from my office. They seem to have outdoor seating, which will be great once it warms up. I definitely will be back to try the French onion soup and the steak tartare, and get my own damn order of trout :)
author: Stephanie S.

description: Fabulous. My best friend and I went there for coffee and dessert last night. It is very reminescient of European outdoor cafes. Our waitor was adorable. When he said "excuse moi", it was delectable. Oh, the food was good too. We had the apple tart and it was very warm, almost like sitting by a fireplace. Well we kind of were. There was a heated panel above us, which I appreciated a lot since it was kind of cold. I also had a hot chocolate and that was rich with real chocolate bits. Mmm. Good experience overall. Good place for a date. Tres romantique.
author: Joan S.

description: Love it. I have been here twice. Once for my best friend's bachelorette (she's a classy gal) and once with my Mother in law (another classy gal) who was in town for Christmas. The restaurant is small, but they made room for my best friend's party of 8. Everyone loved their meals, I believe I had the Coq au Vin which was melt in my mouth good. There was a small jazz group in the corner. I have nothing but fond memories from the two times I was there.
author: Shyanna B.

description:
My mother and I absolutely adored Cafe Claud! I'm always a little skeptical when a restaurant lists "French" cuisine because it leads me to believe at least one of two things: ridiculously high prices and or ridiculously small portions. I am happy to report that this restaurant not only has reasonable prices but also ample portions!

We ordered the carrot soup to start, which was deeeelish. We were suppose to be sharing but I hogged the whole thing. My mom had to wrestle it out of my desperate grasp. The beet salad was also fantastic. I ordered the lamb and my mom ordered the osso buco. Both dishes had the most amazing sauces with meat that was so juicy and flavorful that you felt like you could eat for all of eternity. We ordered the flowerless chocolate cake for dessert and OMG...I'm pretty sure I was having orgasms in my mouth. I haven't had a dessert that good in a very long time.

There is nothing not to like about Cafe Claud. It's only downfall is like most small restaurants here in SF  - the tables are all set so close together. They set a couple next to us and when my mom tried to get up to go to the bathroom, we had to physically move the table over for her to get by. Kind of annoying but definitely worth dealing with to experience this amazing cuisine.

GO GO GO and when you do, give me your recs because I'll definitely be back for more.
author: Julia N.

description:
I hereby applaud the Claude.  

Stumbled upon this place looking for a spot to take my folks.  Everyone loved it.  

I had the butter lettuce salad and the ahi tartare with goat cheese.  Unique, tasty and light (seeing as this was my .. um ... second dinner of the night.)  

Had a bottle of the Chinon red which went well. 

My dad had some pork dish which was incredible and I am going to go back to figure out what it was...
author: Brad C.

description:
Beef Tartare- GREAT!
Flat Iron Steak-Excellent!
Frites-Yum!
Upside down Apple Tart-Delicious!

Ambiance and service was also excellent. What else do you want?  
and the prices are so decent.  Under $100 for three people. I will be back for more.
author: AhLin C.

description:
I came here a bit after normal lunch hours on a decently weathered Saturday.  A bit of wind and overcast, but overall ok.  Their patio had windblockers- yay.  It was definitely a nice chill place.

I had the Croque Madame.  It was ok.  It was better than a regular Croque sandwich, but nothing that I'd die for- but then again, I'm not a huge fan of ham or Croque sandwiches.

My server was Dave.  He was SO friendly and attentive.  He has the voice of one of my good friends.  I'd go back just for him.
author: Cathy U.

description:
We (that would be: Lesla and myself, as always) dropped in to Café Claude for a lunch recently, and what a marvelous lunch we had! I've eaten tons of french cuisine (mostly in Québec), and I have a better-than-average idea of what's what with this sort of thing.

They're located at 7 Claude Lane, and there are outdoor tables, as well as a fine assortment of tables in the appropriately-lit (read: slightly dim) interior. We found the service to be transparent (i.e., no drama) and efficient. Lunch is served 11:30am to 3:30pm (M-Sat), dinner is served 5:30 to 10:30pm (M-Sun), and there's an aprés midi (hors d'oeuvres) menu from 3:30-4:30pm.

So, there's no breakfast available, unless you keep musician's hours, in which case the World's your oyster.

Okay, now the fun part. Lesla ordered soup du jour, split in two (to share, in other words). The soup, which was celeri (that's the french spelling, just sound it out, et voila!), was outstanding. Simple, delicious and perfect.

I ordered the pate du campagne, (listed as "country-style), and it took me way, way back to authentic, country-style french pate ... A decent pate, such as those found in super markets and even specialty shops, is really adequate, in its own right, but this was the real deal. If I'd closed my eyes I could have been back on Peel Street, in Montréal, where we had a deli on the ground floor of my three storied apartment house, that made their own, on-the-spot, or this family's home on the riviere Dordogne, that I'd "roomed with" once upon a time ... mmmm, not 'exciting' (which it doesn't aim to be), but authentic.

 For our main lunches, Lesla had the salade Nicoise, and I had the pasta du jour (which would be "pates du jour" in accurate french). I tried Lesla's salad, which she just-this-minute reaffirmed  was "the best I've ever had" (and she's had quite a few) and it was easily the best I've ever had.

My pasta, a delightful mix of penne pasta and a tomato-oriented sauce, was delectable.

The pasta, itself, was 'probably' homemade, but, in hindsight (this is from memory of a couple weeks ago) I can't be sure. The logic of it all (the fact that every aspect of the food was perfect) dictates that it was freshly-made. But with one of the "thicker" (i.e., tomato) sauces, it isn't as apparent in hindsight. The "thinner" sauces make it easier to distinguish the superior, freshly-made pastas, because one characteristic of the freshness (made-the-same-day) pasta is that it has edges, or surface 'texture' that allows even the thinnest sauce to "cling" to it. It's most apparent with "aglio y olio", or that amazing "pasta con vongole" that I reported on from the Sausalito resto, called Fish, a while back.

Suffice it to say, my pasta was really delicious.

We skipped dessert, opting for a cappuccino, for Lesla, who reported it as being "excellent" and an espresso double (ordered, in engli8sh, as: double espresso), for me. My espresso was-how shall I put this?-adequate. I have a review of another coffee place, back in the Montréal area, and I absolve every place I've ever been for having "really good" espresso, for most people's tastes, but "adequate" (at best) as far as my own taste buds are concerned. C'est la vie, ne c'est-pas? ... bien oui.

I've seen reports for numerous places that discuss, in part, "rude" or "poor" service, and while it's true that even the saints must have had their share of bad, if overlooked, days, my long, wandering 'experience' has yielded this little 'bon mot', as far as the service is concerned: As ye sow, so shall ye reap. Or, as Otis Redding once said, "Try a Little Tenderness." 

Café Claude is also on a nice lane, in a too-small, but wonderful little 'french-ified' part of San Francisco, and you want to go there, you know you do. So go!

By the way, the map shows a few garages in the area, but probably the closest (and public/cheaper) one is at Sutter & Stockton (not on the map). Also, the St. Mary's garage apparently has had issues with parking attendants stealing things from cars. Yikes! Consider yourself alerted.
author: Brian S.

description:
My Sig O and I did New Year's here and it was fantastic!  

The setting is a quiet little alley and this place is tucked back into the side of a building.  Very charming interior and a friendly (and french!) staff.

We did a full 5 course experience and it was nothing but perfection.  The salmon mousse and carpaccio, lobster bisque, fillet (best!), and sinful chocolate dessert.  

At midnight they passed out hats and noisemakers and we all rang in the new year!  The ladies even got cute pink tshirts, how lovely!

I'm not even a huge fan of french food, but we decided that was the most perfect NYE we had both ever had!  Definitely worth a visit!
author: Lindsey S.

description: This place is tucked away in an alley and it felt like I was back in Paris again. Decent sized wine list, pretty tasty traditional French dishes, and a nice ambiance. Dinner service doesn't begin until 5:30pm. I accidentally got there at 4:45 but the cute French guy there was very accommodating and let us sit for a while and have drinks before they fired the kitchen up.
author: Emily K.

description:
There's no better way to spend a 70-degree day (in mid-November!) than have a leisurely lunch at a Parisian cafe over a couple glasses of wine.

If you're itching for a trip to Paris but don't have the time or money, a trip to Cafe Claude is in order - love the accents of all the waistaff (sooo French that you wonder if they're faking it), love the sidewalk seating (true Parisian style), and really love croque madame (which is a contender for the "best food ever," along with fish tacos, pinkberry original yogurt, and the amazing combination of galbi & naengmyun at Choson in LA).

White bread sandwiching bechamel and ham, covered with melted gruyere cheese and topped with a perfectly runny sunny side up egg. Whoever thought up this amazing dish gets my undying gratitude and respect (I'm pretty much a sucker for poached or fried egg on top of anything - salad, pizza, sandwich, porridge, rice...). YUM!
author: Deb I.

description: Well my husband and I were looking for a good French restaurant on a Sunday night.  Ok, so it was ok, but for the price it should have been a bit better.  First, it took a while to be acknowledged by the waiter and after looking at the cocktail menu and deciding on the drinks and our selection, he quickly said we do not have Campari... huh?  I had to point it out on the menu and they did have it and the bartender did a good job of Campari and soda.  The entrees, Omble Chevalier...(with salmon) and Coq au Vin were fine, but the onion soup was beef broth with no onion flavor, onion bits boiled out of flavor and not even tender were topped with lots of gruyere, the crouton should not have been submersed under the cheese layer and soggy.  What makes a good dining experience is consistent quality throughout, service and food. My husband's beet salad had 3 slices of prosciutto but sliced so thick it was hard to understand what balance could have been achieved among the texture and flavors.  We'll continue to look for good French restaurants.
author: Amor S.

description: Really cozy romantic atmosphere with great service and food that everyone liked all around.  One of my friends has dietary restrictions and the waiter was able to answer 90% of the questions about the menu and food preparation right off the bat, and went off to get answers to the other 10%.   The group had the beet salad, the pork loin, the ahi tuna, and the hawaiian fish special, and everyone thought their dish was very good.  We ended the delicious meal with the flourless chocolate cake souffle and creme anglaise.
author: Vivian W.

description:
I can't believe I've never been to this cute Frenchy bistro before!  We had the most exquisitely perfect meal tonight outside under a heat lamp.

To start, my dining companion and I shared a selection of pates and the escargot en croute.

My trout and her steak were both prepared exactly as we wanted, but more importantly, our champagne cocktails (bellini for moi, kir royale pour elle) were not too sweet, yet full of flavor.  

Parfait!
author: Marcus C.

description: Great food, ambiance and customer service.  I've been here with 3 people and tried all their food and everything I've tasted has been excellent!! Even on a rainy day they have heated lamps outside and little tents, it actually felt quite cozy out there. I had a gift certificate for $150, so I ordered a lot of dishes not realizing how large the portions were, so keep in mind if you order a salad...it's like entree size, but also keep in mind it's mainly water hahaha! I had a Caeser Salad,2 different pates, beef tartar, french onion soup, the trout which was VERY good, I don't usually order fish but I had a heavy lunch that day and plus all the appetizers I had ordered I thought I'd order something light, it had lemon and almonds, very nice.
author: Charla M.

description:
This is what restaurants should want to be like when they grow up: great service and fantastic food.

I went here with my girlfriend and another couple who had dined here previously. We really scored by getting the bar table as we were then served by the bartender, the suave and very charming Carrrrrlo. The name is actually Carlo, but that's how he pronounced it, which immediately set my girlfriend to "swoon" mode. Fine with me, as it allowed me to concentrate on the tasks at hand, and that was:

Cocktails made with Pernod!

Really tasty escargot!

Carlo was was an extremely gracious and attentive server and the whole evening was very enjoyable. I had the roasted lamb sirloin with white beans and bacon and it was incredibly tasty and for desert, the creme brulee was almost perfect. Cafe Claude is now one of my new favorite places in the Bay Area and I'm already planning on going back.
author: Ben R.

description:
I'm giving CC a four because it deserves it relative to all the other French options in SF.   The ambiance is great and they have live jazz certain evenings.  The menu is your typical French bistro fare and there was only one fake Spanish accent trying to say Voila about everything.  The steak and frites is yummy, the desserts are good and if you're lucky they even serve Clafouti sometimes which is rare for a restaurant even if it's France.  Don't order coffee there it was so burnt I complained and the cute little French hostess didn't understand what we said so I politely explain it in French so she took it off the bill.  Oh another thing, order the Bordeaux that comes by the glass,half bottle and full bottle, it's uber smooth and goes really well with the onglet.

**This is very versatile restuarant for taking out clients who are Europhiles or scoring on a hot date.  I would definitely take someone shaggable there and load them up with fine French wine and top it all off with a sinful dessert.
author: Amber L.

description:
A romantic treat. Great dining experience, with the live music, lively atmosphere, coziness, and delicious food. Very heart warming, and very Parisian as my boyfriend says!

The tiny restaurant hidden by a tightly packed bunch of umbrellas down a dark, tiny alley is a perfect contrast to what is hidden inside. The place was packed! We were seated in a more quiet part of the restaurant, near a wall mural made to look like you were looking through 'glass' to the 'outdoors'. Ok, so it was near the bathroom/storage area, but it wasn't too disruptive.

Now on to the meal...my boyfriend and I ordered the goose liver pate (we asked the waiter if this was the real deal and he said yes, of course, it's a French restaurant!), the onion soup, coq au vin, and the lamb (medium rare). The soup was savory, cheesy, and bready..very hearty! The pate...was simply fabulous. Creamy, not overly rich, smooth, very refined. It was delicious on the dinner bread. 

The coq au vin was strong on the senses - rich, thick sauce, and chicken that fell off the bone. Came with fingerling potatoes, pearl onions, and bits of bacon (?). It was a heady dish. The lamb was not gamey at all, and very delicious. It was delicate on the senses, but the accompanying herbs, beans, and what looked to be pancetta, provided a fusion of flavors on the tongue. In addition, there were two tomato halves covered in finely chopped herbs - very dramatic flavor!

The service was friendly and enthusiastic, but not in your face or overly attentive. The music was not quite the 'typical' jazz I expected (like lounge). It was more new age this evening, but it could have just been the artists. I'm curious to hear what the other jazz artists that perform there sound like. I love jazz more along the lines of John Coltrane or Miles Davis.

Will definitely be back, can't beat the romantic atmosphere, good eats, and all for a decent price.
author: Katherine P.

description:
Mmmm...  Excuse me while I mmmmmeditate on the goat cheese salad, white wine pate, and coq au vin that I scarfed down a few bites too quickly with my entire family last night.  5 people with good appetites (and wine ones) ate for 125 dollars.  What a steal.  I didn't hear one complaint that our water jug had to be refilled like two hundred times... No, the service was spotless! Minus one star for the unbearably snobby company.  Our waitress somehow pulled off the not-so-snooty vibe, but my god, it amazes me that we managed to  have such a nice meal despite the glares of disgust and contempt being shot around the room in the exact direction of our table...  Well, I never.

Not likely to go here again because I don't shop at Margaret O'Leary.  It's a real pity because the food was divine.  They offer a great selection of wines (local and foreign) by the glass and the bottle and on a nice night we could've easily sat outdoors and enjoyed the gutter stench wafting up from the Barbary Coast.  Still, not bad... not bad at all.
author: Amy M.

description:
Rigatoni pasta special was delightful!

Four gals sitting in the alley way near heated lamps sipping on martinis...it was a great time. 

Our waiter was very friendly and accommodating :)
author: Oanh N.

description:
This is my new favorite restaurant in San Francisco. Tucked away on Claude Alley behind Loehmann's on Sutter, you forget you're in San Francisco as you walk down the alley where Cafe Claude is nestled with a few other restaurants. It's small and cozy and probably requires reservations on weekends. I was there mid-week, and had a drink at the bar while I waited for my dining companion and they were able to seat us right away. Their cocktails are impressive and unique - I was torn between 2 cocktails: 

Mousse D'amerique (flor de caña rum, fresh lime juice, depaz sugar cane syrup, organic pineapple and flor de caña foam) and 

Bouquet (flor de caña rum, creole shrub, brown sugar cube,
mathilde raspberry liquer, muddled lavendar,
fennel, cloves)

I had the "Bouquet" and it was delicious (and strong). All of the cocktails are creative - next time I will try the Mousse D'amerique.

For dinner, I had the Betterave salad which consisted of red beets, snow peas, feta cheese,and pistou along with the Coquilles Saint Jacques which came with a small salad. It was a lot of food, despite being small plates, and I probably could have skipped the salad. Everything was delicious - my only complaint is that I would have preferred for the Coquilles Saint Jacques to be hotter in temperature - it seemed as if they might have been prepared ahead of time and sat under a warming lamp. But, they were delicious.

Apparently they have Jazz on Thurs-Sun nights, so I'll have to go back to check that out.
author: Maren P.

description:
Cafe Claude, Thank you!!  We had the most lovely ladies lunch for 11 in April'08.  
Everything was fabulous and perfect for our group. 
The service there was exceptional - so exceptional that we began to wonder if there were hidden microphones in the pepper mills.  
Us (speaking amongst ourselves):  "... that's too bad that there's no more chicken sandwiches available... oh well..."
Waitress, minutes later: "... looks like we can make one more sandwich for you..."
Us: "man, this side salad is so bare... I mean, it's really just lettuce..."
Waitress, minutes later: "... here are some cut-up tomatoes for your salads..." 

We were very impressed!  After a couple glasses of wine, we were obviously talking waaay too loud... or were we?  
Whatever the case, we're still impressed! 
and the food was terrific. quiche, fries, soup... all was great. everyone seemed to have enjoyed their meals.  
Perhaps a bit nontraditional to start with, we ordered a couple cheese plates (since we were waiting for people) and meats which went well with the bread.  I enjoyed all the cheeses and the prosciutto(and did not care to try the pork or sopresetta).  
Choc cake was delicious.  Every drink was always full and satisfying.  

The best part was that we could focus on celebrating and enjoying each other's company because the restaurant ran so smoothly.  They are professionals, as should be. and their food really is excellent.  

The location is something special as well.  The flow of this place, tucked in an alley, really sets it apart from many restaurants in this beautiful city.  Maybe we fell upon a most gorgeous spring afternoon, but this restaurant will be fully engraved in my mind as one of my favorite lunches, because it was just absolutely lovely.  Bravo!  Bravo!  Bravo!
author: Mela F.

description: I took a client here for lunch this past week and it was my first time at Cafe Claude although I had heard good things about it.  The weather was beautiful so we sat outside and it was perfect.  The service was good...polite and fast.  I ordered the french onion soup which was really good but had almost too much cheese if that's possible.  It was just hard to get through but it was excellent.  Then for an entree I had the salmon which was really good as well.  When the weather is great I would totally recommend this place for lunch.  It's casual but upscale at the same time.
author: Blake B.

description:
I'm a sucker for nice people. Give me a nice hostess, waiter, bartender, whatever - and even if the food is meh, I will still have a nice time. (If the people are mean and the food is great, I probably won't be back)

Had a great post-World-Affairs-Council-lecture dinner here with a friend. I had the tuna tartare, a salad, and we shared a cheese plate. My friend ordered the pasta special - looked way to saucy and creamy for me, but he liked it. :)

We sat outside, which was warm on a Jan. night because of the heat lamp. It started to rain, but we were still comfy under the awning. Only problem was the annoying guy at the table next to us who had no idea he was YELLING his conversation at his dinner partner (who was very quiet in response). I literally had to lean over the table and cock my head to the side to hear my friend talk. If you have someone next to you who understands close-ish quarters, you shouldn't have a problem :)

Drinks: I had a girly somethingorrather with bubbles and ginger and mint. Yummy maybe too sweet for some. My friend had his jack and coke staple.

Did I mention the nice hostess and waitress and bartender? yay.
author: s w.

description:
Cafe Claude is hidden in an alley in the FiDi [and not one of those scary dirty bum alleys, this is a very very QUAINT alley], where it would never occur to me to look for a small french restaurant!

Claude is dimly lit, and really romantic.

I'll be honest, I was completely distracted when I was here, so I can not say ANYTHING specific about the food, except that I remember enjoying it... Really, that's what a good 'date' restaurant should do - focus the attention on YOU, not the decor, the service, or even the food - the food should just be very good, which it was.
author: Liza P.

description:
Wandered over here with a group of 4.  We were hungry, just got out of the Ritz Carlton, and found ourselves seeking out for food.  I remembered an "scary alley that had the cutest restaurant" in it.  I pointed as we walked by. The group decided to give it a try and so we did.  It was about 5:15 and they told us that dinner would not be served until 5:30, however we were welcome to stay for drinks.  And so we were seated, with the cocktail menu and dinner menu.  The wine list was quite extensive.  I had a class of Cafe Claude's own Merlot (2004).  Very tasty!  Smooth and slightly warm, went down nicely.  

The service was a bit slow, they were trying to get themselves together for 5:30... I guess.  They ended up telling us dinner was not ready until 5:45.  It was OK! We really had no rush since we decided dinner would be better then leaving the city in traffic.  

As an appetizer, we had crab cakes.  Those were delicious! There was three little crab cakes served atop baby arugula, slice cucumbers, and 4 cherry tomatoes, drizzled with a lovely sauce that accompanied the dish. ($14)

For my entree, I had Black tiger prawns skewed in kabob style atop a bed of mixed greens with slices mangoes and cherry tomatoes.  A light vinaigrette to finish it off!  Quite delicious.  I loved the little detail of having the prawns skewered in not your traditional stick, but a rosemary stick.  That, I thought, was fabulous!

Overall: interesting/cute location, great food, wonderful drink selection, a bit on the pricey side (but it is French food), and service was OK.

4 stars. Bam!
author: Shali N.

description:
I went here for New Years and had a fabulous time. There was a prefixed menu and we were there for about two hours. The restaurant is really charming and the waitress was great.

The Chilean Sea bass was delicious it was light and buttery. The lobster bisque was fishey for me, but the other people I was with enjoyed it. I think was more of my personal taste. We started out with a scallop and it was one of the best scallops I have tasted, the basil gave it a really nice flavor. I really recommend this place for a romantic evening.
author: Emme J.

description:
After a couple of drinks (at least the ones that I was able to count) at the Irish Bank, my troop of crazies trekked an alley over to Cafe Claude. "It was a bit hard to get a reservation," Lilo says. Hmm. Verifies bits of reviews I have read/heard on how wonderful the food is?

Perhaps it did. Had I not tried to catch the eyes of our server, I would still probably be wondering. My friends and I were having a great time - sure. We were all catching up on our lives - yes. A 1.5 second quiet moment (after what seemed like 20+ minutes since we were seated) made me realize that we still have our menus and a server is yet to come by to ask whether we would at least want some vino. 

Maybe the Rillette du Perigord was tastier than what I had thought it was, but it was essentially a non-event. Our entrees, however - were exceptional; The veal was succulent, the trout tasty. I would come back for the food and the live music by the bar that plays into that great restaurant atmosphere. I'd just make sure to abate my hunger pangs before sitting down in case a replay of the previous scenario happens.
author: Cham M.

description: OK food but expensive! And don't count on your reservation. They'll make you wait 15-20minutes even if you've booked a table.
author: parviz d.

description:
Definitely delicious. One of my favorite places to eat around Union Square.

This place has never dropped the ball when it has come food, and that fancy back ally ambiance is wonderful.

The pate is wonderful. A delicious heart attack waiting to happen. And the lamb steak I had was cooked perfectly, with very addictive flavors.

A wonderful place to visit in SF, to get that french quarter flavor.
author: Zeel J.

description:
Holy hell.. did I mention how freakin adorable the waiters are here? WOW.. I would go back every day if I wasn't poor!!

That's all
author: Sarah W.

description:
As with anywhere, ups and downs. 
The Ups: Outstanding service. Reasonable prices. Authentic French cooking without a bunch of attitude.
The Downs: Crowded. Loud. Inconsistent execution of some classic dishes. Tough access and parking.

This has been a favorite of ours for a long time...ever since I lived in the city in the early 90's. Back then, This was a hidden little gem that always had a parking spot and a candlelit table. Now it's a total scene. Every table packed, even outside, and prices up significantly. 

However, we still managed to walk in on a busy thursday and get a table for two within 5 minutes. The staff is friendly, helpful, and prompt, and the place runs like clockwork. I guess you'd have to be to stay in business for almost 20 years.

We got the onion soup: A+, the escargots:B+ (good, but overbearing pesto), Trout Almands: A, pommes frites: A+ (all fries should aspire to this), and the lamb:B (not very tender, and demiglace was over reduced, leaving it a little bitter) Dessert was the coconut cream: A+ (friggin amazing)

All in all we got apps, entrees, dessert, and 3 drinks each for $140 before tip. Pretty damn reasonable I thought. My only complaint was that it wasn't my secret little spot anymore. Hardly the restaurants fault to be loved to death!
author: Alex D.

description:
The concept of Caf Claude is fantastic. A small cafe in the financial district that reminds you of the cafe in Paris.  I personally found the waitresses a little bit annoying as they speak English in French accent. The food, however, is far from fantastic. The pate plate is very disappointing as you can find better tasting pate in Wholefood. The steak sounds better in the menu than when you ate them. Overcooked with too much salt to inflict hypertension. The dessert is a total waste of money. The chocolate cake is perfect for those who love Hershey chocolate --- I personally would rather eat something non-Hershey. 

In a nutshell, despite the many good things my friend told me about this place, I left this restaurant feeling miserable. Perhaps, it's just my bad food choices. The ambience is not balanced with the food quality.
author: Fred F.

description:
Cafe Claude has been a favorite restaurant for years.  It's quaint, cozy, and I always have a good experience.

Food is delicious, great ambiance, great service, reasonable prices.  A lot of people seem not to care about the whole French vibe but me, I love to travel, I love Europe and, if I can be in America but feel like I'm in Europe once in a while, I'll take it.  

I've been to Claude on dates, I've brought my family, I've had a girls dinner night, I've eaten at the bar.  

Claude Lane is tucked away off Bush Street and definitely gives the feeling of being somewhere other than downtown San Francisco like say, uh. . .Paris?  

I'll sum up Cafe Claude with a quote from the French film Jules et Jim (1962), "They left nothing behind them" which is exactly what happens when eating at Cafe Claude.  

Essayer ce restaurant et sentir l'idylle!
author: James M.

description:
I have only eaten here once.  I got a croque madame hoping to evoke memories of France.  The bechamel sauce was nasty and I couldn't even force myself to eat it.  I have never returned.

UPDATE: The manager of this establishment contacted me in regards to this review and apologized for my negative experience and offered a free meal for me to give them a second chance.  Plus one star for customer service.  Will edit review once I get the chance to return.

SECOND UPDATE:  I gave this place another chance.  I did not take the manager up on the free meal but instead came here with some friends for a birthday lunch.  I stand by my previous review.  In fact, this visit was worse.  The server messed up two orders and the food was disappointing to almost everyone at our table.  Bummer.
author: Mahogany G.

description:
Very cozy, warm restaurant located on the most adorable street. The food was moderately priced and very tasty. Went for a dinner with my best girls - we tried the pasta of the day (gemelli with seared ahi tuna and salmon, capers, olives and spinach in a delightful white wine sauce), seared ahi tuna (again, very tasty sauce), goose liver mouse and roasted potato gratin (OMG - to die for!). 

This place is very cozy - so cozy, you probably shouldn't come with a party of more than 3-4 people. We were a party of four and the table was a little cramped - good thing we liked each other! :)

Also - very good cocktails. My sidecar was well made.

Overall - perfect date or intimate friends dinner restaurant!
author: Adrienne C.

description:
First of all, I love it being tucked away in an small alley!
Took me a bit of time to look for it, but when I did find it, it was like "OUI!!!"

My gf and I had not made a reservation, but we went pretty early, so we got seated right away.  Being absolutely horrible at French, means I know none, I almost pooped my pants when the waitress greeted us in French..."now my genius gf who knows seven languages will dump me, right here, right now," but she switched to english right after, phew!  

Second thing I loved, wow. Look at that wine selection! 

Anyway, as I was saying, I know no French, naturally, I had no clue of what I ordered. 
But I do know bread, and it was tasty!! Perfect, just how you would imagine a French bread should be like, it is exactly that. 

The w.e liver I got was alright. nothing special, but just right. 

The Beef Tatare though, mmmmmmmmMMMMmmmmmmmmmmmMMMmmmmmmm, Yum, and guess what, MORE bread, in sticks! lol. GREAT!!

But here is the minus one: lamb.
Not that it wasn't beautiful, it was, BUT the meat was not nearly as tender as I expected it to be... i thought it was a lil overcooked as well for "medium-well"
I did enjoy the eggplant on the bottom! 

We also had chocolate mousse for dessert, MMMMM! WOOOO!! AHHHHH~~~! OHHH, GUUD, was all I said. 
(take about 5 spoons, I think it will get a lil' too rich after that, but during the first few encounters, make sure you get a spoon-FULL!!)

Overall, a very romantic atmosphere!
I will definitely go back upon improving my French skills...haha

Go try it, I'm sure you will find something to fall in love about. 
-3-
author: TASTY P.

description:
The food is amazing. Because the flavors are so well thought out, you don't have to order a lot to be satisfied. My friend and I ordered appetizers and soups and it was the perfect amount and price! 

I highly recommend their special cucumber cocktail. Literally the best cocktail I've had in SF.

The only reason I gave it four stars is because our waiter was very snooty.
author: Cameo E.

description:
Despite the difficulty finding the place... with no help from other directionally challenged individuals I might add, I quite enjoyed Cafe Claude.  The remote alley where it is located isn't quite as glamorous as Belden Place, but once inside I think Cafe Claud's interior transcends the typical Belden Place restaurant.

The wait staff was quite friendly and attentive (of course, this could be because we were the first people to be seated for an early dinner).  Everyone seemed to have French accents, so naturally their authenticity came into question.

The food was quite good, although not the best I've experienced lately.  I had the flat iron steak (surprise surprise) and found it a bit tougher than I'd like, but tasty nonetheless. Definitely worthy of a repeat visit.  Although with so many other restaurants to try, I'm not sure when that will be.
author: Jeff S.

description:
Since visiting France I'd found only 1 place in the US with pomme frites as good. Strangely it was in Minneapolis, MN. Finding Cafe Claude, I am happy to say I've found the 2nd place. Crispy, hot, thin salty with parsley sprinkled. Mmmmmmmm.
    Additionally, their Steak Poivre is quite remarkable. Excellent sauce, and the potato gratin, haricot verts and roasted tomatoes on the side were the perfect accompaniment.
     Service was top notch, the noise level was a bit loud, but its great fun to be able to eat dinner at 9 PM and lounge around till 10:30 with no one sweeping up around you.
     To top it off the flourless chocolate cake with Creme Anglaise was perfecto.
author: Perry M.

description: Fantastic meal her! The trout almondine was to die for. Lovely atmosphere. Very nice
author: Suzanne L.

description:
My friends and I were wandering around Union Square before the New Year and we really wanted to try and find the Little Paris district nearby.

As we zigged and we zagged thru the streets between the Square and Chinatown, we went down an alley that we thought was the alley but it wasn't the alley.  Instead we came upon Cafe Claude and we were far from disappointed.

We shared the cheese plate, meat plate & butternut squash soup.  All were divine and filled our tummys with goodness.

The entrees were also spot on!  I had their Pasta of the Day which was a Penne dish that I couldn't help but scarf down like a hungry cheetah.  (Sorry friends, but you can't have a taste!)  

We really enjoyed our meal at Cafe Claude and I am going to be taking my sister there for lunch tomorrow since she lived in France and misses the food considerably.  I know in my heart Cafe Claude will not disappoint us.
author: Keika L.

description:
Today, during my Asian American Psychology class, I was about to commit mental suicide when I received a text from my mom.
" Surprise late bite @ 3pm today      mom me" ( Yes, she has still yet to learn how to punctuate texts, but I love her.)
I get home assuming she has some nom nom for me waiting at the table, but she's dressed...nicely. She demands I put on some fake eyelashes. I decline.
We take the bus downtown and she proceeds to walk me down some sketch looking alley called "Claude Lane" off of Bush. I'm scared, but suddenly there are pretty murals on the walls, maroon overhangs, and some white cloth covered tables. "Cafe Claude" doesn't have very good signage, but its the one with the maroon overhang. The green overhang belongs to some Irish Pub.
I'm still confused, so she sits me down and the waiter brings us the menu. First thing I see is "Croque Monsieur". I squeal internally since the waiter is watching me. You see, a few weeks ago, well actually...for a couple weeks, I have been lamenting that I won't be able take my trip to Europe this summer as I had wanted. I was complaining that I wanted French food. And I wanted it now. And my mom brought it to me.
Umm, can you say amazing? And this is during the time when I should be taking her out...I mean, mother's day and all. But anyhow, so I'm having a freaking heart attack of happiness because we pretty much could be in France with the outdoor seating and God help me there are Vespa scooters parked nearby.
So we order. Decided to share our courses instead of ordering individual. My choice. Mom took a Lactaid so everything on the menu is free game. Chevre cheese salad to start- chevre goat cheese on toasts, bed of greens tossed in amazing vinaigrette, apple slices, candied walnuts, cherry tomatoes. Standard, but come on guys, the cheese was all crispy on the outside and gooey inside. Mouth orgasm number one.
For our entree, Porc au Miel. Umm, sweet things and salty things together is my specialty. Tender pork tenderloin ( was that redundant?) in a honey caramel-ish butter sauce with haricots vert and caramelized apple slices. Rich and a generous serving so I'm glad we shared this.....so we could make room for the pommes frites. Umm, fried in duck fat anyone? And served with ketchup AND some spicy mayonnaise looking thing that I have been missing all my life. I really had to pace myself. I really did. Especially since my mom mentioned chocolate cake. Chocolate anything makes me happy, but recently I've been training myself to be a sort of snob. Valhrona or bust, y'all. So I had some high expectations for that chocolate cake....which ended up being a souffle like contraption under the nickname of Moelleux au Chocolat with creme anglaise. This will be the name of my first born child. I'm sorry Bushi Tei Bistro, my souffle de-virginizing at your place was totally not the real thing. This was it. Melty, but dense, not watery, a intense chocolate sensation that lingered on the tongue. And that creme stuff that looked like condensed milk....with the cool raspberries on top and the heat of the chocolate....No words.
author: jeddie k.

description:
I went here for with my gfs last night for dinner and it was AMAZING.  We ordered some apetizers, the pate (3 types), escoge and grilled oysters.  Everything was just great.  For entre, we ordered different things: the steak, the lamb, the pork, and the ahi tuna.  The pork was simply delicious.  It's soft and marinated in a sweet peach sauce that just melts in your mouth.
The waitress recommended the French wine "Chino" for us and it was a great choice.  If you like Pinot Noir, you'll like this wine.
Overall, service was great, food was great.  Next time, we'll order less so that we can save room for their desert!
I will come back here again!
author: Lily B.

description:
This is where Mr. Metro likes to break out his Frenglish. 

"Excuuse moi? Doo yoo af anee moos-terd too goo weef dee Croque Madame? Ew...ant I wood elso leek a cornichon on dee site. Merci! Merci!

Place is packed weef beezneez pe-ople du-rang dee lonch. For le diner ees moch better." 

Can't go wrong here...unless it's crowded. 

4 duckets for fab bistro food in the financial zone.
author: Johnny C.

description:
I love cafe clade !!! 
This is lovely+cozy  little place. The staff is always friendly =D

This is my most-frequented restaurant of all time.. 

My favourite food is Coq St.Jacques , Tuna Tartars , Pranw Brochette , Escargot en Croute. That was the best !!!
author: Shira M.

description:
I went here a couple of times when I lived in SF, and it was OK. More for the scene than anything else, I guess, so I figured it was a decent last-minute option for a quick dinner on a recent trip. 

The food's all right, no better than the numerous french alleyway restaurants in this neighborhood but here's something stupid:

We ordered a couple of cocktails, and when they arrived my son wanted the cherry from my manhattan to chew on, so I dug it out for him. At the bottom of my glass lay a little fruit fly, which is whatever, but we're overpaying for drinks so I might as well tell the waiter. When I called him over, instead of just replacing my drink he gave a boring speech about it being summer, and how there are lots of flies out here, and if I REALLY WANTED TO, he'd take my drink back, but he COULDN'T GUARANTEE that another fly wouldn't land in my replacement. ???

Ciao, Claude!
author: Steven W.

description: I love the setting of the restaurant it is like you are under the Eiffel Tower.The ceasar salad was good so as the potato gratin.I love the pork with caramelized apples. This restaurant is lovely.
author: Amanda V.

description:
It is really 3.5 stars.  The BF and I drove down to Belden Lane on Sunday evening hoping for a miracle that some of the restaurants would be open so we could enjoy the warm weather - only one of the Belden places was open and it wasn't what we were looking for so we opted to head up to Cafe Claude instead.  It was a great experience - sitting outside, people smoking around us, very European and the service was also very European.  We  weren't rushed between courses, our plates were perfectly timed and I had wonderful wine recommendations based on what I was ordering.  

The BF got the pasta of the day which was fantastic, albeit it very rich.  My sensitive stomach could only handle about 5 bites before it became grumpy with me.  I opted for the mushroom ravioli as my main which was interesting.  It was not like any ravioli I had ever had before.  It was a semi-large plate of delicious mushrooms in a port reduction sauce and one large flat noodle on top and one large flat noodle on the bottom of the plate.  It was different, but tasty.  We ended up getting four apps and one main plate, and three beverages - all for around $85.  It felt like a steal considering how full we were when we walked, rather, waddled away.   Not to mention, if you are looking for something a little quieter and less crowded than Belden Lane - Cafe Claude is a great altnerative.
author: Katie P.

description:
Good french onion soup
Good steak tartare
Terrible raviole
Good truffle mousse
Good goose liver mousse with sauternes
Bad shrimp brochette

I like the atmosphere, inside and out.
author: Marina N.

description:
This is yet another late review from our San Francisco visit in October 2011.

The people who work in the dining room and front of house have wonderful energy and obviously love working at Cafe Claude. I personally believe this makes a big difference especially in the restaurant biz, where the work can be grueling and dealing with the public can be draining. When employees have a passion for what their company represents (or their "mission") and can be proud of the product coming out of (in this case) the kitchen - your clientele picks up on this consciously or subconsciously.

So needless to say the atmosphere is truly wonderful. It's just as much about the employees as the beautiful decor. We started at the bar where the bartender was super nice even though it was very busy. This is something we rarely ever encounter in Washington, DC (bad service town). It was even more refreshing since it was our first time - the bar is small and most everyone else seemed like a regular. We were being treated no differently! How nice. :) The cocktails were strong but balanced and delicious.

I thought the jazz trio was fabulous. They had a singer on a few songs - really nice. These musicians, as well as the singer, are real true-to-life artists. We don't get that at Washington restaurants which made me appreciate them all the more.

After about 20-30 minutes at the bar we were seated at our table within 5 or 10 minutes of our reservation. Now this is something that frequently is *not* the case when we have reservations at a Washington restaurant. We're on time but for some reason we cannot get seated until 30-45 mins PAST our rsv. This was not the case at Cafe Claude and was a refreshing change from our experiences at home.

Our waiter was super nice, funny and knowledgeable about the food and wine. We only ordered entrees but he didn't try to up sell or if he did was so casual about it I forgot. This is also another technique which the staff at Cafe Claude could teach to Washington restaurant employees. While I understand the need for up selling - there's a right and wrong way to go about it. Here it was the right way.

Although we did not do appetizers we did share a dessert and it was just as delicious as our main courses (which were btw coq au vin, the best we've ever had and pork tenderloin another *the-best-of* ). 

We also ended up ordering cognac and a brandy with our dessert (tart tatin). It was autumn and it just made the dessert and after dinner drinks perfect. 

So restauranteurs, there is no need for your staff to engage in the "up sell" if what you offer is thoughtfully prepared delicious and graciously served. 

Cafe Claude was and still is one of the very best restaurant experience we've had  and will always be tops in our travels on our next visit.

PS - If mgrs, chef or owner(s) read these reviews and have any heart for those of us living far far away from your beautiful restaurant and charming city, is there any way possible to get the recipe for your coq au vin? (tears welling in my eyes as i type!)
author: Paulette N.

description:
Cafe claude was a bit nicer than I had expected for a 2 $$ type place, but to be honest it should probably be $$$ cause it is a bit pricey...nonetheless, the place is worth it....me and the Gf spent a round $100 after tax/tip for wine, 1 salad, 2 "small" plates, and 1 entrée. The "ravioli" small plate and the tuna tartare where both amazing...especially the ravioli...

As for the place itself, there is a heated outside area which is nice-ish, but it was nicer inside...a bit smushed but not to the point where it's a problem...the crowd at 8 on Sun night was a 40 something, mildly pretentious but tolerable crew...and service was good overall
author: Joey P.

description:
Bonsoir!

What a quaint little restaurant located in an alley for a romantic saturday night dinner date.  The atmosphere is a little noisy inside, but quietness could be had if you decide to eat outside instead.   We decided to dine inside because it was freezing outside.

Appetizers: 3 samples of pâtes and Escargot en Croute .. both were excellent.

Entres: Lamb and Ahi ...advice, lamb medium/well was still pinkish...otherwise the sauce for both dishes was delicious!

The food was actually plentiful so we didn't have room for dessert!

We'll definitely come back here again..
author: Jeff H.

description: I come to Cafe Claude often for lunch, and I order the same thing every time- croque monsieur with french fries...I was with a friend last night and we decided to pop in for a late dinner. I asked the waitress if we could possibly order a croque even though it was not on the dinner menu. She asked the chef if it was possible; she was so sweet and brought it out promptly. Super accommodating! I can always expect a great meal, great service and an authentic french ambiance.
author: Annie B.

description:
Not a big fan of completely raw meat but with the mixing demonstration and explanation of a cute waiter, the steak tartare was a lot more tolerable.  I ordered pasta of the day which is not very memorable (so that's why it's called the pasta of the day, not some fancy name on the regular menu). However, my friend's Coq Au Vin (hm....looks like chicken mole) is really tender. When you stick your fork into it, you can tell it has been cooked in the slightly sweet yummy sauce for quite a while. Sauce and chicken all mixed into one. That's definitely the highlight of the meal. Too bad that's not mine dish. I think I suffer from "the-others-plate-always-tasted-better" syndrome again.

One drawback, we were sitting outside and it was freezing cold. I was wearing a down jacket with my hood on while eating. San Francisco is NOT good for outdoor seating at all.  

Thanks Richmer for sponsoring this French tasting :D. My treat next time!
author: Hinling Y.

description: One of my favorite spots in San Francisco!!!! You have to try it to understand, definitely recommend.
author: Karina A.

description: Had dinner with LP, before meeting other friends.  Quaint area with it's hidden treasures of Yum!  For starters we had the Steak tartar, followed by a melting Filet Mignon.  Need I say more.
author: Jay B.

description: Steak tar tar was excellent.  Onion soup excellent.  Coq ua vin disappointing.   The sauce was very good but the chicken was dry.  I couldn't eat it.  However, the waiter did take it off the bill.  The big negative is the closeness of the tables.  We felt very cramped.  They would do well to take out at least one table in the bank along the wall.  It is not worth a return trip.  There are just too many excellent restaurants in the area.
author: Patricia B.

description:
I don't have anything bad to say about Cafe Claude.  It was a gorgeous day and I was eating outside.  I looked over the menu and passed on a few items I didn't have the guts to try (quail egg) an example.  I guess all those episodes of Fear Factor have really started to tarnish my image about food.  

I went with the safer choice ala the Pork sandiwch.  The sandwich itself was pretty darned good and the pork was juicy which is surprising because it's easy to dry pork out if it's cooked too long.  The french onion soup seemed to be a popular choice amongst other customers and go figure... it's a french restaurant.   

The service was just right and there was no snob factor involved.   Prices were reasonable for the location and dare I say I will be returning.  The only reason I could not give the hallowed 5 star rating is because I've only been here once.  I'm interested in trying something else ... just not the quail egg ... YET!
author: Bill P.

description:
I'd love to give this place 3.5 stars.

We went for Bastille Day this past year and had a blast.  Imagine, a table of six women at an outrageously French bistro!  Had one of the most fantastic syrahs there (wish I knew the name!) and their main dishes were just decadent.  However, the best were their homemade pates.  So good that it almost rivaled foie gras.  Try the Gallatine pate... we ended up ordering an extra one, it was so yummy!
author: Serena Y.

description:
Sometimes when you'd rather not be accosted by all the restaurant folks on Belden, it's nice to walk the extra block or so to Cafe Claude and get seated right away.  

Let's see... I've had the cheese plate, and the pt selection, and French onion soup.  All quite tasty.  Great wine selection.  I manage to go at least once or twice a month.
author: Anonymouse C.

description:
I wish I still worked closer to this spot.  It's a quaint little place, nice to enjoy in its little alley on a warm afternoon.  

The food savory, the staff exceedingly pleasant, the people-watching views impeccable, and area quite awesome (French quarter is a block away, Le Central is a few storefronts down, the Irish Bank is in the next alley, Chinatown a few blocks one way, North Beach slightly off that, etc etc.) - really a rose.  

Think of it like an affordable mini-vacation.
author: Giorgina G.

description: ordered seafood stew. the stew broth was extremely and unhealthily salty, probably the saltiest food ever in my life, and i'm almost sixty. was it a one-time mistake by the chef? i don't know. i'll never find out since this was my first time there and will be the last time too.
author: Akir M.

description:
Oh, what a nice spot for an early dinner. My friend Sarah and I came here for a taste of some food we had never had before, and our dinner consisted of escargotes and the house-made pate to start, as well as steak tartare and our individual desserts of coconut sorbet and creme brulee, all enjoyed with a carafe of the house Merlot.

Our pursuit of snails, whipped meat and raw beef ended up costing us a total of $80, but we found it worth the experience.

I was sort of hoping for the steak tartare in sliced form (such as steak frites or a fillet), but I'd never had it before so I wouldn't consider it a disappointment on the restaurant's behalf. The mustard flavor was a tad heavy, though. The escargotes weren't chewy like the ones I had eaten elsewhere almost 10 years ago, so that was a pleasant surprise.
author: Amy Z.

description: Nice environment...good music mostly...food was ok. I had pork wrapped in bacon - tasty but a little salty :( a little pricy for the food but overall ok experience
author: XYZ Q.

description: Very close to Union Square. I found it funny for a French Restaurant many of the wait staff didn't know how to prounce the name of the dishes. The Saturday night, night life was wonderful, but I found inside the restaurant the jazz sounds was lovely, but it was just too hot. So me and my friend just hung out outside and soaked up the city sounds, while enjoying a hot beverage, and some dessert. Would return, even if going solo, a nice cool place to hang on a Saturday night.
author: L L.

description:
I wouldn't say I have had a bad experience here, however, I think this place is a little over rated.  I love it because it has the outdoor seating with heat lamps if its cold and even if you were to sit inside, you aren't in some large room without character, but the service is always average along with my food.  

I went here for lunch a few days back, and besides the host shuffling us from table to table, the waiter seemed to be MIA.  I had the tuna nicoise salad.  The portion size was decent, but there was only one small slice of tuna, which was way too salty, along with my salad being drenched in way too salty of a vinaigrette.  Meh, not sure, but for a salad of that price just for lunch, I guess I was a little under impressed.  

I may be back if someone else has a hankering as it is a cute place, but I doubt I will suggest it
author: Carlee B.

description:
The schoolbell just rang. Today's class is covering coq au vin and I suggest that the other French bistros in San Francisco send their people over for the Thursday class so that they can take notes.

Flavors were well-balanced, chicken was well-braised (tender, but not turned to mush) and the sauce had a nice level of body. They also chose an appropriate wine to build the sauce, which often turns out to be an epic fail when I have coq au vin out in restaurants. The only thing I would have changed about the dish would have been to roast the pearl onions, as they maintained that "frozen pearl-onion-y" flavor.
