Some quick notes about some of the other reviews, during my experience, the service staff was very nice (I was greeted in French and a few of the service staff were speaking to one another in French when I arrived); I didn't experience any SNAFU's with salt or spice levels; and, it was hard to find but I give them extra points for being hidden down an alley - where all great schools are.

Other gold stars - good bread service, excellent flavor on their duck/pork rillette (they could do away with the greens underneath it though and beef up the garnishes) and well-rounded wine selection.
author: David W.

description:
Would have earned 5 stars if their drinks had any kick.  My wife is a lightweight but couldn't feel her drink at all, and I couldn't feel my 2?  What are they $10 non-alcoholic martinis? 

The service was great, although they didn't check on anything except our drink status often enough.  They were almost too nice and chipper.  The place is small.  As I was walking back from the bathroom the waitress with service was in my way.  I stepped out of the way to let her by.  She refused my gesture (very politely) and backed up 20 feet to let me by.  It seemed a little ridiculous.  The food was really good, but not top of the top.  Really darn good though...  The setting was nice, there was a live musician, it felt safe and warm...
author: Michael B.

description:
This was the first place I had dinner the first time I visited San Francisco, so I have a decided soft spot for it. That said, I've had dinners here that ran the gamut from 2.5 stars all the way to nearly five, so I'll go four, with qualifications.

Point une: I'm just nuts for classically French, bistro places. It's like sophisticated, sexy soul food. The charcuterie and small plates here succeed best. Go for pate or rillettes, escargot or steak tartare and you're almost certainly in for a throughly Gallic treat. Larger plates aren't always so pleasing.

Point deux: The alley location is just as charming as you can imagine, like something out of a movie set. The interior can be either charming or hot and claustrophobic, depending on how crowded it is. 

Point trois: I quite enjoy the cocktails and wine list. The wine service is frequently superb. I once had a bottle of mid-priced Burgundy opened and poured with so much flair by such a handsome man, it darned near took my breath away.
author: Martha S.

description: Very small and located off the beaten path in an alley in Down town SF. Reminds of the old elegant San Francisco before the first tech boom in the 80's. I love to take people visiting from out of town here and watch their faces as  they eat rather simple but extremely well prepared traditional french cuisine. "Oh my god" is the most used phrase of the evening. My personal favorite is the Figs wrapped with prosciutto and when they have it,  the Atlantic Char. Their Petrale Sole is tasty too. I have one friend who is a very particular eater, the kind who makes you cringe when they place their order. The server was kind and accommodating and the food was in her words "perfection". Most servers speak fluent french and but lack that authentic rudeness one normally expects. The atmosphere is loud but it works. Warm summer nights seated at a window table are the most romantic and enjoyable. They have live music and lovely wine list. I would eat here daily if my budget would permit me.
author: Devil I.

description:
I would give Claude Cafe a 3.5, but since it's not an option I'm going to give it a 3 since it definitely wasn't a 4.

The atmosphere was wonderful. With a live band playing, the lighting and decor, the atmosphere deserves a solid 4.5/5. It was a Friday night, the place was cramped, we didn't have reservations and wound up waiting half an hour for a table. We ate outside, which was probably a mistake, because despite the heath lamps, outside you really lost the wonderful atmosphere that indoor seating provides. You can't hear the music, and at night the charm of eating outside wanes a bit. 

The food was just not that great. I had the pasta of the day, which was a seafood pasta in a light sauce. The salmon chunks were over cooked and basically tasted like canned tuna. Other seafood was completely nondescript. The sauce was light and nice, and I probably would have enjoyed the pasta more had it not had any fish on it at all. I had a side of fries, which were admittedly delicious, but your the side really shouldn't outshine your main dish. 

One of my friends had the pan seared tuna, which he described as "just a piece of tuna on bacon" -- nothing he would suggest to a friend. My other friend, however, absolutely loved the escargot, which was rather tasty. I may come back for a lunch of just the escargot, but nothing else really wowed my palette.
author: JessKate O.

description:
What a bummer.  I returned last night and was disappointed overall by the food & service.

Food:  I ordered the French onion soup.  FREAKING AWESOME, as always.  Really disappointed by my trout entree - it was tasteless.  Profiteroles for dessert - the puff pastries were stale... I had to saw at them with my spoon.  The bf loved his tomato soup, steak, & creme brulee.  Sometimes it's just the luck of the draw.

Service:  They must have been short on waitstaff.  The two gents who served us were really nice & amiable.  Problem is, I didn't see them often.  What should have been a 1.5 hour meal turned into 2 hours because of the long waits for food & the bill.  

I'll be back... just bummed that it didn't work out that well this time.
author: Doreen S.

description: Very nice place, we went there on a Monday night and the place was packed. Food was generous size and very tasty. Had the ahi tuna apt delish and had their special the grouper. Waiter was pleasent and cute. Wine was very good but a little over priced compare to a few places I visited. Overall I would go back.
author: LX F.

description: I came back on a Friday night for dinner and the live jazz. While I wish that they would serve the pan seared salmon with fava beans and pistou for dinner (which I love on the lunch menu), I did enjoy the scallops on the specials menu which was prepared with fava beans and pistou like my salmon. the shiitake and oyster mushrooms raviole with garlic and red wine is a good appetizer as well.
author: Diana B.

description:
Should start by admitting I'm no expert on french food. Having said that this is one of best restaurants  I've eaten at period. The french onion soup was amazing. The steak with peppercorn sauce was incredible. The steak was slightly crispy on outside but still tender on inside. I was so impressed with my meal Saturday night I came Sunday night deciding I wanted to eat my last meal in SF here. I'm glad I did. Had the glazed pork chops with caramel apples. It was perfect.I'm usually cautious about ordering pork chops at restaurants, either it's overcooked and tough or it's undercooked which will make me sick. The pork was perfect here.
The apple tart for dessert was also good. I had the Claude Mojito each time and it's probably best Mojito I've tasted.
The decor indoors is beautiful and they have live jazz on weekends. They have outdoor seating which is nice although tables seem close together.
The service was also very good. No snotty french wait-staff here.
author: James F.

description: I absolutely LOVE Cafe Claude!  It transports you into an entirely different place, like you are in Paris.  Many of the wait staff speaks French.  I love the live jazz music as well.  The best part of all is the food.  I have been to Cafe Claude many times and EVERYTHING I've tried there has been AMAZING.  And everyone I've ever taken to Cafe Claude or referred to Cafe Claude has given me rave reviews of their experience.  Try it, you'll love it!
author: Gregg L.

description: Cafe Claude marks as your one of a kind French cafe located on the outskirts of Union Square. They have various live bands to enjoy along with your dining experience. The cafe is quaint and is a good place to bring a date or good company. The dessert is one of a kind. Take for example, the popular creme brulee. It was very well prepared, with a nice thick creamy texture as the filling and a nice crust on top.
author: Ben W.

description:
I don' know how authentic the food is.  I don't know whether the staff hales from here or there.  I do know that the service was attentive and the food good.  That's enough for me. 

I arrive when the place opens on a Sunday evening.  Soon thereafter the room begins to fill.  People must know about and like Cafe Claude.  Certainly given its modest price structure it is a good option in the Union Square district.  

I start with pate that comes with some marinated veggies, lettuce, a cornichon pickle, sharp mustard and bread crisps.  The pate doesn't taste too much of liver (of which I am not a particular fan) and the plate wakens the appetite.

Coquille St. Jacque consists of two large clam shells filled with a savory mix of shrimp and clams in a creamy sauce and some fresh greens and herbs.  Again, a nice plate of food.

Finally trout almondine.  The fresh, sweet fish is covered with a blizzard of crunchy almonds.  Some properly cooked potatoes and green beans complete the plate.  A well-balanced, light plate of good food that tells you why this dish is a staple in french restaurants.  

Good food.  Good service.  Good price.  Go and see for yourself.
author: David D.

description:
yummy yummy.

I came here one of my mates for lunch, and the semi-trek from my office was not in vain.  It was everything I thought it would be, which was awesome.  The food was great, the waitress, although crowded, managed to find us a seat by the window, and the service was quick and efficient.

I always enjoy a nice lonnnnng break from the office, and making my way out to cafe claude never disappoints.  I love that its tucked away down an alley.  Reminds me why I love french food every time.

Tres chic.  Grub it.
author: Erika C.

description: The location is great, down a little alley.  All the food I tried was excellent, especially the tuna tartare.  Nice music, and it turned out I already knew the singer.  And best of all, Horacio at the bar mixes up some great drinks and keeps things rolling.  The only drawback is how tiny the place is, although that seems to add to the ambience.
author: Spike S.

description:
Small, intimate setting with great live music. I didn't try the food (although it smelled fabulous), but I did have some great wine! Great selection of both French and Californian wines.

And a super hot bartender ;)
author: Stephanie S.

description:
Got recharged, re-intoxicated here one fine Saturday morning with my best girlfriend.  At one point, we actually thought we were in France, if I remember correctly - it could have been our blood alcohol percentage or that we were nested in a quite alley surround by French accents and French cellphone conversations filtered only by the smoke of a thousand chain-smoked cigarettes.  We we.

We sayed on the street here, so I can't review the interior.  The street sitting was very attentive, tres chic and the food hit the spot amazingly well.

They're wine selection was great because it had good options of everything, not huge and extensive list, but definitely something for everyone's taste buds.

It was utterly romantic, and I'm not the mushy sentimental type, so get me some industrial buildings and a beige napkin and I'll still get off, but this place was very cozy, hidden, and sensual - much like lurid affair.

I think this place made me a switch hitter.

I will be back for the fabulous french fries or pommes frits that came with everything, the Croque Madame, Pan Bagnat and (but of course) zee booze.
author: Lauren G.

description:
I chose Cafe Claude for my birthday dinner location this year and I am so happy I did!  I loved it!  To start, it's in an alleyway near Union Square.  The setting is very much a European/New York scene with outside, sidewalk seating and live jazz coming from inside the restaurant. 

The service was quick and attentive. They even surprised me with a little birthday dessert and candle which was really cute.  But I'm getting ahead of myself....

To start I had the truffle mousse.  It was a creamy all-natural petaluma poultry chicken liver, truffles and cèpes marinated in sherry. Delicious! Flavor that just melted in my mouth!  It was great with my bubbly champagne that I was drinking. 

For my entree, I ordered the Truite aux Amandes. Translation: pan-seared trout, toasted almonds, white mushrooms, lemon butter sauce, steamed potatoes and green beans.  The French really know how to do it right, don't they??  AMAZING!  I felt like a little piggy because I was all but scraping my plate for the last remnants of sauce with some of the complimentary bread.  (yeah, I really did)

We skipped on dessert (except for the free little treat they brought out). I had cake waiting at home which is a great segue to my next review...
author: Candice M.

description:
Very french which is a good thing and a little bit of a bad thing. Food was okay, nothing remarkable. I had a super fancy ham and cheese sandwich with a simple salad. Service was a bit pretentious as well.  But, they didn't have any ketchup for the french fries.  They didn't run out, they just don't have any ketchup in the restaurant. Weird.

Update:
Apparently, Cafe Claude really cares about customer service because I just received a Yelp! message saying that they now have ketchup. Four stars!
author: Amanda L.

description:
I'm a big fan of their pan poulet ... probably because I tend to be starving and on my 2nd glass of champagne when it finally arrives.  

This place is great for the long leisurely lunch (see champagne statement above) - its adorable, delicious and I find the service quite lovely.  

Also, they have a fantastic happy hour.
author: Sarah K.

description:
I'd have to agree with Christina, the steak tartare here was fabulous, very flavourful, a good mix of ingredients.
The escargot was terrific too, wasn't all about the garlic like many other restaurants like to do.

This restaurant has a relaxing atmosphere with live bands, in a nice quiet alley with a nice selection of wines.

Cafe Bastille used to be my favourite french restaurant downtown, but definitely no longer.

Cafe Claude is a perfect example of what is great about SF,  just when you think you've discovered all there is to discover, you take a wrong turn, find yourself in some dark alley, and find another hidden gem.  

Next time I'm going to be trying the onion soup, mussels, and pretty much anything else I can devour.
author: Dave M.

description:
I've been here twice, the second time today for lunch, and it was good enough to incite me to write a review.

The first time I came here was for dinner a year or so ago.  I had coq au vin, and while it wasn't the best I've ever had, it was awfully good.

Today, I had the croque madame with fries.  The sandwich was excellent: the béchamel had excellent flavor, the ham and cheese were plentiful, and the French white bread was thin and very delicate, just as it should be.  (I have eaten my fair share of croque messieurs and mesdames in France.)  My only complaint would be that the egg was a bit too done for my taste, but the yolk was still runny.  Very minor.  The fries that it came with were also well represented, hot, and crispy.  I'm very, very cheap, and I had absolutely no qualms about paying $11.50 for this sandwich.  (Just writing that I actually paid eleven dollars for a sandwich hurts, but it was worth it.)  It was very filling; I certainly didn't need to order anything else.

My friend and I considered splitting a dessert, but they looked on the smaller side and not worth $8.

I'd give it a go for dinner again, but I'll definitely be back for lunch.
author: Alex F.

description:
Outrageously small portions.

Lack of attention from wait staff.

A bit pricey.

And they sell t-shirts.  I generally dislike places where apparel is served up as well.
author: M M.

description:
Stopped-in on a cold, foggy, drizzly night to get warm and have some dessert.  Sat at the small bar but even though it was by the door, still cozy warm.  Soft three piece band only feet away but not over-bearing.

Ordered the Moelleux au Chocolat soft chocolate cake with creme anglaise plus one little, itsy-bitsy half strawberry on top.  Fabulous!  Topped off with a warm expresso then off into the night quite satisfied.

Already made plans to go back for dinner!
author: Steven R.

description:
Came in for a post-christmas concert late night dinner at Cafe Claude in mid-December. 

It was a very quaint restaurant. The escargot and the cheese plate appetizers were extremely well done. The prawn salad appetizer was boring. 

There were  of us and we tried the fish, the steak, and I believe a lamb dish. The main dishes were not remarkable. The appetizers were the best thing we had.

Since it was our first time, I would definitely go back and try other things on the menu. Not before we give Anjou a try though! 

Oh our waitress Virginie (just in from France) was the best! She was friendly and very attentive without being fussy. She mentioned the steak tartare which we will definitely try at our next visit.
author: Pica L.

description:
My first time trying French cuisine and I loved it! The pate is definitely an acquired taste, but everything was delicious- especially the porc au miel! The people next to us were a little too close for comfort and my purse's contents ended up falling out while I was trying to make room for her. She didn't even acknowledge it-how rude! Anyway, I definitely wanna bring friends here the next time I go to the city.

Sauterne Mousse
creamy all-natural petaluma poultry chicken liver, truffles and cepes marinated in sherry - $5
Coquilles Saint Jacques 
scallops, shrimp, mussels, mushrooms, bread crumbs, gruyere - $11
Porc au Miel 
pork filet, honey, white balsamic vinegar - $18
Marsanne/Viognier
Vins de Pays D'Oc, Grange de Rouquette, Costieres de Nimes 2005 - $23
Spending time with old roommate, Sarah - P to the RICELESS.
author: Genie J.

description:
Tasty French food, they have a large cocktail and wine menu and daily specials. We started off with an aperitif: Absinthe St. Georges for the monsieur, and a Ricard for myself. We were impressed that there were two types of absinthe to choose from (I guess that's what legalization brings.)

We split a beet salad that was a lovely mix of different tastes, and topped with fine haricots verts. For the entrees: The trout was tasty, covered in slivered almonds, but had a bit too much lemon going on. The Coquilles Saint Jacques was basically a bunch of delicious melt-together seafood with béchamel and cheese served on scallop shells, and although it was a small plate, it was rich enough to be a meal in itself (with some bread.) 

I love how this place is off the beaten-path in a little pedestrian street/alley and you can sit outside to eat while keeping warm under the heat lamps. We preferred to start here since it was unpretentious and affordable and then we headed over to the nearby Belden Place afterward for dessert and people-watching.
author: Shannon R.

description:
I am Yelping this so I can remember this really wonderful place.  I came here with some wonderful friends with no expectations.  It was such a fun experience.
The weather was gorgeous and we got a table outside, where Lucy (the cutest dog in the whole world), could hang out with us.   We shared the heirloom tomato and mozzarella salad, which was as fantastic as our waiter.   We also had to have the pommes frites, which vanished quite quickly.
I was still jet lagged so I had the onion soup, which was amazing and just a few thousand calories!  Oh well, it was well worth it and I look forward to our next visit.
author: Ayelet B.

description:
Food was good (truite and special)
Cocktails were good
Ambience was ok, nothing special
 Music was good (but I couldn't see them live, maybe because our table was in another part of cafe).
I expected much more from this place.
author: Olga S.

description:
I have been here twice and was impressed both times.  The first time I went alone and sat by myself knitting.  The atmosphere was romantic and lovely.  My server was sweet, attentive and after noticing I was having a bad night brought me a complimentary glass of dessert wine, despite the fact that I didn't order a large meal a.k.a. didn't spend a ton of $.
The second time I went a year later and I brought a friend.  The staff remembered me and they were as friendly as ever.  
The food is consistent and delicious with a large menu of traditional French fare to choose from.  
If you like French food you should try Cafe Claude as soon as possible and if you don't like French then don't fret, you will definitely find something to enjoy.
author: Kaylee T.

description:
Beautiful location, great service and deliciously well crafted food.

Cheese plate, wine list selection, flank steak and salmon..mmm.  The fries were sinfully good. We ordered a side of them but were so full from our entrees, we managed somehow to finish it! 

Great place for date night =)
author: Aleli L.

description:
By far the greatest french parisian style restaurant in san francisco. I had the steak tartare for starter and flat iron steak for entree. Both tasted really good. The steak was oh so tender and juicy. The sauce was wonderful as well. However I do have a complaint about the steak tartare as it tasted quite bland comparing to those in Paris. I would prefer the raw egg to be placed on top of the steak instead of being mixed together with the tartare beforehand. This had totally blown the freshness away.

Overall, it's a fantastic experience dining here. The waiter was courteous and attentive hence why we gave him extra tip for his professionalism. 

The location is off street but it really suits its parisian style cafe/restaurant. I'm definitely going back!
author: Amy Y.

description: Cute venue, good coq au vin, great chocolate mousse!  We will be back!
author: Julie H.

description: My man and I go here when we want to lay down some dough for some delish food. Its not that it is super pricey, but we end up ordering so much it adds up quickly. Great service and food, you can't go wrong whether you are going on a casual date, need a late night bistro fix or want a safe a place to feed the parents. Also, don't miss the live music -- it really adds to the ambiance.
author: Claudia P.

description:
Very cute place, indeed. The food is pretty decent as well. We came here on Saturday night, so the place was filled with people. However, we had a reservation, so we didn't have to wait. A bread basket greeted us. Hello, gorgeous  the bread was fantastic and we had several of these. The cocktails were a touch on the weak side.
 
We had a number of different dishes among us. The food for me was just ordinary. The steak was on the tough side and fries were a bit soggy. The mussels were OK. Fois gras was just OK as well.
author: Jessica H.

description:
I could eat at Cafe Claude pratically everyday. It reminds me of the (short) time I spent in Paris eating croque madames and drinking cheap one euro wine with Jackie M in our tiny hotel room. 

I love that its tucked away from busy Union Square in a tiny alley that looks like celebrities take when secretly sneaking into posh clubs. The dripping water on the brick makes the walk up to Cafe Claude special as your stomach rumbles with anticipation. 

I love the onion soup here. Its broth is so light and onion-y and works so well with the bread and piles of gruyere thats melted on top (so much that it creates that string from mouth to bowl action). The steak tartare is savory and light (and who doesnt think the little quail egg is so cute??). And of course you can never go wrong with a croque monsieur or croque madame with the skinny herby savory fries that accompany it.  That and the parisian atmosphere makes you feel like youre off the beaten path near Champs d'Elysee taking a break from a shopping trip...

it makes me want to practice my french, walk in with a beret, airkiss the staff for making amazing french cuisine that is the perfect place for a quick lunch to catch up with girlfriends, dinner with parents in town, or a tres delicious dessert (creme brulee!).
author: Stephanie C.

description:
I took my wife here the day after Valentines. WOW, we were so impressed with the service and food!!
I really didn't expect it, but the hostess and waiter were so helpful and nice it was unreal. Right after we walked within 2 minutes we were asked if we were helped and if we needed a drink while we waited for our table which was ready within 5 minutes. My wife had the pan seared trout which was excellent and I had the apple carmelized pork chops which were incredible !! Definetly get the crab cakes. The ambiance was great with a nice jazz band playing in the corner with soft lightning. I would HIGHLY recomend this place to anyone !!
author: Eric C.

description:
I brought my girlfriend to SF for the weekend and want to have a nice dinner while we were there. She's definitely more of a world traveler then I am and her favorite food is definitely French. I however, don't have very much experience beyond the proverbial french fry! 

She left the dinner choice up to me and so I did a little yelp research and stumbled upon Café Claude. It looked nice from the pictures and the food reviews were mostly very good. 

We made our reservation for 9 and walked to the restaurant from the Marriott Marquis. I loved the fact that the entrance was down what looked like an alley. We arrived about an hour early and sat at the bar. The bartender was very nice and the first impression of the staff was very good. They found us a table within about 15 minutes even though we were fairly early and they were pretty busy. 

I let my girlfriend decide what I should have and she chose the steak. She decide on the special that night which was the lamb shank. She also ordered escargot as an appetizer and told me to trust her. I ordered the French onion soup with the thought that I wouldn't care for the escargot. Both appetizers were fantastic. Who knew I liked snail! When our meals came out they looked fantastic and they tasted just a as good. The steak was cooked perfectly and the sauce on top was delicious. I have to say that I was a little disappointed in the fact that the meal was served with French fries. Kind of took the fancy level down a notch. My girlfriends lamb shanks were amazing!! The lamb fell off he the bone and was extremely flavorful and the vegetables that came with it were equally delicious. We had creme Brule for dessert and just like our dinner it was great. On our walk back to the hotel she told me that her meal at Cafe Claude was one of the best french meals she's ever had. 

Our bill was $175 + tip which included 3 drinks a piece two appetizers dinner and dessert. Well worth it for a fantastic romantic dinner in the city.
author: Rich M.

description:
O.M.G Best meal I've ever had (dining out).

I had the trout- it was topped with almonds and white mushrooms, served with green beans and fingerling potatoes. The sauce was to die for! Lemony without being overpowering. 

Boyfriend had lamb-medium, he loved it. 

Small size meals which was perfect- we had room for dessert. YUM! I had the flour less chocolate cake, Boytoy have the sorbet. 

Both experienced amazing French cuisine without a massive bill, or belly :P Total, with wine, main and dessert including tip was $120. We will be back!!

The only downside is the noise- even when we got there it was relatively empty and it was loud. It soon filled up, the live band started playing and we had to get out of there. Worth it though.
author: Bridey J.

description: The food is average, slow service. I'm not impressed with this place at all. The coffee was good though.
author: Yoko S.

description: I AM A FAN! wow where do I start  about this place and how amazing this place was. I was never a fan of french food till I met Claude. mmm the food is rich, melts in your mouth, and the flavor is out of this world. Besides being in a very random alley way that looked extremley dangerous this place was going off! Keep your eyes open though because it's very hard to spot, ZING!
author: Sara N.

description:
I must admit that I was disappointed. It was much better before.
Maybe I am harsh because I am French.

Anyways, First it's a French restaurant but nobody speaks French anymore. The new management is Italian. It's kinda funny to hear them pronounce French words from their menu the wrong way.

The food was good, not exceptional but good. It wasn't typically French though. Service was good and fast. It's not too expensive compared to huge majority of restaurants that charge a lot for crappy "french" food.

It's a good restaurant but don't go there if you are really into French food or looking for a real French experience.
author: Marc L.

description:
Wow. The service is absolutely top notch. I was trying desperately to reserve a table for 4 on a Saturday night, calling several restaurants and leaving messages. Cafe Claude staff were very helpful. They kindly explained that there was no table available but they could squeeze us in for an hour inside or could seat us outside on a first come first serve basis.  I left a voice mail, and they actually returned my call.  It is now Sunday and I still haven't heard from several other restaurants I had called.  

We were concerned about being seated outside because of the weather, but it was bearable.  The outdoor seating area is heated, although only one side is warm. If it were any colder, it would have been uncomfortable.  Luckily the weather wasn't too bad.  I think they should consider putting heat lamps on the street side of the outdoor seating area.

Food was absolutely amazing. The hardy French onion soup instantly warmed me up. The duck fat pate w/ duck and pork meat was a great starter (if you like pate).  The escargot comes with mini pastry lids. The snail comes already shelled and happily swimming in butter/pesto sauce. It was perfect, not too chewy. The pesto was a nice touch. The flat iron steak and potato gratin were to die for!!!!!! Coquilles St. Jaques was ok, a little bit too fishy for me.  

My husband ordered an old-fashion, which had just the right amount of orange flavor. The dessert for us was, of course, creme brulee.  Oh my god, it was big enough to share. Sweet and creamy with heavenly vanilla flavor. Yum!

I will be back for more, and more, and more . . .
author: Su K.

description:
Tonight went to Cafe Claude for the second time. Same great experience with food, service and ambiance. Three of us ordered pate of 3 kinds platter, lamb chop and pasta of the day. Lamp chop is great great great. Pate selection there is no doubt the best and authentic I've had since came back from Montreal. Pasta was with tuna and mussel - very yummy and on season. 

The only drawback was the indoor seating. The area was partitioned in a bad way so it feels cramped sitting there while my back almost touched the person sat next table. We didn't get to seat outside although the weather tonight was perfect. And the atmosphere of the seating outside is something I want to experience there. Maybe next time
author: Penfan S.

description: Food was awesome !!!! I have eaten at so many french restaurants here and in other countries too, but Cafe Claude ranks right up there. The French Onion soup was really good. Their  seared salmon, truite seared white trout,  coriander and fennel crusted tombo tuna, were absolutely finger licking delicious. Have already gone back and will continue to do so. I'm a fan
author: Madhvi P.

description: Came here for dinner and was very pleased to find Cafe Claude incredibly charming. There was live jazz musicians, low lighting, and intimate parties everywhere. We had reservations and were seated promptly. Our host and waiter were very nice and everything we had was so good! Unfortunately I don't remember what anything was called because i barely looked at the menu, but I know something was braided pork or beef and that was super yummy! The one thing that I did personally order was desert where I had to get the creme brulee! It was so good and possibly even the best part of our meal just cause of my bias to sweets :) Anyways I would definitely come again and if you men are looking for a spot that your lady friends would love, pick Cafe Claude.
author: Jackie M.

description:
Feels like you've left the City and have landed in some cafe in Paris. Lovely small space can at times feel not too intimate, but you'll always feel transported.

The days when the jazz band are there can be magical but loud, but it's still worth going for dinner on those nights. Great place for a date and special occasions. Don't bother with lunch; if you sit too close at the ballet, it breaks the illusion, right?
author: Charlene L.

description:
Walk by a couple of times a year on the way to a usually long-overdue haircut, and always remind myself to give it a try.  Finally stopped in for lunch with a couple of friends on one of those recent epic warm November days.

Butternut soup with truffle & chive was delish...smooth & hearty, just the right amount of gruyere to get a little in each spoonful.  Fair disclosure though:  I'm a sucka for truffle.

Endive & blue cheese salad was just fine, not noteworthy but not a disaster either.  Friend also had the soup but was disappointed with her Nicoise salad.  

Waitstaff all seemed new that day but were still sweet, and the outdoor seating wins a couple points xtra for charm.
author: Cynthia W.

description:
Cafe Claude left a bad taste in my mouth both figuratively and literally. The vegetarian lasagna was completely bland. You could tell they were trying to knock off Foreign Cinema even with the date on the menu
but they had October 10th (it was the 21st). Why bother putting the date on the menu if it's not updated everyday? I just realized
on their dated menu they had A.Q. for their daily special and they had to list their specials to us why have a date on your menu? Late Autumn, 2009 or October 2009, date range or put late Autumn in French
if you are going for a pretentious/elegant deal by putting a date you should update it everyday. The food came out 2 minutes after we ordered it frighteningly fast. I bet if you were to reboot your iphone upon placing the order, your food would beat your iphone. I am all for quick service, but for ~$20 plates, you would expect it to take a bit longer than that. 



They gave me attitude when I asked where the bathroom was the door to the b-room was sort of embedded in the wall to make it unnoticeable.
It felt more like going to the bat-cave than going to the bathroom and I peeved Bruce Wayne's butler, apparently, by asking him where the secret passage is. I understand that you are busy but would you rather me use your restroom or your restaurant?
author: Neal W.

description:
My friend deceived me and told us we were just going to go to a cheap french cafe.  Man, I straight up showed up there wearing ripped up jeans and a thermal haha.  It is casual, but not that casual.  People do dress up a bit for this place, so don't pull a jenny.  

Yeah like people said the waiter's french accent is STRONG! So basically everytime he talked we would just smile at him haha

The pates, lemon trout, and tuna with goat cheese were all yummy.  I thought the food came out way too slow.  Don't come here if you want dinner under 45 mins.  I was okay with it because I was having a blast with the people I came with and their live music.  The girl that was singing that night....wow~
author: Jenny C.

description: Ordered the arctic char which was on a bed of vegetable.  Was incredibly moist and succulent.  Pal had coq au vin which he said was great, and his green beans (such an unpretentious vegetable) was incredible with mint and capers.  Great place.
author: Foodie A.

description:
Decided to go here after reading so many positive reviews. I would say that pricing is a little bit higher than the reviews suggest, but definitely fair. I had my first Absinthe based drink here and it was tasty, though it's definitely a licorice liquor.

I had some pate for an appetizer and their special for the evening, penne with mushrooms and pancetta. The pate was excellent, firm, with a strong liver flavor. The penne was only so-so, The pasta was cooked al dente, the way I like it. The mushrooms were also delicious. It also had broccoli leaves, which provided some bitterness to contrast the flavors. Unfortunately the pancetta didn't cut it. I would have preferred something a little more smokey or salty to combat the broccoli, but it was pretty flat. I'd give the place another try and would bump it up to 5-star with some good experiences. Based on this one visit, it only gets a 4-star.
author: Joseph Y.

description:
A gem of a restaurant hidden on a small alley. The staff were great - around when we wanted them and hands off the rest off the time. 

The food was excellent - definitely French. We had two types of pate, salad, a small plate of mushrooms  with fresh noodles and dessert. I can't wait to go back. All the food was spot on, and the very French wine list was interesting- it covered a wide range of regions and had many affordable by the glass selections.
author: Greg H.

description:
Steak and fries are exactly what I want to eat and they have it.

The price for that itty bitty steak and fries is laughable yet tolerable at $15.    I really love the atmosphere of all the alley eateries in and around the FiDi.  Cafe Claude is right on target here. Could be eating at a sidewalk cafe in any non US country.
author: Ian M.

description:
This is the perfect place to go on a friday night when you feel like roaming around Union Square.  

You never need reservations, and if you are forced to wait 20 minutes to be seated you can sit at the bar and enjoy a fabulous FUSION MARTINI.  I prefer the cucumber but you can also select from a variety, including ginger.  There is usually a jazz band, as well, but I have made the mistake of sitting within spitting distance of the singer.  

I love the pate plate, as well as the FRENCH FRIES because the sauce piquante aux herbes is DA Bomb.  

If you love ahi and youre a fan of bacon, order the  AHI entree.  Careful, though: it is very rich. I also enjoy the Porc au Miel because I am a huge fan of basalmic vinegar. 
Also heats up well.

Out-of-townies and fish fans love the trout, but if you arent into picking bones out of your mouth and have not been brought up working the side-to-side fork swish (meat-extracting technique) then I would pass on le poisson. 

If you still have room enough for dessert (not likely), order the MOUSSE.
author: Hannah A.

description:
Being a quarter French I have a soft spot for French restaurants, cafes and bistros.  But sadly I can't give Cafe Claude more than 3-3.5 stars.

The place is charming and quaint.  But the service is on the same level as Denny's and the food is just average.  The salami and pate appetizer plate is very good, but the escargot and ahi tuna were just average.

Drinks also seemed kind of weak.  I wasn't nearly as faded as I should have been after 2.5 drinks.

Go here if you are in the mood for pate, but otherwise nothing that special.
author: Tinou B.

description:
Get the chartucerie platter! Great for sharing over a glass of wine. That and the bread were perfect for a happy hour.

I've also been there for lunch - good food if a bit on the pricey side (for a casual lunch anyway).

It's a bit hidden but you should be able to find your way there if you know the address.
author: Sherrie D.

description:
Ok first off, i have to say my gin (Hendricks, of course) and tonic was perfect.  I know it is a bit of a cliché for to say that for a French Bistro, but i think it is important to think of your first drink to be an appetizer getting your plate ready for the next course. Anyway, i digress: So, friends kidnapped me from my work for a tasty, all-be-it expensive, lunch.  Since Cafe Claude is right around the corner, i let them lead the way.

We started with drinks, of course, and then had the stake-tar-tar (15).  Now, let's ponder this little tasty dish which can taste like heaven or cause you to call your mom to save you from stomach cramps.  Well, needless to say it had a soft, silky texture and with just a hint of smoke. TIP: when ordering stake-tar-tar, make sure they use a quail's egg and that hey crack it right in front of you as we recived at Café Claude.  Do not get skimped with a chick egg as the taste will not mix properly. We did expect the waiter to mix the stake for us for a bit of a show, but we were sadly disappointed when they just gave us the plate and walked away.  Oh well, so much of constancy.

Moving on, we decided to try the sandwiches which we each tried different ones so we can trade. The Croque Madame (11) was smoke, light and with ample veggies. Pan Roti (10) was soft, moist and tasted of rosemary and the Pan Poulet (10) was a bit dry, but the flavor was succulent to the tongue and left a lovely peppery after taste.

Yes, I know it might be a bit much for sandwiches, but if you think about it, Subway is only 5 bucks cheaper and these sandwiches came with salad.  This said, I would recommend highly their lunch
author: Jai D.

description: My partner and I were looking for a romantic French restaurant. We were seated next to the bathroom, which was annoying due to the constant stream of guests coming in and out. Service was slow and the waiter was indifferent. Generic jazz music played in the bar, echoing throughout the space and making it impossible to have a conversation without shouting. The drinks were mediocre (we each chose a mixed drink from the special drink menu). The food was average, nothing special and expensive. I had a salad and poulet roti, my partner had the onion soup and the pork. The total came to $100. We couldn't help comparing our experience to the wonderful Absinthe restaurant - a truly memorable and delicious French dining experience. We aren't in a rush to return to Cafe Claude.
author: Tanya R.

description:
Friday night, we ordered the following dishes

1. Escargot (buttery flavor, with basil)  Good
2. Pan seared Trout (slight fishy taste, not too strong)  Good
3. Sirloin lamb (medium rare, good flavor, not too strong)  Good.

The food was all really good.  The only complaint I have is the environment.  We were squeezed between two other tables and because of that there was a lack of privacy.
author: Bryan L.

description:
Great wine selection.
Just after a trip to Paris, going here was a nice reminder of Parisian style dining. The only reason I went here was because they had some vegetarian options... pasta, lasanga (Italian, yes but ... all made with a more delicate touch). The pasta was perfectly al dente. The endive salad was nice, but would have liked a little more of those tomatoes/candied walnuts. The pommes frites were perfectly done. Overall a great restaurant. Even the alleyway in which it sits reminded me of Paris! Loved hearing the French accents of waitress/maitre de. Seemed like it is frequented by expats!
I would go back only for a special occasion!
author: Sumitra K.

description: Pretty solid downtown lunch spot, but this place is expensive and the food can be hit or miss.  The service is very good - more polite than most.  There aren't many options for vegetarians.  I had the salmon, and while the lentil/spinach thing on top and to the side of it was not bad, the salmon itself was dry and tasteless.  I did ask for it to be cooked through, but it was OVERcooked.  The fries are good, and the lemonade was nice, but I'll have to think again before going back.  I like this place for business meetings, etc., because it's nicer than most of the Kearny St. options, but for days when ambience doesn't matter, I wouldn't go.
author: Molly P.

description:
Now THIS is how you make people love your restaurant.  

Wonderful service, excellent food, great location (in an alley in Union Square), and a wonderful value.

So it's a weekend night with jazz playing, it's popular and crowded.  Our reservation was for 8:30pm, but unfortunately a couple was sitting there, finished with their dinner and paid but didn't move for awhile.  Cinzia, the manager, was so gracious and apologetic - you got the sense she really cares about her customer, knows how to do business, and works really hard.  every staff member was running around in that restaurant and no one complained about how busy they were (I hate it when servers do that....dude....busy = more tips, remember?)

We ordered a goose liver mousse.....yummmmmmmmmm.....highly recommended.

Then we ordered escargots.  yummmmmmmm.......

Then we shared a plate of flatiron steak medium rare.  yummmmmmm.....ok, we've been to SO MANY places that can't manage to cook medium rare correctly.  This was PERFECT.  the veggies on the side were perfect - enough crunch but not too raw, flavored without killing the flavor of the veggies or steak itself.

Then I got the dessert - creme brule....yummmmm.....but i'm partial to creme brulees.  

our neighboring tables on either side, they were so friendly (doesn't happen too often) - which to me is a sign that people are enjoying themselves.  and Cinzia then came by to make sure we had a good meal and we were satisfied.

THIS is a gem.  Go here.
author: Molly U.

description:
I love me my Cafe Claude and the value of the place can't be beat, although it's tougher to say that about the dinner menu now than it was a few years ago, when this place was a steal.

The beef tartare is a must-order dish, the fries are great, the cheese, charcuterie, and pate are pretty good and none too pricey.  Some dishes are hits (lamb with white beans, salmon salad) while others fizzle (flank steak dripping with a canned-tasting gelatinous beef reduction, nicoise salad, which used to be great when it was made with a whole tuna fillet and not the canned stuff).

The atmosphere is relaxed and super-casual, the wait staff is terrific on most days, and the martinis are superb (you get a whole mini-shaker, enough to fill two glasses).  Me?  I could easily live off Cafe Claude's tartare and bread for the rest of my years.
author: Yan G.

description:
Steak Tartar is amazing.  A new favorite of mine.

Best nicoise salad in SF.  Romain is crip, the veges fresh, and the dressing light, deliciously tangy and flavorful.  Too bad they only serve this at lunch during the week.  If they served it more often I would eat here more often :-)

They have fun martinis too - the fig is delightful.

Bread, butter, and cheeses are yummy too.

Especially love the location - a hidden gem down Claude Lane (between Sutter and Pine, just west of Kearny)  It's very cute to find a quiet and clean alley between such busy streets.  SF needs more of these cute alley restaurants!

My 5 star rating means that I would be very sad to see the restaurant go away.
author: Lev E.

description:
It's a cute place for lunch.  But where this place really shines is for dinner.  I've taken a few people here to share a 5 course meal and it's been great.

Sometimes they have live jazz.  And for a time, I was really addicted to their coffee.

Video Review:
http://www.kyte.tv/channels/view.html?name=Restaurant_Reviews#uri=channels/18416/65179
author: Oren F.

description:
Went for steak frites last night and was disappointed. The service was nice and apologetic but the food took forever (restaurant was empty) and honestly food was covered in a sauce to hide the quality. Have been here before and this time moved me to write.
Come on, if this restaurant was in Chicago or New York, it would be gone.  

Having worked in a French restaurant before, I can tell you that the reputation this place has is much better than it deserves. Hotels send people here and it shows. When I showed up once with someone older, they sent me to the worst table for lunch when in fact we were the first people there. Not cool though that was French. The steak was not. 
Go somewhere else unless stuck.
author: Emily H.

description:
Cute little place in the alleyway.

Great service (our waitress was so fun!) and food was fantastic.

Live music, lots of wine..what could be better?
author: Tom L.

description:
- Ambiance 4 stars
- Food 5 stars
- Staff 3 stars

I love this place, but the service can be spotty.  I once waited 30 minutes for dessert, then another 15 minutes for the check.

No complaints other than the service, it's always consistent otherwise.

The owner's a nice guy, I met him at the sushi place around the corner (next to the Irish Bank).
author: Tim B.

description:
This allegedly French restaurant is in a charming little lane (like Belden Place, but quieter and with more shade).  The service was spotty, with pseudo-French waiters whose best claims to Francaise were their aloof, negligent manners.  We couldn't decide whether their French accents were fake or not.  They sounded odd, and one of them said, "eXpresso,"  instead of "eSpresso," which is not a mistake I'd expect a genuine Frenchman to make.  But they forgot at least one order, and failed to refill our drinks, so maybe they were French.

Croque monsieur was great, and onion soup was good.  But the real stars were (as to be expected with purportedly French fare) the desserts!  Creme brulee had excellent flavor (bourbon vanilla) but the texture was far too mottled to be ideal. The Guittard Chocolate Mousse was awesome, with great flavor and perfect texture.  But the Moelleux au Chocolat was absolutely wonderful.  Best dessert I've had in weeks!  It was like a molten chocolate cake, but in a ramekin, with a batter that was perfectly undercooked to yield a moist, soft, slightly dense texture.  Over it was poured creme anglaise that added even more moistness and flavor.  And unlike most restaurants, their espresso was good, too.

Overall, it was a very good lunch that was excellently priced for what you got, and the desserts were easily the highlights.
author: David B.

description:
The evening started a little oddly, as the absolutely gorgeous hostess (think Russian tennis star) was a little frosty, but things picked up quickly after that.  Salads, lamb, butternut squash soup were all good.   I think the waiter was a little bemused by my ordering the charcuterie platter, but I was in the mood for it.  The wine list has both French and California offerings, and our server helped me negotiate the French ones (I was not going to order a California wine, Tasting at Paris notwithstanding, in this french restaurant).

Also of note, I had an excellent cocktail called a Saint Germain.
author: GL K.

description:
I was really excited to try this restaurant after getting recommendations from friends and reading these reviews.  However, I must say I was pretty disappointed.

The service was substandard and the overall organization of the restaurant faulty.  It felt like we were walking in to a restaurant on it's first day of operation.  We came for Dine About Town and the waiter had no clue it was even going on let alone what was on the menu (He just made it up instead of saying he didn't know and later had to correct himself).  Further, he tossed a flyer on the table and left for 10 minutes without even taking our drink order.  

The dish from the Dine About Town website was not available.  We ended up ordering off of the menu as it was just not a compelling offer.  A friend of mine ordered the Trout and the ingredients differed from what was on the menu.  

Overall:
One star for service.
Three stars for food.
Zero stars for organization.
author: Shawna S.

description: Food was just OK  but the service was great. The tables are so close I felt like I was having dinner with the strangers at the next table.
author: Di T.

description: We really like the environment there and the food was very good too! There was live music the night we went but we couldn't hear much from the room where we were having dinner.
author: Roberto G.

description:
It's cute, it's French; adorable, romantic, all those French European things.  The atmosphere is a bit on the loud side indoor, not exactly the quaint quite romantic dinner but more in the energetic Parisian bistro which I generally prefer.  Outside seating are laid out throughout the alleyway with plenty of heaters to keep the chills away.  (Of course, a bowl of french onion soup should cure any and all chill bugs)

We started the dinner with Coquilles Saint Jacques, which is a seafood mix consist of scallops, shrimp, mussels combined together with Bechamel sauce topped on a scallop shell and sprinkled with bread crumbs.   The flavor balances perfectly with the smooth texture and buttery mouth feel.  The small side of bread with pesto is a wonderful touch.  

For the main course, I went with Paleron Sauce Poivre Vert; which is essentially a flat-iron steak with special peppercorn sauce.  The meat was seared to a perfect medium-rare with no excessive juices.  The sauce was wonderful and pairs really well with the lean flavor of flat-iron steak.  There's also a side of gratin dauphinois stacked to a beautiful little tower finished with cheese browned to perfection.  The poatoes are absolutely delicious and enough portion size to fill you up in case the meat couldn't quite cure the hunger. 

We finished the night with an order of Crème brûlée.  I can't say it's the most spetactular Crème brûlée in the world but the crust was perfect and the custard was smooth and delicious.  It has a very authentic French taste to it.  I think you'll really enjoy it if you're a Crème brûlée fan. 

Overall It's a great spot for a quick night get away, an opportunity to imagine yourself in Paris without the dollar shock of most French restaurants.  2 main courses, appetizer, a wine and dessert came to $78.
author: matt c.

description: creme bulee was awesome, the layer was crispy and the inner part is smooth.! just right sweet
author: Wenbo S.

description: I was surprised to find this little gem in an alley way near Union Square.  Its right by Irish bank, Central and Cafe de la Presse.  If you have to decide between Central, CdlP and Claude I'd go here for an intimate dinner.  Cafe Claude has your standard french bistro foods but what it excels in is the atmosphere.  There's nothing more relaxing than live music, dim lighting and french cuisine.  I highly recommend this place for a date, catch up dinner with an old friend or for when parents are in town.  Its simply delightful.
author: Sarah C.

description:
This would be four-and-a-half stars if it could be, but I deeply adore Cafe Claude and choose to err on the side of generosity in this case.

It is not the cheapest place in the city, but the combination of a solid, bistro-type menu with service that manages to be friendly but not familiar, prompt but not hurried, and helpful but not overbearing can be hard to find.  Plenty of wines on the list in the $30 range, which I appreciate; this is one of the reasons I give the place five stars when I would give Jeanty at Jack's (whose food is actually a hair better than Claude's) four stars.  New info: $15 corkage, which is pretty good for the city--hit Coit Liquors in North Beach, Alameda's Farmstead, or Paul Marcus in Rockridge before coming.

My definition of expensive is relative, not absolute:  If I look at the check and am horrified, then the meal was too expensive.  This has happened with $250 checks at nicer places, and with $10 checks at others.  It has never happened to me at Cafe Claude, so I don't worry about what it costs when I'm there--I just don't go as often as I might like.

Highly recommended: any pates (pat-AYZ) you see lying around, including those served to other diners if they don't eat them quickly; lamb shank; anything that ever swam.
author: David B.

description:
Cafe Claude is very cute. However, after waiting to be seated for over 30 minutes (we had a reservation) with no apology, explanation, or anything, I became annoyed. Once our food did come, it was all good, except pretty overpriced for what we got. The one exception was the salade de chevre, which was very good. There aren't a lot of veggie options so be prepared to order a couple of small plates, which add up fast. I tried the mushroom ravioli and was a little surprised to find it arrive as a thin, round piece of pasta lying on top of some mushrooms in a port sauce. The mushrooms were tasty, but I was at a loss to understand where the other half of my ONE ravioli was! I always thought that ravioli, by nature, had two sides with something stuffed in the middle. Apparantly not here. The atmosphere was nice though - I think I'll only be back for happy hour.

Update 8/29: I have to give one star back after being contacted by the restaurant to apologize for our having to wait. I also received a full explanation of the concept behind the unconventional ravioli. I still don't quite understand that concept (I did live in France for two years and never saw ravioli like this), but still, I applaud them for caring enough about their customer service to respond. And, as I mentioned in my review, the food was good and the place is very cute.
author: SL N.

description: Hands down, my favorite restaurant in San Francisco, and has been for almost a decade. Love the location tucked away in its little alley, love the atmosphere, love the food. Echo others that say it's preferable to Belden.
author: Earl H.

description: This is a nice little place tucked away in a small alley in the FiDi/downtown area. The food was great and the service is excellent. I'd come again since I work right around the block.
author: meL Z.

description:
We came here for a coworker's birthday lunch (group of 8).  It was a very cute, well-priced meal, great work lunch place.  The only issues I had were that I had to make the reservation for 11:30 am (they didn't want our large party to back up the kitchen).  Because of the early reservation, they didn't have a lot of things prepped in time (pasta water was apparently still boiling). 

It was a bit of a hike from One Maritime, but worth it for a nice lunch slightly outside of the usual financial district spots.  I'd like to check out their evening gigs at some point.
author: Jessica W.

description:
The only reason I'm giving this 4 stars is that the service we had was just ok.  The waitress was not on her game the night we were there.  Otherwise, I thought it was great and will definitely go back.

We had the cheese plate to start and she also brought out a bread basket with really great hard rolls.  For entres, we shared the trout and the pork dish and they were both amazing.  Both came with fresh green beans.  Oh, so good!  Presentation was good too.  We were wishing we had room for dessert, but we ate too many hard rolls while we were waiting for our waitress....
author: Kim D.

description:
I have to say that my first experience here was a 5* - everything my wife and I had been looking for in a french restaurant - more cafe like, not over the top fancy, but terrific, well prepared French food.  We had an excellent trio of pate, steak tartar and trout almendine.

2nd visit - probably a 3.5.  Service was a bit aloof and disinterested.  Even though we mentioned it was a birthday, there was no mention of it ever again or candle would have been nice.   The tartar was not what we remembered (could have been the server since he prepared it).  

Overall, a solid 4* and we would come back, but probably not for a while...
author: michael d.

description: As usual, Cafe Claude didn't disappoint. Wonderful afternoon lunch with friends. Salads (frisee) were terrific; fennel soup outstanding; pasta with rabbit delicious!
author: Walter A.

description: have a great bistro style food and  good value wines, while listening to sime JAZZ tune :)
author: Rozita N.

description:
I had wanted to check out Gitane, but alas the wait was almost an hour long. Plus it was raining and my stomach was growling with impatience. So Cafe Claude would have to do.

I had been here for a weekend lunch before, but the atmosphere at night is completely different; it's much more livelier with people hanging out at the bar and a small jazz band in the corner.

We started off with the special of the day: moules frite, fries and mussels in a delicious white sauce. I've had some good mussels in my lifetime and these were fantastic. I would go back just for this dish.

The coq au vin was rich, full of flavor, and completely enveloped the senses. Unfortunately, despite it's interesting description, I found the Coquilles Saint Jacques to be a rather disappointing low, the main reason I can't give Cafe Claude 5 stars. It's a mixture of seafood in a creamy sauce topped with bread crumbs and baked on a shell. The taste was just off. It's hard to pinpoint what exactly I didn't like, but after 2 bites, I remember thinking I didn't want to finish it.

I love French places tucked away in little alleyways and Cafe Claude does it well. Overall a wonderful place for a date or to just take in some jazz.
author: Cristofer P.

description: This place is amazing. I went a couple months ago and had the seared Ahi tuna with the onion and bacon confit and it was one of the top 3 most enoyable meals I've ever had. Taste was off the chart and presentation great. This place also has a little Jazz band that plays in the front and its not too loud that you can still have a conversation over your dinner. I would eat here every day if I had the means. But I def will come back.
author: Adam A.

description: Good ambiance.  Friendly service.  But overall I felt our food was mediocre.  French onion soup didn't seem very fresh.  The coq au vin wasn't very flavorful.  Not bad but just not that good.
author: Mark G.

description: The quiche is great! This is my favorite quiche place now.
author: Kool B.

description:
Went in for an after dinner drink the other night.  The place was not busy and yet the staff behaved as though they were overwhelmed by our presence.  Strange.  We left (went to Gitane which wasn't much better).  I had a drink at Cafe Claude's bar a few months ago and that was an odd experience also.  The bartender gave me a different drink than the one I ordered and when I pointed this out he told me I should drink it anyway since it was 'special' because it contained Metaxa.  Oy.  If you've ever had Metaxa you know it's definitely not for everyone.  

Any one of Belden Place's spots are better than Cafe Claude or Gitane.
author: Carolyn S.

description:
I visited once because of the reputation.

Despite polite hints that we would want another table, we were seated next to two women with babies.

Maybe this place has too much business.
author: Lion K.

description:
This place has an nice ambiance to it, but it is almost like you have to pay extra  for what is a perceived as an overtone of French 'Sophistication' . The service at the bar wasn't very good & he wasn't that busy! Our table waitress was attentive & nice.
Drink prices at Claude are absolutely ridiculous, 3 glasses of house zinfandel $10 a pop & only 1/2 way filled up!! A vodka martini  @ $10 & again it should be brimming at the rim, but only a 2/3 fill.
Sorry you could easily do better, it's a pity because the place has character & ambiance, but a no go for me!
author: Steiner A.

description: A gem!  After spending a magical day in the city, my girlfriend and I capped the day with a wonderful meal at Cafe Claude.  Located in a little alley near Union Square, the restaurant prepares fantastic food and offers lively ambiance.  On the cold SF night we visited, the french onion soup hit the spot.  A bit pricey, but well worth it.  Enjoy!
author: Morgan D.

description:
First time at having french food..Had the escargots..was a bit scared trying this, but they were great! garlic, butter, pesto.. yummy! then had the truffle mousse pate.. I'm not real experieced with pate.. but, was good.. as a main dish, I had the coq au vin..that was super yummy.. the dish was large.. plenty of chicken..soft and juicy.. 

the Con: we were seated outside, which was what we wanted..  the service was good in the beginning with our waiter when the dishes were being passed out to us..then he totally disappeared..never checked back on us.. another waiter came out and was serving all the tables, but us! I kept looking at him for eye contact - nothing..finally I had to call him out and ask for our check.. I really wanted to try their desert, but with the obvious lack of service - I wanted out!

Overall: food was great, but disappointd with the service..
author: Linda Y.

description:
Stopped by on 5/23 for dinner at 7pm, we got the outdoor sitting. The manager remembered us from earlier and was supper friendly and accommodating. 

Ordered steak - phenomenal ($22) and desert apple something ($7) - phenomenal, coffee - mediocre. The stuff is friendly, there was Jazz playing from 7:30, not too laud. 

Highly recommend
author: J D.

description: My girlfriend and I found this restaurant walking around the city. They had one table available for us. It was a great find! The kale salad with a poached egg was amazing!! The goulash was also pretty spectacular!  We loved it so much we went back for a second time (this time making a reservation). We highly recommend this when in San Francisco.
author: David K.

description: Went here for my girlfriends birthday a few weeks ago and had a great time. We were promptly seated and given warm bread with a great dipping sauce. We ordered the escargots en croute and streak tartar as appetizers. They were both amazing and filling. We then ordered dessert and paired it with some dessert wines. We ordered the apple tart and creme brulee, both were very tasty. I would most certainly come back to enjoy the food and live music!
author: Erica J.

description: Bread isn't usually something I care for much at a restaurant, but I couldn't stop eating it at Cafe Claude.  This is an awesome place for a first or second date.  The servers are young, friendly, and decked in black Lacoste polos and French accents.  You'll love the live music, and you can never have enough of their French onion soup and steak tartare.
author: Erika C.

description:
I wouldn't say this is a good place for a first date.  It's a bit Lady & the Trampy to be a first date.  You're in the alley, listening to live soft jazz, the waiters are pretending to be french, you can't pronounce anything on the menu: it all adds up to something you'd see in a first date in a prime time shitcom.
But the food is great.  The atmosphere is great.  And the all around comfort level is perfect.  
I was lead to believe by the review that I read that this place is cheap for such good quality.  Not true.  It costs what it's worth; and that's the least you can expect.
author: Patrick A.

description: My favorite restaurant in San Francisco! Their coq au vine is fantastic. I'm usually not a dessert person, I prefer a first dish instead. Not here. The chocolate desserts are all excellent.
author: Kristine B.

description: The server was polite and friendly, but the timing between the appetizer and the entree was too long, 30 minutes to be exact. I feel he had too many tables to attend to. Then the wrong dessert was served, but the server felt bad so he comped us the dessert. The pork dish my date ordered was too sweet; it tasted like a caramel sauce for a crepe, not an entree. The pasta dish with the jambon de paris was delicious.
author: Kevin C.

description:
The pate was excellent, but the coq au vin was the gummy kind and I prefer runnier versions of the dish. I think I asked for a wine rec and I liked what I drank. 

The atmosphere was nice, but kind of loud, and the service was not that great; our waitress rushed us and then left us with a guy who maybe didn't know she left us with him. Annoying.

All in all, kind of a mixed bag, huh?
author: Zoe P.

description:
Love to go to Cafe Claude for lunch during the work week or even on the weekend. Would recommend the cheese plate, their onion soup and daily specials. Not a fan of their Croque Monsieur unfortunately but the cocktails are yummy. 

Great happy hour from 5-7pm, half off cocktails. A lot of the servers speak French which is a plus for those who are bilingual. Friendly staff and pretty reliable service. Make reservations during lunch hours. Live music in the evenings and you can sit outside most days. Love this place.
author: Heather L.

description:
I had no idea this little gem was just around the corner from my office! I came for lunch with Kelly Y. and Michelle L. a few weeks back and we enjoyed a lovely meal.

The menu is standard French fare - lots of sandwiches and salads with a Parisian twist. Very reasonably priced for a sit-down meal and they managed to get us in and out in about an hour.
author: Lindsey S.

description:
My husband chose this restaurant for my 30th and I honestly couldn't ask for more. It's romantic, the service is fantastic, the live Jazz is a perfect back drop for good food and wine.

I highly recommend this restaurant if you're looking for somewhere special.
author: BetheBrit Z.

description: I loved this place. Two friends and I were bumming around San Fran after being on a  San Jose-Crater Lake-Portland road trip, we were tired and hungry, the yarn store around the corner recommended this place. Imagine trying to find a restaurant for lunch when each person in the party has food issues, one is picky, one is vegan and one is a foodie. We all had a great meal and I had the best sidecar outside of  Gibson's in Chicago. I loved the ambiance, It felt authentic French and not a tv playing sports in sight.
author: Jamie H.

description:
The food was great - one of the most incredible (and very classic) versions of steak tartare I've ever had.  It was prepared table side, by the woman who I think is the owner.  She was very knowledgeable, very pleasant, and I could not have been happier to dig into her creation.  

The waiter was nice, but I felt he was a bit impatient and not all that engaging...and my husband and I, after not seeing each other for a week and thrilled to be having a long-overdue date, were giddy and happy and pretty friendly with him - but it didn't feel like the love was flowing the other way.

Anyway, my hubby had the coq au vin (in an amazing sauce) with fingerling potatoes.  I had the blue fin sea bass over ratatouille - it was just ok.  I only ate about half of it.  We brought a special bottle of wine that we'd been saving, and the corkage was only $15.

They have live performances every night I think.  That night it was a jazz quartet - very cool vibe for sure.  We had a lovely, romantic evening, and got out of there for less than $100.  Very unexpected.  We'll definitely be back.  

Next time I'm ordering steak tartare AND the New York steak.  Love me some beef.
author: Lauren S.

description:
UPDATE: Apparently the drink was supposed to have coconut water (and thus bits of shaved coconut) and not coconut milk.  I have added a star for them having messaged me to clear that up (they did not try to bribe me, which i respect).  They asked me if I had any non-alcoholic drink ideas, so if you have any let them know.

---------
I'm not a real fan of bars in general, and especially not places that only put a number for the price.  You think the savings from leaving out the decimal point and dollar sign would be passed on to you, but it's typically the contrary.

Anyhoo, went here to meet with some people after work.  sat outside, and the ambince is nice for being in an alley.  They had some non-alcoholic cocktails, which is promising, but I got something that was described as having coconut milk, grapefruit juice, and pineapple juice in it.  I thought it would eb creamy and yellowish.  What i got was red, clear, and had chunks of white stuff in it.  It tasted kind bland and chunky.  I thought they were perhaps grapefruit seeds, but upon inspection they were not.  They were just gross.
author: Nessie V.

description: Visit this restaurant every time I visit SF. Had the duck confit today and it was fabulous. Perfect texture and palette of flavors on the dish. The live music beginning at 7:30 on weekends is a nice bonus.
author: Lani L.

description:
I'm a cheap date. Well, if I was a girl I'd be a cheap date. I can usually be pleased with a Costco hotdog & soda for a buck fifty. once in a while, I do enjoy a little wine and dine. Because this was a Yelp staple, and they had live jazz it was on the list of restaurants to check out

It's got that "cute" french outdoor area, though I wasn't too interested in trying out in the middle of the winter. The indoor decor is nice, pretty small place, trendy European. Tables for two. Romantic, I can see alot of hand holding ensuing. Men and women mouthing "I love you" to each other. It's a date restaurant that is probably followed with baby making.

Props to the jazz singer. She was freakin smooth. I don't listen to too much jazz but I was digging this lady. 

Now for the food...Escargot was on point. The seared trout was bursting with flavor, perfectly cooked. We got some pork dish that was decent, but because I don't remember it, it must have been nothing to run home about, or the other dishes must have clearly out shined it.

I'm usually stingy with 5's, but how could i not give cafe claude one.
author: Garrett W.

description: The food, service and overall experience was great! We caught the live jazz on Saturday and it was exquisite! We've tried a few French restaurants in SF and this one is among the top, and the music is a bonus. I strongly recommend reservations, as it is a fairly small restaurant with a wait if you get there during a rush.
author: Fernando V.

description:
Food = Killer
Wine = Mind blowing selection, knowledgeable staff, dangerously tempting
Atmosphere = cozy, sexy, vibrant, quintessentially French
I've been, and I'll be back.
author: Katie V.

description:
*Compliments to the Manager
E-mailed me to apologize for the service we receive.

1 star off for service. Made reservation through Open Table and requested a booth table. When we got there the hostess told us that she could not give us a booth table because we were not regular. The waiter that served was ok, gave enough service, but very distant and rushed us through the enitre meal. When I ordered the creme brulee he said to me, "I see your French is better." Hopefully that was a joke.

The food was quite good. (From 4-7 pm, there is a cocktail Happy Hour, Cocktails are $5) We ordered:
1 Bellini - Reminded me of grapefruit juice.
1 Appetizer - Coquilles Saint Jacques - mixture of chesse, seafood, & bread crumb served in a scallop shell, with a side of salad
Very Good
2 Bavette Sauce Poivre Vert - love the side of potato, but the meat was tough
1 Porc au Miel - The Pork was very tender, but the sauce on the sweet side. 
1Pommes Frites - Yum, Yum, Yum  
1 Epinard - Spinich - Nothing special.
1 Creme Brulee - Yummy
1 Moelleux au Chocolat - So, So.  
The entrees come with some side. You can order extra sides, we highly recommend the pommes frites, the fries and sauce is really good.
120 total for 3 w/ Tax & Tip.
author: Erica B.

description:
I went here on a date. We were able to get a table outside, and the weather was perfect. Cool enough for a breeze here and there, but with the heat lamps, it was warm enough to dine outside without looking like crazies.

Our waiter was informative and helpful without being intrusive. He recommended the Bastille Bellini for me which actually ended up being quite tasty.

I had the Maison salad and the Coquilles Saint Jacques seafood small plate. The salad was okay, but the dressing was a little too bitter from the mustard. The seafood place was a little rich and I could feel is just kind of settling in my stomach.

My date had the pork chop special that night and he seemed to enjoy it. I noticed that there wasn't much that went with the pork chop. My date didn't seem to mind, but I'm always wary of dishes served with a huge chunk of meet and nothing to complement it.

All in all, it was a pleasant enough experience. Nothing really stood out to make me want to go there again any time soon. But there weren't glaring mishaps that made me want to avoid Cafe Claude in the future. It was a so-so dining experience.
author: Judy F.

description:
the food was pretty good. Maybe I should never order something I have had before at Bouchon because my croque madame just didn't feel as good as the one i had at aforementioned restaurant with the most amazing brioche eveeer.

BUT

cafe claude is pretty good. Beet salad rips, ambiance is decent. Waitstaff... maybe cause it was lunchtime but, left something to be desired.

drink some of their "its ok " rose...that cracked up my friend Mie and I today
author: Lauren V.

description:
UPDATED REVIEW (8/15/2007)
After my original review, the manager at Cafe Claude contacted me to offer a gift certificate to return to the restaurant to give them a second chance.  According to her, the server was new & inexperienced.  Now, I'm not one to turn down free meals & I can forgive people who are new to the job, so I thought why not?  Nearly a month later, we went back.

I'm not sure what kind of operating structure Cafe Claude works on, but it was kind of chaotic.  When Dana B. & I came in for lunch at 12:30, there was no one at the hostess stand.  We did see the 2 hostesses run around as runners & bussers before acknowledging us, which was interesting.  After a small wait, we were seated.

The food is still quite yummy & the pommes frites are like crack.  I polished off the entire portion on my own!  We had the same server as before, which filled both Dana B. & my heart with trepidation.  Thankfully, there was no butter spillage this time around.  We did see the waiter knock over a full carafe of water at another table (fortunately, the patrons had already left) & break a water glass at another table while clearing plates (patrons still there).

I did appreciate the GM getting in contact with me though to apologize for our first experience, but this particular server needs serious help in slowing down!

So, if you dine at Cafe Claude for lunch, the food is excellent, but bonne chance with the server!


ORIGINAL REVIEW
3.5 Stars.

A co-worker & I ventured here for lunch to enjoy the the outdoor seating.  Claude Lane is much nicer than Maiden Lane--it's more quaint & there were FAR less flying rats--aka pigeons--so we expected a pleasant lunch.

5 stars for the food.
Portions are much larger than expected, so you definitely get your money's worth.  We started out with the Rillette du Prigord, which was so rich & delectable.  Next, we each got a sandwich (mine was pork tenderloin & hers was the tuna), both of were very good & came with a side salad.  We also split a side of pommes frites.

I docked a 1/2 star for lukewarm water & no ice in our water glasses.  Nothing makes me enjoy a meal more than drinking a carafe of water that has been baking in the sun.

Another star docked for the lackluster service.  It started out fine, but towards the end, it was super slow & shoddy.
