As the servers were clearing away our dishes, they moved so quickly that they splattered melted butter from the butter dish all over my co-worker.  Not the most pleasant ending to a meal.  If Cafe Claude had great customer service, the server would have taken an item off of our final tab, but that didn't happen.  Also, we had to make several requests to get our check.

Oh well, c'est la vie.
author: Jenny M.

description: On a friend's recommendation, I took another friend here today for a birthday lunch. I've been to several of the restaurants in Belden Alley, but never crossed Bush St. to sample Cafe Claude's fare. Wow. We had a wonderful lunch with extremely accomodating, if charmingly less than perfect, service from our French waitress. (Her acccent sounded authentic to me...) Salads were delicious  and quite nice portion sizes - neither too overwhelming nor too skimpy. The lobster and shrimp penne pasta special was so rich and yummy. Each of us had a salad and an entree, and I had a glass of wine, all for a reasonable $50. I can't wait to take someone else here for their birthday.
author: Michael M.

description:
Why so many freaking French restaurants in Union Square? Oh well...this one is good.

I was getting scared that I picked a tourist trap when we started punting tourists out of our path while we walked by the china town gate, but because Claude "street" is a little back alley, this restaurant is camouflaged enough to leave it beyond the sight of the camera haulers. You can sit outside on a heated patio which is walled on 2 sides, thus making it kind of private. We ending up sitting inside - perfect ambiance there. Modern, but not sterile. The right music volume, and the right kind of down tempo. 

A very innovative cocktail list for sure. A lot of stuff on there are French takes on classic american drinks. Its impressive the number of things that they were able to pull off that were oh so French, but didn't delve into fusion.

Presentation of our beef tartar appetizer was impressive...they make it for you at your table. The taste matched the presentation - who ever thought a pile of raw meat could be so great? I had the lamb confit, and my friend had the trout. No complaints about either. The carmel/coconut dessert thingy we got (sorry...this was after 3 cocktails...my memory started going fuzzy) was good - perhaps a tad sweet, but it is dessert people.

This place was truly batting 1.000 for me, and came very close to earning a rare 5 star rating, but our waitress was a little strange. She wasn't mean or rude at all, and I totally dug the fro + kylie minogue giant red hoop earrings, but here were some issues: 1) She had a hard time recommending a drink to my friend (but after 5 minutes of deliberation, she did pick a good one) and 2) After I finished my cocktail, she grabbed my glass and took off with no mention of another - I had to grab the bus boy to request a second. So like I said, weird.

You could have any kind of dinner here - formal, casual, interview, mom, pre-gaming for bar hopping, etc. would all fit. You just better like French food - they don't do fusion stuff. I'll be back because of its versatility...its a nice little gem in a neighborhood where I typically need to find a diamond in the rough.
author: Sean C.

description:
Oui Oui!  This place is the epitome of charm.  The darling French waiters who came out to flirt with us and pay loads of attention to Lucy (anyone who is nice to my dog wins brownie points with me).  We shared some Pommes Frites (c'est magnifique!), and an heirloom tomato salad with pinenuts which was a unique and nice addition.  I had the pork sandwich on homemade foccacia with arugula salad.  The flavors in the arugula salad were a nice blend between bitter, sweet & sour.  I am not normally an arugula fan, but YUM!  The pork sandwich hit the spot and Lucy loved the litle bites I gave her as well.

The bar area looks nice indoors.  We sat on the patio for lunch, I could see this being a very romantic place to come on a cold foggy SF night too.
author: Sheila D.

description: I wanted to give this place 4.5 stars, but I rounded down to 4 stars. If you come you should come before 9pm, they have a small trio band that plays just to the left of the bar. There's outdoor seating with heated lamps and plenty of space. The food is outstanding and the wine list is diverse as well. Started off the the cheese plate, that was excellent and the fruit pairing really complemented the cheese. For dinner I ordered a salmon dish with bacon and fingerling potatoes, I don't see it on the online menu anymore but it was great, hopefully it's still there. Anyways the restaurant is awesome, great for a small group or more than adequate date night spot as well. Not too far from Press Club or any of the dive bars in and around Union Square. It's hidden but worth trying.
author: mehul p.

description:
Croque Madam, perfect
Roast chicken, heart felt
price easy, great lunch
author: yutai l.

description: A tight squeeze at the bar while we waited for our table, but the friendly bartender made some seriously kick ass cocktails (he created both of the ones we tried -- one with basil and the other with st. germain elder flower). The escargot was delicious and the filet mignon was perfectly cooked and more flavorful that expected for that cut. We also had the seafood with bechamel sauce appetizer which was yummy but didn't hit it out of the park as the entree and escargot did. Waitress was friendly and professional. Reasonably priced for the high quality of food. The accompanying jazz was good stuff and not so loud that it overpowered conversation. Overall a lovely and delicious experience.
author: Susie Q.

description: It's a favorite stand by of mine. The food is good, prices reasonable and a good place to take visitors. It can be loud and crowded. Nice place to sit outside in the nicer weather.
author: DeAnna D.

description: great cadence, music and very delicate graceful top notch food.  definitely recommend for anyone looking for some  nice but not overly expensive fine dinning and entertainment. particularly for couples.
author: Brendan B.

description:
I have two favorite times of the year to go to Cafe Claude, usually on a warm fall night sitting outside sipping wine and having either one of their wonderful salads--their perfect with just right amount of dressing and seasonings. Or the pate plate-- a little decadent but worth it. 

I also love to stop by after a hard day of Christmas shopping when it's really cold out for the the amazing onion soup. it's a small place so it's cozy and most importantly it's walking distance from union square.  The wait staff has over the years has become less surly, but still very french. The  chicken dish is savory and absolutely amazing, it's like a a party is happening on your tongue with all the subtle favors going on.   The pork dish is also dam good.   I have never had a bad meal there.
author: Princess P.

description:
Definitely recommend this place.

Try a cocktail(s) and/or have dinner. 

This place is great if you want to impress someone with how well you know the city. This should be described as one of the hidden gems. I might bump this place up to five stars after I go back.
author: Joe Z.

description:
The food here is fantastic, no question about it.  As long as you don't mind cigarette smoke in your face during your meal, or the fact that the proprietors will gladly and willingly alienate every diner in the restaurant in order to satisfy their chain-smoking "regulars" sitting outside who they like to "make happy", you'll love it here!

All the dishes were fantastic, but it's hard to enjoy your meal while you are inhaling French cigarettes wafting up from the tables outside.  Be advised: if you go there, sit as far away from the windows as you can, or command them to close them as soon as you sit down.

Oh yeah, don't make the mistake of asking a waiter if you can buy the sleek salt and pepper grinders.  You can't.
author: Aaron W.

description: Went for the first time tonight. What a great experience. My wife and I were in a rush to make a show, and the got fantastic food to us promptly with polite, helpful service. I love pork, and most places overcook it. Not Cafe Claude - I got the pork loin with carmelized onions and honey creme sauce - it's in the 2-3 top pork entrees I've ever had in my life. If I go back a few more times and have a comparable experience each time, I might just bump this rating to 5.
author: Carter S.

description:
I went here last night after going to a gallery and I was glad to have found this place on yelp. They're open later than usual (or maybe I'm used to east bay places closing early) so we were able to eat a good meal at 9:30pm. 

The service was a bit slow considering the amount of guests left at the restaurant, but the servers were very friendly, attentive, and helpful. The ambiance was also great. It's really cozy and and the decor has some nice upscale-but-not-snobby touches. 

We started with a french onion soup and the (peppery) pork pate. My sis-in-law got the mushroom ravioli and I got the lamb sirloin. The soup and ravioli were soooo yummy. The pate and lamb were good too, but a little too salty to my taste. 

The food came out slow and on any other day, it would have been perfect, but with my sis needing to study for a final and me having to get up early for work the next day, we felt kind of rushed to eat the main course by the time it came out. Also, it was already past closing by the time the main food came out and although the servers never rushed us, I felt like we had to wrap up quickly. 

It's definitely a place I'd go back to... when I have a bit more time to enjoy the meal and have a glass of wine. :) AND dessert! I missed out this time! :(
author: Seri T.

description:
It was a decently cool evening in SF and with available space on the sidewalk, we decided to sit outside.  There was a heatlamp overhead that provided just enough warmth for a nice dinner.  There was seating inside but there was a live band and we opted for fresh air and conversation instead.

We started with a pate dish, we opted to try 3 from their list of 4.  We had the champagne, truffle and rilette.  The rilette isn't your typical pate.  It's more like ground up meat, pressed together.  It wasn't liver so the texure was different.  The champagne and truffle was nice and creamy but honestly, you could have gotten the same from a grocery strore or deli.  Still, it was a good dish.

We opted to have the large sized steak tartare as an entree and also went with the evening's special...NY steak(8 oz) with foie gras and truffle demi glaze(Yum!).  The steak tartare was highly anticipated as this is the only restaurant I know that serves it. Meat was very good(flank steak), mixied with quail egg, worstershire, mustart and other ingredients.  I was actually disappointed in the dish as the most prominent flavor was mustard.  The dish resembles tuna tartare except with steak.  

The NY steak was cooked perfectly to our liking and the demi glaze had a hint of foie gras, but couldn't taste the truffle.  The special was $28.  Came with an arugula salad and pomme frites(aka fries).  All 3 items were good. This dish by far was the best of the three we tried, even the pomme frites were good.
author: Will I A m.

description:
One of four French locales we went to during our unplanned weekend of French eating. In all honesty, I was aiming for Gitane but it was closed for lunch...on a Saturday...near Union Square. This ended up to be a good little find.

Ambiance (4): Loved the little cafe atmosphere and the decor of the place. Clean, semi-modern cafeish, and comfortable with outside seating to boot. It was a little bit chilly that day and the place is in an alley so passed on the outside seating but it was nice to have. According to their website the furniture was recovered from a Parisan cafe so I guess that's that.

Food (4): Good food that hit the spot. The menu was composed of salads, sandwiches, pates, charcuterie options, and some main courses. The main courses didn't pique my interest but the other French cafeish selections were what we were looking for for lunch. Squash soup special (good to go), endive salad (that doubled as lettuce wraps...tasty!), chicken liver pate (I came, I saw, I gobbled it up), and the porc sandwich (a French version of the Cuban sandwich...memories like the corners of my mind). All the food had a nice clean and lively taste. Not too heavy and presented in that French way, if you will, were it seems modest and subtle and not overbearing and excessive (I am looking at you Cheesecake Factory). Great spot for lunch and the little bar looked liked a great place to post up after work. Also, if you are in the mood for some liver action and don't want to hit up fancy French inspired place, you can easily get your fix here.    

Service (4): Attentive and friendly server with good recommendations. We felt welcomed and there was nothing lacking overall. 

Value (3): All prices were reasonable and again, great spot for lunch. Not sure if the menu changes for dinner. 

Overall: This was a great spot to stumble upon. Stop in for a great lunch with great service.
author: Alvaro H.

description: Came here for a Saturday lunch.  They serve warm freshly baked french bread that was quite delicious.  I ordered a trout that was extremely well flavored and perfectly cooked.  My friend ordered the salad, but made a special request to add in slices of ahi tuna which she saw from another dish.  The request was graciously fulfilled without a hitch. I left completely delighted with my dining experience here.
author: Jerry W.

description:
Amazing food, great service. I am a vegetarian and they had a number of vegetarian options.

I can't wait to go back.
author: Sekhar C.

description:
I fell in love with Cafe Claude years ago when I went to meet a particularly capricious friend there, I was looking for her and the sleazy waiter mused that "we are all looking for something in this life".

It never fails, years later the boys working there still ride motorcycles and talk like Pepe LaPeu.  It's bistro fare. not stellar - but the ladies aren't flocking here for the food.
author: Teresa L.

description: Cozy place, good wine selection. Food was good, too.
author: Willa M.

description: This is a lovely restaurant, but the food is horrible. I ordered the french onion soup and my boyfriend ordered the lamb. How long does it really take to prepare this???? We sat there for what seemed like forever waiting for our food. The waiter never checked on us, offered more bread or refilled our water glass. When the food finally arrived we were so disappointed. My boyfriends lamb was cooked very well done instead of medium well like he requested. My french onion soup was not really soup. It was a big hunk of bread with tons of cheese. There were hardly any onions at all. We both left the majority of our food on the plate. Will not go back!
author: Nikki T.

description:
Food was great, service was good. Beef tartar wasn't all the rage but if you never had it before, it might as well be this place. Price was reasonable, $6 deserts, main courses are $21-$25. Lobster bisque was wonderful, makes me want to have another serving. Goose liver was good, wife didn't like it, she also didn't like the beef tartar. Started with Lobster bisque, beef tartar, goose liver. Then the lamb and flank steak, cook perfectly. Desert was coconut creme and chocolate mousse. 

I recommend this place. Want to try it for lunch.
author: Phillip K.

description: The food was amazing, the wine doubly amazing. The service was somewhat slow, but that's the only thing keeping this from being 5 stars. Would go again.
author: Mikah M.

description:
I've been craving for the shrimp salad for a week now. this place convinced me to give french food another chance. 
the house wine was bad and that's what took away one star. A french restaurant just can't go wrong with house wine. I mean i don't expect my people to go wrong with rice either!!
ANd it's definitely not a regular place consider the bill came out to more than a hundred for two people!!! 
the entres average $20 a piece...watch out if you are not one of those (us) who are willing to sacrifice your spending money for the entire weekend on one kick-ass meal. 
The service is exceptional too considered it's FRENCH!!! They apparently all speak French and the waitresses are hot on the plastic side!!
In regard to the misconception that it's over run with tourist, i seriosly think they are local expats who work across the street at the french embassy.  I mean speaking all sorts of european languages doesn't make the place touristy right???!!Imagine Chinatown!^_~
author: Xiu L.

description: Discovered this place because of Dine about Town. It sounded perfect, cute little french restaurant off a little alley way from Bush and Kearney, live jazz and excellent food. The place was cute, we sat outside under the heat lamps and could still hear the jazz from inside. There was only one option for the 3 course fixed price Dine about Town menu. Anchovi salad, lamb shanks and apple caramel tart. The two of us ordered that, the soup du jour which was corn chowder and the special of the day which was a pasta dish with meat sauce. The Dine about the Town menu was the way to go. I was very disappointed with the pasta. It tasted like hamburger helper. Everything else was pretty good. Pretty good service except when we had finished paying the check and the waitress comes back 10 minutes later saying she forgot to add the port to the bill. She gave us a new bill for $9....was she kidding?
author: Debbie C.

description:
Cafe Claude was the perfect setting for an after-work catch-up session with a former colleague.  The wine and spirit menu is extensive and the menu provides an exquisite sampling of authentic french food.

We shared the cheese plate to get things started followed by the coq au vin where the wine sauce was well worth the experience and price.  we topped it all off with the coconut tarte.  

our waiter had this heavy thick french accent and was very attentive and cute.  Claude Lane has become one of my favorite alley ways in SF.  With the hip posh Gitane across the way, Claude Lane easily has become the niche for fine french dining in San Francisco.
author: lasok o.

description:
Great service, nice intimate atmosphere with music.

Food is only mediocre though, for what you pay i'd expect a bit more in the way of taste. I felt like everything was very salty, but had no spice, no flavor, it was just salty.

Presentation of the food was good, menu was good, execution horrible.
author: Steven C.

description: We'll, we returned to Cafe Claude for the food and ambiance,  but even more importantly for the music.  The Nova Jazz group was incredible! The combination of great jazz, fine food and wine is difficult to match.
author: Jack H.

description:
A true hidden gem in the Union Square area!  Just the way I like it; a quaint little French restaurant down a tiny alley-like, more than street, Claude Lane that serves up some outrageous dishes.  Had the pleasure of dining at this establishment on a first date and it made an already wonderful date, fantastic!  Decor is very traditional French.  Servers are non-traditionally attentive; which was great because we had one hour before a show and when informed, our server made sure our orders were prepared and presented in a timely manner.  My date had the Betterave salade (a wonderful compliment of flavors and contrast of red beets, peas, and feta), followed by the special of the day Plat (believe it was the fillet ragou), paired with their Garnet Pinot Noir...needless to say, she loved it!  I had this incredible Rillette du Perigord cooked in a confit style, which tasted heavenly!  I followed with this absolutely bomb of flavors form the Porc au Miel which i shared with my date,  whom just loved, loved, loved! Also paired with the same wine, and finished with the best prepared sidecar cocktail...again, my date tried and just fell in love!  Noise level was reasonable, and privacy was adequate for an intimate dinner.
Price was reasonable, service was great and attentive, and despite my date feeling rushed because of the following show, and the quality and presentation was worthy of a solid 4 stars!!!  It is a place i'd recommend and would look forward to coming back.
author: Thomas T.

description: Fantastic!  Amazing, authentic French restaurant!  I've been here a couple of times and had the pork, coq au vin, and salmon.  All extremely delicious!  4 Stars for food (the sauce with the pork, while great, was a touch too sweet and the salmon, in my opinion, was just a hair under-cooked, however nothing bad enough to ruin anything) and 1 extra star for ambiance.  Live jazz on Saturday night that wasn't too loud or obtrusive; gave a great atmosphere.  I really love this place!  It's tucked away on a side street, Claude Ln (escape street noise) so it gives the place a cozy feel and with the comforting food, great wine list, and lovely ambiance to boot, you can't go wrong!
author: Dustin T.

description: I went here a few months ago and I still think about that incredible dinner. The service was friendly, the food was delectable, they have a great wine selection and the location made me feel like I was in Paris for the evening. I cannot wait to return.
author: Mariana C.

description:
A friend recommended Cafe Claude when I was down and out and could not find a place to eat lunch.  I was pleasantly surprised.  It's an interesting little cafe in an alley off Bush Street.  You are greeted by hosts that speak in French.  The cafe is very cozy.

As far as food is concerned, the onion soup is a little too cheesy for me, but otherwise good.  I enjoyed their salmon entree and pommes frites.  Dessert was fabulous!  I love their creme brulee and chocolate mousse.  

I'll be back!
author: Annalynn C.

description:
Back when I was in biz dev/sales and I was making tons of money, this was my absolute favorite place to go for lunch. I was obsessed with the steak tar tare. Marcel, the former GM, used to come to the table, pour a little olive oil and whisk it into the quail egg on top of the hunk of meat, creating a little mayo/aoli emulsion before mixing it with the onions, capers, mustard, etc.

They've gone through several different chefs. I hate to be the type of regular that chefs hate, because I like the dependable nature of going to Cafe Claude and knowing what is good: the steak tar tare, french onion soup, charcutarie plate. There used to be an heirloom tomato salad; I completely fell in love, then when the chef changed, the salad disappeared, breaking my heart. 

The service can be inconsistent. Sometimes I feel ignored, other times it's friendly, on point and professional. Recently the service has been very good. I came in at 6:58 pm one night with a girlfriend and Ladies Happy Hour 2 for 1 drinks were just about to end. Not only did they let us order the drink specials, they spaced the drinks out so we didn't have 4 cocktails on our table.
author: Leslie Ann R.

description:
Charming place, with just-right portions and a splendid spread of flavours (no house specialization on salt, or onion, or garlic, or what-have-you).

Tune tartar was delightful, the cheese plate was well selected (and authentic for French cuisine and yummy nonetheless), and the service was, well, French without being Parisian.  Dining outside under the awnings and heaters was surprisingly comfortable on  misty, brisk evening.

House cocktails were nice recipes, though could be stronger.
author: Hans G.

description:
Uhm LOVE IT! I was put in charge of finding a place for dinner near Union Square for Friday night and hit Yelp, where I saw Cafe Claude have great reviews. Four of us met up around 7 for dinner on a Friday night. It was a beautiful evening so we sat outside- the outside is in an alley which sounds weird but is really cool. The food rocked too. I got the special pasta of the night- tons of seafood and mushrooms for $17, and we ordered a bottle of wine that was great too. The plate looked small to me when it came, but clearly my eyes are bigger than my stomach because I left extremely satisfied.
Bonus point- one the finalists of season one of Top Chef was eating there. I don't know her name, but my friends sat there spazzing out, so that's gotta be a good sign.
author: Emilia S.

description:
French food is rich, fatty and decadent.

I'm not rich, nor that fat, and I wouldn't call myself decadent.

But all the foods I greedily ordered for myself at Cafe Claude made me feel all these things.

For the quality of food, the prices were extreeemely reasonable. I ordered the french onion soup, beef tartare, a glass of cab AND sauterne mousse. Yeah, I did it...and what?! 

"Ya'll beezies know I don't share!" was what I told my girlfriends, but I truly, madly, deeply wanted them to know the joys of my choices so I let them have their share....and so they'd share their escargot and Coquilles Saint Jacques.  "Ya'll beezies know I don't share!! .....unless I get some of yours...Please?"  Everything was delectable and they all warrant another visit to this cute, jazzy restaurant.

So Cafe Claude, kudos to you for being the first restaurant to make me feel rich, fat and decadent all at once-- and showing my friends how things really are when it comes to me and sharing.
author: Chelle Y.

description: Pleasant Paris flashbacks.  Terrific coq au vin, saturated and dissolving under the fork, and as fine a vouvray as I've ever had (Silex, Domaine d'Orfeuilles, 2008 - grapefruity, appley, with a high twinkling minerality), and great company, on a stunningly gorgeous night, with a flawless rendition of Frim Fram Sauce floating out the window over you....  come now.
author: Georgiana M.

description:
We had a quick bistro lunch secret rendevouz on a brisk afternoon. Cafe Claude had a cozy atmosphere, good salads, and some nice shoppers from the Peninsula to look at (Atherton?) The French guy who served us looked young.

We'd go back if we're in the neighborhood again.
author: Chiquita y.

description:
Unfortunately, I wasn't there for the jazz nights, but it was still a fantastic experience. First off, I am in love with their wine list - all very affordable and containing a lot of small appellations from France that I rarely see in the U.S. (the fact that they had two different Saumur-Champigny on the wine list convinced me that I have to go back again and soon!). They have a lot of the wines by the glass, even some by the carafe, and the by the bottle list is about $50 and under a bottle. 

The food was extremely authentic (I don't know that I've run into such solid French food in San Francisco yet - everything was amazing and so reasonably priced!) and paired with the decor, I could almost imagine that I had teleported to France for dinner. First off, the charcuterie selection was pretty extensive and the two we ordered, the duck rillettes and the truffle mousse, were very good quality and not too fatty or soggy. The coq au vin I ordered was slow cooked and tender; I was really excited about it until I tried a bite of my friends' dishes: the sauce for the porc au miel tasted like caramel and the lamb dish not only had great flavor, but the meat was a great cut with little to no fat. All simple, relatively traditional dishes with well-executed sauces that really made the dishes. In short, this placed wooed me and I cannot wait to go back and try the rest of the menu!

A funny little anomaly: the only non-French thing about the place - the staff all seem to be Italian! They are extremely charming and warm, and took great care of us.
author: Kara A.

description:
Goodbye San Francisco, hello New Orleans!

Ok, finding Cafe Claude was a serious mental challenge (it's tucked away in this "hella" obscure alley) but thank goodness we did.

Everything was good here.  The food (I had trout) was phenomenal and the drinks were delish.  I did find it just a bit odd that all the servers were Italian...but hey you're Europe, I'm europe, it's all a go!

Cousin had veggie lasagna (italian!), and I had the fish and Heather had the coq au vin (finally something French).  No matter, I'll be back here for dinner again.
author: Misi P.

description:
this is my friend from belgium/married to a frenchman's favorite french restaurant in sf.  good to know it has backers seeking authenticity!

i've been here a few times.  our waiter was super hot.  besides that, the food is delicious! 

i always always order pomme frites here b/c the aioli has rosemary which is fragrant and makes you want more and more.  

escargo is yummy, small plate of the fat pasta (omg im sorry i dont know my pasta names) with mushroom is delicious too.  i cant remember the rest of what i've had there.  these 3 dishes are what i'd come back for.  

and the extensive wine list tops it all off =)

i also love the dark, romantic, candle-lit, cozy (it's smallll), intimate atmosphere too.
author: Alias A.

description: One star for poor service provided by the overly self-righteous hostess. She should really get over herself. We made reservations on open table for 6:45PM. We were 15 minutes late and so arrived at 7:00PM. She told us (in a way to punish the customer?), "I just sat down a couple at your table because you were 15 minutes late. That is the standard." Wow. EXCUSE ME. I said calmly, "Did you say you gave away our table?" She said quite proudly, "Yes I did. You didn't call. That's how it is here in the city." EXCUSE ME. I live here in SAN FRANCISCO. I have been to plenty of restaurants from 5 stars to 1 star. There are plenty of restaurants in SF that will hold the customer's table for 15 minutes without calling ahead. WHAT IS SHE TALKING ABOUT? She is smoking some wacky tobaccy. We took our money and patronage to Gitane who sat us immediately without reservations. As usual, Gitane was wonderful.
author: Seymour S.

description:
My lunch here the other day was a treat.  Loved the glass of wine I ordered (a delicious Givry), and had one of the most delicious Croque Madame's.  it was perfect.  The egg on top of the sandwich was perfectly prepared, and when the yoke broke, it made such delicious bites with the ham and cheese sandwich under it.

The fries were also nice--thin, perfectly crisp.

My only criticism of today's lunch was ill-timing.  Apparently the server was waiting for my friend to finish her piping hot french onion soup before serving our entrees (in fact, he made mention he would wait until she was finished before even bringing them out).  It made for a much longer lunch than anticipated, especially because she had ordered soup and salad, and would have been content to eat both at the same time.  As it was so hot, she must have slowly sipped the soup for about 30 minutes before we realized he was waiting, upon which he fired our entrees.

Ah well.  The food was delicious, and he was actually very friendly and efficient otherwise.

I'll be back!
author: Lori G.

description:
I would've been a bigger fan of the secluded alleyway entrance, except my date couldn't find the place and got lost on the way here. On the other hand, they have an excellent bar at which to wait, and the food is... well, the other reviews have it covered. Absolutely delicious. The seared ahi tuna alone is worth a visit, as is the soupe d'oignon. 

Our waiter was knowledgeable and very friendly. We didn't get to sit outside, so I'm definitely trying that next time around.
author: Ed M.

description: So I didn't realize until I walked in that I had actually been here before but this was my first time actually eating here. I was pleased that they had one of my favorite cocktails on their cocktail list, the Sazerac, which was pretty good although I prefer it over ice in a tumbler instead of a martini glass. On to the food, we started off with the Ahi Tuna tartar which was ridiculously good, the raw quail egg and cheese were a nice touch. I had the Coq au Vin for my entree which was fall off the bone tender. Our waiter Joshua was great and quite a character, and character goes a long way in my book. If you're looking to eat at a great french restaurant but don't want to shell out the big bucks to eat at a place like a Fleur de Lys you should definitely put Cafe Claude at the top of your list.
author: Boby M.

description:
Still the best French Onion soup I've eaten in San Francisco. The place is beyond cozy and offers an excellent vibe for lunch or dinner. Live music some nights only enhances the experience. However...

Lately the place is definitely busier, and the service hasn't really stepped up to match. I walked in for lunch the other day and was rather brusquely told that I'd better go elsewhere for lunch since the then-empty restaurant was completely booked for the afternoon. Is this their way of seem more, well, French?
author: Aaron L.

description:
Location on Claude Lane is da bomb - close to work, close to Union Square, but off the mass hordes of hawking that happens on rival Belden Place (which has it's share of all right places, too).  

The croque monsieur is very good, and the steak tartare very good (love the quail egg).  But the service was atrocious.  We were a party of three with a relatively uncomplicated order, but parties of 2, 3, and 4 around us who all arrived after us and ordered after us received their main courses before we received our soup.  Anomaly?  I hope so.

The ambiance is lovely, the menu selection all very tempting, but our 90-minute leisurely lunch (which we'd planned the extra time for) became a hurry to finish.  

Authentic French atmosphere and cuisine.  I'd like to come back and give the service another chance - and also to hear some live music.  

Well, and because Cafe Claude is just fun to say (I mean, say it with me:  "Cafe Claude")!  Claude makes you picture some sweet old man in a fedora who mutters things in French and makes you giggle even though you have no idea what he's saying.
author: Evan G.

description:
Lovely place with a nice selection of traditional french dishes. I will have to admit there are not a lot of choices as a veg and even less, if any, for a vegan.

I settled on the artisan cheese plate with a selection of three cheese (brie, blue, and double cream cheddar...I think). To accompany the cheeses there were candied apricots, fresh blueberries, and a few walnuts. The bread is alright but could be better considering it is a French restaurant. I also ordered a side of sauteed spinach which was great.

The onion soup looked tasty. Other menu options include plenty of fish like ahi, salmon and trout and of course there are plenty of meat intensive entrees.

Enjoyable place, friendly staff, nightly specials, and good food!
author: Theresa T.

description:
On a day such as this (glorious), who wouldn't want to be in one of the most beautfiul cities in the world. Better yet, in a fabulous city eating outdoors in a petit cafe with an ice cold drink and tasty food? The quiche was flaky  and  fluffy where it's supposed to be and the salad very refreshing.

I am enamoured!
author: Vanessa J.

description: Great food and atmosphere. We shared the Chevre salad, the Cheese plate, the Coquilles Saint Jacques and Tart Tatine for dessert.  Everything was great - as a big cheese fan I can definitely vouch they offer some high quality selections but the tatine left us disappointed, so -1 pt for the uninspiring finish.
author: Aida T.

description: Great lunch. My girlfriend and I went there for our anniversary for the first time,and we loved the vibe. Great chicken and steak, fresh bread and an amazing bowl of french onion soup. Would highly recommend it.
author: Bradley R.

description:
Went here for Sunday dinner with a couple of friends. Food was good, drinks were good and dessert was rich. The bill was fairly big but when you consider that it's a French restaurant it makes more sense.

I love the cozy feel and the intimate environment but I didn't quite like the dark setting and the small tables. I understand ambiance but it kinda felt like I was eating during a blackout.

I would definitely go here again though, between cute waiters and great cocktails this place is a keeper.
author: Vicky C.

description:
3.5 Stars actually...I went here last week to meet a friend for dinner and like Ashley G. I also found it on opentable.com. My friend was coming from the East Bay and doesn't get to come out too often in the City, so I thought I'd pick a "quaint" place for us to have dinner and catch up(I've never been here myself). The location is very convenient for anyone who doesn't want to drive to the City, both of us took BART, it's about 1/2 a mile from the Montgomery Station.

I like the ambiance of the place and our waiter was nice and attentive. We started out with the beet salad and we both had the MahiMahi Special. Salad was good but our main entree was just okay. Maybe I should've gone with the steak or trout on the menu. However, I still like this place and plan on coming back and trying the regular stuff on their menu. I will update my rating after I come back a second time.

Oh, yeah, this is not the place to bring someone for a break-up meal or to have any conversation that you want kept private or confidential. I couldn't get up from the table without my booty being in another diner's face...bwaaahaaaaahaaaa!
author: Barbra C.

description:
Cafe Claude was absolutley the best way I could have thought of to ring in the early daylight savings time this year! Thanks Bush for negating all my problems I have with your spendthrift habits.  At least I got an extra hour of sunlight to enjoy Cafe Claude.

While typically I would say this cute little tucked away place would be a romantic date spot, I was perfectly happy going with a friend and sharing all the appetizers.  The potatos were good, and the couquilles (sp?) which turned out to be a seafood mousse, were fabulous.  We even liked the escargot, but they were super-rich and heavy on the salt - so beware.

The service was a little weird, but nothing harmful.  Oh, Try the elderberry liquor spritzer...amazing!
author: Dana M.

description:
Went here for an hour long working lunch to suss out dates, work on ideas and calendar. 

Food was fantastic, waitress was straight to the point friendly but quite efficient with out being pushy

Great suggestion, and I would go here again- very cute indoor seating, and a beautiful patio.
author: Danielle V.

description:
Charming, quaint french restaurant tucked away into a private little alley admist the hustle and bustle of downtown sf.  The food here is delicious~  I enjoyed a steak, endive salad, and a glass of the cafe claude merlot-  I was impressed to see that they make some of their own wine  ;)  My group also enjoyed their entrees- one of my friends especially enjoyed her steak tartar (though I still cannot appreciate raw meat served on a plate)  =)    I attribute that to my lack of sophistication...

I must comment on the service here. The hostess was very kind and made sure we were seated in a warm area at their outdoor seating.  Our waitress Mary was so sweet and kind, always asking how we were doing.  Despite having 8 people in our party, our food came out warm and quickly in succession.

Great place, will return, there is also live jazz here in the evening time..  
bon appetit!
author: Vickie Y.

description:
Solid casual lunch place with not too big a crowd and solid food. Wish they had some more creative sandwiches with more interesting ingredients, but if the menu suffers from being a bit basic, it's strengthened by a strong delivery.

If this place had local, sustainably-grown meat, I would be a huge fan. As it is, I will probably come here for lunch once every three months (or less).
author: Christian B.

description:
YUM! Sexy, fun ambience, and delicious food.

I had a special pasta dish - shell pasta with delicious oil & tomato sauce, mixed with prawns and lamb. Cooked to perfection.

Good drinks and dessert menu, too. Can't go wrong!
author: Latte Queen W.

description:
Went to Cafe Claude for the 2nd time for Mommy's bday. Dont have much to say more than what have already been said so I will just review my dishes.
Appetizers--
1) Steak Tartar - Thought that rare steak would be out of my comfort zone, but this was the standout of the night. AMAZING. Minced rare steak prepared with a quail egg, tabasco, oil (olive), and other flavors, mixed table side.

2) Escargot - Delicious-with very prominent butter, parsley, garlic flavor and a puff pastry to top it.

3) French onion soup - Delicious- A must-get. Cheesy goodness topped soup that is flavored just right. In other places, this soup tend to get "too salty".

Entrees--

4) Filet Mignon - Again, Delicious- Thick filet grilled to perfection with foie gras black truffle sauce", and fried balls of mash potatoes. In whole, very tasty, but not standout like the appetizers.

5) Porc au Miel - Pork chops - Seasoned slightly sweet (from the caramelized apples and honey cream sauce) very good, but no where compare to NOPA.

6) Pasta of the day - Cannot recall what, but sword fish & tomatoes sauce - The cousin ordered this. Just from the sound of it, does not sound too tasty. I tried a bight from the cousin's dish.. I would pass on this.

Coq Au Vin - Ordered this because of the numerous yelp references. However, I thought this was good, but not outstanding....slightly too salty. 

Dessert
7) Mousse au Chocolat - Not too rich, but decadent chocolate flavored goodness. I can eat 100 of these if I dont care at all about my weight.

8) Crème Coconut - I had this here once before and I was thinking about it every night for 2 weeks. This is soooo delicious. Smooth coconut creme flan that was just the right consistency. The bitter coffee/caramelized sugar on top gives it the right touch. The first time I had this, there was little bits of dried blueberries that just capped everything off.  The second time i ordered this, no dried blue berries!!! Frankly, I gave this review a 4 stars instead of 5 because of this.

9) Creme brulee - Good--but Mom said mine was better. Nuff said.
author: Alexandra V.

description: I really don't know why everyone thinks this place is so good. We had an extremely mediocre meal here a few weeks ago; so mediocre I don't even remember what I ate. Even my brother and sister-in-law, who took us there because they'd been before, were apologetic about the food. And the waitress was snotty (guess she thought that was "French").
author: jennifer w.

description:
Food, although fairly priced, was below average, unworthy of the multitude of French cafe one can find in San Francisco.

A notable attraction is the live jazz. However, the musicians/singers are tucked in a corner where hardly any sound comes out to the point that, at a table 30 feet away, I had a hard time even hearing them (and I am a few decades away from turning hard of hearing).

Last, the service was unimpressive. I couldn't get our plates and silverware changed between our selection of pate and the Tuna tartar we ordered. Ever tried to mix tuna and pate? Not recommended to the discriminate palate. A waitress came by occasionally, filling only half of the wine glasses on the tables. Either do it or don't, just don't do it half way.

Definitely not worth the $200 I paid for 3.
author: C B.

description:
Made a reservation for dinner on Thursday and was glad I did (thanks to Mitchell I for the suggestion!). Service was great and there was a live band playing nice Amelie-type music (sorry, I am clearly not well versed in French music so that's the only association I can make).  

We had the Coquilles Saint Jacques for an appetizer (seafood baked with cheese) which was fantastic. I also liked my Sex in St. Tropez - not much of an alcoholic drink, but very tasty. The fish in marinara (which was a special) was well cooked, but the mussells were a bit too musselly for my liking. Dessert was amazing. We had the creme brulee (I am a sucker for anything with vanilla bean in it!), warm chocolate cake and upside down apple tart - apparently the 3 house favourites. They were all so good we couldn't decide which we liked best!

Definitely worth all the hype and the $50 dollar bill.
author: Bingying L.

description:
I felt like I had traveled to Paris for the evening - the atmosphere, the jazz music, especially the lead singer, Shelley Mackay was outstanding and her trio.  The food delicious, and the wine diving.

A memorable 5 star evening.

Darby
author: Darby A.

description:
Cafe Claude is one of those fabulous standbys that I keep coming back to time and time again for a fabulous, yet casual meal to impress guests of all ages. The atmosphere is dark and sexy and very French and the waitstaff fits the atmosphere -- they are aloof, yet professional and perfect! And that's just the decor...

The food is great --- it's very authentically French --- and everything that I'd had, from the French onion soup thick with beefy oniony gruyere-y flavors, tto the Coquille St. Jacques that are scallopy broiled goodness, to the almond trout to the flat iron steak with my absolutely most favorite version of potatoes dauphinoise. Those potatoes are cheesy, creamy, tender beautifully rich crusty fabulousness. 

All of this to go with wine -- and live jazz! -- in a perfect little alley in the FiDi, of all places. What more could one ask for?
author: Jennifer C.

description:
My bf and I came here after work for dinner and decided to sit outside and enjoy the warm weather.  FYI - you can only order drinks and cheese plates before 5:30pm.  We ordered ourselves some drinks and patiently waited until we could order from the dinner menu.  

We ordered:
*chicken liver with truffle oil pate - I ordered this b/c most reviews mentioned the pate.  My bf has never had pate and probably never will again after nearly hurling after first taste.  The pate was good, but it's definitely an acquired taste.  I like pate in small amounts, but anything more than that, the rich liver taste is too strong.  This appetizer would be good to share with a few people b/c they are very generous with their portions
*small steak tartare - delicious with a nice bite provided by the dijon mustard and diced cornichons.  Even with the small order, I think it was too much raw red meat for just two people.  I just can't stomach so much raw red meat and didn't feel too well afterwards.
*chevre salad - refreshing and so good!  one of the best goatcheese salads I've had.  The salad had crunchy and sweet slivers of green apple, candied nuts and a perfectly tart and light dressing.
*coq au vin - so savory, hearty, and flavorful!  I loved swiping my bread in the abundant pool of sauce surrounding the chicken.  i just wish the bacon was more crispy.  this dish was the highlight of our meal!

Overall, I think the food is great and service is friendly.  I'm just going to steer clear of the pate and keep my intake of raw red meat to a minimum next time.  I can't wait to try the croque monsieur on the lunch menu though.  I've heard great things, and I'm sure it'll change my mind about Cafe Claude.
author: Jen Y.

description:
On a rainy afternoon, there is no better spot for lunch than Cafe Claude.  It is the cosiest little restaurant tucked away in an alley that is perfect for a mid-afternoon rendezvous with friends or your significant other.  

I just love coming here for lunch which feels like such a treat from the normal lunch fare.  

Try the tuna bagnat and nicoise salad!
author: A T.

description: We booked a table way in advance at a certain hour and also confirmed it 24h before. But got stuck in a game traffic and were 17 min late.  We even called in and informed abt it. When we got there our table was not given to us, although it was still available! She told that it will wait for the next cutomers! then we asked how long do you actually give a table for one booking? She said 30 min, max 45 min!!!  Are you crazy!! In which restaurant one orders, eats and leaves within 30 min! Are you choking peoples or what!...Plus it is such a crowded place, tables were arranged very close.  No privacy! Why go to this place while you can find better and cheaper options, where they actually appreaciate your visit, rather than turning you down at the door after you planned your evening accordingly!!!!
author: C D.

description:
Had a great dinner on Sunday evening.  The Tatar was incredible as was the Pork Tenderloin.   The place is tucked away of an alley, but well worth the search.   

Our waiter was a bit aloof, not sure, but it seemed he was trying to live up the the French character.  

Would definately go back!!
author: Raymond A.

description:
I have been coming to Cafe Claude since I was a kid and everytime I go I leave completely satisfied. 

I was running late for my reservation (due to cocktails at Michael Mina) and I called and they saved a wonderful table for me. Service was fantastic.

French Onion soup: Amazing

Endive Salad: Amazing

Roasted chicken with bacon: Amazing

Steak: perfectly cooked

There was Jazz on Friday night and the staff didnt seem to mind that we were the last ones there. Over all 5 stars. I, obviously, will be back.
author: Michael M.

description:
OVERRATED!!! Service was very sub-par, plates overpriced. The ONLY plus was the Coquilles Saint Jacques...delicious!
Filet was horrible, tough, and about 4 oz., and $28!!! Companion had the monkfish, typically  tender, a buttery taste...not her's. Her "salad" was just that, a salad. Would expect something a little more special from an "acclaimed" French restaurant. 
Going to go back across the street to Cafe Bastille in Belden Alley... The BEST cuisine outside of France!
author: David C.

description: not very good - horrible steak frites, not great ahi tuna burger at supposed to be great price, uninspiring salmon sandwich - and everything is over salted.
author: Wakako U.

description:
I've got to say that this restaurant is becoming one of my favorite places to dine. I had dinner here twice, both on a weekday. I've yet to come back here on the weekend to check out the live jazz. 

I really enjoy their Steak Tartar. I also had the Truite aux Amandes and it was divine. My bfriend ordered the Pasta du Jour, which was penne pasta with scallops and creamy sauce, and he really enjoyed it. For desert we had the mouth watering Moelleux au Chocolat. They even give you extra cream on the side to pour over the warm, melted chocolate center.

When I dined here to celebrate my bday with my bfriend, the staff was very welcoming. They new of my bday in advance and had kept complimenting me on the occasion throughout the night. 

I chose to go here over the other restaurants because of the affordable French cuisine and the cozy ambiance. I like how it is hidden in the alley and only those in the know will come here. I didn't want to go to a place where it would be over populated.
author: Eriko W.

description:
Group of my BFF's (4 of us total) made reservations on a Monday night, last minute, for 8:30.....thinking it was cheap 'cause we read the lunch menu (our bad).  Still, after seeing the dinner menu, we thought it was not that expensive.  

VERY CUTE OUTSIDE tables, very paris bistro,...but maybe they could buy some heat lamps?  This probably rocks in the daytime for lunch.  We ate inside.  At a VERY small table...warning no one over 165 pounds should attempt their chairs and tables...ask for the booth.

We had, shared amongst 4 of us:

Tomato Soup (very good special of the day)
French Onion Soup (very good, if small portioned)
Shrimp Brochette (shrimp was good...dish was strange...WARNING:  this is really a salad)
Traditional Escargots (how can this be bad, so it was ok)
-Entree-  Penne with 3 pigs (special pasta, pretty good if you like bacon 3 ways)
-Entree- Lamb with Rosemary  (standard)
-Entree- Coq au Vin (...um....OVERSALT...would not order again)

Another warning:  DO NOT order the house 'cafe claude' white chardonnay.  The waiter let us taste it to see....and it was not drinkable.  We got a different bottle at 44 bucks, which was just ok.

Service was ok....we were checked upon, although our very busy waiter with a party of 12 RIGHT NEXT TO US tried to be attentive, and he was good, it was obvious there was too much to do.  Luckily the manager ?"Lela"? assisted and saved the day.

All in all, after tip, 200 bucks was too much money.  Even if we had not ordered wine it would have been 150, and that was too much.  

I am thinking of a small french hat in the outer richmond on clement...........
author: David S.

description:
One of my favorite restos for lunch or dinner. They just do everything well: the 

I have tried just about everything on the menu and the menu does change often. The steaks are always tender, the sandwiches fresh, the frites thin and just the way I like them. The specials are usually a special treat. Try the tomato soup when it's available. 

Save room for dessert: the tarte tatin or the fondant chocolat will put you in a good mood. I just wish they would bring back the passionfruit dessert.
author: Akasha A.

description:
I love love love their flour-less chocolate cake.  It's warm, moist, with just the right amount of sweetness.  I would come just for that.  I would recommend against their hot chocolate you (in case you are thinking about it) - it's just milk with a little chocolate powder. 

Their coq au vin is also excellent -  very very tender - a party in my mouth. 

It's also 2 blocks away from home, also a plus.
author: Amy L.

description:
My friend has been raving about Cafe Claude for months now so I've been wanting to try it for awhile.  We finally made plans to eat here on Saturday night for my belated birthday dinner and it was well worth the wait.

Cafe Claude looks like it belongs a few blocks away on Belden Place, with the rest of the French bistro litter.  However, this cafe has staked claims on its own alley, and rightfully so.  The food, service, and live jazz were amazing!  It's not easy to find all three in good quality under one roof.  We had the Truffle Mousse pate, a cheese plate, Tuna Tartare, and some of the best pork loins ever (served with caramelized apples in this divine sauce).  I also had this yummy drink called Le Petite Ecolier - pineapple juice, cranberry juice, grenadine, and Sprite.  It was perfect.   

The prices are very reasonable too - about $10-12 for small plates and $18-24 for main entrees.  It was also nice that they didn't rush us out of the restaurant even though there were people waiting to be seated.  This is a lovely little restaurant - I am definitely looking forward to going back.
author: Kalista W.

description:
Oooh la la! We came here for dinner after a day of sightseeing in SF and it was a perfect place to end the day. It can be a little hard to find especially for out of towners like ourselves but definitely worth the search. 

The restaurant is very cozy and seating can be a little tight but I thought it added to the ambiance. Our waitress had the cutest accent and was very attentive. For starters, we had the escargot and rillettes du perigold. This was my first time trying escargot and it was excellent. The escargot is covered with butter and garlic and I couldn't stop dipping my bread into the sauce. The RDP was good too but the escargot is definitely worth trying. 

For the main course I had the Coq au vin and BF got the lamb sirloin. The Coq au vin was good but not great. This was my first time trying this dish and I found the sauce a little strong. The lamb sirloin was good but I thought the emergo beans as the side the highlight of that dish. We ended the evening with the Creme coconut (house flan). It wasn't too heavy and had just a hint of coconut.   

Food=4 stars
Service= 5 stars

Overall, I give this place 4.5 stars.
author: t s.

description:
This is an "experience" theme restaurant, so don't expect an ultra high end, quiet "Cicada" type experience.  Instead, enjoy the furniture brought in from France, the bistro-type food and and affordable but tasty wines.

Why do they try to stuff the live band into that tiny little stage?  I hope they take a "claustrophobia" test before they agree to perform there!  You should dine here just to see this...

This place is so bustling with energy and happiness.  I kid you not, everyone seems to be having such a good time here.  And it's not like I've only been there once, so I can testify to that.

It's a pretty small place, so just be aware of that.  And the parking, as with much of SF, is horrible.  Horrible parking.  And since it's in an alley, you have to navigate carefully to get here.  If you see a beautiful Asian woman dressed in all black (who looks like she could be anywhere between 20-35 years of age), she's the owner.  It's so trippy hearing an Asian woman in San Francisco speaking with a French accent.  Now that's diversity.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
***Save yourself from getting lost: this is located at Kearney and Grant@ Bush; and don't mind the scary alley it gets better!***

So Misi P. and I had a fun time finding this place as google told us that Claude Lane didn't exist!!

Take the time and look for it--this was a wonderful find. After a long, uncomfortable flight it was nice to be entertained by a jazz band and wonderful servers. 

I had the coq au vin. It was a little sweet but the chicken was cooked to perfection. Misi's cousin had the lasagna which looked amazing and if I get a chance to come back I'll definitely have that. 

My dessert was the Molleux au Chocolat, which after 5 years of French, I butchered when ordering it....ORGASMIC!! The food-gasm lives on in San Francisco!
author: Heather B.

description: I was recently in SF just visiting and yelp pointed me to this great place, it was literally in an alley!  I got the steak and a salmon dish, were pretty good.  Hopefully I'll get to go again and write a more detailed review next time.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Wow...what a great find.  French hostess was extremely helpful since I was eating by myself and wasn't sure whether or not I would eat inside or out.  Outside is the way to go...off the main street, so no homeless or views of undesirables walking by bugging you.  Would have given it 5 stars, but my pasta/chicken special of the day could have really used a lot more seasoning.  I know I can add my own salt, but the sauce or the dish as a whole should have definitely had more.

The special cream of asparagus soup was perfect.

Tres Bien!!
author: Mark C.

description:
Food Program: 4 stars
Beverage Program 5 stars
Service: 5 stars (biased)
Decor: 4.5 stars

This is one of my favorite spots, I've probably been here 20+ times. The GM, Cinzia, is a perky, sweet Milanese woman who tells entertaining stories with an adorable Italian accent to boot. Their sommelier is Sean, who also does the list for Gitane right next door. 

I haven't had a bad experience here yet. This is biased though, as they know me and know that I send a lot of my hotel guests here since it's great and just around the corner. 

The menu is classic French bistro food, which would I would choose for my last meal if it ever came down to that.  

Best items on the menu are:  the onion soup, which is perfectly and delicately flavored, not the saltwater that most places try to pass off as French onion soup. The paté is house made and deliciously rich. I'm a huge fan of the escargot en croute and the steak tartare, which has a roughly chopped texture to it which I love. They prepare the tartare tableside as well. 

The coq au vin is a rooster braised in wine for hours so it falls off the bone, wonderfully tender and rich. The lamb is quite good as well. Everything reasonably priced, in my opinion.

Now for the beverage side. 

The list is is almost entirely French with about eight California selections. Most of the wines on this list are under $100, and all very reasonably priced. I love bev programs like this because the wines are super good value. Ask for Alex if you need help navigating the list, he is extremely knowledgeably and good-natured. 

If you're looking for a wine white and can deal with some residual sugar, try Francois Chidaine's "Les Tuffeaux", a semi-sweet chenin blanc from Montlouis in the Loire valley. The wine is a steal, with a huge amount of complexity. Very traditional producer making single-vineyard chenin blanc. 

Cafe Claude also has a nice cocktail list, in a similar vein to Gitane but with all different items. They also have a selection of absinthes and pastis which is icing on the cake for me. 

Did I mention live jazz on weekends?
author: Michael H.

description: We went here on Thursday Jan. 3rd. I loved this place as my boyfriend & I first walked up, adorable in the quaint little alley nestled between a couple other restaurants owned by the same people. We sat outside and it was chilly but we were close to the heater and we were bundled up so it was fine. we got a couple drinks and ordered the steak tartar, it was brought out with all the accompaniments, mustard, pickles, capers & such where our server mixed it for us table side, it was delicious! We also ordered a 3 cheese plate. In the midst of things another couple arrived to the patio, which has 3 long 'community' tables. One table was full of one party, our table and the third table only had one couple each, leaving 6 more seats per table. We were really having a nice quiet romantic time and out of 12 seats available they chose to sit right next to us, practically on top of us. We were going to have dinner here, but it just got awkward and intrusive, very inconsiderate. Our server, Yamona, was trying her very best to be accommodating, she could see we were uncomfortable. She offered to give us a little single two-top table where two ladies were finishing up with coffee, so we ordered another drink and decided to wait while we finished our cheese plate. Unfortunately the ladies were taking quite some time, meanwhile the couple next to us seemed to get more and more irritating. So we decided to just head out and get a bite somewhere else. Our server felt so bad, she asked if we'd like to move to a table inside, we declined and so before bringing us our check she brought us a complimentary bread pudding. She was a great server and really expressed a genuine concern. It's nice to have real kind service. We will be back to stay for dinner next time! Thanks Yamona & Cafe Claude
author: K W.

description:
Recently made my second trip to Cafe Claude for dinner, and was seriously disappointed.  Had a reservation on a Wednesday night. It wasn't too busy but waited quite a while for the staff to notice me and check me in.  Ordered wine (bar staff were friendly and helpful, allowing me to taste a few wines before deciding on a bottle).  Had one of the pates to start, and it was pretty good. But half way through it, the waitress brought out the main course (we had both ordered the coq au vin)!  I said that we would like to finish our first course, before starting on the second course, so she took the food away. Is this 'normal' to be served the main course whilst still enjoying the appetizer??  Unfortunately, when we had finished the pate it seemed the waitress didn't want to serve us (perhaps she was embarrassed by her mistake?) and so it took a while for the plates to be cleared and the main course brought out.  And that's when Cafe Claude really went down in my opinion....  the two plates of coq au vin that had been brought out 25 minutes earlier had been sat under a heating lamp, and were now brought back to our table!!!  The plates were dangerously hot and an unpleasant 'skin' had formed on top of the food.  Surely a restaurant such as Cafe Claude could manage to serve up 2 fresh plates?!  The food was just fine, though certainly nothing to write home about.
For dessert, we had the creme brulee, which would have been very nice, had it not been warm on the outside and cold in the middle.
All in all, I really believe Cafe Claude can do better.  But for the $$$, I'm not sure I'll try/risk it again.
author: Izzy A.

description: Found this cute little restaurant on a side street in the city. Great ambiance. Live jazz and warm wait staff. The steak tartar was amazing and the coq au vin was wonderful as well. The only reason I did not give them a 5 star was their by the glass wine list and the escargots . My husband and I tried 3 of the reds and did not like any of them. With France having such an amazing selection of wines from small growers that are reasonable price, I was surprised to find such a disappointing selection. I stuck with the champagne which was nice. The escargots had a breaded topping which I didn't like and the flavor was not the traditional butter and garlic. To finish off our meal we had the creme brûlée which was delicious and perfectly made. All and all I would recommend this restaurant but probably by a bottle if you want a decent red wine.
author: Kenda H.

description:
I love this place for both lunch and dinner! If I ever take someone on an interview and I get to chose where we go, I pick this place. Classy, cozy, sophisticated ambiance and cuisine. I love their croque monsieur and pomme frites.

For the dinner service I like their steak tartare and roasted chicken. But by far, their dessert is what I keep coming back for! They have this hot, rich, decadent soft chocolate cake served with a little jug of creme anglaise that you can pour on top of the cake... mmmmm I am drooling just thinking about it!!!!

The prices are reasonable for what you are getting. I would recommend this place for a group dinner or intimate lunch, but I think dinner service might be too crowded for a date-type setting.
author: ting b.

description: Cafe Claude is reliable and quaint. We've eaten here multiple times and always enjoyed it.  The French Onion Soup is fantastic!  And, of course, who can resist the pommes frites?
author: JoAnn W.

description:
Wow, who would have known...As others have said that this a hidden gem. Its at the end of a an alleyway in the heart of the city. The place too has heart. The setting is intimate. Tables close by so you can hear others conversations but not intruding. The staff was very friendly and very knowledgeable about the menu. The food, the food is why we will go back.
We started with a glass of wine and a non alcoholic juice drink. We both wanted to try numerous items on the menu so our appetizers were the onion soup, its a French place so you know its gonna be good and it was. We also had the Chicken liver pate, which took me back to my youth. It tasted just like my Grandma used to make.
Our entree's were the trout and the filet mignon. Both were on point, the sauces were what made them stand out. The beef had a truffle foir gras sauce that was rich and tasty and the trout had a light butter sauce that brought out the flavor fo the fish. I also had to try the augratin potatoes, yummmm lots of butter and cheese never goes wrong.
We ended with the carmelized apple tart, not bad but have had better. 
Overall the value was impressive..less than 100 bucks before tax.
author: Cassandra C.

description: A little overrated for the price.  Not that it's not good but it was decent.  However, the experience and price didn't justify a higher rating.  It's so unmemorable, we can't even remember our meal a month later.
author: R S.

description:
The only problem is this place is too small.  And hell, I will never want to sit at the table next to the door to the bathrooms.

Their best dish by far is the steak tartare.  Every time I come here I will always order that.  The tuna however wasn't that great, but otherwise this is always a great place to take a date to.
author: John D.

description: Came here for Valentines Day and staff was very accommodating.  They were able to accommodate my special request and the service was exceptional.  The live jazz band was great as was the food.  They had a prefixed menu; I had the duck, which was very tender. Great date spot.
author: Roscoe M.

description:
took ma girl here for our 5 year, Food was excellent!!!!

reading the other reviews I thought it would have been a better ambiance. Romantic, not so much, music was just background music, it did not feel like a performance to either of us. Service was a little sketchy.

Good for a get together with friends not so much a place for an anniversary.
author: John E.

description: One of my favorites but best to eat outside -- weather permitting -- or inside after the rush.  We actually had to leave the other day as we were seated inside and the noise level was intolerable and we could not hear each other to have a conversation.  The food is just wonderful and the service excellent.  I particularly like the Nicoise Salad but have never had a dish I did not enjoy.
author: Vicki B.

description:
This is the first place I've eaten in San Francisco outside of Chinatown (I'm a DC native). My super-organized and super-on-top-of-everything friend got me, herself, and another friend a reservation shortly after I landed at SFO. I was a bit out of it when I arrived. 

ATMOSPHERE: I don't know - I was just recovering from a 6 hour nyquil-induced nap that knocked me out for the duration of my flight in. All I remember is the bathrooms are hidden behind these black sliding doors. Cool stuff. The rest is a haze.

SERVICE: The waiter misunderstood our designated orderer when she said "We'll have the escargot as an appetizer and the pasta of the day for all of us." Okay, that was kind of her fault for phrasing it like that (she meant we would EACH like to order the pasta of the day), but c'mon, one plate of pasta can't feed a table of grown people! The waiter was just like "hokay" and brought us one dish of pasta and six french snails. At first we thought it was peculiar that only one of us had pasta, but we figured since its a french establishment, maybe they were playing up the whole chivalry thing and serving the girl (wayyyy) before the men at the table. We realized this was not the case after we slurped down our snails, and by combining our powers of deductive reasoning, collectively came to the conclusion that our order had in fact been misinterpreted (understandably so). When we brought it to our waiter's attention, he began to defend himself, but stopped himself, apologized, and went to the kitchen to remedy the situation. He made our two additional dishes of pasta du jour top priorities in the kitchen and we were inhaling our orders minutes later.

FOOD: Awesome. I'm a big fan of pasta, sun-dried tomatoes in my food, and protein. This pasta had all of that jazz (protein in the form of lots and lots of ham).
author: Jack T.

description: Wine selection is great. Service is as personal as time permits; it's good. The food is really good and the space and clientele makes a comfortable, pleasant ambiance.
author: Harlan L.

description:
Usually crowded around weekday lunch hours. If you sit inside, your hair and clothes might soak up this greasy smoke smell. If you sit outside, there are a lot of alley gnats flying around. 

Can get kinda noisy there. On a deliciousness scale, the food ranges from tasty to so-so.
author: Trixie J.

description:
I love this place.  I used to work near there and the food is ALWAYS perfect, lunch or dinner.  And ther drinks are amazing.  The service is spotty.  The big giant bald guy is really rude and so is the non-French bartender. 

 The french onion soup is great, the sandwiches are great at lunch and the chicken is always tender and juicy.  The atmosphere is awesome if you can get over the pee-laden alleys of SF. There is also an element of having to "work for your food" but I assure you it's worse in France.  It's good for a leisurely lunch or just for a quick and wonderful coffee to go.  I think it's better than the Belden Lane Frenchie joints.

They have tasty drinks at Happy Hour for $4.  Everything is great--drinks, appetizers, entrees, desserts.  Try their truffled pate.  Yum.
author: Sarah B.

description:
This place is fantastic.  Everything I had was delicious, the service was great, and the ambiance can't be beat.  It's the kind of place you step into and it immeidately becomes the perfect time of evening for an intimate meal, then you go back outside and realize it's 2 pm!

I can't wait to go for dinner sometime as all I've had is lunch, but I can say their soups, salads, and sandwiches are great.  I particularly enjoy the beet salad, seafood salad, and the french onion soup.  love it.
author: Lita F.

description:
Cafe Claude saved me from an evening of disappointment! We walked over to Cafe Bastille, only to find it closed on Sundays - but hurrah to Claude, which is open seven days a week!

There were more flies than people outside when we sat down, but it filled up respectably and dinner was wonderful. I'm not sure whether they actually needed to change out flatware after each course, but I guess it's nice (though not exactly environmentally sound) to dine somewhere where the staff cares enough to give you four forks over the course of an hour or so.

+happy hour cocktails are $4, blood orange martini gets my vote
+the forestier pate was flavorful and rich
+escargots are delicious (as most anything slowly congealing in garlicky pesto is, but still...)
+endive salad's flavors are a bright combination
-too full for dessert
author: Jessica H.

description:
I luuuv the low key vibe here
walking through an alley to meet up with my cousin for her birthday dinner was definitely different but i have her to thank for int reducing me to fine dinning and french cuisine.

I really enjoyed their Steak Tartar and also the Truite aux Amandes which was a trout with some kind of brown butter sauce with almond slices and it was divine. My other cuzn ordered the Pasta du Jour, which was penne pasta with scallops and creamy sauce, and he really enjoyed it. 
For desert we had the mouth watering Moelleux au Chocolat. They even give you extra cream on the side to pour over the warm, melted chocolate center. 

I really hope i come here with a date someday especially on one of their live music nights
author: Isabella T.

description:
What a surprise!  I am normally not into chichi cafes, or French food at all for that matter, but Cafe Claude was fantastic!
We had a fantastic corner window table, and the service was IMPECCABLE!  The waiter even poured my ketchup for me!  I had the special of the day which was artichoke hearts stuffed with goat cheese and wrapped in proscuitto.... OMG YUM!  It was served with an arugula salad that was ok.  I ordered a side of fries and those were awesome too!
Overall an A+
I will definitely go back for another leisurely lunch.
author: Alexis J.

description:
It's been 2 years since I went here, but I do remember enjoying it thoroughly.

I just remember having some type of sandwich and the couple next to me trying steak tartar for the first time, and not knowing what to do :)
author: Jonathan B.

description:
As you turn the corner onto the alley that houses Cafe Claude, you may find a voice in the back of your head telling you that this alley couldn't house a quality French restaurant. Ignore the voice.

Cafe Claude is a charming place, from the shaded outdoor seating to the tables packed in their small space. The hostess, who sounded French, was extremely gracious and found us a table at lunch on a Friday without a reservation. 

And the food, oh the food. To be honest, the bread basket that starts the meal contains sub-par French bread. But the small dish of beautifully fresh and creamy butter that accompanies the bread more than makes up for it. The menu isn't large, but there's something for pretty much everyone on it. I ordered a croque monsieur, which came with frites and a small salad of arugula . You're definitely doing yourself a disservice if you don't get it. I haven't had a croque monsieur this good since Paris, and the bechamel was perfectly seasoned. One word of caution, however. If you do get the croque, you'll most likely have to defend your frites from your suddenly agressive dining companions. They're that good.

My dining companions had the pan roti sandwich, which was amazing, and the quiche lorraine, which was disappointing compared to the sandwiches. 

Overall, if you're looking for somewhere to have a nice French meal and good wine (and you don't mind splurging), Cafe Claude is the place to go (but make a reservation!).
author: Victoria N.

description:
I think all the glowing reviews of this place raised my expectations too much. The overall experience was okay, but some things were lacking that prevents me from giving this place e a higher rating. 

This is probably partly my fault, as earlier in the day I gorged myself with bbq meats from Chinatown, so I wasn't quite done digesting. 

I had the coq au vin, probably not the best choice after having the above meal, but it's something I always wanted to try. The sauce was very strong - I guess that's expected for a wine based sauce - but it went well with the chicken, which was also not lacking in flavor. Overall, I was pretty pleased with the dish, but it was on the pricier side ($20) for a chicken dish. 

Salad was pretty good. I don't remember the details, but it had an asian flair to it. Salad was cheap - under $10.

Service was inconsistent. While the waitress was really nice, she seemed overextended, and always appeared out-of-breath, or disheveled when speaking. 

Atmosphere was very pleasant, and the outdoor heatlamps did their job keeping us warm. 

I would come here again if I were in the area, but probably for lunch as it's cheaper.
author: Jimmy C.

description:
Great first date that will definitely impress her (tho expensive).

Food: great, Tastey, and adventurous (Escargot, TarTare...)
Service: great
atmosphere: romantic


I took a girl on a first date here.  She knows her restaurants so when I found one she had never been to, brownie points.  

Food: I am all for adventurous food so we ordered Pâté Campagne (pork pate) and Steak Tartare (raw steak 'salsa'). Highly recommend.  Also the cheese plate for dessert (just remember to save some wine)

Service:  attentive, nice  He was very patient, returning multiple times because it took awhile for us to digest the menu.  Also, most of the staff sounded like French was their native language.  

Atmosphere: small romantic authentic cafe tucked along an alley.  lighting great.  The dinner ended up lasting 3hrs and not once did I feel rushed.  They allowed us time to digest and chat before inquiring about dessert.  

only negative: little pricey.  I knew going into the dinner, but it was even more than I expected.  

But hey, if you want a romantic first date that will impress her (and are willing to spend the money)  FIVE STARS
author: Nolan R.

description:
mmmm....French Food! yummy! I don't know what it is about San Francisco, but I can honestly say I have never had a bad meal in that city. My love affair with french food is actually relatively new and I am not sure how I discovered this love, but it is here and Cafe Claude made my Sunday in the city just perfect.  This place is a hidden gem tucked neatly in a dark alley near Union Square and as soon as you walk up you see the darling tables on their small patio and you immediately think you are in Paris.
