So go! Eat! Be merry, at Cafe Claude! Bon appetit!
author: Shari D.

description:
this is a sweet little place.  the food is better than okay, but the wait people just might be faking those accents.  still, i go here on the occasional late afternoon when i just can't bear same old same old.  i take a depressing book and my journal and join in the ennui that plagues our fair, faux-european city.  sometimes i consider wearing an uncomfortable hat to cafe claude in the fashion of bebe from southpark, but that would be too cliche.  instead, my frown is my chic accessorie. une nause dans les mains, en effet.  good wine list, always a good endive salad.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5mrGC-wCYVQ
author: kimb s.

description:
everything was superb! ahi tartare with goat cheese - filling but not heavy, perfect for a hot summer night. my lavender lemon drop martini was fantastic as well.

then there's the 3-piece band tucked away in the front of the restaurant! something about the bass in a low-lit atmosphere is so sexy! good work, claude!
author: Valerie N.

description: Love this place! I had the best coffee drink of my life there. Excellent pate. Very nice location and extremely pleasant atmosphere. Super-friendly, helpful, attentive, and caring staff. Incredible lighting. Not too loud. Did I leave anything out? Spent part of an afternoon here and it was truly perfect.
author: Eater S.

description:
Since I get my hair done close by, I sometimes go here for a glass of vino before or after my appointment.  I used to be a big fan of this place.  I liked the decor, the service was always good, and the french onion soup was nothing to shy away from.  However, I was highly disappointed with one of my last visits.  Well in advance, I made reservations for 8pm on a Friday.  Let me rephrase that....I made reservations for 8pm on Bastille Day.  My dining companion and I arrived on time, as usual. ( i have this thing about being late I just think it is rude!) We were told that it would be about 5 minutes, perfectly acceptable for a busy french holiday at a trendy-ish french restaurant.  Now, being smashed like sardines on Claude lane with all of the other people that seem to want celebrate their french heritage (ie. an excuse to drink heavily) with no wine in hand, we started to become a little annoyed.  Our dinner reservations were at 8 and it was 8:45.  OK fine.  I admit I am very impatient, but being Bastille day and all I was trying to let it slide.  until...until...my friend asked to use the restroom.  She was told no "I am sorry, I can't let anyone in." says the roided out big man in the yellow jacket in the deepest toughest voice ever.  Apparently the words "staff" written on the his back made him oh so important for the evening. That was enough for us to leave-pronto.  
I have since visited cafe Claude and like the food just the same but unfortunately I have that icky memory that I just can't let go.
author: Jenny M.

description:
Came here on a double date.  We had gone to Union Square earlier to look at the large Christmas tree and to do some last minute Christmas shopping.  We picked this restaurant, because it had close proximity to Union Square, it received good reviews on Yelp, and we had a $15 coupon for the restaurant.  This restaurant is located a couple of blocks from northeast of Union Square.  It was cold that night, and we preferred to sit inside.  However, all the tables inside were booked, so we decided to stay and eat outside.  The outside heaters were sufficient.

For appetizer we ordered the Pate Plate, which is our own choice of three pates from a total list of four.  We picked the Rileltte du Perigord, Truffle Mousse, and Sauterne Mousse at the recommendation of the waitress.  I enjoyed eating my bread with the pate spread on it.  I think that I can only eat pate once per year, because it is high in cholesterol.

For entrees I ordered the Paleron Sauce Poivre Vert, which is a steak.  My girlfriend and my friend M ordered the Porc au Miel, while M's girlfriend K ordered the Ahi.  We all enjoyed our entrees.  I sampled the other entrees, and I like the pork entree better than my steak entree.  The pork entree was really good.

We were quite stuffed at the end of our meals, because we had eaten a lot of bread.  For desert we all shared a Mousse au Chocolat.
author: Daniel W.

description:
Super cute French restaurant!  Last time we were there, the boyfriend got the lamb, which he says was tasty!  I'm pretty faithful to the cheese plate, filet mignon and a bottle of wine, of course.  You must try the Creme Brulee-- it's one of the best I've tasted.  The restaurant is pretty small and gets really busy, but there is seating outside in the alley.  

Also a good place for lunch after a little shopping at Union Square!
author: ASHLEY G.

description: This place was super cute!! Found it through yelp and was intrigued with the idea of a European style street hidden in a nook of the city. Went there for lunch and the food was delicious. My boyfriend got the roasted chicken and said it was some of the best he'd ever had, and I got the pasta of the day (delicious but a bit too salty). I'm a huge coffee fan, and my cup was only refilled once (and the coffee was old), so I took off a star. But I would definitely recommend this place!
author: Amy J.

description:
with a reliable go-to place for a lunchtime french fix like cafe bastille right around the corner from my office, it's easy to forget about the other french gem tucked away in an alley nearby...how can i resist the call of bastille's quiche and frites?

ah, but i have discovered a good reason to keep heading up bush and bypass belden place - cafe claude's pan poulet.  $10 gets you a ginormous roasted chicken sandwich served on a nice ciabatta-like roll, with tomatoes, butter lettuce, egg, and mayonnaise, plus a mixed green salad on the side.  i could barely finish half and got to enjoy the other half for dinner.  i was tempted to order the onion soup but post-holiday pig out, i opted for something less rich (hence no frites, croque monsieur or madam - next time!)  they also offer a daily changing pasta and specials.  cappucino and espresso drinks are served w/ a tiny square of dark chocolate - who needs dessert?  (although no nonfat milk)

the seating is cozy (or cramped, depending on your own preference for personal space) and there's outdoor seating as well - even in the rain!  (well shielded under umbrellas AND awning, with heat lamps of course).  service can be slow - not the best place for a quick lunch.  but the servers are ever so charming and cute, as are the hostesses and the overall restaurant vibe.  definitely a good place to go for happy hour or to catch up with friends over drinks and small bites - i gotta try the pates...

i'll have to keep heading up the hill to try more french joints =)
author: Jen P.

description: What a great little place! The food is delish and the service is even better. Very pleasant and attentive waitstaff... we did have some trouble understanding our waiter when he described the specials in his very French accent so we just nodded and smiled...oui oui!
author: Donna V.

description:
yum.    minus one star for the waiter not bringing me another glass of wine after a bug got in my white wine.  bug juice does not improve the taste of wine.

the s.o.'s escolar with the mashed potatoes was a great entree choice.  my trout with green beans and fingerling potatoes was tasty too.

loved the atmosphere although the tables were a bit hard to get out of.
author: Tamiko J.

description: Very cute cafe with outside covered seating available.  We stopped by for lunch and ordered the quiche and pan poulet sandwich.  Lunch is probably a better deal since most of the food is $10-$15.  The chicken in the sandwich was very moist and yes they put lots of mayo on the sandwich so it tastes even better! It was a very satisfying sandwich with a nice mixed greens salad on the side.  The quiche was also very good, very cheesy and flavorful.  It's a bit small, for $9 but it does come piping hot straight out of the oven.  I would go back to try some of the other dishes.
author: Emiko M.

description: A great place for a first date, or to meet friends after work, they have jazz most nights of the week. A solid wine list and plenty of French people mingling about (hey, that's appealing to some people I suppose). The food isn't as good as it used to be, ever since they stopped serving Shepard's Pie at dinnertime.
author: Nish N.

description: BEST NICOISE SALAD in the city! You can choose either fresh raw tuna or albacore tuna. It's charming, quaint, and hidden away in a little alley way across from Beldan Lane.  I felt like I was at a cafe in Cannes, Paris, anywhere in France.  It may have been b/c I was with one of my girlfriends who was in SF for the weekend whom I met on my study abroad program in France and we hadn't seen each other since then...The atmosphere is DEFINITELY French with outdoor seating and the service was fabulous.  The waiters are definitely willing to pratiquer en francais avec vous.  The food is awesome and reasonably priced.  The have demi bouteilles de vin (the rose is GREAT from the Rhone region in France) and we ended the lunch with a couple rounds of Pastis...A+++++++ for food, service, and atmosphere.  If i worked in the Financial District, I would be here every day for lunch.
author: Jenny W.

description: I do love this place, I really do.  Food is good, if a little overpriced for what it is.  LOUD in the evenings.  And the tables are right on top of eachother.  Does anyone else ever get the feeling that all of these waiters are FAKING their french accents? Well maybe not all of them, but most.
author: Jenny S.

description: The service certainly felt French, in that slightly condescending way, and the portions were puny, so that, too, felt authentic, but my salad nicoise had a glob of mayonnaise-drenched tuna that was more hospital cafeteria than Parisian bistro. Yuck. Don't go.
author: Iana S.

description: This is one of the best kept secrets in SF dining.  I have been here with my boss, my parents, my boyfriend....and always had a perfect evening.  The restaurant is cozy and perfectly candlelit.  The jazz bands that frequent Cafe Claude are phenomenal, and make for a more eventful evening if that's what you are looking for.  But for me, the food is the best!!  I am a huge fan of french cuisine, and after the recent departure of Petit Robert (seriously - so sad) this is my favorite in the city.  In fact, during I recent trip to Paris I found myself craving the Paleron De Flanchet (steak frites) and the Moelleux au Chocolat (warm chocolate cake, which they pour creme anglaise into the center of at your table).  Also, be sure to try the absinthe champagne cocktail!!
author: Liz C.

description:
Dinning at Cafe Claude was phenomenal. 
- Great atmosphere 
- Friendly and efficient waiters (our bottle of wine actually lasted all evening)
- Pretty authentic food (not 100%, the gratin dauphinois had cheese sprinkled over it, for example, and is only meant to be made with creme fraiche, but still good) 
- The food is divine

I highly recommend the chocolate mousse!
author: Sam D.

description:
Terrible is the only way to explain our visit here Saturday afternoon for lunch. The lettuce in the salad was wilted and actually turning brown clumped underneath the few fresh leaves on the top as if this was a deliberate way to hide a known issue in the kitchen.

After ordering the Charcuterie plate, that usually is served with a nice basket of fresh baguettes, we were told that they did not have any baguettes today and instead gave us day-old stale bread. C'mon it's a french cafe on a nice alley in downtown San Francisco, not a Chilli's at the Airport in Dallas!

Even the coca-cola my son had was flat and tasted like soda water. Jeez, it wasn't like we ordered anything difficult but everything was just bad.

Really disappointing considering that we used to go here quite regularly years ago, so I just assume new management has brought this place down, way down.
author: greg d.

description:
Cafe Claude is inconspiculously tucked away on surprisingly quiet Claude Lane. This very charming and very French cafe and bar, as we soon discovered, is a perfect stop for after work cocktails. Around 6 pm it was not too cold, so we opted to sit outside on the patio without the aid of a heat lamp. Our waitress quickly took our order of three very different cocktails. I decided I would try a drink composed of pear liquor, elderflower syrup, and coconut, while Kenny decided to be oh so adventurous and order a ho hum margarita that you could probably get anywhere. Taka's cocktail was rather unique- gin with green tea and some other flavorings which I cannot remember. The drinks arrived in martini glasses, the extras saved in individual small shakers. The coconut concoction was perfectly clear, so much so I could have mistaken it for water. Tasting sweet, smooth, and mostly of coconut, this tropical drink was a big hit at our table, especially for Kenny, who,  as expected, decided that his drink was boring, and begged to switch with me. As I was in a kind and sharing mood, I let Kenny have my drink and I took the margarita which was pretty standard, save the fancy presentation in a martini glass. The green tea- gin cocktail was surprisingly tasty as well. 
While we only stuck around for one round of drinks (after all, we were headed to Zeitgeist) we did not get to try their food which, by one look at the menu would appear to be quite special. Next time I have a special occasion to celebrate, I would make a point to come back to Cafe Claude.
author: Kate A.

description: Always heard this place is great, finally tried it.  We got croque madam and quiche lorraine.  The quiche came out lukewarm.  Croque madam is good, but can't compare with Tartine's open face croque monsieur.  However, I reserve partial judgment on the food before I try their dinner.  Service was decent.  The best part is probably the ambiance, which is in an alley with some outdoor seating - a good alternative to Belden (same alley feel w/o the multitude of restaurants).  So far, not great for me, but I'd give it another chance.
author: Rob C.

description: Not fresh. Not flavorful. Not friendly. Nothing like real French cooking.
author: Jim H.

description: What I was most looking forward to during my trip to San Francisco was the food and this place did not let me down!  I had the endive salad and Porc au Miel.  It was definitely one of the best meals I have had in a long time.  My sister and I even went back the next afternoon for lunch.  Don't let the fact it is located down an alley dissuade you but DO make reservations.
author: Sarah G.

description: Went to Cafe Claude last night before the dinner rush, they fit us in without reservations, as long as we could be done by 7:00.  Staff was very attentive, cocktails were good and arrived quickly.  We had a small meal- Chevre salad that was delicious, Raviole de Champignon- delicious port reduction, Coquilles Saint Jacques warm chocolate cake and coffee.  Everything was very tasty, arrived in good timing and order, and hit the spot after walking around union square for a couple of hours.  Would definitely go again.  Also we ate inside at a small table (didn't feel too cramped), but they do have outside seating as well.  Bill came to about $60.
author: joseph m.

description: Has great food and is a sexy hot little spot in an alley, exactly as it should be!
author: Katherine N.

description: Amazing Onion Soup.  The food was really good, but the cocktails left something to be desired.  The wait staff was friendly and it's got a nice vibe about it.  My girlfriend loves French food and she really liked it and thought it was better than Cafe Bastille, which we also liked.
author: Bill P.

description:
Cafe Claude is one of those tucked-away San Francisco treasures.  Unlike the nearby Belden lane Claude is far less congested.  The alleyway is a charming backdrop for an impressive jewel-box bistro.  

The food: simple, well-prepared, French inspired classics ranging from steak tartar (prepared tableside) to onion soup.  (Both of which are worth coming here for alone).  Don't miss their cheese plate--the Brillat-Savarin is a turophile's fantasy.  With entrees under $20 and a decent wine list, Claude is perfect for a low-key, spontaneous dinner.  

The staff here is attentive and very accommodating.  I have always had great service, even when it's busy (and it does get busy).  The only downside to this otherwise excellent restaurant are the restrooms, which are shared with the rest of the building.  It's jarring to step into the dingy common hallway to access the restrooms when enjoying an otherwise fantastic dining experience.

One last consideration:  for the smokers out there, they have a few tables outside where they'll let you light up to your heart's content (the alley isn't too windy and there are heat lamps to cut the chill).
author: Elijah T.

description: My return visit to Cafe Claude was for a Saturday lunch. I was surprised to see they were packed! We had to wait for a table and ended up sitting outside on the heated patio. The day was sort of blah, but their quiche and croque monsieur MORE than made up for the lack of sunshine. The food here is just so good, and affordably priced in my opinion. A great place for lunch or dinner when you're downtown; a gem in a sea of overpriced places with subpar food.
author: Beth T.

description: The last time I went the waiter was rude, and I got the impression it was because he thought I looked shabby.  My date didn't care, nor did any of the other patrons seem to care.  Oh well, the waiter was French, after all.  He did recommend a proper wine for our chaotic food selection.  I actually think the food wasn't priced unreasonably, considering what this place aspires to be.  I didn't order anything that would have been too challenging for the cooks, either, so everything came out ok.  I'd only come here again to bring a date, somebody I thought was special, whom I also thought might be impressed by the ambiance.  Otherwise, the money might be better spent at any number of other nice restaurants.
author: Mynameisdavid M.

description: Cafe Claude is the perfect french cafe to enjoy a well-cooked meal after shopping.  I went today with my co-worker Jodie, after we sat through a work-related seminar on a Saturday, and let me say, there is nothing better than a bellini to start off a meal. Not that the seminar was bad at all, but the bellini at Cafe Claude was sweet and yummy. I had the french onion soup and croque monsieur. I wanted fries and a salad with my sandwich and luckily it came with both.  The prices were reasonable, not super high, but not super cheap - mid range actually for lunch. I like the atmosphere and the waiters were attentive and friendly.  Will definitely go back again.
author: Natalie S.

description:
So, my party probably had the worst experience (to start) Cafe Claude could offer. 
We arrived around 4 p.m. which appeared to be the end of the patio servers' shift. 
There were 6 of us and only one table that had six chairs so we sat down, despite that it was a used table- a few coffee mugs from the previous patrons. 
The waiter approached us and mumbled something about it being a dirty table and we apologized and said that we didn't mind we just wanted a drink for happy hour. He walked away mumbling something else and reappeared with what appeared to be his manager. The manager also acknowledged the dirty table and we again apologized and asked if they could just pick it up and we'll wait. Now, why is this such a huge deal?!!? 
The table was cleared and the manager asked if we wanted menus, again we made it clear we were there for happy hour and his response was, "happy hour is in the bar, and, well you are sitting out here" and so we questioned why we couldn't do happy hour outside, his response, "well I hope you aren't in a hurry because happy hour starts at 4:30p.m." OMG! 
Our response was "check your website, it says 4p.m." 
We finally got our menus and at about 4:30 a different waiter came and took our order, total BS. 
Our final waiter was really nice, great in fact. He must have been the only one working that actually knows what customer service stands for....service! 
I was so disappointed and the manager and the first waiter made us feel so awful for being there- I hope both of them read this. 
The waiter had braces and didn't speak clearly at all...although we understood all his mumbles...
author: Janell D.

description:
Wonderful wine list. 

This is a dark romantic restaurant with great live jazz...makes you feel like you're in Paris and in love. 

The food is also great...especially the steak tartate (heaven)
author: Gwen H.

description:
The food was good (not sure how it compares to other French food though). 

I got the Agneau (lamb, beans, bacon, roasted tomato) to start, and tried the French onion soup (really really good!!!, one of the best I've had), and tried the potatoes gratin, and they were decent; different). For dessert I tried the Tarte Tartin (caramel apple tart; the caramel tasted like caramel, but had a burnt/bitter flavor even though it wasn't burnt), the apples were yummy, and the crust was really good. It was best paired with the vanilla ice cream they served with it).

The service was great; the servers/staff were all really nice and friendly.

The price was typical of what I've seen of French bistros and such.

Dress was like dressy casual (no t-shirts or flip flops, jeans are fine).
author: E C.

description: Watch out for the seared tuna with fava beans.  Don't get me wrong: the tuna was amazing.  But the fava beans were a bit peculiar.  There was something nuclear about it - the sauce for the fava beans was bright green and unidentifiable.  Maybe it was the lighting or maybe it's the fact that I can't eat Fava beans without thinking of the scene from "Silence of the Lambs."  Next time, I'll just stick with the porc au miel...."with liver and a nice chianti."
author: Margaux S.

description: We sampled soups a l'oignon, escargots en croute, fromage, ( asst of artisan cheeses, honeycomb, seasonal fruit, candied walnuts, and walnut levain). It was all delicious! I'll be back to explore more...
author: The Truth T.

description: Great food and great service. One of the better places to eat in the touristy area of Union Square. Makes you feel like you're on a little street in Italy. Great wine also. A must-try!
author: Alexandra B.

description: Overrated. Uneven service. (Especially when noting that some staffers are sniffing something white before going back to pick up some dishes,...Zee manifique fleur au Columbia, c'est formidable.)
author: miriam b.

description:
This place is classic bistro. Reliable coq au vin, fries, pate. 

I personally go back to get my pate fix.  esp. the duck rillettes that's about it. It's not extraordinary or anything but reliable...much better than Absinthe in Hayes Valley. 

Also a good place to escape the tourist after shopping around Union Sq.
author: Tiger P.

description: Great little semi hidden spot. Made reservations on opentable. Had the Croque Madame which was very good. Reasonably affordable for french bistro food. Wish they carried Badoit. Never understand why french places tout their french products but stop at the fizzy water and serve pelligrino.
author: Pierre C.

description: Went here for an anniversary dinner Saturday night and had one of the best meals that I've had a long long time.  Pan Seared Ahi in some sort of creamy bacon lemon sauce,  a nice cab,  Mushroom ravoli thing,  desert... and so on.   It was worth every bit of the bank it took to have a wonderful dinner with my girl.
author: zachary m.

description:
Cafe Claude is a very cute French bistro, located off the beaten path near Union Square. Although this popular restaurant and bar has a pretty intimate atmosphere, you'll find a lively crowd accompanied with live jazz here Thursday through Saturday nights. I haven't been in years and figured it was time to refresh my memory, so my friends and I came for a visit. As we walked up, we passed by the folks dining outside and could hear the cool music coming from the windows. =)  
 
By the time we sat down, we were all starving. Raechelle is a huge charcuterie fan, so we shared the platter of artisanal meats and pickled veggies. We also shared the endive salad with blue cheese and walnuts, which was fresh and light. In between courses, we kept peering over at the steak tartare that was being served tableside next to ours. It looked so good. We told eachother we would defnitely come back for that next time. For our mains, Joann and I were feeling carniverous and opted for the flat-iron steak. My steak was a little tough but I still enjoyed it....I just kept thinking I should've ordered it "medium" not "medium well'. Raechelle had the trout with haricots verts & toasted almonds which she thought was just okay. I think she would have enjoyed it more if it had no bones. By the time the dessert menu came, we were stuffed and content with our meals and service. I still love this place and can't wait to come back and try that steak tartare!
author: Anne E.

description:
I have been here about three times already and decided it was time to give them a nice review. 

Sometimes you just don't want the standard fare available in the area... you know... the food you just pick up and go back to the office to... I felt like sitting down and having a nice experience while eating and I did not want to go to the usual Belden Ct places.... so, I said... Cafe Claude!  The location is a bit hidden, which I like because it seems like you are going to a secret spot... although, it is good... and as such it is hard to keep it a secret.  As you walk up to the alley it is located in... you all of the sudden feel like you are transported to a land far away... well... as long as you don't sit outside looking towards Bush street. But no worries... they have this divider up to cover that up... so... you don't really see it if you sit outside.  

This place can get a little packed at times, so make sure to make a reservation or go at an off time (as in, not at noon for lunch) because it gets a little harder to find a spot.) The décor is very nice, a bit dark, so it totally gives it that feel like you are in a little bistro in Europe.  This last time I went, I ordered the Saumon, that would be Salmon for us non French speakers. This dish is just delightful!  Everything from the presentation to the flavors is great!  This dish is pan seared salmon with fava beans stew, pistou (this is Pesto), egg plant caviar, and basil leaves. All for the wonderful price of $13.   Since I was working... I decided against being a lush... I got the iced tea... perfect brew, light and tasty. My lunch companion sampled the Pan Bagnat which is albacore tuna with aioli, capers, shallots, niçoise olives, tomatoes, crumbled egg, and anchovies. He also decided to go for the gold and order the pommes frites (or Fredom Fries... as he insist calling them). 

This was an overall great experience and I absolutely plan to return.  As a bonus, they also have music on some days. You can check out their website for updates.
author: Amelia M.

description: what a bunch of dicks when it comes for service.  The food is good though not  great.  In terms of snooty-ness it comes close to the Baker Street Bistro, when the you feel like an utter smuck for asking more water-- because you not asking for more whine!
author: JO Y.

description:
Not having any luck with parking near NOPA, my dining companion and I decided to head back to his place in Nob Hill, park and walk down the street in search of something to eat.  Within minutes I remembered Cafe Claude.  

I have only been for lunch but this Friday evening was an even better dining experience.  Walking down the alley you almost feel as though you are in Europe.  Upon entering you were consumed with everything French.  There was an amazing Jazz Trio performing, only adding to my European experience.  We immediately were seated.  Other than a slight wait for our wine to be delivered and our French Onion Soup arriving luke warm, we had a great experience.  We notified the waiter of our luke warm soup and they didn't miss a beat and brought it back tot he kitchen and served us another piping hot bowl.  Soon thereafter we had the pleasure of watching our steak tartar being prepared table side.  All eyes appeared to be on us, as this is a dying art in dining.  The tartar was to perfection, rich with just the right amount of spiciness from the mustard as we requested.  This was paired with an endive, bleau cheese, green apple and candied walnut salad.  All washed down with a beautiful 2000 Bordeaux.  (We ordered a half carafe realizing later that we were only charged for a glass, too late we were already home when this was discovered.  Perhaps that was to make up for our luke warm soup.)

Escape to France in your own back  yard by having dinner at Cafe Claude, you will be happy you did.
author: Scott P.

description: Awesome food! We did family style and we split the steak tartare, escargots, chevre salad and a couple other things I can't remember. Really excellent food! The restaurant and booths are a bit smaller than standard diner size, buy everything just adds to it's charm. Will definitely go back.
author: Kym P.

description: Come to Cafe Claude if you want to be snubbed by your waiter and ill-treated by the hostess.
author: Jackie G.

description: I love this place (always have for the last several years -- first stop off the airplane).  The decor, the walk down the alley, the croque madame, and the bottles bordeaux blanc.  I was there Saturday with a friend and we had a fabulous four hours.  No joke.
author: S W.

description: Underwhelmed by the food, service on Christmas Eve was mediocre at best and the interior is outdated.
author: Ila L.

description: My favorite place for lunch near Union Square.  Claude Lane is a little alley that runs between Kearny and Grant, Bush and Sutter and you can eat at an outside table in good weather.  Great salads, sandwiches, and light French dishes at lunch and even more choices at dinner.  Live jazz in the evening makes this a very romantic spot (check their website for jazz schedule).
author: Mary B.

description: One of my favorite places to sit outside on a nice evening in San Francisco and catch up with friends. I classify this as one of those spots that has the feel of being in another country.
author: Raymond M.

description:
Serendipitously profound.

To start off, we both had randomly selected this restaurant on our own accord.  It's quite amazing that when we touched base that day, we both came up with Cafe Claude.

The venue itself is tucked away into the many nooks and crannies the FiDi possesses.  If you walk by the alley while on the phone, you'd be sure to miss it.  But once you pass the uninviting pseudo wall blockers, you'd find yourself whisked away into a seemingly another city.  The French speaking Asian lady-owner quickly hosts you to an assortment of tables both inside and out.  We sat outside, heat lamps on.  The atmosphere appears to be frequented by Financial District business people that know the best kept French secret in town.  However, we did sit next to a table of French gangsters with their import cigarettes (they got up and smoked elsewhere like gentlemen),  white pants, no socks, and skinny shirts with the collar wide open.  That actually was a plus to the whole experience.  Just to hear a table of people laughing and speaking French.

Once inside, the place opens up to 10 or so tables.  A live jazz band is squished into the corner.  A tad loud, but the music selection was smooth and nonabrasive.  An 8 stool bar and a hellava wine list helps to ease the wait.  And on a Saturday night with 8:30PM reservations, I would say it was at full capacity, with patrons still waiting for a table.  The place is quaint but the vaulted ceiling made it feel just right.  Warm low set lights and candles kept the joint hazy and optimal for sharing that nice red.  They boast quite a wine list, but unfortunately, its not online.  The decor is a mix of strategically placed frames and photos - trendy, but not so much where it gets too mind boggling.   Good masculine and feminine balance.

All servers were French and spoke with a thick French accent - very nice touch.  The service was professional, a bit dry but fair, not too much on the entree suggestion pitch, but overall way above par.

Brochette - $12 black tiger prawn salad with mango, etc.  Yum.  Tasty scrimps.
Tartare de Thon Rouge - $12 raw ahi tuna, goat cheese, quail egg.  tuna was fresh and firm, goat cheese was almost Philadelphia Cream Cheese-ish.  Not a fan of the cream cheese.
Coq Au Vin  $17 - chicken with red wine sauce, bacon, mushrooms and pearl onions.  very tasty and dense.  chicken was off the bone tender.  sauce was a mild reduction with a very herbal scent.  good stuff.
Agneau $23 - roasted lamb sirloin - these deli pre-sliced lamb slivers had a lot of taste.  however, the medium rare ordered came out a tad too raw.  The intramuscular fat (marbling) was undercooked giving it a little chewiness and yes, you guessed it, a need for dental floss.  But the sauce was mildly tart and delicious.
Pommes Frites $5 - Must have frites.  Perfect seasoned and fried.
Tarte Tatin  $7 - the upside-down apple tart with caramel sauce and whipped cream.  eh, actually was disappointed with the inverted apple pie from 7/11.  the apples were overdone and soggy, it looked real dark, and the taste was can-like.   Pass.

Overall, the experience est bonne.  You still get that city-feel with the sounds of blaring of taxicab horns without all the visuals.  You really do feel transported to a private French cafe.  There are no other restaurants in that alley, so it has that exclusive feel.  Our server let us dine for hours, without interruption or hint-dropping.  Definitely a great place to intimately share a great meal, tap a bottle of wine, and ultimately create long lasting memories.
author: Isaac L.

description:
We had a party of 4 for Saturday lunch at 1:00  that went on to abouo 2:45. It started Ok but service got slower and slower. Lovely cocktain menu with great names for drinks.  I had the ceasar salad with the trout almandine. Both had lovely  prestations. Someone had the beet dish - three stars. The Tuna sandwish was too much bread and just ordinalry tuna fish. The cheese course had a piece of very hard orange cheese and my husband and the person sitting opposite botrh complained to the waiter at the same time. The response from the chef was that  was the way it was soposed to be and they had no other cheese to substitute. No soft cheeses at all. There was aslo confusino about the tea menu - the flower blosom tea finally appeared  after a second request. Convenient location andlots of people speaking French. I am not sure why things moved so slowly.  I hate having to raise my hand to get the check etc. 
$240 for 4 with 1 glass of champage each.
author: alice c.

description: Loved the food, loved the location, loved the staff, loved the music. I love Cafe Claude. We went there for lunch, best chicken breast sandwich I've every had.
author: Dwight M.

description: If you live near the city or are visiting, then Cafe Claude is a must!   It was a surprising find ( located in a small alley off of union square)  a few years ago and we have been back three times since.  We always sit outside and have enjoyed the delicious ahi nicoise salad, roasted tomato soup, the mussels and the sandwiches.  If you are a desert person you must try the creme brûlée.   The service and ambiance are fantastic.  If you are a willing to pay a few extra dollars for lunch you will really enjoy yourself at Cafe Claude.
author: Sara J.

description:
Came here the other night as part of a San Francisco date night and it was a good thing we got there when we did. We showed up around 5:20 and were told they didn't open until 5:30 So we took a walk around the block and found our way back down the dark little alley that the restaurant sits in about 5:35 The dining room (which isn't very large) was half full. We were able to get a table with the assumption that we would be done by 7:00 (i guess someone had the table reserved at 7:15)

Anyway on to dinner: 
We split a large steak tartare ($16) as an appetizer. It was about the right size for 2-3 people and the table side preparation was fun and it was nice to know exactly what flavors to expect along with the beef.

I had one of the specials of the night, 3 lamb chops in a garlic wine sauce ($24). It was flavorful and moist and cooked to order, but failed in comparison to the pork my girlfriend had ($20). It was served with baked apple slices and green beans and was covered in a white balsamic, honey sauce that my mouth couldn't really pin down. It wasn't really like anything I'd ever had. The sweetness of the balsamic and honey melted together with what tasted like browned butter into something magical

Food and service were worthy of 5 stars, but the music in the dining room was a little louder than I would have expected for a french restaurant which made conversation a little difficult so I marked it down a star
author: Bill H.

description: My boyfriend and I celebrated our anniversary with a nice romantic dinner here. It was fantastic! Service was great, food was delicious. We shared the escargot - how couldn't you enjoy this doused in garlic and butter topped with a puff pastry! He then had the soup of the day, cream of cauliflower and I had the salad with toast and goat cheese which both were extremely satisfying. For our main course, he had the "coq au vin" - a chicken stew marinated for 5 hours and he devoured it. I had the "thon" which didn't come with what it said on the menu but was tasty. Would have liked it cooked a little more rare, it was a tad on the dry side, but no complaints overall! As we were incredibly stuffed, we though we had to try dessert and we got a flour less chocolate cake which was probably the richest desserts I've ever had, and so worth it! Overall, it's a definite 4-5 star type of place! Can't wait to go back!
author: Meghan F.

description: I'll keep it short: I tend to go to Cafe Claude for business lunches. The service is always good & friendly, and they are always very accommodating with my frequently last-minute lunch reservations (they accommodate whenever possible, but it's not always possible). The food is always well-prepared & presented, and just the right size portions. The room is beautiful, with just the right lighting. I feel like I'm having dinner when I'm in there (and that's good)! The soup there is so good that I'm loathe to get it from any other place! Just a wonderful balance of flavors. Excellent place. Great room.
author: Eric H.

description: Don't bother for lunch the menu is blah, but dinner...whoa, dinner is amazing.  The escargot, baked brie and garlic with baguette is heaven on earth.  A 90 Silver Oak would be the only way to improve the experience.
author: B G.

description:
alright, now an avg. of 4 stars seems pretty reasonable...

as for me experience... i give it a 3.5.  we had reservations at 8:30... and probably didn't get seated until near 9... okay, maybe like 8:50...  but if you have reservations, i kinda expect to be seated when we are supposed to be... esp. at such a nice restaurant like this...

the decor was totally cute, and really cool how they have live music there.. it's off in a little alley, a little hard to find... 

the food - not the greatest.  i had the pork, which was good, but too sweet for me.  i tried the lamb - it was alright... nothing special... the chicken was tender.  the best dish there that we tried that night had to have been the sea bass - delish!!  it was a special, so don't bet on it being served when you go.. but if it is, get it!

the portions are actually pretty good sized... i mean, they gave me 3 pork medallions, and the chicken had at least 4 drumstick size pieces... 

overall, not bad, but didn't knock my socks off.
author: Kimberly F.

description: This is great small French cafe tucked away in the alley  so you don't feel like you're in the financial district.  Like the Nicoise salad and I am a fan of the cheese plate and charcutterie plate.  Good wine list.  Highly recommend when you want to get away for lunch or a swing in after work for the cheese plate and wine.  The waiters are cute and speak French which adds to the ambiance.
author: Wendy B.

description: When I worked around the corner from the cafe I would come here at least once a week, especially for their yummy goat cheese salad.  They have delicious ice tea, and those handsome French waiters keep your glass filled!
author: Joni M.

description: Worth going just to LOOK at their Creme Brulee with the little slice of strawberry on top.
author: D. R.

description:
Cafe Claude was a bit difficult to find, down an alley.  But it's worth the search!  

We dined on a Sunday night and were pleasantly surprised by the friendliness of the patrons (native San Franciscans).  My wife ordered the moules et frites and I had the coq au vin.  The sauces were rich, complex flavorful sauces that could not be ignored.  We asked for a second basket of bread to dip and soak up the wonderful flavors.  

We split a creme brulée that had a subtle bitter burnt sugar shell encapsulating the vanilla creamy custard.  Yum!  And the cafe au lait was served in something akin to a handle-less Japanese cha-wan.  All good fun was had and we will keep Cafe Claude near the top of our list.
author: Ken A.

description: The food is just good, but the jazz in the evenings, the atmosphere and the cute french waiters keep me coming back. I'll confess to a couple of dates here too :)
author: Stellah D.

description: Have yet to go here for dinner.. i hear they have great music goin on some nights. If you're sick of Belden Lane, walk on over to Cafe Claude. It's just one block over in the "other alley" and it's go an ecclectic mix of french cuisine. I had the snow crab melt, which was really melting in my mouth. And surprisingly they didn't overkill with the mayo. But the thing about this restaurant was the dessert. YES.... i HATE bananas, but my friend convinced me to have a bite of his chausson au chocolat, which was bad because i nearly finished the whole thing myself afterwards. The bananas are sliced really thin and is just drowning in milk chocolate sauce that you barely taste it, wrapped in a crepe like substance, and added with the creme fraiche ice cream... i was licking the plate clean!
author: Marina K.

description: I work near Union Square and I have eaten at Cafe Claude off and on for nearly a decade. Lunch meetings, dinner with Friends, etc. While my husband and I were still dating we ran through the alley during one of those infamous San Francisco downpours. Breathless and soaking wet, I was just trying to figure out the closest place we could eat. The cafe was cozy and all the candles were flickering. It was like something from a movie! To say the ambiance was romantic does not begin to describe it. "Magical" might be a better word. This was hands down the most romantic meal I have ever had. (The company may have had something to do with that as well.) The food was as delicious as it always is (onion tart is my fave) and you have NOT I repeat Not had creme brule until you have had it here.
author: Melissa B.

description:
a delicious treat of a restaurant for a visiting out-of-towner.

ambience is great - darkly lit, decor that stops right before kitchsy, and attentive service.  live music is always a plus, and it was a subtle, appropriate accompaniment rather than a distracting center of attention.

and the food - oh, the food!  if i had to choose one thing they do best, it's their meat.  i've personally never had such tender cuts in my life - no matter which of the three dishes we ordered.  only complaint: the porc au miel comes with a decadently sweet caramel sauce and carmelized apples, which by the end prove to be too much.  on the bright side, my fellow diners were more than happy to pick up my slack and gobble down the apples plain.

the salads were also delightful if not relatively standard.  another standout was the wine (avalon, a napa cab sauv), two bottles of which the bf went straight home and ordered for his mom.

perhaps it was slightly pricey - but really, it was equivalent to boston prices and i only know of a spattering of restaurants there that could hold a flame to cafe claude.  so 5 stars for location, ambience, and taste!
author: Allison B.

description: Every time I come here, I think to myself, "why don't I eat here every day?". I guess the answer is that  a daily intake of Cafe Claude would most likely lead to a 100 pound weight gain. The food is just so delicious, I can't stop myself! Now that the b/f is working in the neighborhood again, I think I'll need to kick up my cardio to offset the more frequent visits that are sure to happen.
author: Michelle D.

description: Awesome! French food was to die for. The atmosphere was great. Our waitress was very nice and sweet and most importantly did not rush us through our meal on a busy night! Hidden Gem, you must check it out.
author: magda j.

description: I stopped by Cafe Claude Saturday night for a drink and caught jazz vocalist Shelley MacKay's set.  What a treat!  She has a beautiful voice that she used to create a fresh and unique take on her songs.  I think she's at Cafe Claude regularly so go hear her, you won't be sorry!  Derrick was my bartender and he was wonderful- friendly, informative and attentive without being intrusive.
author: Dorothy E.

description:
love it, love it, delicious! 
i went tonight for dinner for the first time. i've always had great food when i've gone for lunch and the desserts are fabulous, i'd go just for them! i stuffed myself so bad i didn't feel too well on the BART home but that will soon subside leaving me only with pleasant memories..
author: rukshan b.

description: I came on Monday night w/ my bf, where it's not busy and very casual.. So it's totally perfect. The waiter and host  were very friendly, service was great, c'est parfait. We ordered some small dishes, but our favorite were the Charcuterie Plate (the pate are heavenly), Steak Tartare, and Coquilles Saint Jacques. Wine list is awesome. Perfect for dates :).
author: dannydan d.

description: Yes, three stars but when you need a glass of Lillet Blanc and some Steak Tartare at 11am (and you know who you are) it will do nicely.
author: patrick g.

description: I went here with my friend Michelle once and it was the perfect palce for catch-up drinks! Their cosmos come in their own mini-shaker so that you can refresh your drinks as needed.
author: shoba d.

description: I've been coming here for years.  It's a lovely, ambient respite from the FiDi hustle and bustle, with a solid menu best enjoyed outside, but within earshot of the regular live jazz.
author: Vanessa C.

description:
intimidated as i was by the traditional french menu and the negative vegetarian reviews, i still decided to give the café claude a chance. while the entrée selection is nearly untouchable by herbivores, the cheese plate, salads and sides make for quite a filling and tasty assortment. i particularly enjoyed the port-salut [cheese] and the chèvre [salad]. the pasta with pesto, which they happily prepared sans chicken, was delicious though inauthentic.

the outdoor atmosphere was charming, as was the wait staff, all of whom were quite fluent in french. i look forward to returning, and next time saving room for dessert.
author: shannon e t.

description:
i was pretty underwhelmed by cafe claude. i went there for lunch with a client, and got there a little early. they have a swanky-looking interior with a cute, rounded bar where i waited. first, if you're going for lunch, even on a weekday, make a reservation! i did not know this fun fact until informed by the hostesses, and we had to sit outside in the chilly march drizzle (luckily my client was a good sport). i will say this, their heating lamps work pretty well! i was not shivering, and was actually even able to take off my jacket (though i kept behind me in my chair for warmth). 

we both opted for sandwiches; i ordered the croque monsieur and my client had the pan bagnat. my croque monsieur was yummy, but really greasy. i suppose that's to be expected of sandwiches with melted cheese on top, but this was like REALLY greasy. and my client's pan bagnat's contents were spilling out onto her plate and she had to use a fork and knife to eat it. the server was very blase and we waited a while for our check. i'd definitely give them another chance, i guess i was just expecting more.
author: Kris G.

description: I really like this place It's super cozy, charming, delicious food, and great service. What else can you ask for?... plus it is just a short walk from Hotel Nikko. The night that I went for dinner to Cafe Claude I also was able to listen to the Jazz ( nightly )... oh loved it I was immediately transported to Paris. Dishes you should try: Ahi seared ahi tuna, onion confit, bacon, soy green peppercorn sauce ( this is a must ) Porc au Miel pork filet, honey, white balsamic vinegar and Pommes Frites french fries, sauce piquante aux herbes so good. In addition to the regular menu they have great dinner specials. I can't wait to go again!
author: Ernesto C.

description: Loved Cafe Claude! Each dish was authentic and delicious. the chocolate mousse was a wonderful texture of pudding  and caramel but definitely chocolate. Great service and cozy.
author: Nicole D.

description: Went there last night for another one of my special dates with my boyfriend, I  checked out this place from opentable.com, looked at the menu online and decided this was where I wanted to go, My boyfriend and I each started with the onion soup, so so so good, my mouth is watering just thinking about it, then we had the pork pate which was equally as good. For entrees he had the Hangar Steak Special and had the trout, this restaurant was very good, they had good food, good ambiance and friendly staff, I would definitely come here again, also the location is so neat, tucked away in a quite clean alley, it almost feels like you're in a foriegn country.
author: Ashley G.

description: This place sucks.  The service was really bad.  The food was gross.  We spent $70.00 on a cheese plate.  It was disgusting, plus they tried kicking us out of the restuarant.  I was writing a paper for a class and the host  was trying to read over my shoulder.  It was just bad.
author: Kenny C.

description: Excellent bistro.  Friendly service and very good food.  I love French Onion Soup and found there's delicous.  Had superb trout, another hard to find favorite.  My husband had excellent chicken.  Only problem was not having room for dessert.
author: Gayle F.

description: Food and service were both excellent. We got there in the midst of the lunch crowd and the server thanked us profusely for waiting. The salad nicoise was great and so was the veal scaloppie wih spinach mashed potatoes and hericorte verts. We indulged in a delicious cheese platter as well as creme brulee and the total cost for 3 of us including tip was $80. Definately a place I'll go visit again (this time in the evening to catch the live music)
author: Sarah H.

description: Nice for a little meal! I'm french and it really looks like french food. I had a very nice carrot soup and le croque monsieur is really good and you would get the same in Paris. So go ahead.
author: Amaury d.

description:
They're lucky they get four stars after being rude rude rude. But, the food is always great, the service is on par, and I love the cozy atmosphere.

  I've eaten here a few times. I usually come for dinner while I'm killing some time before I get to go home after work. The first time I visited the host looked at me as if I had three eyes and was then huffy and puffy because I was a solo diner. He then asked me how long I intended on staying at the restaurant. What the hell? I should have told him I'd go elsewhere but I was starving and I wanted a tasty dinner.  After I was seated my waitress was kind and attentive which made up for the snobby host. My meal was cooked perfectly and I even stayed for dessert. Since that visit I have returned a couple more times( and I still get the three eyeballs glare when I walk in alone) but the atmosphere, the fresh ingredients, and the flavors keep me coming back. I've been on a hunt for a grilled cheese in downtown and Cafe Claude has a original take on a classic. Ham on the inside, cheese on the outside ON TOP OF the bread. Go figure... It's pretty darn good and I heart the skinny fries that accompany the sammie. Cafe Claude is worth the visit even if it does mean that you may be treated like you're a visitor from Mars.
author: chelsea b.

description: I must start at the beginning and say that the chèvre salad was nominal, but the "eh" factor ended there.  The escargot en croute  was AMAZING: buttery, garlicy, pestoy and yes, snailey.  I had the seared ahi tuna with onion bacon confit--which I wish I could describe better than, "it's ahi tuna!" and "it's bacon!" and "it's ahi tuna AND bacon!", but really I think you get my drift.
author: Danny S.

description: blech, dim lights can't hide bad food.
author: Fzarond K.

description:
from now on, i will take my frites only in the narrowest of well-known hidden alleys. 

frenchtastique.

.
author: michael w.

description: Great restaurant with a nice outdoor seating area. Gotta try their escargots, coquille saint jacques and truffle pate. They are delicious and I just can't get enough of them! Order lots of small plates to share so you can try everything! Mmmm and end with their dark chocolate mousse!
author: Yun Y.

description:
The food: excellent, fresh, reasonable yet filling portions, great drinks.

The ambiance: nice.

The service: laughable. 

And I'm actually quite easy to please.

I've been here twice, both times for a late-ish lunch around 2:30.  Both times we were promptly seated, but each time we had to wait at least 15 minutes to have drink orders taken, and then another 15 for our lunch orders (no exaggeration).  The first time I ordered quiche and was told at least 20 minutes after ordering that they were out of it.  Settled for a delicious salad.  (It happens, I know.)  The next time I was there, the server brought my friend the wrong salad, gave me the wrong sandwich, and completely forgot our side order of haricots verts... with no apology.  All of this while at least three or four servers were standing around the hostess stand talking to each other.

Now, I know 3 in the afternoon isn't exactly prime time for lunch service.  And the servers around the hostess stand were definitely on break and had no responsibility to serve me or help out.  Understood.  But come on.  If it's such an inconvenience to serve someone lunch at 3 in the afternoon, why not just close from 2 until 5?  I really enjoy the food and the ambiance, and I wanted to give them more stars.  But it was honestly so irritating, I don't think I'll give them another chance.
author: Jace W.

description: Very salty except for the tuna tartare, which was delicious.  Too bad, because the ambience and portions were nice and the staff was accomodating.
author: B B.

description:
overall experience was very good. 

foods:  pretty good and fresh. 

a good place for lunch and dinner.  has a touch of formality yet not too pretentious/trendy setting.  the location of off in a small alley so it's quiet...
author: Truc N.

description: We Went here for a late dinner on a weekday and it was very nice, although it is tucked in an ally and we nearly walked right by it.  We ordered a salad, the duck pate, and the pork with peaches.   All the food was prepared very well.  While admittedly, I have nearly no experience with french food, It felt authentic, because all of the cooks and staff spoke french to each other.  I thought it was a pretty good value considering the quality of the food.  Portioned seemed a bit on the small side at first, but I left full and very satisfied.  The coffee at the end of the meal left much to be desired (cafe au laut, and a mocha) so I would recommend skipping the coffee here and heading to one of the many local coffee shops in the area.
author: Jerad D.

description: I'm all about charming french things...located in   small alley off of Union Square with outdoor seating in alley you can pretend you are in Paris for an hour or two.  The food is nothing to write home about but it makes a good spot for lunch or drinks after shopping in Union Square.
author: Michelle M.

description: What a deliciously adorable place. The vibe is an artsy cafe that is both upscale and relaxed. Outside seating is made cosy with heat lamps and plants and you can admire the colorful murals and passersby in the hidden alleyway. Inside, there are interesting and, at times, humorous black and white portraits of Paris lining the walls. A full, glowing bar gives warmth to the space. For a French restaurant, the menu is surprisingly considerate of vegetarians. Two of the three specials were specified as vegetarian by our knowledgeable and courteous server. Regular menu items included a few salads, a vegetarian lasagna, a cheese platter and a few sides. Having a light dinner, I sampled the beet salad with snap peas, feta and pistou. It was sumptuous. The herb fries were a delightful accompaniment - think, long, crisp, fearful and served with an amazing, creamy and slightly spicy sauce. I also had a unique chilled red wine with my meal that was fruit forward and extremely pleasant. Though slightly on the pricey side, dining here was an excellent experience.
author: Jesal P.

description: Simple French food without the American-sized portions.  The waiters are certainly French and are straight out of central casting.  Live jazz on Thursday through Saturday nights and it's not so loud that you can't hear your company.  Small bar, but a nice wine list of French wines and a helpful sommelier.  Very San Francisco setting and for the price you can't beat the French food.  Great date restaurant.
author: Geoff K.

description:
This place is a real gem, tucked away in the alley of Claude Lane. I've been here twice, both occasions were for dinner and I thoroughly enjoyed myself. It's cozy, quaint, and the perfect place to take your SO out for a romantic meal. 
I had the onion soup for starters which was pretty good, and not too salty which is a major no no. It was on the cheesy side, but I love cheese so no complaints here ;) Of the Petits Plats I've had the Escargot which holds a special place in my heart. This was actually the first place that I tried this delectable dish and I now I'm hooked. I love the flaky crust that they top it off with, and there's just a burst of flavor with every bite. I've also had the Steak Tartare which they do give you a hearty serving of, and since I ordered mine with a little Tabasco, it had a real kick. The Pate Plate was delish - smooth and creamy. As for entrees, the Truite aux Amandes  (pan-seared trout) was good, but I liked the special of the day better which was a stuffed chicken and very tender. 
Definitely check this place out, but be careful where you sit! Don't sit at either of the two tables to your left when you first walk in...Why? Well, the tables are positioned in a perpendicular manner and you will either be A) staring at a couple eating their food or B) be the couple being stared at...umm awkward? Just a tad :)
author: Irene B.

description: This place is decent but overpriced. I was here with a group of 4 and we tried all of each other's dishes - the best dish by far was the Porc au Miel (pork with a really delicious honey/balsamic sauce). The french fries, salads and steak tartare were good too. The steak and mushroom raviole were just okay.
author: Lila T.

description: Reunited with an old friend here.  We've both never been.  The ambience was pleasant, cozy and dark.  Very French I suppose.  ;)  Anyhoo, the food was good, but not spectacular.  We had the pork with honey...the dessert was our favorite part.  Who can resist chocolate?
author: Vera D.

description:
small, petite restaurant, and cute ambient.

We have group of 6 and were sitting outside, under the construction billboards.

Food quality isn't bad, but not the best.  We got the 6 escargots as a group appetizer and that was delicious.
I got the French Onion is a bit too salty.
My wife got a Sweet Carrot soup with hints of Truffle oil and that was good.
Steak tartar prepared in front of you, unless you are sitting outside, then the waiter is doing it somewhere else that you don't get the experience to see how he mixed the tartar with cornichons, capers, quail egg, mustard, parsley, croutons, shallots.
Overall food is okay. Some are good and some are below average.  They could be better. 0.5 or rounded it off to 1/1 stars

Overall experience is, the waiter is promptly response and very attentive.  Self proactive in helping you, answer any questions, pour water without you hinting them and explain very detail on how the food is done.  That is a 2/2 stars right there! Good services!

The fact that we were sitting outside and didn't heard the jazz music that were playing in side, 0/1 star.

Price adds up if each order app, entrees, and a half bottle of wine to share, total per person is 40 dollar.  I don't' believe this restaurant is $$, it should be $$$.  0/1 star.
author: James L.

description: Delicious food. I brought a friend from France who said the taste was similar to that served in Paris. While as a vegetarian, I was limited to the lasagna, my friend was quite pleased with her dish and I thought the cheese plate was delightful. I do recommend reservations if you want to sit inside but the patio was heated and we were fine out there.
author: Stacy L.

description: All I can say is: mediocre.   I came expecting a great experience and left completely unimpressed.  I ordered the trout, the man-friend ordered the coq au vin, we finished the night with the apple tart, which was sadly the best part of the meal because it was full of caramelized apples.  The trout was swimming in butter, which as it turns out, isn't always a good thing, especially not when the vegetables are also bathed in the stuff, and the coq au vin was on the salty side.  Go if you want overpriced food that's only lukewarm.
author: Kim T.

description: What is up with french food in the city lately?  First Cafe de la Presse changes, now Cafe Claude (and Cafe Bastille for that matter) has gone downhill.  Haven't been there for lunch, but dinner on Sat night was pretty boring.  Well except the mousse pate with champagne - but I can do that at home.  Had a salad and the vinigarette was sweetened with sugar, the sauce of the meat was much too bland and the fish was just ok.  Well their raspberry infused vodka was yummy...  oh, but the jazz trio was great!
author: Aga N.

description: Ah cafe Claude, je ne sais quoi!! Amazing service, they will take care of you like you never seen before. I can tell you since I'm 100% french this is typical, escargot, foie-gras, tartar and they do it very well. Bravo!
author: Mattin N.

description: Cafe Claude gets five stars for excellent service and a great wait staff!! It's tucked away on an alley off Bush Street - and has very comfortable indoor/outdoor seating. The menu isn't big on vegetarian options but they were incredibly accommodating and altered their dishes to suit us. They have excellent wines and champagne by the glass,  the salads and entrees were fresh and flavorful and the people were incredibly friendly. We can't wait to return soon!
author: Julie P.

description: hey a real french waiter that looks like super buff owen wilson ish. the food was good but what is up with the super tight space. we're americans here. great service, romantic setting and over all, the food was decent. might need to give it another try...
author: Tiff W.

description: I and my friend were totally happy with the authentic French dishes of Cafe Claude. I love all aspects of the restaurant. Before staring our main dish, we were served with some bread which was incredible. The bread was exactly what I used to have in France. Today, I had a Pork dish and my friend had chicken and we found the 2 dishes incredibly delicious. The pork was nicely marinated with apple sauce..and the chicken looked too plain and white but the flavor was authentically fragrant. It was amazing. I would strongly recommend this gastronomic restaurant.  Plus.!..! The atmosphere is very cozy and classical ..
author: Pauline K.

description: Lovely little lunch spot.  Dishes are a bit hit or miss, but by "miss," I mean "not quite worth the $$" not "oh god, i'm going to puke."  Not quite right for business lunches, but perfect for lunch dates.  One of the few lunch places downtown with dim lighting, which adds a touch of romance.
author: Sheila W.

description: Sometimes you need a place to linger over a bottle of wine and catch up on the news of whoever you're with. Surrounded by vintage Air France posters and a huge zinc bar, this is a good place to do it. The food is solid--it's not the gastronomic temple that other places are. This is the place to have a jazz band in the background and be unrushed over a plate of their excellent cheeses. Actually, I wish this place was my secret. Forget about what I just wrote. It is really bad, the escargots are served raw, and all the waiters all smoke galoises while working. Don't come! Stay away!
author: Trevor S.

description: Cafe Claude is hidden in this cute little alley and has a great atmosphere.  The food is pretty good and the prices are quite reasonable.  It's open on Saturdays too so sometimes I like to come here to have a glass of wine somewhere quiet after going shopping.  We went there for valentine day's dinner once and there was a bossa nova trio playing that was really good. I've had the french onion soup, nicoise salad, steak tartare, charcuterie plate, cheese plate, and they have all been pretty good.
author: cecilia g.

description: This place use to be my favorite go-to frenchie place! We got to know the manager, Dauphina, who was super-nice and always made our steak tartare just the way we liked it. Since she left, we haven't been back often as the new manager is not as friendly (which I guess, makes him more authentically French ;)) The food is definitely high quality, but I can't say the regular menu has any stand-out dishes. I would recommend ordering from the daily specials menu. I must say that I highly recommend the tarte tartine...simply delicious!!  Please come back Dauphina!
author: Hoiling W.

description: My go to french restaurant.  It's tucked away in a little alley and it's close to home--so points to that!  Food is simple and delicious and there's jazz on weeknights.  Also a great place for a lunch outside on a nice day.
author: Helen T.

description: My all time favorite for a sit down lunch, drinks after work or an earlier dinner. Staff is attentive, prices are good and the food is excellent!
author: Maggie M.

description: This is a wonderful place to take a date.  You can go semi-casual or spruce it up a bit, but the ladies will be impressed in your selection of fine dining.  I just wish I had date to go there with again.  The food is excellent and the service is what one would expect.  Make it happen.
author: Toome B.

description: I take my mom here for lunch.  We have wine and pate and yummy bistro food, and pretend we are french for an hour or so.  The steak frites - YES.  And I also enjoy the wine by the glass list.
author: Natalie M.

description:
It looks like I'll be adding to the collective wisdom here. I'm in SF for work and staying in this area, and Yelp recommended this as a moderately priced and fairly good French restaurant. Stopped in here with a friend on a Monday night, sat right down (go Monday). Very friendly and attentive service, and the food was very reasonably priced, and very tasty. I'm happy to add to the 4 star Yelp average.

We had some trouble finding it just because it is tucked in one of the alleys, but that's not their fault. Yelp and an iPhone together got us there.
author: Steve B.

description: Took my wife here for luch on her birthday back in June...forgot to write review. We both really enjoyed it! Tasty food..pleasant service...relaxed..not too expensive...middle of San Francisco...what more to say?
author: Mark C.

description:
I've been here about a half dozen times and have always had a great meal.  What I like:

* Very, very delicious food.
* Reasonably priced, especially given how good (and "french" :) the dishes are.
* Solidly reliable lunch spot for business meetings -- it's got that nice upscale but not over-the-top decor, and there's something on the menu for just about every palate, and it's all good.
author: jonathan c.

description: Oh, how I love Cafe Claude.  I often reminisce about my standard choice of onion soup, croque madame, moelleaux aux chocolat and beautiful red wine.  I think it's time for me to go back!
author: Tania K.

description:
i like to go here on lazy sundays, sit in the alley tables with my shades on, get a HUGE mocha, sometimes with amaretto, and pretend like i'm in venice.  watch the clouds, smoke a clove(when i did things like that) and be relaxed.

my favorite story is why i came to claude the 1st time to begin with; a friend was there and a girl at another table asked for one of their bowl sized mochas 'non-fat'.   the waiter, who apparently was french, said in a glorious accent "nun-faat, we do naut serrvvve nun-faat!"
author: Carol S.

description: Great for a pre-theatre dinner on a Sunday.  Wasn't sure it would be possible to make it for a 7pm show with a 5.30 reservation but we had loads of time.  We were seated in the front room that looks out on the alley and it was a wee bit cold to begin.  We shared the duck rillettes and a goat cheese salad. Very nice. Rack of lamb was nice and pink and the gnocci and wild mushrooms were a delicious combination. My steak with gratin dauphinois was just right. Finished with huckleberry creme brulee - again just right. Cocktails are only $5 between 4 and 6pm so we were able to get 2 at that price. A bit more than our usual haunts for pre-theatre (Grand Cafe or cheap Thai) but well worth it.
author: Denise P.

description: Great service, lovely atmosphere (very European feeling), AMAZING food (try the Coq Au Vin).  Great experience!
author: Danna P.

description: I love Belden, but this place beats it.  Wonderful food, beautiful atmosphere and prompt attentive service. The jazz gets loud, so if you are not a fan sit outside or in the back portion of the restaurant. I had the Coq au Vin and it was lovely.
author: t m.

description: coq au vin. i wanted to stop, but i couldn't. wiped that plate clean!
author: Debbie Chiou S.

description:
Oh YUM! After a horrendous V-Day dinner, we decided to do a round 2 at Cafe Claude. And boy were we glad. Small and cozy, this French bistro oozes with old world class. Some might feel a little claustrophobic because the tables are so close, but I for enjoy looking at what my neighbors are having and chit chatting about our delicious dishes. When the weather gets warmer, I'll definitely be back to dine in their outdoor patio. 

Our server was adorable, attentive, and oh-so-helpful! He helped my date dissect the menu while I ordered using my rusty 4 years of high school French. He humored me quite a bit. We started off with a trio of pate--peppercorn (tastes like the pate in Vietnamese sandwiches), truffle mousse (fabulous, a must have), and confit-style (tasted rancid, avoid at all costs!). For our entrees he had the lamb smothered in a red wine reduction while I order the coquilles saint jacques. The lamb was delicious, but nothing special. The coquilles on the other hand was like nothing I've ever had; like a seafood pot pie, the scallops, shrimp and mussels were delicately cooked in a creamy gruyere sauce, placed in 2 giant seashells, and then topped off with a crispy breaded top. Heaven. Differing from the norm, we topped off the night with the chocolate mousse (the creme topping tasted like creme brulee!!). 

Thank you Cafe Claude, I'll be back!
author: Linda T.

description: We ate there Saturday, July 30.  We had a reservation for 8 pm and were seated promptly.  It continued to be very busy, seating people at 10 pm.  No matter how busy, the service was attentive, but not overbearing, just very efficient.  I had a wonderful butter lettuce house salad with mustard vinagarette-- just perfect for a nice salad, actually a fairly large size.  My companion had the special creamy corn soup which was delicious.  We shared a great cheese plate and dessert.  Even though we didn't order 'entrees', servers were great.  The jazz combo really adds a great ambience.  This will be one of my go to places in SF
author: Cindy L.

description:
URP.  So full of rich food.  Must write overdue MBA finance papers.  But I don't wanna.  I wanna go to sleep from all the rich food.  Went here with Ryan W. who is stating once again that he is not going to write a review and defer to my better journalism skills. HAH! Lazy bastard!  Oh well, I'll forgive him because he's decent company.
This place is located on a tiny alleyway between Grant and Kearny and it's little bistro style does remind one of Paris.  The food is far richer than what one would eat in Paris but I can always forgive a heavy hand with the rich ingredients.  I had the roasted bell pepper soup...YUMMMMM.  Ryan W. had the roasted prawns...YUMMMMM  My main course was the ahi tuna accompanied by the potatoes au gratin....SUPER RICH YUMMMMM  Ryan W. had the roasted chicken penne pasta....GREEDY BASTARD DIDN'T SHARE BECAUSE IT WAS YUMMMMMM  Then we split some coconut flan...OH DEAR GOD YUMMMM  About $60 each including my Bellini and Ryan (I'm on the wagon) W.'s Perrier.
C'est bonne.
author: Jill D.

description:
cafe claude is one of my favorites. the atmosphere, alley location, live jazz trio....don't even get me started on the cheese plate.

always a pleasure.
author: heather m.

description: Cute lil Frenchie joint tucked away where you can pretend you are actually in some provincial town. This can be done if you drink enough wine, try it! Good food, lunch has good prices (never been there after dark) and there is no beating people talking to you nicely in Frog.
author: Colleen B.

description:
Server was professional and funny, kept our wine glasses full and had a good knowledge of the menu.

Ambiance was GREAT: you sit semi-near your neighbors but you can't tell they're there because of the small sphere of candlelight that lights up your table and the person across from you. Very intimate and romantic :)

Around 7:30 I was delighted when a man dragged in a huge standing bass and the band began to play lovely jazz, which filtered lazily over the restaurant in a pleasant manner.

Food--divine. I ordered this fish dish with scallops and breadcrumbs and the waiter didn't even laugh at me when I couldn't pronounce the name (hehe).

ALSO if you want a GREAT treat, order the flowering tea. They bring out the hot water in a wine glass and the flower in a ball and you get to drop it in yourself and watch the jasmine bloom.

Cheese plate was a great way to start the meal, too. 

Impressive presentation and a really intimate, classy atmosphere. One of my favorite eats in the city.
author: K.Robyn L.

description: I thought this was a cute little bistro type restaurant with outdoor seating in the middle of an alley.  Inside the restaurant is a little intimate setting.  The steak tartare was awesome.  I also tried the hangar steak which was really good as well.  My favorite was a drink that I had made with coconut water which I though was a really unique drink.
author: Jen L.

description:
I would recommend this restaurant to anyone. I love their steak with pommes frites. The steak is juicy and they have the best french fries I have ever tasted. I've been to France a couple of times so I know this restaurant meets the French standard.
I also love their "creme coconut" house flan. It's sooo goood. The last time I went there, I had 2 creme coconut just for myself.
I'd love to try their "bouillabaise" (sort of a seafood stew) but they removed it off of their menu. 
Cafe claude, I love you.
author: Tati R.

description: Like being in Paris, but with English speaking waiters.  I like the ambiance, the food, the location.  It can be expensive, for what it is, thus the four stars.
author: Julia M.

description: Romantic date spot, fun with a group too!  Cafe Claude is not a secret, but when you walk down the somewhat obscure "Claude Lane," and step into the tiny but very cool establishment, you'll feel like you've discovered a hidden gem.  Food quality and presentation are both superb and offerings are unique (although not sooooo exotic as to frighten patrons unfamiliar with French cuisine).  Wine list is extensive  and,with what my wine fanatic friend tells me, fairly priced.  Service is attentive and knowledgable.  Jazz music makes the expirience all the more enticing.  Romantic spot for a date (hidden, rich food, music) but fun with a group too!  8 of us went on New Year's Eve for Cafe Claude's (very reasonable) price fix.  Service was just as good as when dining with a smaller party, and everyone in the group loved the food.
author: Jenni D.

description:
Claude Lane discretely echoed of St-Germain-des-Pres. Ancient cigarette butts wedged between softly worn cobblestones. Casually dressed post-work drinkers leaned against the brick, conversing vehemently with their hands. A woman dwarfed in a navy trench speeds around the corridor, her wedge heels announcing her departure. I paused at a London style pub before entering Café Claude. The restaurant spilled onto the street with delicate tables and a generous billowed awning. The indoor dining area bathed in candlelight. The air thick with wine, butter and cream. Well coiffed bar patrons made room for us as we followed the zigzagging hostess to our table. The rest was a flurry of deliberation, exploration, and endorphic satisfaction.  

We started with a few modest glasses of '07 Cartlidge & Brown pinot noir, bread and butter, and a salad of red beets, snow peas, feta and pistou. For our entrees: a traditional vegetarian lasagne laden with roasted eggplant, zucchini, spinach, tomato, béchamel, herbes de provence; and steak tartare with cornichons, capers, egg yolk, mustard, parsley, croutons, and shallots. To our surprise, the tartare was crafted at our table. Our server cracked the quail egg and mixed the herbs and raw meat with dramatic flair and severe wrist movements, the grand finale was a pinch of pepper and garnish. The whole experience was fantastic and incredibly suspenseful because it seemed like he'd never be done (sort of like Rowan Atkinson's shop character when he created the never-ending package for Bill Nighy's extramarital necklace in "Love Actually".)
