description: the food here is pretty good. i like the outdoor seating, although Beldan Place is even better due to the stringed lights and various restaurants. my company was the highlight of the night though. long overdue good conversation with an awesome friend.
author: Regina C.

description: Claude could use some help in the kitchen. It has always been a great spot, hidden away in the alley. I'm giving three stars just for what it is and the jazz. In all honesty, my last visit we grazed the menu and shared plates of what could have been from trader joes. Fun to hit after a sfmoma date.
author: Jeff B.

description: Worth going for the atmosphere and the jazz. The food is pretty good too :)
author: Silvia M.

description: I've been going to Cafe Claude for years, and it's always a wonderful experience. My Francophile sister and brother-in-law were in town from LA, so we decided to have them test out Cafe Claude. The food did not disappoint. The onion soup, chevre salad and tuna tartare were  a delicious start to the dinner. The lamb and steak entrees were cooked perfectly. The tarte tatin and moelleux au Chocolat  desserts were a sweet way to end the evening. Oh, and the wine list is fantastic too!
author: kelly m.

description: i actually liked the nicoise, both times! roast beef and creme brulee are quite good too, coffee is good as are the mocktails. outdoor seating is comfortable for lunch (indoor is good anytime), much more so than the nearby alley with the restaurants smushed up against another (altho, those are good for a glass of wine and perhaps paella; the lack of intimacy won't disturb, but i still long for piazza navona).
author: Hae-Jin K.

description:
My pork  was so good, I did a small dance every time I took a bite. Seriously.
We ordered the cheese plate to share among us, and it was absolutely delicious! The pairings were marvelous- honey, cranberry, dried apricot...yummy-ness. The entrees? See first sentence. There were no vegetarian main entrees, so we had to pick the chicken out of the pasta of the day. The dessert certainly could have been better, considering how good the entrees were. We shared the creme brulee and chocolate flourless cake. I don't know if they meant to serve it this way or not, but the cake was totally batter on the bottom half. We were celebrating a birthday, and told the hostess when we were being seated, so they put a candle in our dessert. We made reservations using Open Table on their website, and were seated promptly at 6:30 (it was also pretty empty at that time too). When we left around 9, there was a good number of people waiting, so  be sure to make reservations! Also, we were seated 4 people to a booth, and it was a little cramped, so only sit with 3 other people you know really well in one of those things.
author: Lindsay W.

description: Absolutely delicious. I have never had a better filet mignon; their appetizers and desserts are also excellent.
author: J a.

description: I landed in SF late and not too many restaurants were opened.  Saw that this little place got 4 stars on yelp and it was within walking distance of our hotel so we decided to give it a go.  I was semi excited because this was my first time eating French, but unfortunately I felt my money could have been better spent elsewhere.  We ordered the Escargot en Croute for an appetizer, the pan seared trout w/ fingerling potatoes and beans (Truite aux Amandes) for me and the pan seared salmon w/ fava beans (Saumon)for the bf.  Both of us weren't wow'ed by the escargot.  The puff pastry and garlic overwhelmed the dish, and the snails were a weird texture that I can't even explain.  (I eat snails quite often, so it's not a mental thing).  My dish was OK taste wise, but the sauce made it so incredibly heavy.  I normally love fish and can probably eat a whole trout by myself, but I wasn't able to finish the 1/2 tail I was given because of the richness.  The bf liked his--his only complaint being the dish wasn't filling.  Worked out because he helped me finish mine.  Food overall was just meh.  Service was great; our waitress was attentive and kept apologizing for the wait on the food, even though it wasn't that bad.  The atmosphere is definitely date material (live music and all).  Would I come back?  No.
author: Jennifer C.

description: came here with a coworker for lunch the other day.  this place is DARK, even during the day.  anyways, got seated by the window; the server/waitress was super nice.  got a salad with blue cheese dress, which was meh to okay.  i had the quiche with fries.  the quiche was tasty, but i'm sure it was over 1000 calories.  the prices were reasonable; my cost was under 20$.
author: H. L.

description: Good place for lunch. Nice ambiance. A little pricey, so good to go in once in a while.
author: Jackie N.

description: the honey cream pork chop is the best plate i have ever had. love this place!
author: Cass M.

description: i came here for my birthday lunch with a friend.  i loved the setting.  it was discreet and almost made me forget i was in SF.  sure, it's in an alley...but not just any alley, an alley that has this quaint restaurant that serves delish food.  my friend order the day's lunch special, a salmon burger.  the salmon was cooked perfectly...almost made me wish i had ordered it instead.  but my pan poulet was quite good too.  so all in all, it was a good experience and i would love to try some other dishes and dinner too.  :)
author: lucie l.

description: i would have never discovered this place if it wasn't for yelp.  it's in a dinky alley between bush and sutter near the crocker galleria.   i had the cream of white corn soup and the steak tartare which was fresh and flavorful.   i decided not to have dessert so i could try the frozen yogurt at caffe ambrosia down the street.  they have a great wait staff that checks on you often.  this is wonderful little french place without all the attitude.   i  will definitely be back.
author: Leon C.

description: My girlfriend to me here before we were going to go see a show in Union Square....i was extremely dissapointed....first the tables are extremely close together and we were stuck in the corner were we couldn't even face each other or sit next to each other....she was sitting at 3 o'clock and i was sitting and 6 o'clock , we also heard the couple next to us on their first date....which must have not been going well because the lady didn't eat any of the food she ordered and kept asking for to go boxes, she had 3 stacked up on the table by the end of their dinner....i ordered the french onion soup and it came out lukewarm (benefit of the doubt)....i should have said something to the waitress but i ate as much as i could and waited for dinner...the dinner was very good...the service was just ok...if it wasn't for the cold french onion soup and our seating arrangement maybe Cafe Claude would have been 4 stars but due to that they are getting a 2 star rating and i probably won't be back....
author: D J.

description:
in an effort to be redundant:

this place is great!  i love their pate. perfection.

everything else is as good as you'd expect it to be.  it is my favorite stop when i'm in SF :)
author: J W.

description: I worked nearby and was recommended by a coworker to come to Cafe Claude for dinner. The restaurant is located inside an alleyway, making a little harder to find. The service was great - my waiter constantly came to me and asked if everything was okay. The food was more disappointing and was mostly bland. My lasagna was tasteless and the steak was very ordinary.
author: Raymond L.

description: Feel like having great French food without the snootiness? If so, this is your place! Small interior but there's plenty of outside seating. Personal service, good wine list, and pretty good mixed drinks.
author: Xuyen H.

description: Yikes!  I have had many dinners over the years here, and have always been pleased. I am not sure what is going on, but they need to manage this place better.  I ate there recently with a group of friends.  Service was slow.  My coq au vin arrived in a blistering hot plate, and when I cut into the chicken it was so cold - nearly frozen.  No - I did not want to know that they microwave their coq au vin.  i really wanted to believe that they actually cooked it, slowly, during the course of the day....  The waitress was nice, took it away quickly, but my friends were nearly done with dinner when the new entree arrived (not cold, tasty).  When they brought the check, they did not comp anything (Really?the coq au vin perhaps?  Maybe even dessert?).  As we were leaving, the waitress ran up and said that we had paid the wrong bill and requested that we pay her the difference.  Admittedly, we did not review the bill with a fine tooth comb, but with not much alcohol the bill was already $72/person.  The whole scene was kind of surreal.  Note to manager - if the kitchen messes up - you comp the dinner. Period.
author: Zelda F.

description: Too bad , great idea, rip off on the food , price and portions.........
author: doug w.

description: For some reason, I thought this place was off of Kearny.  I was really close...it's actually in a little alleyway off Bush nr Kearny.  I walked up and did a onceover of the place.  The front definitely looked like a cafe straight from France.  The interior however, was a little more modern with just the right amount of color tones spread out about the space.  One of the hostesses quickly welcomed me in and was ready to seat me, but I told her I was waiting for a friend.  When my friend arrived, we decided to sit outside under the awning, which nicely protected us from any stray raindrops.  My friend had the same comment about how the place reminded her so much of a Parisian cafe.  Having never been to France, I agreed and took her word for it.  We sat and chatted for a while, sipping on Bastille Bellinis.    Our waiter came by several times to see if we were ready to order.  We couldn't decide right away.  I'd never been to a French restaurant before and I knew ordering french fries from anywhere else, does not qualify (BTW, they actually serve French Fries and French Beans here).  I didn't know what to really expect.  The menu is actually fairly diverse for being French.  I take it that there's a South-eastern France/Italy influence which would explain why pasta is on the menu and one of the specials of the day.  We ended up settling on THE ravioli dish for my friend, and the Coq Au Vin for myself.  I say THE ravioli to prepare potential diners for the single approximate sized 4"x4" ravioli that they serve you.  I didn't try it, but my friend was a little disappointed that it was only one piece.  I chose the Coq Au Vin (pronounced Co-Ka-Van, which I remembered from a 3's Company episode...and confirmed when my waiter repeated it back to me...I've never taken French mind you) because the chicken sounded like it would be prepared nicely.  I was greeted with 2 pieces of chicken...a leg and thigh (my favorite pieces)...covered in a wine sauce with mushrooms and something else that I forget.  Excellent dish.  Chicken was moist, and I made use of the sauce with the dinner bread provided.  I didn't realize that sides had to be ordered separately, but it was ok.  It was just the right amount of food for me (actually, I wouldn't have minded seconds).  We passed on dessert this time, but I'm sure there will be a chance to sample it another time.    I would definitely go back to sample more off the menu...along with a few more Bellinis too.
author: JeFF T.

description: really small place. the tables are really close together. you can hear other people conversations. they also have live music playing and great service. my friend took me here for my bday and we ordered the tuna tartar, steak tartar, the steak, and french fries w/ aoili. everywhere i go if there is tuna tartar on the menu i have to order it. it was a disappointment b/c there was goat cheese in it. who puts goat cheese w/ tuna? it was too thick and the combo just didn't taste right. however, the steak tartar was super yummy. very flavorful and fresh w/ a touch of spicyness. my steak was perfectly cook and great flavor b/c of the peppercorn sauce. the steak came with potatos, and green beans which was delicious. the fries were super addicting. the sauce that came w/ the fries is to die for.
author: Karen H.

description: Very good and quite reasonable.  Went for lunch, sat outside, was a rare beautiful SF day.  The onion soup was amazing, and everything else was great no complaints.  The creme brule was warm and melts in your mouth, enjoy!
author: Brad T.

description: "Have always liked whatever i ordered; the french onion soup is amazing. my friend's coq au vin was yummy
author: Jocelyn L.

description: excellent meal. great service. love the location at the end of a little alley. highly recommended.
author: nick m.

description:
it's been months since i was there and i still have great memories.
the atmosphere and the music got me, but i remember it being a bit tight on space. unless you are into your neighbours..
author: Boryana M.

description: I have never had a bad experience every time I have dined here.  This last visit was Ladies' Night (The Heartlettes) and when we showed up they didn't have a table ready for us.  With a little complaining they made up for the inconvenience with a free glass of champagne.  We were only seated about 15 minutes late and from that moment on, it was bliss.  French food can be quite expensive (especially in San Francisco)...this is great French food at a good price.  Nothing too over the top.  The waiter was very knowledgable about the cheese, wine pairings and the food in general.  He was very warm and attentive and made the experience wonderful.  The ambience is slightly noisy, but very cute.  You feel tucked away in a little alley in France...left to enjoy your meal leisurely.  Food is meant to savor, so I enjoy when you have moments to break (or drink) between dishes.  I fully recommend this restaurant (just not for large groups b/c of the noise).  I will surely be back again soon...
author: Jennifer E.

description: This place was great. The wine was excellent (I had the Givry French Burgundy). I went in for a salad, had their general dinner salad - it was relatively simple concoction of butter lettuce, onion shavings, and tomatoes, with a really tasty and unique dressing involving raw mustard. It was so good I decided to try the pasta. Meatballs were excellent, plentiful, and big. Perfect combination of pasta, meatballs, tomatoes, olives and cheese. Again, it wasn't complex but they cooked it perfectly. Having such good luck so far, I decided why not stuff myself completely by going for dessert as well. I tried the flourless chocolate cake, Amazing! Ate the whole thing even though i was already totally stuffed. And all in all, the place is not cheap by any means, but compared to other places I've been in the area it wasn't too bad on the high end. Also, the staff were really friendly, funny, and charming. Great place. Definitely would go back.
author: E S.

description: food is ok, they have some flare here and there. service is polite. i like places in alleys.
author: kiki b.

description:
spontaneously walked by this lonely alley, and saw the sign and decided to eat! 

what spontaneity.

had my first escargot here. which didnt even taste gross which was great
i ate half! 
also got the trout and the vegetable lasgna. not a fan of vegetarian lasagna, or lasagna in general so wouldnt get that again. but the trout was very potable. make sure to get it.

good food, and good french bread. but if you get hot water it came lukewarm. which was just straight up unacceptable on that cold night sitting outside. the water must have been an even 100 degrees. and would not have even burned the most sensitive skin

anyways, if you are in the area a good place for decent french food with live music. it appears they change their menu everyday too fancy pants
author: Porkers T.

description: ok, this is a little biased, since i had one of those all-time most memorable experiences here, but  i love this place! a close friend and i spent 5 hours here just having drinks, occupying a table during the dinner rush and the service people still were very attentive and we had great service. tucked in a little alley in the heart of the financial district, this is a great place to go after a hectic day at work to relax and unwind (or vent). hopefully next time i'll get around to ordering some food!!
author: Karva S.

description: I've decided that "alleywalk" cafe seating in Financial District SF, much like sidewalk eating most everywhere, leaves a lot to be desired so I chose to sit inside with my lunch partner.   We had an early lunch and there was no problem getting a table; when we left, around 1:00 pm, I could see that those behind us may not have been so lucky without a reservation.  The lunch menu looks good and prices are about what I've come to expect, which is to say priced so that commoners like me who are paying for their own can have something to eat but probably can't have wine or dessert without thinking 'what have I done to my food budget for the week!'   I had the pasta of the day, which was chunks of pork loin and vegetables in a glace that was a little oversalted, over fusilli.  My partner had the salmon sandwich.  We both had an espresso to top it off.  Nice lunch?  Sure, and I may go back for cocktails to see how that works.  Is it special? Is it a hangout?  no.
author: Laura H.

description: Great food, lovely ambience, friendly staff & pet friendly!
author: ek i.

description: i was introduced to cafe claude by a good friend of mine years ago.  i thought it was so quaint at the time.  it's still a cute, mellow little place.  the food was good .
author: Seong P.

description: i have gone here several times and have never found their food or wine outstanding.  it's alley location was something i like to find-- anything off the beaten path-- so i expected more.  i think if they could pump up their wine list the experience could be even more exciting.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description: So we went to Cafe Claude on a Thurday in February for lunch and the place was absolutely packed, but we had reservations so we only had to wait for a few minutes. We asked for a table outside, and so we wedged ourselves in between two other couples. On the way I managed to almost spill everyones water at all three tables. How was I to know they used TV trays as patio furniture. Having never dined at a true French bistro, I didn't realize that it meant literally rubbing elbows with the person next to you. After finally settling in we ordered a couple glasses of wine and a beet salad for an appetizer. In my opinion, that was the best single dish I ate in San Francisco, and is probably one of the best dishes I have ever tasted. The combination of the beets, feta, pistou, and snow peas tasted like spring. (I know beets are a fall vegetable, but so what). Amazing flavors. I ordered the roast chicken with olives and lemon and my wife ordered the Crouque Madame. Mine was cooked very well, the flavors blended beautifully. my wife was not quite as enthusiastic about hers, but the accompanying pomme frites were very good. If I lived in San Francisco it would be very easy for me to become a regular there.
author: S. C.

description: The jazz music set a very cozy romantic mood. It was late on a Saturday night and the hostess was able to seat us in earlier than our original reservation. Nice. I love gruyere, and their french onion soup comes out piping hot with a nice layer of cheese. Entrees are good. I had the halibut. But I would come back just for french onion soup and a bottle of wine. Listen to the live music. Relax. Would be a date spot, but don't expect quiet conversation. The tables are quite close together, so you might bump elbows getting in and out of your seat.
author: Kay M.

description: this place is really pretty, kinda hidden but i love that it is so intimate, i only dine here once w/ my bf but i remember the prawns was so good and the service was good and the price point are very reasonable...i want to go back soon..
author: Jo Z.

description: On a serendipitous evening, I found  myself at Cafe Claude drinking and eating in some fine company.  We started with some fancy vodka infused 'tinis.  Then moved on to a great red from the Rhone region.  We ordered appetizers for a variety of noshing.  Started with the cheese plate and the seafood raviole.  Both were rock solid and the cheese really accentuated the wine and I LOVE it when that happens.  The pomme frites were killer with a spicy aioli.  Lastly, we got the beef carpacchio.  This was THE dish to get to top them all.  They bring out a tray of ingredients including, dijon mustard, capers, fresh ground pepper, a quail egg, some chopped greens onions and a mound of finely chopped raw beef.  It is all slowly mixed in methodically and served with some toasted and buttery thin sliced bread.  It was awesome!  What a gem! Oh, and the live music was perfectly romantic and chill for the setting.
author: Chard M.

description: Not the most up to date review, but I remember coming here with my mom, and we tried all the highlights on the menu.  Great atmosphere.
author: Emily H.

description: A hidden gem tucked away in an alley, Cafe Claude is by far one of the more authentic french bistro's in SF...all the way down to the french speaking waitresses. Among my favorites are: the French onion soup, bavette frites, and the pate sampler....killer calories but ultimately worth spending an extra hour on the tread mill the next day! The tarte tatin is a must...
author: Roger T.

description: what a happy surprise when my friend brought me to cafe claude!  i had no idea that such a cozy and cool little restaurant existed tucked away in a quiet alleyway so near to union square.  we sat at the bar and sampled some cocktails first - the st. germain cocktail and papaya margarita were both excellent, and my friend and i are now on the hunt for elderberry liqueur - and then each got a soup and split the cheese plate.  the onion soup was so oniony and cheesy and warm and good, and the cheeses with honey and apricot and almonds were also a hit.  i'm already plotting my next visit ...
author: ali l.

description: i've had the trout and coq au vin (yum), and heard rave reviews about the steak. a really nice, relaxing little place tucked away from the crazy throngs of shoppers, commuters (myself included) and other daytrippers. last night i got out of there with the pan-seared trout (with great attention paid to the sides of toasted almonds, white mushrooms, lemon butter sauce, steamed potatoes and green beans), an awesome glass of sancerre and tip for $36. worth it? for the atmo, food quality and service, i think so.
author: rachel m.

description: lovely. great value for money. not amazing food, but the ambiance and service makes up for it... and the location. it's like being in europe all over again :)
author: Jennifer N.

description: please don't get rid of the traute aux amandes.  it is my favorite dish on the menu.
author: Jung H.

description: Cafe Claude serves the BEST moelleux au chocolat that can be tasted in this country!  Exquisite touch:  the creme anglaise is offered on the side, in a little pitcher.
author: yvette c.

description: Quite cozy and the food was good.  It's charming and romantic if you are in the mood for that.  A few too many tourists now and again but we do live in a great place for tourists so that is to be expected!
author: Misti L.

description: I can recommend the Coq Au Vin - it is the best I have ever tasted.   i like it better than the one in AbsInThe.  They serve a pretty good cheese plate and pate plate as well.  The onion soup - a bit sloppy, not enough care put into it.  Too salty, sometimes burnt, just doesn't taste right. I like the endive salad as well.  Good jazz music.  Great service.  It gets 4 stars because it can get a bit noisy, the service is improved since 2 yrs ago.  We always bring our own wines -- we go way too often.
author: tc h.

description: Came here during lunch with a bunch of coworkers for my birthday. This isn't the best french food I've ever had, but the place does a great job of combining charm, convenience, and overall good experience. The food was around the price I'd expect for this type of place and area. In a great unassuming alley, there are places to eat outdoor or indoor on a colder day. Service was slightly slow, but since we were just taking a long lunch it didn't matter as much. Generally, everyone was happy with their food. I had the salmon and it was perfectly cooked. I did hear a few grumbles about the pasta bolognese... and people enjoyed the frites. Yum, bring on the aioli!
author: Jeannette L.

description:
always a reliable great place for a relaxing couple's dinner or a small get together with friends.  took our manhattanite friends here and they were duly impressed.

their steaks are always remarkable and well prepared. location is fabulous and ambiance is quite parisian, esp with the jazz trio they have live. service is very friendly, efficient, and charming if you get a french speaker.
author: Judy J.

description: It's my new favorite place in The City to come and have a drink.  The bartenders are so friendly and really can mix a fine drink.  I've never been disappointed by any dish on the menu, and some of the off menu creations were simply perfect.
author: Zac F.

description: Perfect for a low-key night out with hubs.  Nothing earth-shattering with the French bistro fare, but consistently very good, nice atmosphere, and friendly waiters.  Great on the weekends for lunch with girlfriends, as well.
author: Brooke F.

description: Yum.  I love this place.  Great food.  Great service.  Great atmosphere.  Great value (2 of us ate and had a bottle of wine, all for $75 before tip).
author: Margaret S.

description: I love this place and always have.  It's got great atmosphere and tremendous food.  If they've got it, go for the Squab or other game as they do a great job with stuffed game.
author: Ken M.

description: stopped in for late night cafe and dessert. great small comfy local place with very friendly staff. loved the coffe and chocolate desert. so glad this place is here and stays open late for dessert!  merci!
author: l c.

description: Ah, finally a French place that doesn't come with a condescending wait staff!
author: Joe P.

description: First time visit and we were please with the food and service. Tables are a little close together, especially in the front room, and it was a bit noisy, but not excessively. My wife and I had no trouble conversing in normal voices.  We hope to go back again soon.
author: Jim C.

description: One of my favorite places to eat.  Nice to eat outside at night.  European style seating in a quite alley.  Great food and reasonable wine.  Only negative is menu doesn't change that often.  Very reasonable in terms of price.
author: reza f.

description: This is my favorite bistro in Downtown. It is very French and the service was very friendly and nice, too. The food was, of course, good, too. I rate appetizers higher than entrees, though. If you are lost for a dinner in Downtown, this is always the place to consider.
author: Charlie S.

description: I had a good meal, but not great.  It was my second time at Cafe Claud after I had a much better meal the first time.  The escargot is their signature dish.  Wine was OK, but I thought overpriced for french.  Nothing more frustrating than a restuarant that can't reproduce the consistency you expect.
author: Chris C.

description: Is it just me, or do all of the waiters have fake French accents?...Maybe they're French-Canadiens? In any case, fake accents or not, this place serves up good food...no, excellent food.  A bit on the pricey side, but the atmosphere, service and food are all there.  Great place for a romantic date, as the decor is dark, and candles are scattered throughout the main room.  I've come here with my bfriend and with friends, and we always have a great time.  For that, I give it five stars!
author: M M.

description: Was in town with a co-worker for a conference.  He has a friend in the area and this is the second time we have met up with her while in town for a conference, and both times, we ended up at a French Restaurant.  First time was Absinthe, and Cafe Claude for round two!  Food was great.  We shared the pork/duck rillette to start, then I had the endive salad and coq au vin.  Others had fish and the vegetable lasagne.  All the dishes were great.  It was a solid four stars because we also enjoyed some good wine.  Corkage was $20 I think.  But the extra star came with dessert......pommes frittes!!!  I'm not much of a dessert person....and I can't pass up some frittes....Everyone might have been full but I was still a little hungry because the portions are typical french(smaller than oversized American portions).  I ordered the frittes and in no time, everyone was digging in to them...they were delicious.  Good aioli or something on the side for dipping.  I thought about a second order, but we decided enough was enough...  :-)
author: Vince V.

description: Adorable.  Real anchovies on the ceaser salad.  A must if you are downtown and need lunch.
author: Susan M.

description: Maybe I ordered the wrong thing (french onion soup, potatoes, and salad with mojito)? Okay yes I know a mojito has an excuse for not being amazing at a little french place but it tasted like well not a mojito more watered down rum than anything else. The soup was so-so and salad went down in one bite---not horrible but not amazing. I do give it a plus for it's cool location...maybe i'll go back and try something more adventurous because the service was pleasant.
author: Nicki B.

description: i love claude's. for years, been going there. the food is always good, and the staff has been fantastic (mel, chris, pasquale, where did you all go?!). french onion soup in general, usually too salty, too cheesy, too something... perfect here. steak tartare.... forget this review, i'm going and getting some now. oh, parking is impossible to find though...
author: armand t.

description: This is a true French Bistro without the attitude! We arrived 30 minutes prior to our reservation - just to make sure that they knew we were coming - we were told our table would be ready on time!  We asked for a table where we could sit next to each other, and Cinzia made sure we had just the right arrangements!  Our waitress Sophia was very attentive to our concerns about a great wine, and we settled upon a 2004 Gigondas - marvelous.  We chose a menu of "small plates":  starting with the Selection of Pates; French Onion Soup; Escargots; and Coquilles St. Jacques.  Tres Magnifique!  All of this plus a live jazz trio made a memorable evening!  Compliments to Open Table reservations, this was a wonderful evening.
author: Brian G.

description: I've eaten here four times and never been disappointed.  Love the tuna or steak tartare and the great wine list.  Live jazz, great French wine, warm decor, and voila, you have a complete restaurant.
author: Brian M.

description: Slip back to the outdoor bistro days of gay Paree...everything abou this restaurant is perfect!
author: kate s.

description: This place is great!! A coworker from mine is from Paris, and he recommended this place to me as authentic French food in SF. It is located down a quaint little alley. Inside it is warm and bustling, just a nice upscale (yet cozy and unpretentious) vibe. My sister was in town and we wanted a place to hear some music, but quiet enough that we could still have a conversation. We went on a Sat night which is one of their "jazz nights". We sat at the bar and had delicious drinks (the egalite was amazing), chatted with the friendly bartender, and listened to lovely jazz in the background. A waiter accidentally dropped a tray behind us which got a bit of spaghetti sauce on my sister's pants and on our jackets. The waiter was amazingly gracious and apologetic, offering to pay for our drycleaning bill. They also gave us quite a few few drinks and free french fries as an apology. It was a really great experience, we were joking that we'd happily have a spaghetti sauce spill anytime! A great spot, and great staff.
author: Sarah Y.

description: absolutely love it. everyone here is very friendly and accomodating. i generally have all of my downtown business meetings here. The food is delightful. the escargo is simply something you must try. the drinks are delicious from the bar. the menu selection could be better, but overall i love the atmosphere here. it's tucked away in its own private little side street in the middle of downtown san francisco
author: nightlife i.

description: A friend of mine had been telling me, "Before going out on a Saturday night, why not get some dinner at Cafe Claude?"  for about three months;) So, naturally, when a place comes recommended I'm hypercritical in my review. I've gotta say, you win this round, Cafe Claude. Well done! My pan-seared trout was prepared very well, full of flavor! Our choice to indulge in the moelleux au chocolat might have been the best decision made all night! The service was warm, attentive, and...I'm just gonna say it...all very attractive people. (I don't usually order steak tartare, but to have some eye-candy prepare it next to your table the way I saw them do is a pretty enticing offer!) Long story short, what I thought was going to be a quick dinner, turned into us moving to the bar to hear more of the live music and have more drinks. Alright Cafe Claude, you wined me and dined me! I'd like to think I'm not an easy date. This place deservedly gets four stars! I think it's befitting to say, in the words of chingy, Cafe Claude is "a quarter piece, she far from a dime." :)
author: anne b.
